webTitle: Bierhoff limps out of England showdown

fields.headline: Bierhoff limps out of England showdown
fields.trailText: Germany's captain Oliver Bierhoff will miss the clash with England on Saturday after limping out of a training session yesterday with a calf injury.
fields.body:
Germany's captain Oliver Bierhoff will miss the clash with England on Saturday after limping out of a training session yesterday with a calf injury.

The Milan striker tore a muscle in his right calf and had to have his leg heavily strapped with an ice pack. He will be out for at least a week so will also miss Tuesday's game against Portugal.

"I was standing when I felt a knock on my calf. It was like I was hit by a stone," Bierhoff said.

The training session had to be halted after hundreds of autograph hunters invaded the pitch. "I had never seen anything like it," Bierhoff said. "It was chaos."

The 32-year-old drove back to the Germans' hotel in the Dutch town of Vaals with the team doctor where he had a medical examination which revealed the muscle damage.

webTitle: Blair banks on polls and goals

fields.headline: Blair banks on polls and goals
fields.trailText: As if Downing Street cared about a football result. Oh, but it does. You can bet your bottom euro it does.
fields.body:
Pummelled by the WI and rabbit-punched by NHS horror stories, will the prime minister's worst dozen days in office end with his being clangingly kayoed by Saturday's football result in Charleroi? Will the government's opinion-poll ratings take an even more cataclysmic dip if England's footballers are literally sent packing for home by Germany?

As if Downing Street cared about a football result. Oh, but it does. You can bet your bottom euro it does.

Blair's team are not that daft. They know how easily the polls' slippery downward slope can be painfully polished by no more than a generally cheesed-off discontent among the bulk of the nation. Even the abysmal weather so far is not helping the overall midsummer malaise.

So is it total bosh to suggest that, following fast on England's dumb football show on Monday, an out-and-out humiliation on Saturday might yet be seen by historians as the defining 90 minutes when Blairism and The Grin began their irreversible nosedive?

By the same token, of course, should Master Tony's bonny lads in white muddle through on Saturday and go on, say, to reach the final, just imagine how those poll ratings might shoot up once he's embraced our Kev and the heroes on the tarmac at Heathrow on July 3. (All Bulletins Go; and that sort of shared Top-o'-the-News triumph would even assuage the imminent and likely disappointment of losing the 2006 World Cup bid, which Blair had pledged to the nation with certainty only 18 months ago.)

Two-three, two-three... after Monday night, you could almost set the lamentation to music. It is an old tune. And yesterday was a notable anniversary for English football as well as, many would claim, for British poli tics. Precisely 30 June 14ths ago, in Leon in Mexico in the 1970 World Cup finals - and just as they did in Eindhoven this Monday - England's defence inexcusably blew a two-goal lead, that time against West Germany, and lost by 3-2. Cue national dirges.

That June 14 of 1970 was a Sunday. Prime minister Harold Wilson had called a general election for June 18, only four days later. All omens looked good: Labour had cleared the field in May's local elections, they were seven points clear in the opinion polls, June's first fortnight had been blessed with a heatwave and, including an epic toe-to-toe thriller against Brazil in Mexico, Bobby Moore's England team had easily qualified for the quarter-final four days before the poll at home.

Two-three, two-three... to his death, Wilson flatly denied he had banked on an eve-of-poll England football victory sweeping him back into power - "governing a country, laddie, is not about knowing its football fixtures" - but subsequent memoirs by the original spinmeister's cabinet colleagues proved he was telling a whopper.

Denis Healey says Wilson had called a meeting at Chequers as early as that April: "Harold put the considerations clearly before us ... If the England football team was defeated just before polling day, would the government suffer?"

Denis Howell says: "Of course Harold fretted about the football. But the polls were all swinging to Labour.

"However, on the morning after the Sunday football defeat, at a factory meeting in Birmingham, nothing was about policy, only one thing mattered and all the shouts were of the 'We threw it away!' variety and 'It was [the manager Sir Alf] Ramsey's fault'. For the first time I had real doubts. The mood was changing. My wife Brenda said: 'I don't like the smell of this, it's like 1959 [a Tory landslide]'."

By the Friday lunchtime - as Wilson gave best to Ted Heath's 40-seat Conservative win and readied himself to go to the Palace to hand in his seals (Herself was at Ascot, wouldn't you know) - a newly ex-cabinet minister, Tony Crosland, succinctly put down Labour's defeat to England's football team "and the disgruntled Match-of-the-Day millions".

Thirty years on, another Tony sweats on something similar.

webTitle: Players told to get a grip

fields.headline: Players told to get a grip
fields.standfirst: Keegan keeps low profile as recriminations continue after Portugal defeat, writes  Martin Thorpe
fields.trailText: Keegan keeps low profile as recriminations continue after Portugal defeat, writes Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
Three days after England's defeat by Portugal and the book is still not closed on what went wrong. Another page turned yesterday when it was reported that several senior players had told Kevin Keegan in no uncertain terms that he had got his tactics wrong.

The England coach, no fool he, was keeping a low profile yesterday and instead one of his coaching staff, Les Reed, acted as spokesman and duly blamed the players for the failure to get a grip on Portugal's rampant midfield.

However, to see this as a pass-the-buck session or evidence of conflict in the camp would be wrong. Keegan encourages players to express their views and that can only be healthy, so long as he retains the clarity of mind to distil the truth and then act on it. It also shows how much the defeat hurt and that they are determined to avoid a repeat against Germany on Saturday.

The report of player dissatisfaction is understood to centre on Tony Adams, Paul Ince and the captain Alan Shearer telling Keegan at half-time in Eindhoven, and more vociferously afterwards, that more men were needed in midfield to counter the slick passing and movement that enabled Portugal to come back from 2-0 down to win 3-2.

One can understand the eagerness of Ince, for one, to avoid a repeat of his Portuguese experience. "We were badly outnumbered in midfield," he said. "We were being overrun. Portugal seemed to have extra players wherever you looked. At one point they seemed to be coming past us from all angles."

According to the report, Keegan has been forced by the strength of opinion to adopt a 3-5-2 formation for the Germany game. The truth is that such a shift is likely anyway, given that it is the formation the Germans use and mirroring it makes tactical sense.

Reed, however, said that Keegan still had not decided whether to switch to 3-5-2 or stick with 4-4-2. But in a way this is a side issue. For Reed believes the reason England were overrun had nothing to do with bodies in the middle. It was about the players' response to going 2-0 up.

"We had a game plan we thought would work to our advantage," he said. "We felt that if we could get amongst them in midfield, break up their play before it developed, they would be vulnerable on the break and particularly vulnerable to crosses. And in some ways it went too well for us in that respect."

He believes that after going 2-0 up so early the players got carried away and forgot the plan. "It possibly affected different players in different ways and we lost a little bit of our impetus in terms of getting involved with the Portuguese in midfield and breaking up the play.

"We didn't expect to go into the lead quite convincingly as early as we did. It was a part of the game plan I think we probably expected to invoke later in the game, and I would say that psychologically that may have thrown us."

He insists that, after Portugal equalised, messages went out from the bench for the players to return to plan A but they couldn't. "The players were receptive to the messages but one must remember there are 11 players out there who [must] respond to what you're doing.

"The Portuguese are a very talented midfield. Just getting messages on and giving instructions doesn't guarantee that things are going to change. You've got to give credit to Portugal in the way they handled what we tried to do.

"Football is about cat and mouse, about how one set of players respond to the others, and then it is down to the players on the day. That's why you have a winner and a loser."

Reed was confirming what many already knew, that the Portugal midfield was much better than England's. Yesterday in training England worked on how to avoid getting stretched and leaving too much space between attack and defence.

Keegan also had a brainstorming session with the players in which he seemed to win the argument, steering malcontents away from the notion that a packed midfield would solve all problems.

"He was trying to put across that maybe sometimes some of the players have got to take it on themselves and sort things out," said Dennis Wise. "That's where we went wrong, really.

"The gaffer wanted a few people's opinions, he wanted to have a chat about things and so we all sat down and put our thoughts across because he wanted to hear them. He took note. He's that type of person. He wanted to hear how we went a little bit wrong, what we could have done, what we felt we could have done.

"Maybe it was up to us on the pitch to try and sort it out because it's very hard for him, when the game is going on, to try and sort things out."

English players thinking for themselves may be a novel concept but to progress in this tournament they need to learn the art, and fast.

Tactically the focus now shifts to Germany, who offer a totally different challenge. "They will want to play at a much lower tempo," said Reed. "They build up from the back whereas the Portuguese move it out from the back as quickly as possible to use the midfield.

"The Germans will drop deeper in the hope they'll pull you out in order to get in behind you. And they are much more shape-orientated than the Portuguese. Not rigid but clearly more identifiable."

Which at least should be more to the liking of England's yeoman players.

webTitle: FA tells Beckham not to repeat gesture

fields.headline: FA tells Beckham not to repeat gesture
fields.trailText: David Beckham has been warned by the Football Association about the one-finger gesture he made to a section of England fans after Monday's defeat by Portugal in Eindhoven.
fields.body:
David Beckham has been warned by the Football Association about the one-finger gesture he made to a section of England fans after Monday's defeat by Portugal in Eindhoven.

The European governing body, Uefa, declined to take disciplinary action against the hot-tempered Manchester United midfielder even though photographs of his gesture from the middle of the pitch appeared on the front pages of many newspapers. But the FA has warned him as to his future conduct and another discussion on the subject was due to take place last night.

It is understood that the FA took into account the provocation Beckham received when a small section of fans barracked him and shouted obscene remarks during the game. He and other England players were also the target of insults as the team headed down the tunnel after the game.

The FA has warned Beckham that further reaction would almost certainly lead to disciplinary action by Uefa - probably in the form of a ban - and that England could ill afford to lose their one world-class player.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Norway's captain Henning Berg looks likely to miss the remainder of his team's Group C matches - against Yugoslavia on Sunday and Slovenia on Wednesday - because of the recurrent thigh injury which made him limp off during the 1-0 win against Spain.
fields.body:
 Norway's captain Henning Berg looks likely to miss the remainder of his team's Group C matches - against Yugoslavia on Sunday and Slovenia on Wednesday - because of the recurrent thigh injury which made him limp off during the 1-0 win against Spain.

But the Manchester United defender said: "We have the chance to get to a quarter- final and by then I could be ready again."

 Steffen Iversen, who headed Norway's winner against Spain, had good news for Tottenham fans yesterday when he ended lingering doubts about his future by committing himself to the club.

The striker bought from Rosenborg in 1996 has been seeking a new contract. His existing deal, which has two years to run, is worth £5,000 a week and he is thought to want about four times that, bringing him more in line with the club's top earners.

"I never wanted to leave Tottenham and when I get back from Euro 2000 I believe I will sign a new contract," the 23-year-old said. "In the time I have been at the club this is the best squad we have had. The manager [George Graham] has signed a lot of young players and also one of Europe's best strikers in Sergei Rebrov. With this combination I am convinced that we can not only push for Europe but win trophies next season."

 Jaap Stam's chances of playing for Holland in their second Group D game, against Denmark in Rotterdam tomorrow, remain in the balance.

Stam, who strained his groin during a practice session on Tuesday, did not train yesterday and the Holland coach Frank Rijkaard said: "It's just too early to say whether he can or cannot play. I just have to assume not for the time being. He has made some progress but we'll just have to wait."

If Stam is out Bert Konterman, who has joined Rangers from Feyenoord, will replace him. Konterman came on for the last 16 minutes against the Czech Republic after the Manchester United defender suffered a cut eye in a clash of heads with Jan Koller.

 Sinisa Mihajlovic, the Yugoslav defender and free-kick specialist, has been given a one-match suspension after being sent off in Tuesday night's 3-3 draw with Slovenia in Charleroi. He will miss the Norway game.

Meanwhile Yugoslavia's captain Dragan Stojkovic has said he plans to retire in December at the end of the season in Japan where he plays for Nagoya Grampus Eight.

 Representatives of the English and Turkish football associations met in Eindhoven on Tuesday to discuss ways of improving relations between the two camps after recent fan violence in Istanbul and Copenhagen.

The teams could still meet in the quarter-finals despite both losing their opening group games and there have been rumours that clashes between the two sets of supporters are being organised.

David Davies, the FA's chief executive, said: "Officials met in an attempt to forge closer links and to discuss ways of avoiding any further animosity between fans from the two countries."

Today some 1,600 policemen will be on duty at the Group B match between Turkey and Sweden in Eindhoven. It is expected that as many as 20,000 Turkish fans will converge on the southern Dutch town.

webTitle: Up for it, out of it and more interested in sex than violence

fields.headline: Up for it, out of it and more interested in sex than violence
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner takes a screen break with fans in Magaluf.
fields.body:
For someone whose customary beat reporting from the front line of televised sport covers roughly the area between my favourite armchair and the fridge, occasionally taking in the toaster, it is quite a novelty to be flown abroad for an international tournament; especially several hundred miles in the wrong direction.

I am following the first week of Euro 2000 from Mallorca, and I am not alone. Before the tournament, the net had been full of opportunities to "follow the Three Lions in the sun". Couldn't be easier. Book it online, Easyjet from Luton, 10 days in Ibiza or Magaluf for £200-odd, and two drinks for the price of one during matches. Get drunk, get laid, watch the footie. The team will probably be back before you and at least you will have a tan.

Watching the match abroad - anywhere abroad - is a halfway house between being there and staying at home with Gary and Des. You get the shared experience and restricted view you would have at the ground, but your drinks are full-strength. This is a big selling point in Magaluf, where the resort's priorities are neatly encapsulated in notices around the walls of the bars: pint of vodka and Red Bull, 750 pesetas (£2.85); two Diamond White plus one shot, 800 pesetas; pint of Sex on the Beach plus free Aftershock, 500 pesetas; Viagra, 900 pesetas, ask at the bar.

Sam, who I have met in Palma and who, like most ex-pat Brits here is involved in selling boats and houses, has driven me five miles from the classy, boaty side of town to Magaluf, explaining how the resort cost him a million pound property deal. "I am driving up the hill out of town," he says, "past all the souvenir shops, with this very rich, rather correct German lady in the car, when we come to a halt outside a shop displaying its range of comedy towels. She looks over, and right in the front she sees a huge one with a picture on it of a hedgehog shagging a scrubbing brush. 'I think I will look on another part of the island,' she says."

Ollie and the Chislehurst posse, packing the Horseshoe bar at the heart of Magaluf's drinking and pulling sector, seem unlikely to be similarly upset. "Magaluf, Magaluf, we're all pissed-up and we're going to Magaluf," they sing somewhat inaccurately (apart from the pissed-up bit) since they are already here. They have warmed up, and in some cases peaked, during the Germany-Romania match. The German tourists, outnumbered and mostly in family groups, have wisely opted to watch the match in quieter bars at the bucket-and-spade end of town, but that does not stifle the cheers that greet John Motson's assessment of the Germans as "a shambles". A shambles with a point, mind you.

We watch the match on the BBC, thanks to the enterprise of several bar owners in acquiring Sky Digital cards through British contacts. It is not quite as much fun as it used to be, spending half your holiday seeking a hotel with the requisite satellite dish, or following the match on foreign TV, but this unofficial access to our national broadcaster does allow me to credit Trevor Brooking with what I fear will not be the last use of the British cliche of choice when it comes to Germany. One minute Motson is saying, "This is just a shadow of German sides of the past," and "This is extraordinary and most un-Germanlike," and the next Trevor is saying, "You just can't," - go on, Trevor, go for it - "write the Germans off."

Ollie was born a decade too late for Mexico 1970 when it first became inadvisable to write the Germans off and is therefore innocent enough to assume a 2-0 lead for England is a winning one, and downs several large, lethal cocktails a bit too ferociously.

I have never seen anyone cash his chips in quite so quickly. Just seconds after leading the bar in a manic dance of celebration, Ollie is himself led down the street by his mates Tony and Jono who are trying to revive him.

It is probably not the ideal time to catch a word with the lads, but they are happy to tell me of their success selling mobile telephones to every man, woman and child in their part of Kent, and how the proceeds will finance a frightening amount of excess in Magaluf; having it large, in the argot of Chislehurst.

The equation for the lads was a simple one. Spain was warmer and more fun than Eindhoven or Charleroi, and since they were more interested in sex than violence, it was the place to be.

The official guide to the Balearics has a rather sweet way of putting it: "The English penchant for self-criticism has caused this fine resort to acquire an undeserved notoriety as a beery, working-class playground in the mould of Blackpool or Skegness. It's true that Magaluf has a very lively nightlife, with discotheques such as BCM and English-style pubs open till the early hours of the morning, and that a number of the less mature British visitors -unaccustomed to such a free and easy atmosphere - occasionally become excessively boisterous, but tourists are also attracted to this resort by its clean streets and pine-covered mountain environs."

The pine-covered environs seem strangely irrelevant as England's lead disappears and despair deepens. We are now watching Eurosport, what with Des being unavailable on Sky Digital, and lacking even familiar commentators to lighten the gloom.

The refreshingly unfussy commentary of Dave Farrer is appreciated, though, by those who are sober enough to care (me) and I note how similar to my colleague Ron Manager Eurosport's "consultant" Joe Kinnear sounds.

I am none too sorry when Sam drives me away from Magaluf, which has left me feeling my age rather too keenly (although one of the Chislehurst lads informs me it is grab-a-granny night in the piano bars). There is something a little too frantic about a place where everybody is so relentlessly up for it, but the atmosphere is benign enough and I suspect even the Germany match will pass off with only serious damage to Chislehurst livers.

Next day we watch the Spain-Norway match in a tapas bar in the centre of Palma, eating unusual meatball and sausage things we have chosen merely by pointing, something impossible to do in Magaluf where the smell of cooking fat warns you off anything unfamiliar or chipless. By Saturday, I shall be back in my familiar chair, remote in hand, hoping to write the Germans off, but sadly without the opportunity to celebrate by having it at all large. I might treat myself to an extra slice of toast.

I am following the first week of Euro 2000 from Mallorca, and I am not alone. Before the tournament, the net had been full of opportunities to "follow the Three Lions in the sun". Couldn't be easier. Book it online, Easyjet from Luton, 10 days in Ibiza or Magaluf for £200-odd, and two drinks for the price of one during matches. Get drunk, get laid, watch the footie. fields.headline: Turkey's wild child grows up
fields.standfirst: Ian Ross on Sergen Yalcin, the man most likely to save his side tonight
fields.trailText: Ian Ross reports on Sergen Yalcin, the man most likely to save his side tonight when they face Sweden.
fields.body:
It was five years ago when it dawned on Sergen Yalcin that he might just be on to something, that he possibly had it within himself to be something more than just another player with the traditional Turkish sporting traits of fierce partisanship and almost spiritual passion.

It all happened when a journalist told the young playmaker he was, in the gossip-driven world of the Turkish media, being openly compared to Paul Gascoigne.

At that point in Gascoigne's pantomime of a career the Geordie was public buffoon No1, the big man with the childish demeanour, the genius with a burning desire to swap his gift from the gods for a frothy bottle of the brown stuff and the back-slaps of his fawning acolytes.

Sergen did not know it at the time but the comparison was apt for, just as English football simply must serve up its perennial enfant terrible, it is incumbent upon the Turkish game to lay a chosen son upon the slab to be sacrificed at the high altar of disparaging public opinion. The culture may be different but there is the same voracious public appetite for scandal.

Like Gascoigne, Sergen is unable to offer anything more than a cursory defence when he is accused of allowing ego to eclipse reason during his formative years as a professional footballer. But, unlike Gascoigne, he was smart enough to appreciate that notoriety is a fickle dance-partner. In short, while the England midfielder continued to sing from the same dog-eared song-sheet, Sergen decided to move on.

For a while Sergen's world revolved exclusively and unapologetically around Sergen - which possibly explains his response when first informed of the comparison to Gascoigne. "Really?," he inquired. "So he is the Sergen of British football, is he?" It does seem likely that the pair would get on famously.

To his detractors - and there are many - Sergen is a luxury item in a team which can ill afford luxuries. The 27-year-old is the personification of indolent arrogance, arguably the most gifted Turkish footballer of his generation and yet one who, for several years, unashamedly placed his personal ambition above the greater needs of the many.

"Being criticised no longer bothers me; I'm used to it," he said. "I get criticised for being lazy, for not doing enough work for the team, for not scoring enough goals from my position just behind the strikers. I'm not bothered any more. I have proved that I can play, that I can dictate the play.

"I do believe it is time that people take a long, hard look at me and accept me for what it is I have to offer," he added. "I don't destroy, I create. I am a good player."

Notwithstanding his resemblance to a startled rat peering out from behind a lavatory brush, Sergen's fame was such that he pursued the agenda of a playboy with absolute relish, adding an over-fondness for gambling to his list of misdemeanours simply because it was the done thing. That is what they call real style down in the old quarter of Istanbul.

And yet, cunningly concealed somewhere between the misunderstood maestro and the rather sad, attention-seeking child is a footballer of immeasurable worth, a player with a classic left foot who could chip a ball into an ashtray from 60 yards.

Those who have a fondness for decrying Sergen's abilities have suggested that, when playing at the highest level, he glitters rather than shines. It is a theory to which few who made their way to Arnhem's impressively modern Gelredome on Sunday afternoon would lend their support.

The bizarre interpretation of the shoulder-charge ruling by the Scottish referee Hugh Dallas may have presented Italy with the penalty that pushed Turkey to defeat in their opening Group B fixture but Sergen's contribution was immense, an intoxicating cocktail of neatly threaded through-balls and passes so visionary they might have been delivered by Mystic Meg.

Sergen's current club is Galatasaray but, rather like Gascoigne, he has the demeanour of a nomad and, having all but exhausted his options in his own backyard (he has also had spells with Istanbulspor and Fenerbahce), he is rumoured to be looking to transport his skills and attendant baggage to foreign shores. The Newcastle United manager Bobby Robson is a long-time admirer.

Meanwhile, having finally accepted that, as the linchpin of his national side, he has a responsibility not only to himself but to others, millions of others, Sergen has dedicated himself to banishing the bitter memory of the embarrassment Turkey suffered during the last European Championship finals in England, when they fell at the first hurdle, pointless and goalless.

"We were so naive in England," he said. "We didn't have experience of the big tournaments and that worked against us. Turkish football is improving all the time, season upon season, and we are here to let everyone know that we are worthy and we are motivated."

They are words Gascoigne would have been proud of, had he ever been sober and sensible enough to say them.

Venue Philips Stadium, Eindhoven

Kick-off 7.45pm

Referee D Jol

(Netherlands)

Head-to-head Sweden 1 win, Turkey 2 wins, draws 1

Television

Live on ITV from 7.30pm - repeated at 2.35am - and Eurosport from 7pm.

Highlights on BBC1 and Eurosport at 12 midnight.

Radio

Live on Radio 5 Live from 7pm

Sweden

Injuries R Nilsson (concussion)

Suspensions P Andersson

fields.headline: Britain 'needs the euro'
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain would benefit economically from joining euroland, the European commissioner in charge of monetary union told the Guardian yesterday
fields.body:
Britain would benefit economically from joining euroland, the European commissioner in charge of monetary union told the Guardian yesterday

On the eve of his first official visit to London, Pedro Solbes insisted, in the face of continuing doubts from the Treasury and the Bank of England, that the balance of advantages was clearly for adopting the single currency. "British membership of EMU would be a good thing for Britain and the EU, as we would all benefit from an enlarged euro area," he said.

With Tony Blair's "prepare and decide" strategy under heavy fire, Mr Solbes' carefully crafted comments are evidence of the firm belief in Brussels that a bigger euroland is better - and that the commission has a role to play in stimulating discussion, if not actively proselytising.

Citing exchange rate fluctuations and the strong pound, Mr Solbes warned that staying outside the euro "could in the long term have negative implications for the British financial industry".

He will tell the Commons cross-party treasury select committee today that long-term foreign direct investment could suffer if Britain stays out.

"There is a real divergence in the economic cycles. But if you accept this argument in an absolute sense you will never be able to join. If you decide to go in the differences in cycles are reduced as a result.

"Participation in the euro would in itself diminish the risk of asymmetries between Britain and the euro area."

Mr Solbes said the fall of the euro against the dollar since its launch 18 months ago did not reflect the underlying strengths of the European economy.

He sought to dispel anxieties that Britain, or any of the EU's 15 member states, could be forced to harmonise taxation or fiscal policy, despite a recent row over commission guidelines on tax cuts and good budgetary practice. "We only have the power of proposing. Ministers have power. We cannot advance unless ministers agree.

"Monetary union requires greater coordination of economic policies, but to go further is the consequence of a political decision, though that is not today's problem."

He opposed the creation of a "Mr Euroland" to speak for the 11. But the forum should hold more press conferences and be more transparent while ensuring that the 15-strong Ecofin forum was not marginalised, as Britain and the other euro opt-outs fear it will be.

Nicknamed The Whisperer for his quietly spokenstyle, Mr Solbes is a committed European who helped negotiate Spain's entry to the EU in 1986 and as finance minister played a crucial role in early decisions on the single currency.

"I'm going to Britain because I know monetary union is not a hot topic there," the bearded 57-year-old socialist joked last night.

Recognised as a hard-working but low-profile member of the commission, Mr Solbes, an economist, is keen to advertise the strengths of the euro: low inflation, public sector deficit reduction and price stability.

He has focused on the sort of structural reforms agreed at last March's Lisbon summit and on urging restraint on finance ministers contemplating tax cuts or spending increases that would have to be clawed back in harder times. Inflation in Ireland and Spain are among his current worries.

webTitle: Slower earnings growth hints at end to rate rises

fields.headline: Slower earnings growth hints at end to rate rises
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Fears that falling unemployment will lead to a wage and price spiral faded yesterday when official figures showed a sharp slowing in the growth of average earnings, increasing speculation that interest rates have peaked.
fields.body:
Fears that falling unemployment will lead to a wage and price spiral faded yesterday when official figures showed a sharp slowing in the growth of average earnings, increasing speculation that interest rates have peaked.

With millennium-related overtime and January bonus payments dropping out of the calculation, earnings growth in the three months to April fell to 5.1%, down 0.6 percentage points from the March figure. This was despite a further drop in the number of people out of work, according to data from the office for national statistics.

Although the market is still prepared for a further quarter point increase in borrowing costs by the end of the year, some City economists said the next move could be down.

Geoff Dicks, at Greenwich NatWest, said: "We still need to slow the underlying rate of growth since the ex-bonus element [of earnings increases] is running at 4.4% against the more acceptable sub-4% rate that we had over most of last year.

"But the message today is that a tight labour market per se is not necessarily a threat to inflation and confirms what we have long argued: that the upside on rates is limited. Who knows? After these data it may have disappeared completely."

The decline in earnings growth was accompanied by an 8,600 drop in the claimant count in May to a new 20-year low of 1,109,00, and a 60,000 fall to 1,684,000 in the alternative measure of unemployment, the International Labour Organisation definition, which has a wider scope.

The employment level hit a new high of 27,873,000 in the latest three months, up 112,000 on the previous quarter, though the headline figure masked continued divergence between the performance of buoyant service and depressed manufacturing industries. Manufacturing shed 2.5% of its workforce in the latest three months compared to the same period a year ago as the strong pound and intense global competition forced firms to cut costs.

Employment minister Tessa Jowell said: "This is good news for the economy and for people seeking work...These figures are about real jobs for real people." The minister announced the launch of three new specialist teams in Thanet, East Ayrshire and Hartlepool, each with £1.5m to invest over the next year, to help people find work.

David Walton, senior economist at Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, cautioned that good inflation news from the fall in average earnings was being offset by the continued weakening of the pound, which pushes up import prices.

He added that higher public spending would ensure that domestic demand remained robust, keeping upward pressure on interest rates. He is continuing to forecast another 0.5 percentage points on the Bank's 6% repo rate.

But Darren Winder of UBS Warburg said: "Overall, the decline in average earnings growth coupled with below target inflation and the prospect of a substantial decline in house price inflation suggests that interest rates are probably more likely to fall than rise over the balance of the next 6 to 12 months."

webTitle: I'm retired, do I have rights?

fields.headline: I'm retired, do I have rights?
fields.trailText: 15 June: I am 54 I have been in marketing all my life but I decided to retire four years ago. Retirement being not what it is meant to be, I decided I would like to go back to work.
fields.body:
The problem

I am 54 I have been in marketing all my life but I decided to retire four years ago. Retirement being not what it is meant to be, I decided I would like to go back to work.

I was unable to get into my chosen career so I took a job with a private hire company. I am employed full time on the minimum wage and my employer tells me I am not eligable for holiday pay, sick pay or being paid for public holidays. I also have to buy my own uniform and private hire licence.

Anthony Jemmett

The solution

I believe that your employer is acting illegally. There are some exceptions to working rights rules, but if you are actually employed by this firm, I believe that they have no right to withhold these rights from you. Of course, many private hire drivers are effectively freelance (which is why they buy their own licences etc.) and this would make them exempt from the working time rules, but this does not seem to be the case with you.

I suggest that you approach your local ACAS (whose number is in the phone book) or Citizen's Advice Bureau to find out what steps you can take to assert your rights if indeed, they are being violated. They will help you - you won't have to fight alone.

Having said all that, it is clear that you would much rather be working in your chosen profession - marketing - anyway. As you have discovered, this is a profession where youth and vibrancy are favoured, but it seems tragic to waste your valuable skills. What about looking at a related field, like sales or customer service, where more experienced employees are beginning to become more in demand? Companies are recognising that customers trust older personnel more than young, thrusting go-getters, especially when it comes to taking advice, making certain purchases or helping solve a problem.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

I also have to buy my own uniform and private hire licence. Anthony Jemmett The solution I believe that your employer is acting illegally. There are some exceptions to working rights rules, but if you are actually employed by this firm, I believe that they have no right to withhold these rights from you. Of course, many private hire drivers are effectively freelance (which is why they buy their own licences etc.) and this would make them exempt from the working time rules, but this does not seem to be the case with you. I suggest that you approach your local ACAS (whose number is in the phone book) or Citizen's Advice Bureau to find out what steps you can take to assert your rights if indeed, they are being violated. They will help you - you won't have to fight alone. Having said all that, it is clear that you would much rather be working in your chosen profession - marketing - anyway. As you have discovered, this is a profession where youth and vibrancy are favoured, but it seems tragic to waste your valuable skills. What about looking at a related field, like sales or customer service, where more experienced employees are beginning to become more in demand? Companies are recognising that customers trust older personnel more than young, thrusting go-getters, especially when it comes to taking advice, making certain purchases or helping solve a problem. Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: EasyJet loses in landing charge row

fields.headline: EasyJet loses in landing charge row
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Luton Airport, home of EasyJet, yesterday won its second-round contest with the low cost carrier, which is trying to prevent the airport from imposing higher landing charges.
fields.body:
Luton Airport, home of EasyJet, yesterday won its second-round contest with the low cost carrier, which is trying to prevent the airport from imposing higher landing charges.

The Civil Aviation Authority has ruled that Luton does not have a dominant position in the market and that the airline, owned by the Greek entrepreneur Stelios Haji-Ioannou does not have a case against the airport.

The airport's chief executive, Graham Roberts, said last night that he hoped this would bring an end to the difficulties between the two and allow them to start negotiations for a new deal on landing charges.

Since it set up business five years ago at Luton, the low cost airline has rapidly expanded and there are now plans to float the company later this year.

Mr Roberts said that the original deal was set "at rock- bottom" price, which was advantageous to the company and the airport. But now Luton wanted to introduce a more realistic rate, in line with changes in the market.

EasyJet pays a fee of around £1.60 for each departing passenger. The airport says it has to pay the local council £3 for each EasyJet traveller and wants to increase the fee to around £7.

Mr Roberts rejected EasyJet's claim that Barclays Bank, a 65% shareholder in the Luton airport company, was threatening rises in the airline's low cost tickets. Mr Roberts said that Barclays was only an investor and had exerted no influence at Luton on landing charges.

Mr Roberts said that he was "very pleased" with the CAA's decision. "We want to main tain our relationship with EasyJet as a value for money airport. All we are asking Mr Haji-Ioannou is that he is sits down with us and resolves our differences."

He said that the new landing charges would apply from October, adding that the airport "would not be brow- beaten by EasyJet. We are fighting with the Marquess of Queensberry's rules and are seeking a fair return for our help." He added that Luton was expected to make a small profit when its annual report is published later this month.

Mr Haji-Ioannou has 14 days to appeal against the decision. He has not threatened to leave the airport, but says that he will not expand the company's services from Luton unless the issue can be settled to his satisfaction.

fields.headline: A lack of inspiration
fields.standfirst:
Bach Cantatas
**
Aldeburgh Festival, Suffolk
fields.trailText:
Bach Cantatas
**
Aldeburgh Festival, Suffolk
fields.body:
John Eliot Gardiner's Bach Cantata Pilgrimage will keep him more than fully occupied throughout the 250th anniversary year. The idea of taking the Monteverdi Choir, the English Baroque Soloists and an ever-changing roster of soloists on perpetual tour through the sacred buildings of Europe, performing all of Bach's cantatas on the dates in the church calendar for which they were written, will turn out to be either a triumph or folie de grandeur . Aldeburgh got three of the concerts this week, two of them at Long Melford near Sudbury, the final one, on Tuesday afternoon, at Blythburgh Church, which has long been one of the festival's most precious and inspiring venues.

Inspired, though, was something that these performances were not. The nine surviving Pentecost cantatas were the focus of this particular triptych; the final concert included the two written in 1724 and 1725 for Whit Tuesday, Nos 184 and 175, interleaved with the Third Brandenburg Concerto and the unaccompanied motet Jesu Meine Freude. Gardiner's way with this music is familiar enough now - urgent, sometimes driven, often moulded in a self-consciously expressive way. It's an approach that can seem over-wrought, but, whatever the misgivings, there is usually a real buzz about his concerts and real technical finesse in their execution.

That was what was so surprising about these performances: the uncertainty of some of the contributions from the normally so dependable Monteverdi Choir, the ragged edges and moments of sour tuning in the orchestral playing, the sheer lack of any sense of occasion, despite the fact that, as for all the pilgrimage concerts, every ticket had been sold weeks in advance. Some of the solo singing was very fine, especially from the tenor Christoph Genz and alto Claudia Schubert, and there were moments when everything did come together and the focus sharpened. But for someone of Gardiner's stature and musicianship the overall standard really wasn't good enough. Rehearsing, performing and recording three programmes in three days seemed to have taken a bigger toll than he envisaged.

webTitle: Investors take hope after Microsoft's court coup

fields.headline: Investors take hope after Microsoft's court coup
fields.standfirst: The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft's shares enjoyed a respite yesterday as dealers interpreted a surprise move by the courts to hear the company's appeal as providing a ray of hope that the computer group might not be split in two.
fields.body:
Microsoft's shares enjoyed a respite yesterday as dealers interpreted a surprise move by the courts to hear the company's appeal as providing a ray of hope that the computer group might not be split in two.

In early trading the shares reached $70 (£43), up more than $3 but still well below the $120 at which they were changing hands six months ago.

One analyst said the mood had swung strongly in Microsoft's favour after the appeal court in Washington indicated it wanted to be given the chance to consider the appeal by Microsoft.

This was because the appeal court had ruled in Microsoft's favour on two other occasions during the three-year legal wrangle.

The stance taken by the appeal court came late on Tuesday when Microsoft's lawyers took the first steps towards asking for a stay to the landmark ruling made by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson last week which set out stern action against Microsoft on anti-competition grounds.

It appears to complicate the sequence of the potential appeal, which the government has indicated it would like to see take place in the supreme court, the highest in the US. Legal experts suggested that the unusual move by the appeal court might deter the supreme court from deciding to hear the case if the lower court were able to hear it more quickly.

However, Judge Jackson, who appears to have infuriated Microsoft by giving interviews before handing out his final ruling, could still ask the supreme court to take the case. The appeal process is still far from certain and could still take months to be concluded, a factor acknowledged by Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman.

"Our position is simple. This is a case that will be decided by a higher court," he said. "The principles that apply in terms of 'was Microsoft's behaviour pro-competitive in every respect?', that's already been stated in every respect."

He said that an appeal was a standard right in the US. "It's hard to say exactly -probably in the order of 12 months before a decision comes down," he added.

Microsoft is arguing that the judge's ruling, and his determination that his order should take effect in 90 days, would have "far reaching and irreversible consequences".

The computer company is claiming that the judge committed "an array of serious substantive and procedural errors that infected virtually every aspect of the proceedings".

fields.headline: European court threat over BT
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's efforts to offer consumers a genuine alternative to British Telecom have been panned in a written warning from the European commission which threatens court action unless the situation improves soon.
fields.body:
The government's efforts to offer consumers a genuine alternative to British Telecom have been panned in a written warning from the European commission which threatens court action unless the situation improves soon.

Brussels will announce today that Britain has failed to implement a directive designed to allow consumers to switch operators with a minimum of fuss. The criticism is likely to resurrect accusations that industry watchdog Oftel is too soft on BT.

British consumers should have been able from January 1 to pick and choose between rival telephone operators without having to dial a prefix every time they want to make a call, EC officials say.

Oftel admitted yesterday that the necessary legislation would not be in place until the end of 2001, almost certainly heralding a legal battle with Brussels.

The government sought and won a three-month exemption from the EC's rules on the grounds that BT needed more time to comply with the directive. That exemption expired on April 1. The EC's patience is at an end and officials are adamant that there is no prospect of granting Britain any more favours.

"We can't extend it [the deadline] any longer and now they have to comply. It's a barrier to competition and a market obstacle to new entrants," one official said. "We have been extremely accommodating but this directive is just too important."

At issue is the availability of "carrier preselection" which allows existing BT customers to shop around for the best deal for local, national or international calls while keeping their BT line.

Brussels believes that if real choice and competition is to take off, consumers should have a seamless connection to the service provider of their choice.

But Oftel said yesterday that such a facility would not be available for national and international calls until the end of this year and people would have to wait until December 2001 before being offered the same option for local calls.

Oftel says BT has had enough on its plate dealing with the millennium bug and organising national number changes. It also maintains that technical peculiarities of the BT network mean the change is complex and requires considerable investment.

"Carrier preselection is on its way and there is an interim solution," an Oftel spokesman said, referring to the autodial box offered by some operators.

He conceded, however, that the boxes had to be installed on an individual basis, were not universally available and there was nothing to stop their cost being passed on to the consumer.

He also admitted that carrier preselection was "significant in terms of promoting choice and competition" but said the government was likely to argue that it was complying with EU law because of the availability of autodial boxes.

Britain has one month to respond to the EC's warning letter and officials in Brussels said yesterday that if they did not receive a satisfactory explanation they would press ahead with legal action. If the European Court of Justice were to find in favour of the EC, the government could face a fine as well as public humiliation.

fields.headline: Lakatos
fields.standfirst:
Lakatos
***
Ronnie Scott's, London
fields.trailText:
Lakatos
***
Ronnie Scott's, London
fields.body:
If you were a fiddle player, and Anne-Sophie Mutter, Maxim Vengerov and Yehudi Menuhin had all turned up at your gigs, you'd have to be doing something right. Just like Roby Lakatos, the classically trained but gypsy-inspired Hungarian violinist who is now at Ronnie Scott's with his quartet.

It's not as wild and deliriously undignified as the Romanian Taraf de Haidouks ensemble, which last brought gypsy music to Ronnie Scott's, and Lakatos's playing has more angelic purity than the rougher, more approximately pitched work of the Romanians. But the violinist proved on his opening night that close observance of the rituals of traditional Danube-cafe music has not blunted his urge to improvise. And though there was plenty of swoony, romantic rhapsodising (maybe a little too much of it for the audience, which looked a little restless in these episodes), he has an ear open to a more modern world than 19th-century central Europe, even if he hasn't quite made it all the way to the 21st.

The leader's breath-taking technique really came into its own on the up-tempo Hungarian folk-dance music, which was full of crash stops, sly build-ups and headlong nosedives like a journey on fairground switchback. Fast bowing released notes that came at you like hailstorms, mixed in with sudden slashing discords and beautifully constructed long runs.

Lakatos's technical mastery was matched by cimbalom player and guitarist Ernest Bango, whose name seemed particularly apt when he handled the former instrument. He displayed a clattering virtuosity as he did the work of vibes, keyboards and drums at once. But the intriguing aspect of the ensemble is its closet jazz inclinations. Pianist Kalman Cseki played some crisp, boppish interludes, Bango expertly caught the Django Reinhardt Hot Club sound on guitar for Lakatos to wheel and dive over, and the phrasing of this music's deepest traditions was subtly reshaped in Lakatos's hands. It won't be enough of a jazz band for some, but it certainly means business.

Lakatos is at Ronnie Scott's, London W1 (020-7439 0747), till Saturday.

fields.headline: When three become one
fields.standfirst:
Lucy Pearl
**
Hanover Grand, London
fields.trailText:
Lucy Pearl
**
Hanover Grand, London
fields.body:
One imagines that Raphael Saadiq, an ex-member of the under-appreciated R&B group Tony Toni Tone, pinches himself every night in disbelief. Not only has he managed to recruit Ali Shaheed Muhammed, the DJ from hip-hop group A Tribe Called Quest, to his new project, but Dawn Robinson, formerly of En Vogue, is also on board. Each member of Lucy Pearl brings something dif ferent to the table: Muhammed, credibility; Robinson, sass; and Saadiq, musicianship. With that kind of pedigree, Lucy Pearl seem an exciting project - the perfect pop band. Yet, like most supergroups, they promise more than they actually deliver.

Their debut album is lightweight R&B pop, urban soul music before it got seduced by the shiny baubles and bright lights of materialism. The group concern themselves with love and having fun: honorable sentiments perhaps, but they lack the yearning and burning that might make the music truly work. The songs are all very nice but don't reach the soulful heights of Lauryn Hill, nor do they have the goofy esprit of Missy Elliott. Most of them are too respectful and smooth, living up to the coffee table vibe of the project.

There's a "throw things at the wall and see what sticks" approach to this showcase. The songs are performed in an excruciating Jive Bunny-style medley and suffer as a result. It's meant to be fun but feels false. Saadiq has been cast in the role of geeky master of ceremonies. Unfortunately that means routine audience participation games and proving to us that he can really rock. Alongside the heavy funk band that is de rigueur for R&B and hip-hop groups now, Saadiq is an unlikely axe hero.

In an ill-advised move, Lucy Pearl constantly sought to remind us of their musical pasts. By concentrating on note-for-note renditions of instantly recognisable songs such as En Vogue's Hold On, they lost their better material such as Trippin' in the fog of guitar pyrotechnics. Unlike Saadiq, Ali Shaheed Muhammed had a low-key role: apart from a few turntable tricks and a thunderous scratch technique his presence was negligible. This is no bad thing because there is only one true star in Lucy Pearl: Dawn Robinson. Although she was uneasy when she wasn't belting out their catchiest songs, Robinson has the talent and presence to save Lucy Pearl from being a blip on her musical CV.

fields.headline: Reign of error
fields.standfirst:
The flow of jokes just would not stop
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Yorkshire's sale of its water company is unlikely to include that most familiar of marketing phrases: one careful owner. Few firms have suffered such a tally of PR disasters in a life as short as 11 years.
fields.body:
Yorkshire's sale of its water company is unlikely to include that most familiar of marketing phrases: one careful owner. Few firms have suffered such a tally of PR disasters in a life as short as 11 years.

When the company changed its name to the Kelda Group two years ago there was a general - and only half-heartedly denied - assumption that the old title was as deadly an albatross as Windscale, the discredited predecessor of Sellafield.

The killer episode, which led to the premature departure of almost all the original board, was the drought of 1995-96 which struck at the company's normally sodden catchment areas in the Pennines. At the same time, 26%of what water remained dribbled from leaky pipes.

The company was also tarnished by the Diana Scott affair, when a robust consumer champion lost her job as head of the regional Ofwat committee, amid claims she had been too gutsy, and then suffered spooky setbacks when she tried to get on to the Yorkshire Water board.

Executives meanwhile cracked jokes about leaks at what they thought was a private business leaders' dinner in Harrogate; they applied for a Chartermark for high service standards in the middle of the crisis; and they entered a technological award competition - for a device which claimed to mend dripping pipes.

Humbler staff did not like to say that they worked for Yorkshire Water, in spite of the pride the county usually takes in anything bearing its name.

webTitle: To hear or not to hear

fields.headline: To hear or not to hear
fields.standfirst:
Hamlet
***
Shakespeare's Globe, London
fields.trailText:
Hamlet
***
Shakespeare's Globe, London
fields.body:
You have to put up with a lot of distractions at the Globe: the mercurial weather, the officious ushers, the restless crowd. It's hard to focus on "To be or not to be" when some Yankee tourist is wrestling with his crinkly Pac-a-mac. But it says a lot for Mark Rylance's performance and Giles Block's production that they overcome the countless obstacles built into playgoing at the Globe.

Rylance is one of nature's Hamlets: alert, humorous and capable of combining whimsical dottiness with a troubled inner life. He handles the soliloquies superbly, as if the words were coming new-minted into his brain. In the first solo he seizes on his mother's "dexterity" in hastening to incestuous sheets, as if morally revolted by maternal fickleness. And "O, what a rogue and peasant slave" shows Rylance's mastery of the space as he traverses the stage playing off the audience while also suggesting Hamlet's self-flagellation.

This is, above all, a witty Hamlet who grows into a stoical acceptance of death. Rylance treats the Ghost's subterranean rumbles as an underground joke, mercilessly joshes Polonius and dons a shit-stained nightgown to denote his antic disposition. But in the last act, as he obsessively clutches a skull, you feel this is a Hamlet who has matured into a keen awareness of mortality. Despite an occasional excess of vocal virtuosity, Rylance offers us a quick-brained Hamlet intrigued by moral and material putrescence.

He's backed up by a speedy Jacobean production in which each scene melts into the next. Block has also devised some choice bits of business: Claudius's ostentatious preference for Laertes over Hamlet at court, and Ophelia's eavesdropping on Hamlet's exile, which precipitates her into madness. Some of the surrounding characters seem under-explored but Tim Woodward is a suitably bluff Claudius, James Hayes lends Polonius a touch of sinister blarney and Mark Lockyer's Laertes has a speech of fire that really does blaze.

It's a traditional production with an original central performance. But, as so often at the Globe, I found the play came most alive when I quit my assigned seat to roam around the yard: if you can't beat the distracting multitude, canoodling and flicking through their tourist guides, the only thing to do is to join them.

In rep at the Globe until September 24. Box office: 020-7401 9919. A version of this review appeared in Saturday's paper.

fields.headline: Charleroi's angels
fields.standfirst: Harry Pearson  sees citizens left high and dry by Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Thirty minutes before kick-off, in a concourse behind the Stade de Pays, a Belgian police dog handler is patrolling among the little knots of Yugoslav fans.
fields.body:
Thirty minutes before kick-off, in a concourse behind the Stade de Pays, a Belgian police dog handler is patrolling among the little knots of Yugoslav fans.

He is a squat man with a vast belly and copious, elaborately cultivated facial hair. If dog owners eventually come to look like their animals you might expect this fellow to be walking the canine equivalent of a hippopotamus with a handlebar moustache.

Instead he has a thin, pale brown animal that looks like a dingo. It does not look capable of intimidating anyone.

In fact, if this policeman is planning to frighten any potential troublemakers, he would do better to bark himself.

The dog walks on tip-toes. Its tail is curled down between its legs; dark eyes swerve from side to side, showing the whites. Every once in a while the handler dips at the knee and gently touches its head. It is a trainee, a pup. The owner is getting it used to crowds.

No doubt it will be kept well away from England v Germany on Saturday, but today's match is not so much low-key as dropping right off the bass register.

The ground is half-full. Behind it, in one of the peculiar concourses that run between the back doors of terrace houses and the back of the stands, a group of police officers is sitting eating sandwiches in a children's play area. One of them is sitting on the steps of the slide.

The staff at the soft-drinks stands are standing around glancing hopefully at anyone who looks like they might be thirsty, and absolutely no one is singing along to "Un, Deux, Trois. Allez, Allez, Allez" in the Au Vieux Bison Fute Club Karaoke.

Behind the towering new stand which rises dizzyingly above the pitch - its jutting roof giving it an alarmingly top-heavy look - the occupants of Résidence Pallas, an 11-storey block of flats that sits directly behind it, are out on their balconies.

Many of the balconies are adorned with Belgian and Italian flags - not surprising as there are some 250,000 Italians in Belgium, the country's largest immigrant group, and most of them live in the mining and steel towns of the Pays Noir, of which Charleroi is the capital - and the people on them seem to be staring at the stand's mass of concrete and shiny, tubular metal.

When the top tier is removed after the tournament is over they will have their view of the pitch back, and will be able watch Les Zebras again, Philippe Albert and all. For the moment they can only listen to the noise of the crowd.

Thirty yards further along, the residents of the altogether smarter Résidence Clarines are literally in a happier position. Their apartment building is separated from the mass of fans by a privet hedge and a 3ft-high mesh fence. Their building is lower than that of their neighbours, but because of the gap at the corner between the stands they have a perfect view of the pitch.

Well, a full third of it, anyway. No wonder they have their deckchairs out.

Contrary to what has been said and written in Britain, Charleroi is not tiny. It is home to 50,000 more folk than Alan Shearer's home city. No English journalist would describe Newcastle as tiny. Well, not unless he or she really wanted a sack full of letters from indignant Geordies.

Charleroi does feel small, though. Partly that is because it is hemmed in by the high-sided Meuse valley, partly because of a remarkable federal road-building programme. Back in the 60s the national government poured money into restructuring Belgian cities: in west Flanders much of it went on modernising and extending the harbour at Zeebrugge but in Charleroi it was spent on building not one but two ring roads.

This, as citizens of Charleroi's arch-rival city Liège caustically observe was "as many as Brussels and Paris put together!".

The idea presumably was to improve Charleroi's communication links with the rest of Europe though Belgians, embittered by years of political graft, naturally suggest darker motives. The reality has been rather the opposite.

Charleroi's ring roads cut it off from the world, a double moat of tarmac, concrete and roaring motors. Life was always tough in Charleroi. There were economic slumps, poverty and industrial disasters - in one of the most infamous, at the Marcinelle coal mine in 1956, 262 men died of whom 136 were Italian - but there was once wealth here too. The Passage de la Bourse in the lower part of the town was once considered a rival to the lustrous arcades of central Brussels.

Nowadays the plaster is flaking off its vaulted ceilings and many of the shops are empty or occupied by traders in second-hand paperbacks.

The decision to invest money in rebuilding the stadium for Euro 2000 is another attempt to regenerate the city. It is an attempt to give this once powerful industrial giant a European-wide name. So far it has succeeded in all the wrong ways.

At the top of the steps leading up from the vast car parks near the Palais Des Expositions, a pair of north African brothers have set up a little fold-out table and a Calor gas cooker. The elder man is sitting in a battered white panel van nearby talking on a mobile phone. The younger of the two is frying merguez sausages in a big, flat aluminium dish.

There are bowls full of salad on a yellow table cloth next to him. There is no one else around. "Eat while you walk. Sale price" the boy shouts when he sees me approaching.

"Not many people for the game today?" I ask.

"Maybe they will be very hungry when they come out," he says. Or when they wake up.

webTitle: And now, live and direct from our expert voyeurs . . .

fields.headline: And now, live and direct from our expert voyeurs . . .
fields.trailText: I f you have already tuned in to Talksport during this European Championship you will have discovered a spiky and innovative new radio channel. A little too innovative for the BBC's liking, in fact. This week the Beeb brought a court action to stop the station claiming it was providing live coverage of Euro 2000.
fields.body:
I f you have already tuned in to Talksport during this European Championship you will have discovered a spiky and innovative new radio channel. A little too innovative for the BBC's liking, in fact. This week the Beeb brought a court action to stop the station claiming it was providing live coverage of Euro 2000.

Only Radio 5 Live and the Capital Radio group have radio rights and access to the stadiums. The men from Talksport have been commentating on matches off the television, feeding in sound effects to make it seem live.

Mike Hales, head of BBC Sport publicity, said yesterday: "In one match their commentators were celebrating a goal because on TV they saw the ball go over the line. But it wasn't a goal. Our man at the ground had seen the linesman's flag go up out of picture.

"When Belgium played Sweden on Saturday, Talksport took the trouble to play the two national anthems. But in the stadium the anthems had been sung at a different time, and by a male tenor with a choir.

"It's a sham. They've been duping the listeners.

"We don't have any objection to Talksport commentating a match off TV, provided they don't refer to the commentary as live, and provided they make it clear that they're not in the ground. We must honour each other's agreements."

Not being a practising Catholic I have never enjoyed the guilt-thrill of the confessional, the stern and steady eye of an admonishing priest. But here's a confession.

Many years ago I reported a First Division match at Molineux from my TV, back in London. Winter blizzards had hit the M1 and there was no way I was going to get to Wolverhampton on time. My newspaper, I hasten to add, had been informed. I hate to say this but it was one of my best reports. Each goal, after half a dozen replays, was described in precise detail. All the match stats were there and the quotes from the managers were fresh and immediate.

But what if those blizzard winds had blown the TV aerial off the roof? I would have been stuck and so, dear reader, would you. There are dangers that come with reporting off the cathode.

Once, at the world snooker championship in Sheffield, I saw a reporter who could not find a seat in the press area taking copious notes from the screen, not realising that the match had been played some hours before.

It can only be hoped that Talksport is aware of the pitfalls. What if Wimbledon is washed out and Auntie puts on some grainy old footage of Jimmy Connors hammering Ken Rosewall? If the men from the radio don't realise what's going on, and provide "live" commentary, all credibility will be lost.

If this week's test in Birmingham is rained off the TV men may decide to show some ancient action. The famous Lord's test of 1963, perhaps. Turn on your radio tomorrow and you just might hear Wes Hall charging in to bowl to Ted Dexter.

Then again, that is unlikely because Channel 4's cricket archives only go back as far as England v New Zealand 1999. But if I were a Beeb boffin I think I would stick on some old Euro 96 footage over the next couple of weeks, just to throw the men from Talksport.

In that case, if you tuned in to 1089/1053 AM you might hear: "And now the whole stadium has fallen silent once more as Gareth Southgate prepares to take the next penalty which could give England a 6-5 advantage over Germany . . ."

Or maybe: "And the referee is consulting the linesman. Geoff Hurst's shot hit the underside of the bar and bounced down and there seems some doubt about whether the ball actually crossed the line . . ."

I f Talksport continues to broadcast off the box, and the TV boys have any sense of fun, we could be transported back to those vintage wireless days when Juan Manuel Fangio and Stirling Moss vied in motor combat, when Randolph Turpin outpointed the great Sugar Ray Robinson and Roger Bannister ran the four-minute mile.

Come to think of it, these Talksport chappies may be on to something after all.

webTitle: Owen is the victim of Keegan's backward thinking

fields.headline: Owen is the victim of Keegan's backward thinking
fields.standfirst: Richard Williams says England should cherish a true talent
fields.trailText: Michael Owen was not at all pleased when Kevin Keegan told him he would not be going out for the second half of England's match against Portugal on Monday night.
fields.body:
Michael Owen was not at all pleased when Kevin Keegan told him he would not be going out for the second half of England's match against Portugal on Monday night.

"He was absolutely gutted when I took him off," Keegan said yesterday, "as he was when I left him out against Malta. But I said to him: 'You will have your day. You will play a lot of games for England and you will do all the things you want to do that cause peo ple trouble.' But on that day, in the way we played, with what we were trying to do, he wasn't effective enough."

It is not an easy job being an international coach; not easy to tell a 20-year-old that his day will come; not easy when that 20-year-old is one of England's tiny handful of world-class players. It is not easy to tell him that, although he scored the goal that provided England with a respectable result against Brazil three weeks ago, with the sort of moment of improvisatory brilliance that would have had us swooning had it been performed by a player in a yellow shirt, the coach did not trust him enough to give him a full chance to do it again. It is not easy when you remember what he did to Argentina's defence two summers ago in St-Etienne.

Perhaps the worst part of it was that, during his 45 minutes on the pitch at the Philips Stadium on Monday, Owen had actually delivered England's best pass of the night. In the 18th minute he went out to the right wing to get the ball and played a disguised ball inside to David Beckham at such an angle and with such swiftness that the entire flank of the Portuguese defence was thrown off balance, allowing Beckham to cross the ball for Steve McManaman to score the goal which put the team two up.

There were lots of good things about England's performance in the first half but nothing better than that. Beckham, Paul Scholes and McManaman all did well but none of them produced a pass as instinctive and effective. Owen is a special player and there was the evidence, if we still needed it.

But, in Keegan's view, he has an important deficiency. "We just weren't holding the ball up well enough," he said when explaining his decision to send on Emile Heskey in place of his Liverpool team-mate.

Over the next 45 minutes we all saw how well Heskey held the ball up, which was not at all -and just about as much as Alan Shearer had held it up in the first half and was to do again after the interval. And Shearer achieved nothing remotely like the pass that Owen had given Beckham.

Holding the ball up is an old-fashioned virtue that has nothing to do with the way a top international team must play today if it wants to win major tournaments. You hold the ball up for one of two reasons: to run the clock down towards the end of a match or to give your team-mates time to catch up with the play. In today's game, however, if they need time to catch up, then either the wrong tactics are wrong or the platers are wrong.

Keegan is right that Owen failed to hold the ball up in the first half. When he received the ball with back to goal and a defender on his neck, he was always trying to twist away and always ended up losing possession. But at some time in the second half he might have tried it again - for the fifth, sixth or seventh time - and made it work. And that is all it would have taken to get a result, as it was against Brazil.

Portugal, too, had a striker who could not hold the ball up. His name was Nuno Gomes, he is 23 years old, he had never scored an international goal before this week despite having won eight caps, he was ap pearing against England only because of injuries to others and he was not given the benefit of support from a Shearer-type partner. He was up there all alone. And when he received the ball with his back to goal in the first half, as he did on several occasions, he tried to twist past his marker and invariably forfeited possession.

But Humberto Coelho, Portugal's coach, did not see this as a reason to take him off. "England were very strong on the counter-attack," he said afterwards, "but we kept playing to our style. We didn't think of our opponents. We just did our own job."

Gomes, having been picked for his own qualities, was part of Portugal's style and was there to do his own job. And Coelho was rewarded for his faith in the second half when Gomes finally received a ball he liked from Rui Costa, a diagonal pass that allowed him to slide between Tony Adams and Gary Neville and clip the ball past David Seaman for the winning goal. Twice more he was to try it and twice more he almost scored.

"I'm never disappointed with young players," Keegan said yesterday, in response to an invitation to discuss his decision. "You have to realise how young Michael is and that, although he's got quite a lot of experience for one so young, he hasn't got the experience of most other players around that field. I just felt that he wasn't getting in the game. When you're young, sometimes it's hard to know what you have to do to get into the game. I just felt we needed another alternative up there. That's what I told him, and that's the truth."

Unlike some of his predecessors, Keegan is a straight sort of fellow. There is unlikely to have been a hidden agenda behind his decision to show such a public lack of belief in one of his players. It is hard to imagine, for instance, that Shearer's preference for the company of Heskey on the pitch would have influenced him.

But the coach made a mistake and he had better not repeat it on Saturday night, when speed and imagination will be needed against Germany's creaking rearguard as England face their last realistic chance to remain in the tournament.
