His name was Nuno Gomes, he is 23 years old, he had never scored an international goal before this week despite having won eight caps, he was ap pearing against England only because of injuries to others and he was not given the benefit of support from a Shearer-type partner. He was up there all alone. And when he received the ball with his back to goal in the first half, as he did on several occasions, he tried to twist past his marker and invariably forfeited possession. But Humberto Coelho, Portugal's coach, did not see this as a reason to take him off. "England were very strong on the counter-attack," he said afterwards, "but we kept playing to our style. We didn't think of our opponents. We just did our own job." Gomes, having been picked for his own qualities, was part of Portugal's style and was there to do his own job. And Coelho was rewarded for his faith in the second half when Gomes finally received a ball he liked from Rui Costa, a diagonal pass that allowed him to slide between Tony Adams and Gary Neville and clip the ball past David Seaman for the winning goal. Twice more he was to try it and twice more he almost scored. "I'm never disappointed with young players," Keegan said yesterday, in response to an invitation to discuss his decision. "You have to realise how young Michael is and that, although he's got quite a lot of experience for one so young, he hasn't got the experience of most other players around that field. I just felt that he wasn't getting in the game. When you're young, sometimes it's hard to know what you have to do to get into the game. I just felt we needed another alternative up there. That's what I told him, and that's the truth." Unlike some of his predecessors, Keegan is a straight sort of fellow. There is unlikely to have been a hidden agenda behind his decision to show such a public lack of belief in one of his players. It is hard to imagine, for instance, that Shearer's preference for the company of Heskey on the pitch would have influenced him. But the coach made a mistake and he had better not repeat it on Saturday night, when speed and imagination will be needed against Germany's creaking rearguard as England face their last realistic chance to remain in the tournament.

fields.headline: England blame it on euphoria
fields.standfirst: Keegan's cavaliers lost their heads in Eindhoven and radical surgery is now required, says  David Lacey
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has 72 hours to get his team and his tactics right if England's latest attempt to dominate the international stage is not to end in yet another undignified pratfall into the orchestra pit following Monday's surrender of a 2-0 lead to Portugal, who eventually won 3-2 in Eindhoven.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has 72 hours to get his team and his tactics right if England's latest attempt to dominate the international stage is not to end in yet another undignified pratfall into the orchestra pit following Monday's surrender of a 2-0 lead to Portugal, who eventually won 3-2 in Eindhoven.

Germany, England's opponents in Charleroi on Saturday, are clearly not the force they once were but, unless Keegan sorts out his midfield and defence, they will not need to be. The Germans are not so far gone that Mehmet Scholl, Thomas Hässler, Christian Ziege and Oliver Bierhoff would fail to exploit the sort of freedom given to Rui Costa, Joao Pinto and Luis Figo.

There is a strong case, too, for a revolutionary selection next time, with the willing but limited Alan Shearer left out, Michael Owen used as a lone striker supported by Paul Scholes and Nick Barmby, and Nigel Martyn replacing a nervous, vulnerable David Seaman in goal. It will not happen, of course; as captain, Shearer will undoubtedly go down with his already listing ship.

Nevertheless injuries have forced two changes on Keegan for the match against the Germans. Tony Adams has a calf problem which will keep him out of both this game and the encounter with Romania in Charleroi on Tuesday. Thus his only chance of taking further part in Euro 2000 will be if England reach the quarter- finals. Steve McManaman also misses Saturday's match with a damaged knee.

Presumably Martin Keown will replace Adams with Gareth Southgate recalled should the England coach decide to switch to a back three. Dennis Wise, who came on for McManaman against Portugal, appears set to stay in the team with Steven Gerrard the most likely addition if Keegan opts for playing five across the middle to lessen the risk of re peating the catastrophic defending which cost England their opening game.

While a win and a draw might be enough to see England into the quarter-finals, dropping points against Germany or Romania could equally see them eliminated. Unless the organisation and discipline in their own half of the field show a radical improvement it is hard to envisage two English victories as a realistic prospect, not least because an outstanding opportunity of victory has so lamely been thrown away.

When North Korea lost 5-3 to Portugal in the 1966 World Cup quarter-finals after taking an early 3-0 lead there were mitigating circumstances. For one thing, the Koreans had not learned how to close a game down in a winning situation. For another, the Portuguese had Eusebio.

So what is England's excuse after finding themselves 2-0 up by the 18th minute? Why, after such a marvellous start, has Keegan's team reached a point of elimination from the European Championship with the tournament barely begun?

Lack of experience is not a factor. Nine of the side fielded by Keegan had started against Argentina in St-Etienne in the 1998 World Cup and eight had successfully denied the Argentines a winning goal following Beckham's dismissal. England's subsequent exit on penalties at least provided Glenn Hoddle with a hard-luck story.

Even Alf Ramsey could offer some sort of plea of mitigation after England, then the World Cup holders, had gone out of the 1970 tournament 3-2 to West Germany in Leon having, like Keegan's side, taken a 2-0 lead. The overnight loss of Gordon Banks to a stomach upset and the mistake by Peter Bonetti which allowed Franz Beckenbauer's saveable shot to bring the Germans back into the contest were circumstances no manager could have foreseen.

In becoming the first England coach since Ramsey to lose a match like this, Keegan can reasonably argue that much of what happened was beyond his control. Yet he it was who decided to trust in Paul Ince being able to shield the centre-backs much as he had done in the 1-1 draw with Brazil at Wembley a fortnight earlier, eschewing the opportunity to pack the midfield.

Players, not systems, win or lose games but, as Rui Costa, Pinto and Figo increasingly strolled around England's half like men picking apples, the amount Adams has owed at Arsenal to the defensive qualities of Patrick Vieira and Emmanuel Petit became glaringly obvious. With Scholes continuing to join the attack Ince was left on a deck aflame with Portuguese passing and movement, and by the time Wise joined the firefighters, after McManaman's injury, England were all but gutted.

"As a team we didn't defend well," Keegan admitted yesterday, "and that applies to the front players as much as those behind them. Portugal caused us a lot of problems and we didn't come up with all the right answers.

"After we had taken a two-goal lead I think our players got a bit carried away. The atmosphere was euphoric. We needed then to stop Portugal playing for 10 minutes or so. But situations like that are very hard to control. And what would people have said if I'd reacted to going 2-0 up by bringing on Martin Keown? Even at half-time, when it was 2-2, I still thought we could win."

This is not an England team with outstanding ability in several positions. While the goals by Scholes and McManaman reconfirmed Beckham as one of the most accomplished crossers in the modern game, he did little after half-time because England were unable to win enough possession to get the ball to him.

England invariably set out for these tournaments amid strident declarations that they have an outstanding squad capable of taking on anyone. Harmless though such routine chest-beating may be, it becomes embarrassing when the team's limitations are exposed as swiftly and ruthlessly as they were in Eindhoven.

fields.headline: Rioch offered Wednesday job
fields.trailText: Bruce Rioch is poised to return from the managerial wilderness next week with relegated Sheffield Wednesday. Their chairman Howard Culley was expected to meet him last night in the hope of persuading him to take control at a club who have debts of £14m.
fields.body:
Bruce Rioch is poised to return from the managerial wilderness next week with relegated Sheffield Wednesday. Their chairman Howard Culley was expected to meet him last night in the hope of persuading him to take control at a club who have debts of £14m.

Rioch, a former manager of Arsenal and Bolton, has been out of work since resigning from Norwich City midway through last season.

The other name linked with the Yorkshire club is the former Sheffield United manager Steve Bruce, currently in charge at Huddersfield Town.

If Rioch and Bruce decline Culley's overtures the task will be handed to Peter Shreeves, who had expected to leave Wednesday when his short-term contract expires on Tuesday. He has been working at Hillsborough in a caretaker capacity since Danny Wilson was sacked almost three months ago.

Culley faces a rough ride this evening when he addresses an extraordinary general meeting of shareholders, called by supporters who want to pass a motion of no confidence in the board.

Gianfranco Zola's agent Fulvi Marrucco has said the Chelsea player is prepared to take a "sizeable pay cut" to return to Napoli, who won promotion to Serie A last season.

West Ham's former England Under-21 midfielder Trevor Sinclair has signed a one-year extension to his contract, keeping him at Upton Park until 2005.

Derby's Argentine striker Esteban Fuertes is poised to sign for the French First Division club Lens. Fuertes, 27, has been playing on loan with the Argentine side Colon since his spell at Pride Park was curtailed by work- permit problems.

webTitle: The best library scene: The ninth gate

fields.headline: The best library scene: The ninth gate
fields.trailText: Dispatched by the wealthy book collector Boris Balkan to track down the last remaining copies of the Satanist text The Nine Gates Of The Kingdom Of Shadows, Dean Corso (Johnny Depp) finds himself in the sumptuous country house of wheelchair-bound bibliophile Baroness Kessler (Barbara Jefford).
fields.body:
Dispatched by the wealthy book collector Boris Balkan to track down the last remaining copies of the Satanist text The Nine Gates Of The Kingdom Of Shadows, Dean Corso (Johnny Depp) finds himself in the sumptuous country house of wheelchair-bound bibliophile Baroness Kessler (Barbara Jefford).

Narrowing her eyes, the Baroness peers inquisitively at her guest.

"What is it you wish to discuss, Mr Corso?"

Corso catches the Baroness's eye.

"Ah, there's a book in your collection I'd like to examine if possible_"

For just a moment, he hesitates.

"It's The Book Of The Nine Gates Of The Kingdom Of Shadows."

The Baroness lets slip a small smirk.

"The Nine Gates? It's an interesting work. Everyone's been asking me about it lately."

"Is that so?"

The Baroness wheels herself into the adjacent room - her library. Corso gazes in astonishment at the sheer scale of her collection. Absent-mindedly, Corso faces his hostess.

"Do you truly believe in the Devil, Baroness?"

"Enough to devote my life and library to him", she responds. "Not to mention many years of work."

The Baroness spins around, her gaze directed at Corso.

"Don't you?"

Corso considers his answer for a second before replying.

"Almost."

See also: Citizen Kane, The Breakfast Club, Ghostbusters

Don't see also: City Of Angels

Pointless trivia: After starring as Ichabod Crane in Tim Bur ton's Sleepy Hollow, Johnny Depp bought Goldeneye, the one-eyed horse who starred in the film, saving him from being put down.

fields.headline: Out in the cold
fields.standfirst: The expensive failure of a combined mail shot has left the charities involved reflecting on the wisdom of the message.
fields.trailText: The expensive failure of a combined mail shot has left the charities involved reflecting on the wisdom of the message.
fields.body:
You give money to a charity appeal that says "your gift will make a big and immediate difference". You imagine an African child being fed, an old person's cataract being removed or potable water reaching a village. You don't expect your money to be spent on the cost of the mail shot.

Twenty-two charities are this week smarting from the collapse of a fundraising scheme where costs have totalled more than £100,000, while only £50,000 was raised by the direct mail shot. Six planned mailings have now been abandoned.

The operation was started by Europe's biggest direct marketing agency, WWAV Rapp Collins, which came up with the idea of sending out a joint mail shot. This, in theory, gave smaller charities the chance to raise money through direct marketing by sharing the costs.

Under the banner Fundraising United, a letter was sent out to 400,000 households in March, signed by the television presenter, Jon Snow. He asked respondents to enter a prize draw for £10,000 and to donate at least £10 to one of the 22 charities involved. The deadline for the draw was April 26.

The charities invested on the understanding that WWAV Rapp Collins would reimburse them if it didn't work. The agency's chief executive, Chris Gordon, stated: "The money raised will . . . be distributed to the various charities and they will not be out of pocket as a result of taking part in the scheme."

However, the money donated will be counted as part of the reimbursement. So if a charity invested £10,000 but raised £2,000 through donations, the agency will only pay £8,000. In effect, money donated by the public will be forwarded to the charities but used to cover the costs rather than going to the cause.

Gordon argues that the agency is being more than honourable in refunding charities' investment. "Donors have not funded a loss-making marketing scheme, the agency has." He says that most fundraising direct marketing breaks even, at best, when recruiting donors. "Money is made when charities develop a relationship with donors and convert them into committed givers."

It is generally accepted among professional fundraisers that charities need to invest to accumulate new donors. But when a scheme goes wrong, it is a high price to pay - both in terms of finance and reputation.

The Charity Commission will not comment without time to study the detail, but a spokesperson says: "Decisions about fundraising methods are in the hands of a charity's trustees, who should review their efficiency on a regular basis."

Some of the charities are refusing to comment, describing it as a "delicate" time in the negotiations. At the time of going to press, the agency had not sent out cheques to reimburse the charities. While some donations have been forwarded, a spokesperson for WWAV Rapp Collins, Robert Mayes, says the agency is waiting so they do not distribute the money in bits and pieces. Yet the direct mail appeal stated: "Consider making a donation of just £10 and your gift will go straight to whichever charity or charities you choose." Seven weeks after the closing date of the prize draw, which took place early this month, charities would now like to see financial matters settled.

Two charities acknowledge they have recruited new donors, but there is general disappointment. So what went wrong with this approach? Mayes says the agency has not yet analysed the results, adding: "It has never been tried in the UK and it is disappointing."

Andrew Puddephatt, director of Article 19, which was involved, thinks the market for cold mailing is "fairly exhausted" and says the failure of the scheme is a significant lesson. "Although the idea of a composite mailing was good to reduce costs, with so many charities on one letter, it ended up being quite a dispersed message."

One page of the mailing had a picture from each charity and a description of what £10 could buy, from saving "the life of a homeless animal" to helping to "change the world". The charities varied from household names such as Voluntary Service Overseas to the New Economics Foundation and the Soil Association.

Stephen Lee, senior research fellow in fundraising at South Bank University, isn't surprised at the outcome. "Donors support causes not charities. This approach dilutes the power of an individual cause and diminishes the immediacy of the appeal."

Simon Dowe, development project manager at Children on the Edge, believes the design was part of the problem. "The layout was suspect; it looked like a Reader's Digest prize draw not a charity appeal. I nearly binned it thinking it was just a circular," he said.

His charity, part of the Body Shop Foundation, invested £7,500 and so far has received £4,000 in donations.

Another issue is at whom the appeal was targeted. Mayes says the agency used a range of "lifestyle" lists of people who had given to charities before. However, the opening line of the letter is clearly aimed at people who like to win prizes. "Dear Friend," writes Jon Snow, "Just imagine yourself, one day in a few months from now, walking into your bank and depositing a cheque for £10,000 in hard cash, tax free."

Lee says: "If the message focuses on winning something, people who respond are more interested in the prizes than the charities, and you have to question whether this is the right motivation."

Grace Thompson, head of fundraising at Sign, declines to say how much her charity invested but is disappointed to have raised only £724. "We always knew it was a risk but for small charities like ours recruiting new donors is very expensive." Thompson says in future she would research an idea more thoroughly. "We have had our fingers burned, but hopefully we shouldn't suffer financially."

The driving force behind this joint approach was the high cost of direct marketing and Lee argues that it was an interesting and forward-thinking initiative to tackle the problem of how smaller charities can recruit new donors. "It works in terms of economies of scale, but the diminution of the message is too high a price."

For direct marketing to work, he believes charities need to invest long term, develop their brand and focus on one issue. "At a time when charities are having more success at the other end of the continuum with face-to-face fundraising, small charities should think again about mass market cold mailings," he says.

webTitle: Final whistle for Match of the Day

fields.headline: Final whistle for Match of the Day
fields.trailText: The BBC has lost the right to screen highlights of Premiership matches on Match of the Day.
fields.body:
The BBC has lost the right to screen highlights of Premiership matches on Match of the Day.

The BBC bid £40m for the three-year package from the 2001/2 season onwards while ITV bid £61m, the BBC reported.

At the same time, BSkyB has held on to the rights to broadcast 66 live matches when the existing deal runs out at the end of next season.

And US-based cable giant ntl has won the rights to screen 40 live games on a pay-per-view basis, according to reports.

The winners in the auction of the three packages were announced by Premiership chiefs this evening after they spent the afternoon analysing the sealed bids.

The decision brings to an end the biggest televised soccer shake-up in nearly a decade, and the first of the new millennium.

Three separate Premiership packages were up for grabs, one focusing on highlights and two offering live rights.

Only "free-to-air" terrestrial broadcasters were allowed to bid for the highlights package. One of the packages was the first ever Premiership pay-per-view deal.

All sealed bids had to be submitted by last night and league bosses opened them this lunchtime, before making their decisions on a "highest bidder wins" basis.

The current shape of TV football coverage was largely forged in 1992, when Sky won the right to broadcast Premier League matches live for five years.

A further auction in 1996 saw it retain these, while the BBC kept hold of its right to show edited highlights. Both of these existing arrangements come to an end at the close of the 2000/2001 football season.

While ITV had stopped short of saying it was hoping to launch its own version of Match of the Day, station bosses made no secret of their interest in acquiring the rights to the highlights. The victory will offer them the chance to reunite Des Lynam, who switched from the BBC last year, with a Match of the Day-style format.

Media analysts believe ntl, which has yet to match Sky's UK customer base, will probably have to forge a deal with BSkyB to make its broadcasts viable.

The packages

ITV

ITV have won the right to screen a Saturday evening highlights programme after 7pm and a Sunday night equivalent show, after 9pm. The first can contain edited highlights of three Premier League matches and three-minute clips of others. The latter can include highlights of two matches not shown live that day, plus three-minute excerpts from others.

The highlights package also entitles ITV to show a Saturday morning Premiership preview programme incorporating three-minute clips.

Sky

Sky can show up to 66 games a season (formerly 60), on Sundays and Mondays. They will get the "first pick" of Premiership matches, provided they show at least three per club each season.

ntl

ntl will be able to show up to 40 encrypted live matches a season on Sundays, although they will have "second pick" of fixtures. No more than eight matches from one particular club can be shown per season, and coverage must not clash with that of any live other Premier League match.

webTitle: Leeds schools removed from council control

fields.headline: Leeds schools removed from council control
fields.trailText: The government will today announce the biggest privatisation yet of a failing education authority, when Leeds becomes the latest Labour council to lose control of its school services following a damning inspection report.
fields.body:
The government will today announce the biggest privatisation yet of a failing education authority, when Leeds becomes the latest Labour council to lose control of its school services following a damning inspection report.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, will this afternoon reveal that a joint venture company will take over the £300m service, with local councillors specifically excluded from a five-strong management board.

The move dashes the Yorkshire authority's hopes that a review by accountants PricewaterhouseCooper might have allowed councillors to retain some control.

The need for intervention in Leeds was signalled by ministers in February, following publication of a highly critical report by the Office for Standards in Education, which the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, admitted was "serious and shocking".

School services in Tony Blair's former home borough of Islington were contracted out to the private sector earlier this year in the most significant move to date, but the scale of problems are bigger in Leeds as it is one of the biggest education authorities in England.

In Leeds, continual political interference by Labour councillors was singled out by both the Ofsted report and Mr Woodhead.

Ofsted identified weak leadership in Leeds in the past as the main reason for the "parlous state" of the authority. Leeds council was unable to recruit an education director for four years, it claimed, partly because of perceptions of political interference.

In addition, a catalogue of weaknesses, particularly at secondary school level, included failure to monitor the progress of schools or to support those causing concern.

The new deal will see a management firm selected by Ms Morris from the Department for Education and Employment's approved list, which will join council staff in a radical reform of the service.

The company will appoint two board members who will join two senior Leeds education officers and a chairperson appointed by the education secretary, David Blunkett, from a list of possible candidates submitted by Leeds.

The transfer is expected to be completed next spring and could mean redundancies, although existing Leeds education staff will initially be re-employed.

The city's education director, Keith Burton, who was appointed less than two years and who won praise from Ofsted for "making a start" on reforms, is likely to have a board place.

Last night Leeds was not prepared to comment in advance of the announcement, but the Liberal Democrat opposition accused the council of "throwing away the legacy of 100 years' service to education."

Graham Kirkland, deputy opposition leader, said: "For the past 100 years, local councils have been responsible for the education service and they had built an enviable reputation."

Andrew Carter, leader of the Leeds Conservative group, said that the move was a humiliation but also "a leap in the dark - a huge government experiment with the children of our city."

Ms Morris is expected to make the announcement this afternoon after briefing headteachers and local authority chiefs about the plans. In Leeds, the issue has been a particularly sensitive one with teaching unions, who claim they are victims of a political consipiracy.

The government has now recommended intervention in a total of 15 local education authorities, and has recently extended its list of approved consultants and provicers in anticipation of the need for further action.

Ofsted started statutory inspections of all local authorities in England two-and-a-half years ago as part of Labour's drive to raise school standards, and has now inspected around half of them - 75 in total.

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life!
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: Everyone's still standing, so everyone's still betting. Yesterday's surprise results caused our tipsters a few problems, and the only bet to come in had more than a bit of luck about it. But that's gambling.
fields.body:
Everyone's still standing, so everyone's still betting. Yesterday's surprise results caused our tipsters a few problems, and the only bet to come in had more than a bit of luck about it. But that's gambling.

The standings now look like this:

Scott Murray £69.17
Sean Ingle £60.01

Mike Hodgkinson £48.75

Paul MacInnes £30

Now for today's selections, which all concentrate on tonight's sole game, Belgium v Italy...

Scott Murray

Half-time/Full-time: Belgium/Italy 28/1 (£5)

Although Italy got off to a good start against Turkey, their performance was far from perfect. The Azzuri huffed and puffed for most of the match, let in a sloppy goal and, even when they finally got their act together, ruined most of their good work with profligate finishing.

They should still have too much class for Belgium, mind you, but the hosts will be a tough nut to crack and wouldn't surprise anyone if they continued their good run of form by taking an early lead.

Sean Ingle

Goals scored: 2 or 3 10/11 (£5)

After yesterday's fiasco I'm playing safe. No more extravagant £10 win doubles on Spain and Yugoslavia. And no more of me confidently talking up my predicting prowess either, especially as tonight's game is such a tricky one to call.

Belgium are rightly favourites, because they're at home and have a 3-1 smashing of the Azzuri last November (in Italy as well) still fresh in their minds. But Dino Zoff's men, despite their woeful form of late, are perfectly capable of getting a result too. Neither defence is water-tight, which suggests there will be goals. But neither attack is red-hot either - suggesting there won't be a repeat of last night's six goal Yugoslavia v Slovenia humdinger.

That's why I've put a fiver on two or three goals in tonight's match. That way the likely scores (1-1 or 2-1 to either side) are covered.

Mike Hodgkinson

Italy to lead at half time 2/1 (£10)

Judging by the way the Azzuri started against Turkey, you might presume they've lost their 'sluggish starters' tag for the purposes of this tournament. Presuming Italy will crack into the co-hosts at a lively rate, it may be worth chancing them to head into the break with their noses in front at 2-1, which looks fair enough.

Paul MacInnes

Italy to lead at half-time 2/1 (£4)

Day five and I've already lost it. After watching a game with 0-0 idly scrawled all over it turn into a 1-0 victory for the Vikings, all my faith in probability has disappeared (as well as another £4 from my kitty). All the same, my conservative instincts won't leave me, so I've backed Italy to be leading Belgium at half-time. My well thought out argument for doing so? Italy are usually good, and Belgium are usually rubbish. There you go. I'm going to lie down now.

webTitle: The South Coast dream that quickly went sour

fields.headline: The South Coast dream that quickly went sour
fields.trailText: Hampshire know all about making the news. They warmed up pre-season by attracting the biggest draw in world cricket (and Alan Mullally), then rejoiced when the arrival of Shane Warne coincided with an upturn in the usually stagnant world of county memberships (up 900 to 5000 on last year). But now that the cricket's been under way for a couple of months, Hampshire are really coming into their headline-grabbing own. And for all the wrong reasons.
fields.body:
Hampshire know all about making the news. They warmed up pre-season by attracting the biggest draw in world cricket (and Alan Mullally), then rejoiced when the arrival of Shane Warne coincided with an upturn in the usually stagnant world of county memberships (up 900 to 5000 on last year). But now that the cricket's been under way for a couple of months, Hampshire are really coming into their headline-grabbing own. And for all the wrong reasons.

There's plenty of time left, of course, but Hampshire are currently bottom of both their leagues (division one of the Championship and division two of the National League). Before today, when they take on Durham, they'd lost 11 out of 16 games in all competitions this season, and had won just two (with three draws), one of which was a ten-over slog in a rain-ruined B&H group game. Hampshire Hawks? Hampshire Hamsters might be more appropriate.

The problem has not been so much with the bowling: Warne (22 first-class wickets at 22.57 in a seam-dominated season) is beginning to feel at home, and even in the temporary absence of Mullally (now bowling well again after injury) and Peter Hartley (still out with a calf injury), players like Dimitri Mascarenhas and Simon Francis have chipped in with four-fors.

It's the batting that has fallen woefully short of last year's standards. Going into today's match, Hampshire were yet to top 263 in all cricket, and had only passed 166 once in the one-day game. Worse, they'd been dismissed for less than 150 ten times in 22 innings, and had mustered just three batting bonus points in six Championship games.

The top order is a shambles. Last season Jason Laney, Derek Kenway and Will Kendall all averaged over 40 in the Championship. This season they scored three half-centuries between them in their first 61 innings. And of Laney's 21 knocks, 19 ended before he reached double figures. Even more gruesomely (look away now), John Stephenson, who won a Test cap in 1989, failed to pass 33 in 17 innings, while opener Giles White got to fifty twice out of 22 return trips to the pavilion. No-one, not even Robin Smith (four fifties), made a hundred in any competition. Barry Richards must be turning in his commentary seat.

So what's gone wrong? After all, Hampshire have simply added Mullally and Warne (who replaced Nixon McLean as the overseas player) to a squad that finished seventh in last year's Championship. Yet that may be part of the problem: they could be the first side ever to finish seventh one year and suffer under the burden of expectation the next. When Warne turned up, messiah-like, people really seemed to believe he could work miracles. It could just be that his team-mates have been treading water all season, expecting Warne to walk on it for them. Now they're all struggling to stay afloat.

Then again, maybe Hampshire just played out of their skins last summer and have now found their true level. They have three players (Smith, Warne and Mullally) who would get into any county side, but not much else. Like West Indies, who have survived in recent years thanks to a handy threesome of their own (Brian Lara, Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose), the Hawks are discovering that they need more to feed off.

Whatever the reason, Hampshire are fast becoming the whipping boys of the county circuit. They have finished bottom just once (1980) since the full 17-team Championship began in 1921. Now they might find themselves finishing last twice in one year. Hampshire could be in the news again come the end of September.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous County View, in which he poses a little quiz question, click here

fields.headline: Brainstorming, Bickering and Buying
fields.trailText: IT'S GOOD TO TALK/SHOUT/SLAP
fields.body:
IT'S GOOD TO TALK/SHOUT/SLAP

Kelvin Koogan had a day off today and left "director of technical development" Les Reed to answer all the press's questions for him. This is a fine example of delegation - one of the modern executive's foremost skills (as the Fiver was explaining to its mum the last time it wanted its smalls washed). Delegation at a press conference is one thing however, delegating your team selection quite another.

"Ke[l]vin thinks the players have a contribution to make," said Reed this afternoon in response to suggestions that Koogan and his players rowed over tactics after Monday's defeat. "He thinks it's better to speak to each other rather than keep it to themselves." So does Dennis Wise who, tipped to take a place in England's starting line-up on Saturday, offered his opinion on the post-Portugal "brainstorming session". "The gaffer wanted a few people's opinions, he wanted to have a chat about things," Wise explained. "He took notice, he's that sort of person."

So what were the lessons to be learned from this constructive session? Er, dunno really. "Maybe it was up to us on the pitch to try and sort it out," said Wise, "It's very hard for [Kelvin], when the game is going on, to try and sort things out." However, fellow senior player Paul Ince - do they get any seniorer? - did not share this view. "We were badly outnumbered in midfield", said the supposed midfield anchor. "We were being overrun. Portugal seemed to have extra players wherever you looked." Don't panic!

Ince also told this morning's Mirror that Monday's scenario will not be repeated. Which hopefully means he's about to drop himself, but more likely means that Incey is confident of a change of tactics. But whatever you take from today's interviews, there does not appear to be a consensus within the England camp on how the team should play. And, if all types of opinions are being voiced and, in some cases it seems, being listened to (as Martin Keown put it, "In the main, the manager makes the decisions") is it any wonder that England look lost on the field?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MATTHAUS IN CENTRE OF BIG ROW SHOCK

You've got to feel sorry for Germany coach Erich Ribbeck. His team are useless, he's not very popular and he's pretty sure to be turfed out on his ear come the end of the tournament. So the last thing he needs as he attempts to salvage his battered reputation is for the whole German squad to start bickering like a pair of tanked-up Gallaghers. But that's exactly what they're doing.

At the centre of the row is - surprise! - Lothar Matthaus, whose inept defensive display against Romania was the last straw for team-mates already unhappy at his inclusion in the team. Asked whether the rest of the players wanted Matthaus to be dropped, Oliver Bierhoff replied: "I am loathe to say it here and now. I don't want to say anything here." And having given us one line, the big striker kindly gave us another so we had something to read between: "We will speak to the coach in private and I hope he listens."

Sadly for Ollie and the equally-cross Oliver Kahn, Mehmet Scholl and Jens Nowotny, Ribbeck intends to give his beleaguered sweeper his 149th cap against England. "Lothar is a favourite of mine," the German coach explained, not exactly diffusing the situation. "He admitted he was tired after the Romania game but we showed weaknesses that can't be explained just by age and lack of condition." So Germany are going to field an unpopular, knackered old man alongside ten piqued and angry individuals... it's going to be really annoying when they win, isn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Instead of joining his mates in camp in Lagos, Kanu has been parading himself in Abuja, promoting his heart foundation programme. This is not how to be patriotic" - Dominic Oneya, chairman of the Nigerian FA, rails at his star striker. Too right mate, and while you're at it, why don't you sort out that bloody Jimmy Saville?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IN SUTTON DEMAND

Last season he huffed, puffed and generally fluffed his way to a grand tally of three goals - the last of which came against Hull. By common consent he was "the worst buy since President Kennedy's convertible", and he romped away with the Fiver's worst player of the season award. It's Chelsea's of Chelsea striker Chris Sutton, he's priced at £7m, and, ladies and gentlemen, you'd have to be stark raving bonkers to buy him.

"Hello, John Gregory here. Can I buy Chris Sutton please?" That was roughly what the Aston Villa manager told Kuddly Ken Bates last week. "I'll give you £7m cash, or you can have a straight swap deal with Gareth Southgate. Do we have a deal?" Which makes sense, apart from the bit about the sulky goal-shy flop costing the same as the all-round good egg and England international.

But needs must etc., and Villa are losing players faster than Vanessa Feltz is losing pounds at the moment. Gregory has also enquired about signing Tore Andre Flo as part of any Southgate deal, but the intelligent Norwegian has shown no desire to join a sinking ship. Or move to Birmingham. "I think Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's arrival will make it harder for me to get in," Flo admitted last night, "but I am going to stay and fight for my place." Then he explained why: "I think they might sell somebody else." Lucky John eh?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Juan Veron's agent is in talks with Lazio over the Argentine midfielder's future. Today's La Stampa newspaper claims Veron wants to leave Rome and that Manchester United is his preferred destination. It is, however, more likely that Veron will sign a new contract with the champions of Serie A.

Arsenal and Chelsea have both been linked with a move to sign Roberto Baggio on a free transfer. As ever, the main stumbling block appears to be Baggio's wage demands, thought to be somewhere in the region of £50,000-a-week.

Coventry are tipped to make a £3m bid for Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson, and it's a move the Swedish international would welcome. "Coventry sounds interesting to me," he said today. "They made some good signings last season, like Hadji and Chippo, and above all they play in the Premier League - that's where I want to play."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Paolo Maldini has recovered from a calf injury picked up in training and will play against Belgium tonight.

Steven Gerrard sat out of England's training session this afternoon, but he is still expected to be fit for selection for the Germany game.

Dominic Matteo has decided to play international football for Scotland. The Dumfries-born defender has never played a competitive international for England and is eligible to switch allegiances. "I am absolutely delighted that we can name Dominic in our squad for the opening World Cup qualifier against Latvia. This is a major coup and a great boost for us," admitted Craig Brown.

Airdrie have been ordered to release 27 players six weeks before the start of the season. Only Eddie Forrest, Alex Neil and Austin McCann have escaped the massive clear-out, although manager Gary Mackay's job is also safe. Provisional liquidators KPMG cite "unsustainable costs" and losses running at £10,000-per-week as the reason behind the job cuts.

Danny Wilson will have further talks with Bristol City this week over the vacant managerial position at Ashton Gate.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

fields.bodyText: IT'S GOOD TO TALK/SHOUT/SLAP Kelvin Koogan had a day off today and left "director of technical development" Les Reed to answer all the press's questions for him. This is a fine example of delegation - one of the modern executive's foremost skills (as the Fiver was explaining to its mum the last time it wanted its smalls washed). Delegation at a press conference is one thing however, delegating your team selection quite another. "Ke[l]vin thinks the players have a contribution to make," said Reed this afternoon in response to suggestions that Koogan and his players rowed over tactics after Monday's defeat. "He thinks it's better to speak to each other rather than keep it to themselves." So does Dennis Wise who, tipped to take a place in England's starting line-up on Saturday, offered his opinion on the post-Portugal "brainstorming session". "The gaffer wanted a few people's opinions, he wanted to have a chat about things," Wise explained. "He took notice, he's that sort of person." So what were the lessons to be learned from this constructive session? Er, dunno really. "Maybe it was up to us on the pitch to try and sort it out," said Wise, "It's very hard for [Kelvin], when the game is going on, to try and sort things out." However, fellow senior player Paul Ince - do they get any seniorer? - did not share this view. "We were badly outnumbered in midfield", said the supposed midfield anchor. "We were being overrun. Portugal seemed to have extra players wherever you looked." Don't panic! Ince also told this morning's Mirror that Monday's scenario will not be repeated. Which hopefully means he's about to drop himself, but more likely means that Incey is confident of a change of tactics. But whatever you take from today's interviews, there does not appear to be a consensus within the England camp on how the team should play. And, if all types of opinions are being voiced and, in some cases it seems, being listened to (as Martin Keown put it, "In the main, the manager makes the decisions") is it any wonder that England look lost on the field? * * * * * * * * * * * * * MATTHAUS IN CENTRE OF BIG ROW SHOCK You've got to feel sorry for Germany coach Erich Ribbeck. His team are useless, he's not very popular and he's pretty sure to be turfed out on his ear come the end of the tournament. So the last thing he needs as he attempts to salvage his battered reputation is for the whole German squad to start bickering like a pair of tanked-up Gallaghers. But that's exactly what they're doing. At the centre of the row is - surprise! - Lothar Matthaus, whose inept defensive display against Romania was the last straw for team-mates already unhappy at his inclusion in the team. Asked whether the rest of the players wanted Matthaus to be dropped, Oliver Bierhoff replied: "I am loathe to say it here and now. I don't want to say anything here." And having given us one line, the big striker kindly gave us another so we had something to read between: "We will speak to the coach in private and I hope he listens." Sadly for Ollie and the equally-cross Oliver Kahn, Mehmet Scholl and Jens Nowotny, Ribbeck intends to give his beleaguered sweeper his 149th cap against England. "Lothar is a favourite of mine," the German coach explained, not exactly diffusing the situation. "He admitted he was tired after the Romania game but we showed weaknesses that can't be explained just by age and lack of condition." So Germany are going to field an unpopular, knackered old man alongside ten piqued and angry individuals... it's going to be really annoying when they win, isn't it? * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "Instead of joining his mates in camp in Lagos, Kanu has been parading himself in Abuja, promoting his heart foundation programme. This is not how to be patriotic" - Dominic Oneya, chairman of the Nigerian FA, rails at his star striker. Too right mate, and while you're at it, why don't you sort out that bloody Jimmy Saville? * * * * * * * * * * * * * IN SUTTON DEMAND Last season he huffed, puffed and generally fluffed his way to a grand tally of three goals - the last of which came against Hull. By common consent he was "the worst buy since President Kennedy's convertible", and he romped away with the Fiver's worst player of the season award. It's Chelsea's of Chelsea striker Chris Sutton, he's priced at £7m, and, ladies and gentlemen, you'd have to be stark raving bonkers to buy him. "Hello, John Gregory here. Can I buy Chris Sutton please?" That was roughly what the Aston Villa manager told Kuddly Ken Bates last week. "I'll give you £7m cash, or you can have a straight swap deal with Gareth Southgate. Do we have a deal?" Which makes sense, apart from the bit about the sulky goal-shy flop costing the same as the all-round good egg and England international. But needs must etc., and Villa are losing players faster than Vanessa Feltz is losing pounds at the moment. Gregory has also enquired about signing Tore Andre Flo as part of any Southgate deal, but the intelligent Norwegian has shown no desire to join a sinking ship. Or move to Birmingham. "I think Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's arrival will make it harder for me to get in," Flo admitted last night, "but I am going to stay and fight for my place." Then he explained why: "I think they might sell somebody else." Lucky John eh? * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Juan Veron's agent is in talks with Lazio over the Argentine midfielder's future. Today's La Stampa newspaper claims Veron wants to leave Rome and that Manchester United is his preferred destination. It is, however, more likely that Veron will sign a new contract with the champions of Serie A. Arsenal and Chelsea have both been linked with a move to sign Roberto Baggio on a free transfer. As ever, the main stumbling block appears to be Baggio's wage demands, thought to be somewhere in the region of £50,000-a-week. Coventry are tipped to make a £3m bid for Sheffield Wednesday's Niclas Alexandersson, and it's a move the Swedish international would welcome. "Coventry sounds interesting to me," he said today. "They made some good signings last season, like Hadji and Chippo, and above all they play in the Premier League - that's where I want to play." * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Paolo Maldini has recovered from a calf injury picked up in training and will play against Belgium tonight. Steven Gerrard sat out of England's training session this afternoon, but he is still expected to be fit for selection for the Germany game. Dominic Matteo has decided to play international football for Scotland. The Dumfries-born defender has never played a competitive international for England and is eligible to switch allegiances. "I am absolutely delighted that we can name Dominic in our squad for the opening World Cup qualifier against Latvia. This is a major coup and a great boost for us," admitted Craig Brown. Airdrie have been ordered to release 27 players six weeks before the start of the season. Only Eddie Forrest, Alex Neil and Austin McCann have escaped the massive clear-out, although manager Gary Mackay's job is also safe. Provisional liquidators KPMG cite "unsustainable costs" and losses running at £10,000-per-week as the reason behind the job cuts. Danny Wilson will have further talks with Bristol City this week over the vacant managerial position at Ashton Gate. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO BBC1: Match of the Day Live (7.30pm, 1am) Belgium v Italy. fields.headline: Greenspan applauds technology
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The increase in productivity generated by the internet and other technological advances is improving the US economy, the chairman of the Federal Reserve said yesterday.
fields.body:
The increase in productivity generated by the internet and other technological advances is improving the US economy, the chairman of the Federal Reserve said yesterday.

In a speech to the New York Association for Business Economics, Alan Greenspan said the advances were structural rather than cyclical and therefore likely to be sustained.

He said the gains in productivity were "largely driven by irreversible advances in technology and it's application - irreversible in the sense that knowledge once gained is almost never lost". The most basic result of companies adopting new technology was significant changes to the way goods and services are produced so that workers needed fewer hours to complete their tasks.

But Mr Greenspan said this had not led to a rise in unemployment because the "vibrant economy" meant that "labour resources freed up by technological advance have found ready opportunities elsewhere".

webTitle: Historic deal at North-South Korea summit

fields.headline: Historic deal at North-South Korea summit
fields.trailText: The leaders of North Korea and South Korea signed an agreement at their historic summit today to work toward reuniting thousands of families who were separated by the Korean war, to provide desperately needed South Korean investment for the North's failing economy, and eventually to reunify the peninsula.
fields.body:
The leaders of North Korea and South Korea signed an agreement at their historic summit today to work toward reuniting thousands of families who were separated by the Korean war, to provide desperately needed South Korean investment for the North's failing economy, and eventually to reunify the peninsula.

However, the agreement aimed at easing half a century of tension on the Korean Peninsula made no mention of two big concerns: the North's long-standing demand that the United States withdraw its 37,000 troops from South Korea and Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programmes.

Reunificiation itself is an enormous task that some observers say could take decades, even if the accord is carried out by both countries.

After the late-night signing in Pyongyang, the North's capital, President Kim Dae-Jung of South Korea and the North's leader, Kim Jong Il, smiled broadly, shook each other's hand vigorously and toasted each other with glasses of champagne.

Kim Dae-Jung praised his counterpart for helping him reach a "historic agreement" and said the two of them must "proceed together on a path of reconciliation and cooperation."

The surprising warmth and good humour of the first two days of the summit transformed the realities of half a century of cold war tensions and marked the end of an era marked by acute tension .

Earlier the North Korean leader, who has stunned observers by his openness, questioned his portrayal as a villain by the west. The United States has long described his heavily armed country as a dangerous, rogue nation.

"I have visited China and Indonesia in the past, and also made many unofficial visits overseas. So I don't understand why I was described as reclusive," Kim Jong-il said at the summit in the North Korean capital Pyongyang. Western news reports say President Kim's visit helped me out of seclusion," he added, causing his counterpart and the other North and South Korean officials sitting at the conference table to explode in laughter, as South Korean television cameras sent his comments around the world.

The two leaders had discussed a range of issues. These included reopening roads and railways across the heavily armed border, reuniting tens of thousands of Korean families separated during the Korean war and creating a telephone hotline for discussions during crises.

The peninsula's rail and road lines were closed around 1948, when the two Koreas formed their own governments and sealed their border. After the 1950-53 Korean war ended, the two sides turned the border into the most heavily armed one in the world.

By reopening these routes, the two countries could promote trade and business deals that are desperately needed by the North's ailing economy and eventually reunite many Korean families.

Since the 1990s, North Korea has been dependent on food aid from its traditional foes: South Korea, Japan and the US. Desperation for economic aid is believed to be a major factor in driving the North to agree to the summit.

Despite repeated warnings by Seoul officials not to expect too much from the talks, the unexpectedly warm welcome for the South Korean leader led to speculation that the North may finally be willing to shed its self-imposed isolation, or even to follow the lead of China in beginning to opening up its economy to global capitalism.

Fifty South Korean journalists were allowed to travel to Pyongyang for the summit and were providing the only information available to hundreds of foreign journalists who were restricted to covering the meetings from Seoul.

The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, saluted "the vision and wisdom" of the two leaders in opening the historic dialogue.

fields.headline: Dark rumours surround Chinook crash
fields.standfirst: Conspiracy theories abound about the crash which killed 25 top security personnel says Observer Northern Ireland correspondentJohn O'Farrell
fields.trailText:
Conspiracy theories abound about the crash which killed 25 top security personnel says Observer Northern Ireland correspondent John O'Farrell

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.body:
The conflict in Northern Ireland has left many mysteries in its wake.

The reopened probe into the 1989 murder of nationalist solicitor Pat Finucane and the new inquiry into Bloody Sunday in 1972 are the successful minority of a host of demanded new investigations.

The remaining issues which have yet to be satisfactorily resolved attract conspiracy theories, which grow in proportion to the silence of the state.

Today saw the government rejecting claims of malfeasance on its part.

The Secretary of State Peter Mandelson denounced as a hoax a letter displayed yesterday by the DUP's Ian Paisley Jnr which purported to come from Mandelson's office, advising First Minister David Trimble to keep quiet about the murder last month of Edmund McCoy.

The IRA is accused of involvement in the killing, and the "hoax" letter suggests playing down its involvement for the good of the peace process. Mandelson accused Paisley Jnr of bringing "politics and, I am afraid, your party to a new low".

Another candidate for the conspiracy industry is the Chinook helicopter crash into the Mull of Kintyre in June 1994. The Ministry of Defence inquiry into the crash, which killed 25 top security personnel and four RAF crew, blamed the pilots for "breaching safe flying rules".

This line was reiterated this morning by the armed forces minister John Spellar, after the most senior Scottish law officer questioned the MoD verdict.

Lord Advocate Colin Boyd QC said in a letter to an MSP that evidence about the reliability of the Chinook's computerised control system, FADEC, "reinforced" concerns about the crash. Lord Boyd did not, however, propose reopening the inquiry.

The calls for a new inquiry have mainly come from the families of the two blamed pilots, who had unblemished records before the crash. They believe that "the government would rather protect the elite within the MoD than to protect natural justice".

The allegation is that the MoD spent a fortune on a bad system, were warned against it in advance by colleagues in the USAF, but went ahead with the deal anyway. Any alleged cover-up is to save face, rather than anything darker.

webTitle: But I don't have a prostate gland...

fields.headline: But I don't have a prostate gland...
fields.trailText: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
I 'm using contraceptives and trying to get pregnant. We're all for rooting for the sight of that little blue line, but it mustn't appear until I'm medically prepared for it. What once my body did naturally, now the drugs I'm taking strive to imitate. My natural menstrual cycle must be suppressed. A drug-induced cycle has to take over. I must only conceive under strictly controlled conditions.

Welcome to the topsy-turvy world of infertility. In this strange place, at the same time as trying doggedly to have a child, you mustn't have unprotected, non-interventionist, unproblematic, natural sex. Which, of course, is exactly the sort of sex everyone, if only they admitted it, wants to have.

None of us likes contraceptives. I can't think of a single person who claims a condom or cap enhances sex. Yet it's considered prudish to confess to gaining physical pleasure from the faint promise of procreation. The presumption is that you're some kind of lapsed Catholic. The creed that coupling is simply for sensual satisfaction rather than conception is now widely held. But, although it's very unfashionable to say so, there is something special about having the sort of sex which may, possibly, lead to the creation of another human life. It has an extra edge, a whiff of danger even, certainly a soupçon of loss of control, which can be at the heart of wild, unfettered passion.

But unfettered passion isn't on my personal Action Plan, which the Assisted Conception Unit issued me. The first item on this timetable is Buserelin, a sex hormone- reducing drug I have to sniff four times a day. It stops me ovulating. From the moment I start sniffing Buserelin, nothing is natural.

The leaflet inside the Buserelin box, sold as Suprefact nasal spray, is not that helpful. Under "Why use Suprefact?" it gives only one reason: "to treat cancer of the prostate gland". I, of course, have no prostate gland. Under things to tell your doctor, it lists: "if you have had your testes surgically removed". Well, not surgically. I was just born that way. Interestingly, it also warns you to advise your GP if you think you may be pregnant. As a result of having your testes removed, I wonder? Anyway, at least I now know if I ever put myself through this IVF thing again, I needn't be so embarrassed when picking the carrier bags of drugs up from the pharmacist. "That's for my prostate cancer, " I shall say, proud and loud.

It's strange. Although the sales of this drug must have soared once it was adopted for standard IVF treatment, women's needs still aren't addressed in the instructions. How many of us have to take it before we are written into the medical textbooks? Does nobody know we're taking this stuff by the nose load?

Medicine may be a male world, yet IVF is always a woman's problem. Of course, in my case, it literally is - it is my genetic chromosomal condition which causes frequent miscarriages. Yet it still seems unfair that, while I am denied the joy of sex, it is mandatory that my boyfriend masturbate: if any sperm hang around too long, they die. The consultant told us the male partner must ejaculate every two to three days. ("So it's official," quipped my boyfriend. "Tantric sex is bad for you.")

Even when it is the male partner's problem that brings you to the clinic - through sluggish sperm, low sperm count or inexplicable infertility - it's the woman who must go through a battery of tests, have her blood taken as if in competition to be the world's largest donor, have dye injected into her womb, her legs put in stirrups once a week at least, and more scans of her inside than ever she had holiday snaps.

My boyfriend just had to have a blood test and produce a "sample" which, the embryologist assured, "we have facilities for". These facilities turned out to be a cupboard-sized room containing a handful of well-worn and very soft-porn magazines. My boyfriend suggested they get something a bit better. The doctor was apologetic. "Whatever we put in there gets stolen," he said. But who cares what the medical students get up to - that's my boyfriend's job done.

Meanwhile, I start to sniff Buserelin four times a day. I keep it by the bathroom sink. There's my toothbrush, toothpaste, almond oil moisturiser, earring collection, and the small brown bottle of Suprefact nasal spray. For a couple of days it sat awkwardly amongst these ordinary objects; now I hardly notice it. It fits in all too easily. Infertility has become part of my everyday routine.

But there are some things you cannot change so easily, some everyday dreams that won't die. So, secretly, we keep shagging, savouring the faint hope of fecund sex.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Dissatisfaction with parents peaks at 13, a survey of teenagers revealed this week. So what can parents do?
fields.trailText: The Question: Dissatisfaction with parents peaks at 13, a survey of teenagers revealed this week. So what can parents do?
fields.body:
Mary MacLeod
Director of the National Family and Parenting Institute

I've got a 13-year-old son and a 15-year-old daughter, so I speak from experience on this one! Young people are doing things earlier now than they did in our day, which is one reason for friction. At 13 they start to get a bit serious about life, and realise they've got exams to get through and choices to make. Their relationships with their peers become more unstable, which has a knock-on effect within the family. And they develop tastes that seem alien to their parents - in my case, a son who's into heavy metal. What should we do? Try to understand; keep calm; and keep talking to them.

 Verdict: Try to understand

Wendy Elms
Mother of four children aged 16, 13, 12 and nine

Thirteen is the age when they suddenly want independence, they want to go places and do things on their own. And it's a shock for parents - one day you know where they are, who they're with, what they're doing; the next day they want to do their own thing. Your instinct is to want to hold on to the old days. I guess at least 50% of the problem is that parents are learning about teenagers. My advice: don't just say "no" to everything they want to do, listen to them, and think about what they've got to say. Don't panic or think everything is going out of your grasp.

 Verdict: Listen to them

Clare Mansfield
13-year-old schoolgirl from London

I would have thought things get more difficult as you get older, but I'm not there yet. I do feel more grown-up: being 13 is very different from being 12. If there are problems, I think a lot of it is to do with parents being too cautious. You're getting into your teens, you want more space - some parents seem to go over the top in saying no. I think they want to keep us as their little girls and boys; they're as scared for themselves as for us. But me and my friends aren't into drink and drugs; we're mostly into buying clothes, and money is a big issue. That's one of the main problems.

 Verdict: Don't be too cautious

Julia Cole
Counsellor and mother of two kids, aged 19 and 15

Thirteen is a transition: hormones are kicking in and your child is growing up physically and wanting independence. And while they are struggling to make sense of all this, you're suddenly faced with someone quite different as your offspring. Of course they're still the same person inside - but there's a sense in which they have become a stranger. You have to come to terms with that. If it's your eldest child, you're learning, too, how to parent a teenager. What helps? I think trying to remember what you were like at 13: we've all been there, even if the pressures were different for us.

 Verdict: Remember being 13

Dirk Flower
Psychologist working with young people and their families

I think there are three reasons why 13 is a crunch age. First, they're becoming group-focused, rather than family-focused: they value their friends' views more than their parents'. Second, adolescence happens to them earlier than it did to their parents, which is another source of conflict. Third, families are under stress: by the time children are adolescents parents are busy, and maybe not around a lot of the time. Parents should try to spend time with their children at this stage. They should also try to build up trust with their teenager, by talking and listening to them.

 Verdict: Make time for them

Hereward Harrison
Spokesman for ChildLine, the national helpline

The peak age for calls to ChildLine is 13 for girls, 14 for boys - and we know that girls mature slightly earlier. They're going through so much: girls are starting their periods, boys are having wet dreams. Sometimes they don't know what it's all about, they haven't been told what to expect. The body is pushing the mind. Everything is changing for them. I think parents have to acknowledge what's happening by talking to their teenagers: talk about what's going on, make sure they understand. Make clear boundaries: teenagers like clarity. Sometimes you've got to say no.

 Verdict: Talk to them

fields.headline: In search of New Dad
fields.standfirst: Doting dad, deadbeat dad, five-minutes-a-day dad - as Father's Day approaches,  Dave Hill  asks which is the most accurate image of modern fatherhood.
fields.trailText: Doting dad, deadbeat dad, five-minutes-a-day dad - as Father's Day approaches, Dave Hill asks which is the most accurate image of modern fatherhood.
fields.body:
Big question: is this a grim age of fatherhood, or a golden one? Are dads with dependent children better at being parents than their own dads were, or are they getting worse? You could be forgiven for believing either is the case - or both. On the bright side, displays of paternal devotion have become ubiquitous, from the endless images in the 80s of New Men and their newborns, to their crescendo in recent weeks with David Beckham parading his little boy alongside his winner's medal. Oh yes: and the prime minister spent a fortnight at the cotside of young Leo.

But if such scenes seem to signify a fatherhood renaissance, another version of what's happening is less cheering. The "deadbeat dad" who leaves his family in the financial lurch has outstripped the teenage single mother as the folk devil of family life. And he is but one manifestation of a more generalised disquiet over men's failures in departments in which their own dads were rarely required to succeed: "being there" emotionally and dealing with the parts of parenting that are a grind rather than a romp.

What, then, is the true story of fatherhood today? In lots of ways it is one of uncertainties - those of fathers themselves and those of mothers and children about what fathers are and ought to be. The unsatisfactory but developing body of sociological data on fathers today bears this out. Charlie Lewis, professor of psychology at Lancaster University, has produced a digest of 21 recent survey findings relevant to fathers, for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. In his introduction, he notes the "continuing confusion over the part men actually play in today's families, and a lack of consensus about their potential role in child-rearing".

The explanation for this is to some extent straightforward: it is simply that fathers vary. Indeed, over the past 30 years of rapid family change, they have become so varied that broad generalisations are treacherous.

This is vital to keep in mind given the current preoccupation with paternal desertion. While substantial numbers of fathers do lose touch with their children after a relationship ends, most maintain contact - and a vast majority live in the same household as their children. And when we look a little deeper at how modern fathers go about being parents, it becomes plain that we are living through a social revolution with the potential to be glorious.

It is a staple of "sex war" journalism that nappy-changing, dinner-cooking New Dad is a myth. It is true that, in most two-parent families, men do continue to be the ones who earn most, if not all, the money, while mothers take on the bigger share of childcare and other domestic responsibilities - but in households in which both parents do paid work, these things are commonly reported to be equally shared. There is also a substantial minority of households in which fathers are the main carers, with mothers going out to earn.

What's more, men have become more available to their children when they're not at work, being more closely involved and spending more time with them. Revealingly, the most pronounced shift in parenting from mothers to fathers is taking place not among the trendy, liberal middle classes but among families in which the men are unemployed or working part-time. The affluent may talk the talk, but it's the working man who is more likely to walk the walk.

Such trends buttress optimists' belief that a New Dad figure is slowly emerging, one who may replace the "traditional" template for fatherhood of male breadwinner and distant disciplinarian with something more rounded, more emotionally available and generally more involved . But while evidence of such a change is mounting, it is plain that the transition is far from complete or painless. When men today are asked how they feel about being dads, they routinely tell researchers they'd like to "be there" for their children physically and spiritually in ways their own fathers often failed to do. Yet many still don't do it and many who are actively involved with their children say they are unhappy with their situations.

Culture, not biology, holds the key to this discrepancy. Lewis notes that "men who work long hours and share childcare with their partners are more likely than others to report feeling stressed and dissatisfied with their lives". In other words, "having it all" can be a problem for fathers too.

There is also the little matter of a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do. "Despite the increasingly 'hands-on' reality of fathering for many men," Lewis writes, "cultural stereotypes of fathers as 'providers' and 'breadwinners' continue to exert a strong influence over men, women and children's attitudes to parenthood." Perhaps this in part explains why, even though parents in dual-income families often say childcare is shared, it is rare for the fathers to describe themselves as the main carer or for the mothers to describe themselves as providers. Men are aware that more is expected of them as parents these days, yet they still see their principal duty as bringing home the bacon and still often regard themselves as less well-equipped for childcare than women are. What's more, mothers and children often agree.

Conservatives insist this proves the need for family roles to be re-configured along "traditional" lines. Yet when fathers raise children without mothers, whether due to bereavement or family breakdown, they frequently learn that, breastfeeding aside, there is no kind of nurturing they can't do, and once bound to their children in the ways mothers are, they don't want to be "free" of them again. This suggests that what fathers and families need most urgently is not a return to the past but to be given the kind of cultural permission and practical support for the beautiful, bruising task of parenting that mothers have bestowed on them by virtue of their sex. Can this be achieved? Will men - and women - organise to achieve it?

There is a long way to go. So much public debate about fathers has focused on custody and maintenance, with fathers represented by "fathers rights" militants bewailing judges and "feminazis". While the workings of the system certainly gives cause for concern, the wider effect has been to render the whole territory of fatherhood reform toxic to activists of wider vision and goodwill. Adrienne Burgess, author of Fatherhood Reclaimed (Vermilion), points out: "The good dads/bad dads dichotomy . . . results, in part, from the invisibility of fathering. The only time we find out what they do is when we find out what they don't do, such as pay child support, or when they abuse someone."

Happily, this imbalance is beginning to be corrected. Fathers Direct, the information and lobbying organisation for dads, now has the ear of the government, which has backed small but important schemes to foster active fathering among men. Of course, there's a bit more to be done before Britain catches up with Sweden, which has its own minister for the family and regards male parents as equally important as female ones.

Still, let's look on the bright side. Maybe Leo will wake our PM up in more ways than one.

The facts

 Seven out of 10 families consist of children living with both parents.
 70% of non-resident fathers have some contact with their children; almost 50% see their kids every week.
 66% of women working full-time and 48% of women working part-time say childcare is equally shared.
 58% of fathers with few or no academic qualifications say they take equal share of childcare, compared with 35% of those with degrees.
 More than 25% of fathers work more than 50 hours a week. Fathers of teenagers particularly resent this.
 Fathers who work full-time are more likely to define parenting in "traditional" terms, eg disciplining children.
 53% of fathers and 42% of mothers believe that a father's role is to "provide".
 Most unemployed fathers who do the childcare regard themselves as "failed providers" rather than successful child carers.

 Fathers Direct is on: 020-7920 9491. Charlie Lewis's summary of fatherhood data can be found at www.jrf.org.uk/
