Revealingly, the most pronounced shift in parenting from mothers to fathers is taking place not among the trendy, liberal middle classes but among families in which the men are unemployed or working part-time. The affluent may talk the talk, but it's the working man who is more likely to walk the walk. Such trends buttress optimists' belief that a New Dad figure is slowly emerging, one who may replace the "traditional" template for fatherhood of male breadwinner and distant disciplinarian with something more rounded, more emotionally available and generally more involved . But while evidence of such a change is mounting, it is plain that the transition is far from complete or painless. When men today are asked how they feel about being dads, they routinely tell researchers they'd like to "be there" for their children physically and spiritually in ways their own fathers often failed to do. Yet many still don't do it and many who are actively involved with their children say they are unhappy with their situations. Culture, not biology, holds the key to this discrepancy. Lewis notes that "men who work long hours and share childcare with their partners are more likely than others to report feeling stressed and dissatisfied with their lives". In other words, "having it all" can be a problem for fathers too. There is also the little matter of a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do. "Despite the increasingly 'hands-on' reality of fathering for many men," Lewis writes, "cultural stereotypes of fathers as 'providers' and 'breadwinners' continue to exert a strong influence over men, women and children's attitudes to parenthood." Perhaps this in part explains why, even though parents in dual-income families often say childcare is shared, it is rare for the fathers to describe themselves as the main carer or for the mothers to describe themselves as providers. Men are aware that more is expected of them as parents these days, yet they still see their principal duty as bringing home the bacon and still often regard themselves as less well-equipped for childcare than women are. What's more, mothers and children often agree. Conservatives insist this proves the need for family roles to be re-configured along "traditional" lines. Yet when fathers raise children without mothers, whether due to bereavement or family breakdown, they frequently learn that, breastfeeding aside, there is no kind of nurturing they can't do, and once bound to their children in the ways mothers are, they don't want to be "free" of them again. This suggests that what fathers and families need most urgently is not a return to the past but to be given the kind of cultural permission and practical support for the beautiful, bruising task of parenting that mothers have bestowed on them by virtue of their sex. Can this be achieved? Will men - and women - organise to achieve it? There is a long way to go. So much public debate about fathers has focused on custody and maintenance, with fathers represented by "fathers rights" militants bewailing judges and "feminazis". While the workings of the system certainly gives cause for concern, the wider effect has been to render the whole territory of fatherhood reform toxic to activists of wider vision and goodwill. Adrienne Burgess, author of Fatherhood Reclaimed (Vermilion), points out: "The good dads/bad dads dichotomy . . . results, in part, from the invisibility of fathering. The only time we find out what they do is when we find out what they don't do, such as pay child support, or when they abuse someone." Happily, this imbalance is beginning to be corrected. Fathers Direct, the information and lobbying organisation for dads, now has the ear of the government, which has backed small but important schemes to foster active fathering among men. Of course, there's a bit more to be done before Britain catches up with Sweden, which has its own minister for the family and regards male parents as equally important as female ones. Still, let's look on the bright side. Maybe Leo will wake our PM up in more ways than one. The facts  Seven out of 10 families consist of children living with both parents.  70% of non-resident fathers have some contact with their children; almost 50% see their kids every week.  66% of women working full-time and 48% of women working part-time say childcare is equally shared.  58% of fathers with few or no academic qualifications say they take equal share of childcare, compared with 35% of those with degrees.  More than 25% of fathers work more than 50 hours a week. Fathers of teenagers particularly resent this.  Fathers who work full-time are more likely to define parenting in "traditional" terms, eg disciplining children.  53% of fathers and 42% of mothers believe that a father's role is to "provide".  Most unemployed fathers who do the childcare regard themselves as "failed providers" rather than successful child carers.  Fathers Direct is on: 020-7920 9491. Charlie Lewis's summary of fatherhood data can be found at www.jrf.org.uk/

fields.headline: Bye bye, bedtime
fields.standfirst: According to leading sleep researchers, children aren't getting enough of it. So why do parents find 'Goodnight' so hard to say?  Yvonne Roberts reports
fields.trailText: According to leading sleep researchers, children aren't getting enough of it. So why do parents find 'Goodnight' so hard to say? Yvonne Roberts reports
fields.body:
A toddler screams in the supermarket trolley. His mother, embarrassed, exhausted and fearful that she will be accused of committing that most cardinal of parental sins, raising a spoilt brat, slaps his legs and tells him: "You're a very naughty boy."

"What that lad needs," a pensioner pipes up, "is a good night's sleep."

Once, it was simple: children were seen and not heard and in bed by six. And now? We all know the young require a proper dose of sleep and yet, according to a study in this month's Journal of Sleep Research, children are suffering an "epidemic of sleeplessness" which is damaging their performance at school as well as undermining their relationships. According to the author, Anne Meijer, one in four children aged between nine and 14 did not feel rested and 15% had sleep problems. She concluded: "Children who feel better rested display a more positive self-image, have more control over their aggressive behaviour, are less bored and are more receptive to their teacher."

The study was conducted on Dutch children but similar levels of sleep deprivation are emerging here. Professor Gregory Stores, head of research into child sleep disorders at Oxford University, says: "Sleep disturbance is very common among young children. It is an epidemic."

Very young children, he says, need 12 hours a night. By the time they are nine, 10 hours might be enough (this depends on how active the child is; boys, he says, tend to need more). If they regularly don't get enough, he warns, they will become irritable, depressed, inattentive, disruptive and hyperactive. In extreme cases, they may even be incorrectly diagnosed as having Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder.

Hetty Einzig of the Parenting Forum says sleep deprivation impacts on concentration levels and "also leads to physical and then emotional depression in childhood as well as ill health. Instead of administering drugs we should first be advocating an extra hour of sleep each night."

So why are we allowing our children to be become so dog-tired? Bedtime was once supported by a consensus: "Early to bed, early to rise, makes a child healthy, wealthy and wise." Observer photographer Jane Bown has grown-up children but throughout their childhood she says she happily put them to bed at 6pm; good for them, and good for me, she has explained. Now, the nine o'clock watershed is the only reminder that, by then, children are expected to be safely upstairs.

In the playground, says Professor Jim Horne, director of the sleep research laboratory at Loughborough University, children vie to see who goes to bed the latest. "If you say you've stayed up beyond 10pm, that conveys bravado." His own children, aged 11 and 13, go to bed at nine "at the outside . . . and not without a struggle."

Christina Hughes-Onslow has four children. The seven-year-old goes to bed at seven; the nine-year-old at 7.30pm; the 10-year-old goes an hour later and the 15-year-old chooses his own time. "I'm regarded as pretty draconian and strict among friends," she says. "But my children have a choice: go to bed at the allotted time or watch me go apoplectic. It's not just for their sake, but it's also because I need time on my own, too."

The delayed bedtime is also related to the rise of the dual-income family. Horne points out that parents not only come home late, their arrival injects excitement at precisely the time a child should be winding down. Common sense says leave the office earlier or pack up full-time work, but often necessity dictates otherwise.

Pamela is the divorced mother of four children, aged six to 16. She is the sole breadwinner. Initially, she attempted to stagger bedtimes but she ended up permanently on the go and irritable, with no time to herself. Now, they all go to bed at 10pm; everyone spends time as a family and the smaller ones show no undue signs of weariness. "It's the best I can do in the circumstances," Pamela points out. "For all our sakes."

The cause of inadequate sleep can vary throughout childhood, Stores says. Apart from their parents' longer working hours, he pinpoints the transformation of children's bedrooms into technological wonderlands; apnoea or other breathing problems; or, for teenagers, the pressure to study long and late for school with sleep disrupted by anxiety-driven nightmares.

As important as the hours children sleep, however, is also the preparation that comes before the light is switched off. "From a very early age, children need a consistent system of events, a countdown period which leads to bed," Stores advises. "If no two evenings are the same, if a night is marked by say, a dramatic video, it doesn't help."

So how can we prevent life turning into a zombie zone for adults and children alike? Some private schools issue guidelines, suggesting appropriate bed times; Mary Macleod of the National Family and Parenting Institute was once called into a school to act as a facilitator for parents, so that they could all reach an agreement on bedtimes for children according to age. "They then had a platform from which to argue together when their children put on the pressure," she says.

A child's sleeping patterns should also become a higher profile public health issue - one of the first queries for teachers faced with a disruptive child. And parents might productively ask if they're placing their own needs above those of their child.

"Bedtime is often late and rushed because guilty working parents want quality time with their children to be full of fun," says Hetty Einzig. "But the transition to sleep is also a very important, peaceful period of the day. It is an intimate space, a really significant ritual, when children relax and open up more than at any other time of the day. And that sometimes gets ignored."

fields.headline: My dad and me
fields.standfirst: Sally Weale  asks a father and son how much has changed in a generation
fields.trailText: Sally Weale asks a father and son how much has changed in a generation
fields.body:
Ask Paul Brown what he recalls about his father from childhood, and he will tell you about Sunday trips to Margate, feeling safe with his dad while teddy boys and skinheads sparred on the seafront. He will tell you about longing for Thursday nights when his father, flush after payday, would came home with sweets for the four children. He remembers school holidays when he'd go with his dad to the factory where his father, always dressed in a suit, made those plastic windmills children love.

But what dominates his childhood memories is lying in bed and hearing the front door shutting as his father went off to work at the crack of dawn; then late at night, listening out for the sound of his dad's car pulling up, the front door opening, the front door closing - until the same time the next morning, when his dad left for work once more.

"Looking back, I think he was a good dad in his own way," says Paul, now 38. "He did two jobs, so he was at work from 6am to 10pm, making sure he kept us kids in shoes."

Jim Brown, now aged 70, was the archetypal father-provider. "He did what he thought parenting was," says Paul. "I'm not sure what I felt at the time, but now I can see how I've benefited. He taught me the importance of responsibility." But Paul wants to be more than just a provider of material comforts to his children - twins Yolyn and Jordan, 13, and Louis, 10. The fact that he hasn't lived with them since his relationship with their mother broke down six years ago is no obstacle as far as he's concerned.

"I just remember dad working, grafting to earn money. In terms of talking about what was happening in my life, he wasn't really there. I see my role as being part of my children's everyday lives. I am provider, protector, adviser. Someone who will open up opportunities for them, someone who emotionally supports them."

Paul, who lives in Leicester, sees his children every other weekend and telephones them regularly. "When I was living with them, I'd see them every night and every morning. I was part of their lives. I met their friends. Now in order to be part of that, it's a lot of hard work."

He tries to talk to them intimately (it's easier with his daughter than his two sons, he says); he hugs and kisses them (Jordan's not keen); holds their hands and makes a point of telling them he loves them. Yet he still finds it difficult to talk intimately to his own father. "Dad and I only have conversations about practical things - jobs, cars, sport, mortgages. The only time I've really talked with him was when me and my partner split up. He said I should stay with her. He struggled with the fact that you can be a good father and not be in the home. Whereas he was in the house when I was a child but I didn't spend time with him, I'm not in the house with mine, but I spend time with them."

Paul was at the birth of all of his children. He changed their nappies and fed them. After work, he would look after the children while their mother did a part-time job.

Jim, on the other hand, didn't see any of his four children born. He was nearly there for Paul, who was born at home, but he was sent out to call the doctor and by the time he returned, Paul had been delivered. "In those days most men never saw their children born," says Jim. "I didn't do a lot of nappy-changing and all that. I used to find time to take them to the park.

Because my wife never worked, she was the one who dealt with their growing up. I was busy working hard, trying to be a good father, making sure that they kept out of trouble, that they had enough to eat, that they had clothes to wear and good manners. Because of that, most likely the little things that I should have seen, I didn't see."

Jim didn't talk about love with his son. "In your family, you show love to them by what you do. You don't have tell your son, 'I love you.'" He thinks Paul, however, is a brilliant father. "I was devastated when he split up from the children's mother. But if there's one thing I'm really proud of, it's how he looks after the children. He is a devoted father."

The two men recently went to France for the day. Paul planned the trip because he wanted to tell his father that he loved him and that he thought he had been a good dad. But, somehow, the conversation kept veering off on a tangent.

"It's one of those conversations I want to have before he dies," says Paul. We've had ups and downs, but the only reason I am where I am today is because he gave me direction and support and I knew he would always be there for me."

From one father to another, it doesn't get much better than that.

webTitle: Chinook death crash pilots still take the rap

fields.headline: Chinook death crash pilots still take the rap
fields.trailText: Defence minister John Spellar has rejected calls for a new independent inquiry into the 1994 crash of an RAF Chinook helicopter which wiped out a significant part of the Northern Ireland intelligence establishment.
fields.body:
Defence minister John Spellar has rejected calls for a new independent inquiry into the 1994 crash of an RAF Chinook helicopter which wiped out a significant part of the Northern Ireland intelligence establishment.

Flight ZD576 was carrying 25 senior security staff from Belfast to Scotland when it slammed into a hill on the Mull of Kintyre. All on board were killed.

An air force board of inquiry found that the two pilots, flight lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Richard Cook, were entirely to blame for the crash. The families of both men have been campaigning ever since to clear their names, and doubts have repeatedly been raised about the safety of the highly complex Chinook machines.

Suspicion has focused on the sophisticated computer software fitted to the helicopters, known as Full Authority Digital Electronic Control (FADEC).

In 1998 the House of Commons select committee on defence concluded that there was "no compelling evidence" of technical faults.

The latest calls for a new investigation are based on a claim that Scotland's senior law officer, Lord Advocate Colin Boyd QC, has questioned the original inquiry findings.

In a letter to Scottish parliament member Kenny MacAskill, the lord advocate revealed that Crown counsel had considered new evidence on possible technical reasons for the crash.

However, Boyd also says in the letter that the new information does not invalidate earlier findings of pilot error. He said today that he had written to MacAskill only to clarify the legal situation, not to reopen doubts about the negligence verdict.

Spellar was more specific. On the Today programme, he insisted that the pilots were responsible for the crash. "By flying too fast and too low in fog and in a hilly area they were breaching safe flying rules," he said.

Mike Tapper, father of Flt Lt Tapper, accused the Ministry of Defence of dismissing the 'new evidence' out of hand. "It seems that the government would rather protect the elite within the MoD than to protect natural justice," he said.

Leading Conservatives have called for the RAF's verdict of gross negligence against the two pilots to be dropped. Defence spokesman Robert Key said the posthumous charges should be set aside in the interests of natural justice.

"The only thing that is certain is that nothing is certain," he said.

fields.headline: The price of growing old
fields.standfirst: Selling the family home to pay for residential care is an explosive political issue. Labour is considering easing the capital limits, but new research suggests there are better and fairer ways of tackling the problem
fields.trailText: Selling the family home to pay for residential care is an explosive political issue. Labour is considering easing the capital limits, but new research suggests there are better and fairer ways of tackling the problem.
fields.body:
Malcolm Ranger remembers vividly how he was told to sell up the family home to fund his mother's nursing home fees. "She'd been in hospital for months, with a heart condition and congestion on the lungs," he says. "She was incontinent, permanently on oxygen and a catheter, and couldn't feed herself. But they wanted her bed and kept piling on the pressure for me to get her into a care home."

That felt bad enough. But there was worse to come when a social worker casually let slip - in front of Ranger's mother - that her home in Accrington, Lancashire, worth around £45,000, would have to be put on the market to finance the move. "I couldn't believe what I was hearing," he says. "I thought I was going mental, breaking down. Not only were they prepared to send this desperately sick old lady out of there, they also wanted her to give up her home and her bit of savings for the privilege."

Sadly, Leonora Ranger died last December, at the age of 85, just as a "progress meeting" was being convened to move her out of hospital. Two other women on her ward died within weeks of being shifted to nursing homes. The whole experience has left her son bitter at the callous way he feels she was treated - and angry at a system that seems to penalise people who have scrimped and saved all their lives.

Next to pension levels, the cost of long-term care is one of the most emotive political issues facing the government. And following the drubbing Labour received from pensioners in the local elections, it is one issue it can ill-afford to ignore. Up and down the country there are hundreds and thousands of constituents whose assets bring them to just above £16,000, the cut-off point at which the state pays some of their care costs. Only those with less than £10,000 don't have to use any of their capital.

Half of all people over 80 who live alone - the ones most likely to need long-term care - have assets above the £16,000 threshold. Already, some 40,000 homes are sold each year to pay for nursing and residential home fees. And the proportion of this age group who own their homes is set to rise from 46% to 60% over the next 15 years.

With its long-awaited response to the royal commission on long-term care due next month, there are strong signals that the government plans to soften the capital and savings limits. This would play well with middle-income older voters and their relatives, and work out a lot cheaper than the commission's recommendation to make all personal care costs free. But new research findings, to be launched tomorrow by the Nuffield Foundation, suggest that such a move may be more trouble than it's worth.

The Nuffield report examines the implications for different categories of pensioners of reforming the capital limits and other means tests. It comes up with surprising results.

Increasing current capital limits to £20,000 or £30,000 - the kind of figure being bandied about in Whitehall - would apparently have a negligible effect on the assets pensioners could hang on to when they go into care. Only a really dramatic rise to, say, a lower capital limit of £60,000 and an upper one of £100,000 would significantly bene fit older people, particularly those in middle income groups.

On the other hand, a modest increase in the personal expenses allowance - the sum that care home residents are allowed to keep from their income - could reap political dividends. Raising this allowance from its paltry level of £15.45 a week to perhaps £30 would put about £700 extra a year into poorer pensioners' pockets. Importantly, for a government keen on targeting benefit rises on the most needy, the lion's share of this extra expenditure would go to the least well-off elderly people.

Disregarding more income, rather than tinkering with capital limits, could therefore make a lot of sense, says the report's author, Ruth Hancock. This is because of the way income and capital are run down when someone goes into care. Whatever the level of capital you own, all your income (except for that £15.45 pocket money) has to go towards meeting care costs.

For the average person with assets above the £16,000 threshold, this means paying £190 a week from your capital towards typical weekly care home fees of between £310 and £370. The rest would be paid for out of your pension, attendance allowance, interest on savings and other income.

According to the report, at this rate it takes a pretty long time for most people to run down their capital to the £16,000 threshold: nine years for half of them, and four years for three-quarters of the population. Meanwhile, raising personal allowances would give care home residents more cash to enjoy in the here and now.

So has the problem of selling homes to fund care costs been over-hyped? Philip Spiers, of the Nursing Home Fees Agency, certainly feels there is too much emphasis on the capital limits issue. "With such a shortage of funding for adequate services, any additional money that is available should be put into that, rather than increasing people's personal wealth," he argues.

The NHFA, which gives specialist advice on paying long-term care costs, reckons that any substantial increase in the capital limits threshold would have a disastrous effect on care homes, because local authorities could not afford to subsidise the vastly increased numbers of non-fee paying residents. There are also serious doubts about how increased capital limits could work fairly, given the north-south housing price divide.

But the strength of feeling around this issue has never been just about economics. Selling up the family home under duress has a distressing symbolic significance. Not only does it mark the end of independence and normality for the older person in question; it can also feel like an affront to pensioners who have worked, saved and paid taxes to provide for their families' futures.

Hancock acknowledges that the psychological impact of the capital and savings rules can be considerable, particularly when - as in the Ranger family's case - the means tests are applied insensitively by professionals. However, she argues that, compared with the wider problems besetting the long-term care system, small increases in the capital limits are barely relevant.

The Nuffield study takes a side-on look at some of these problems, such as the perverse financial incentive that encourages local authorities to place older homeowners in residential care, rather than keep them in their own homes. Making all personal care free - or disregarding most of people's housing wealth - would wipe out that incentive at a stroke. Yet ministers are likely to view either option as too costly and of limited benefit to the poorest pensioners.

In all this discussion of means-testing minutiae, there is perhaps a danger of losing sight of the bigger picture. People are angry about parting with their property principally because they imagined the state would provide for them in old age. In particular, they resent a system that provides free care in hospital, but demands that you pay for it in a care home.

It was this, plus the indecent haste with which the authorities wanted to discharge his mother, that really upset Malcolm Ranger. He says: "They made you feel like you were being greedy, when in fact everything was being done for their convenience, to avoid paying for her for one day more."

Between a rock and a hard place

In the run-up to its white paper on long-term care, the government has been consulting on ways to reform the funding system. So how might the various options - raising the capital limits, relaxing other means tests, or making all personal care free - impact on a situation like that facing the Dunn family?

Andrew Dunn's mother, Beryl, who is 83, suffers dementia. Since the death of her husband in December, she has not been able to cope alone. At present, she is being well cared for, free, in a special hospital unit near her home in Grantham, Lincolnshire. But she will not be allowed to stay there permanently. Her son, who has power of attorney, has had to put her £55,000 semi on the market to help pay for the nursing home she will shortly move to. The fees there will be £350 a week. Beryl has around £5,000 in savings, gets about £78 a week from her state and private pensions, and receives the higher rate attendance allowance.

As things stand, Beryl will have to pay the full cost of her first four years in care. Nor would matters improve much if the government raised the current capital limits by a small amount. If, for example, the upper limit was raised from £16,000 to £20,000, she would be eligible for state support marginally sooner, but would still have to eat slowly into her remaining capital. If the lower capital limit was simultaneously raised from £10,000 to £15,000, she would still have to wait almost four years for state support, but would not have to use up any more capital.

A much bigger increase in the upper capital limit, to £60,000, would make her eligible for local authority support almost immediately. But over three years she would still have to contribute around £35,000 from her pension and savings, with some £100-£200 a week coming from her capital. If, on the other hand, capital limits were left untouched, but all personal care costs were made free, she would only need to contribute £20,600 from her pension and savings, and would not have to draw on her capital.

fields.headline: Sod's law
fields.standfirst: Denise Hall on the sacrilege of destroying Ireland's peat bogs to satisfy gardeners
fields.trailText: Denise Hall on the sacrilege of destroying Ireland's peat bogs to satisfy gardeners
fields.body:
Peatlands originally covered one-fifth of Ireland. Today, less than a quarter of that amount remains, and every year an area of Irish bogland 20 times the size of Monaco is lost because of turf extraction for commercial fuel or garden centres, mostly in Britain. Tree planting, drainage and reclamation are other culprits. In some parts of the country, huge diggers gouge and grab more turf in a day than one family on a smallholding could remove in a lifetime.

Yet many rural families still look forward to cutting turf with an intensity that has little to do with actual need. There's nothing like it - a freedom that's hard to describe. Even the air is different. And then there are the birds - larks and all kinds, though not as many as there once were. My father remembered seeing eagles when he was a boy. They're gone now, but there's still plenty of wildlife that you wouldn't see anywhere else. And it's grand, healthy work.

Teddy, a hale 80-something, has gone to the bog during the month of May every year of his long life. Without a sod of turf for the winter, you have, he claims, only a poor sort of a fire. "The heart is missing from it. Then there's the smell - nothing like it."

And he's right. There is nothing quite like the aroma of burning turf on an early autumn fire, a heavy, musky scent that's like a warm, wild honey, stolen long ago from unknown flowers. It catches in your throat, weaves its way into your clothing and stays with you all winter. It is the scent of autumn, and a guarantee of survival during the dark winter nights ahead.

The bogs have a deep hold on Irish culture. They were always places where a person could hide, and knowing the pathways or toghers (ancient wooden trackways) through their treacherous expanses has often proved invaluable during times of trouble. They could hide other things too - flagons of poitín, guns and, sometimes, the bodies of those who had died under suspicious circumstances.

Today they are environmental wonders with hosts of vegetation, 100 animal types, two rare butterflies and an amazing nine different species of dragonfly, all still flourishing. But their future - along with rarities such as the Vertigo geyeri, a tiny and extremely rare snail, and the glacial relic Saxifragea hirculus - is far from certain.

Ireland is one of the last countries in Europe where a wide range of boglands - fens, raised bogs and blanket bogs - still exist in their natural state.

Now conservationists have issued a warning that, if they are to be preserved, urgent action is needed. A recent survey of 30 bogs by the Irish Peatland Conservation Society revealed that their environmental impact is far more significant than has formerly been realised.

The bogs are depleting, but the strange thing is that bogs naturally expand laterally, burying whatever lies in their path. They will kill trees, bury their stumps, slowly enclose stone walls, houses, tombs, occasionally releasing some piece of ancient jewellery, like a gold torque, or a mummified body whose secrets can only be guessed at. But, mostly, a bog will hold patiently on to what it has been given.

Dead vegetation also accumulates in those murky depths. And since vegetable matter under water decays very slowly, it can take hun dreds of years for the build-up to reach a point where a layer of peat finally breaks through on to the surface of the water. But then there's no stopping it. The bog continues to spread triumphantly, upward and outward, bearing a living layer - vegetation, water, plants, reeds, flowers and mosses, all destined to be reincarnated as peat themselves one day.

In the UK, fewer than 6,000 hectares of lowland-raised bog now remain in a near natural condition. Yet peat is still being extracted from these bogs and from bogs in Ireland to satisfy the demands of the lucrative gardening industry. Destroying them is a sacrilege, like knocking down St Paul's cathedral.

fields.headline: Solving riddles
fields.standfirst: Stephen Thornton argues the case that the NHS should commission social services to create a seamless system
fields.trailText: Stephen Thornton argues the case that the NHS should commission social services to create a seamless system
fields.body:
When the prime minister set out his five challenges for the health service, he included the "partnership challenge". This is about the way the health and social care systems can work better together to improve patients' experience of care. The modernisation action teams were then set up to examine the problems and come up with solutions. Its purpose was to generate a potentially radical debate on the NHS.

Partnership working is not a new idea. And it has improved markedly over recent years, in part, through new mechanisms provided by the Health Act 1999. The extent of the difficulties caused by the boundary between health and social care, particularly for older people and those with physical disabilities, has been underestimated.

The current system, with separate assessments and different resource allocation formulae for health and local government, can be a major obstacle to integrated care. People do not want to be in hospital or residential care unless they really have to be, but they are caught up in a system riddled with perverse incentives that keep them there. When a person is in hospital, the cost is the responsibility of the NHS. When discharged, he or she becomes the responsibility of social services.

Many admissions to hospital and residential care could be prevented by better co-ordination of health and social care organisations. If these patients are treated at home, the pattern of multiple admissions could be reduced, as well as the development of dependency that often follows the initial admission. Many patients in acute hospital beds could be cared for in other settings - not just those ready for discharge, but those who no longer require the services of an acute hospital. The government outlined its ideas to provide intermediate care settings, where rehabilitation is a priority, in its recent national beds inquiry report.

Partnership is only a partial answer to the interface between health and social care, and as part of the modernisation review we have proposed a more radical solution. We believe the best approach for patients would be a single assessment and single resource allocation mechanism. This means a single commissioning process.

There would be considerable advantages in new levels of primary care trusts commissioning personal social services and residential care. For the patient, this approach would lead to fewer boundaries and primary care would be able to take a more holistic approach to care.

It would provide incentives to encourage the faster transfer of patients from acute care and there would be less opportunity for organisations to try to shunt costs from health care to social services.

We are not advocating immediate change - several building blocks would need to be put in place if the primary care trusts were to commission personal social services. They would need a unified resource allocation for all health and social care funds used for older people and people with physical disabilities, with audit trails to ensure that the allocation is used for these groups. The constitution, representation and governance arrangements of trusts would need to be reviewed to ensure appropriate social care expertise is available. This should be coupled with the development of more common protocol driven and non-medically led approaches to aid the commissioning process.

Taking this approach for elderly and physically disabled people does not mean that all social care commissioning should rest with the trusts. For example, the responsibility for commissioning learning disability services could sit with local government, and health services supporting children in education could be commissioned by education with health service advice. If a standardised approach is used, who takes the lead on commissioning becomes less relevant.

We are not advocating a takeover of local government services, but the provision of a single budget from which the most appropriate package of care would be commissioned for the individual. This would resolve some of the key perverse incentives, but part of the equation still to be tackled is the split between means-tested and free care. Without substantial investment there will still need to be means testing to support charging for elements of the care package. If trusts do have responsibility for commissioning social care they will need the ability to charge for elements of it.

The next step will be to test this process. If these pilots can deliver truly integrated health and social services and ensure a better experience for the individual, the challenge will have been met.

fields.headline: Sticking point
fields.standfirst: Older people can play a key role in rebuilding communities but Martin Shreeve says ways must be found to harness their contributions
fields.trailText: Older people can play a key role in rebuilding communities but Martin Shreeve says ways must be found to harness their contributions
fields.body:
Two years is not long to change public policy. But it is the time within which the Better Government for Older People programme has operated - a period of political activity whose intensity has been unprecedented for local authorities and non-governmental organisations.

The programme is a key part of the modernising government initiative driven by the Cabinet Office minister Ian McCartney. Since May 1998, a partnership of central and local government voluntary organisations and older people has tried to demonstrate that engaging all stakeholders and, in particular, harnessing the skills and experience of people over 50, works.

The lessons from the programme and its 28 pilot projects and recommendations are published tomorrow in All Our Futures. The evaluation of the programme by Warwick University highlights that the single most important lesson is that agencies at all levels working together with older people can produce better and more effective outcomes.

But older people involved in the programme say there is a long way to go to ensure their voices are listened to and acted upon.

The programme has been as much concerned with the concept of better government as it has with improving services for older people. Building sustainable systems and the capacity to develop further are just as important as short-term service gains.

A key goal has been to support the development of local strategies for an ageing population, a concern for all our futures. Our society is ageing, not just the individuals within it. New mechanisms, as well as new ways of thinking and acting, are needed if we are to meet the challenge of an ageing population.

We have emphasised the significance of involving older people more effectively, not merely as a means of countering discrimination or pursuing a goal of greater social inclusion. The greater significance lies in both recognising and harnessing the contributions that older people have to make in building a better Britain for all.

Modernising government and local democracy and delivering on best value demand that older people play a more active part in their communities. Older people have the potential to be the glue, the social capital, that binds and rebuilds our communities for all our futures.

But older people cannot deliver that on their own. They need a supportive, inter-generational compact that is inclusive and active. It also needs central and local mechanisms and structures to support it and develop its capacity.

Our experience from the pilot programme is that while the goal may be achievable, the mechanisms are not in place in all areas, not sufficiently sustainable in most, and the capacity is not fully developed in any to deliver on the ambition or aspiration.

This requires not just better decision-making but tackling the barriers that prevent true and effective partnership working now and in the future.

Change is required at all levels of government and service provision if we are to achieve better government, security for all our futures and a better quality of life in older age.

Combating ageism is a prerequisite - not just for improved services to older people and sustainable levels of security and quality of life in older age, but to ensure that the skills, experience and contributions of senior citizens can be harnessed to regenerate our neighbourhoods and revitalise local democracy.

Age discrimination in employment has been the primary focus of government in seeking to tackle ageism. But age discrimination is more widespread than just employment. Issues of age discrimination in health have had more recent prominence, but it permeates many areas of public and private sector provision.

Most frequently identified within the programme are educa tion and transport. While lifelong learning is an aspirational title, the experience of many is that lifetime equates to the period pre-retirement, and learning is seen to be synonymous with vocation rather than education.

Similarly, integrated transport and concessionary travel have a hollow ring if transport is integrated and affordable, but unavailable or inaccessible to provide the opportunities for older people to make their contribution to their families and communities and enjoy as inclusive a quality of life as other age groups.

Ageism and age discrimination are, in short, barriers to wider engagement and contribution to local communities, including service provision and participatory democracy.

Opinions differ as to whether age discrimination can most effectively be tackled by legislation. But the vast majority of older people engaged in the programme believe that legislation is an essential prerequisite for change.

The continuing work of the interministerial group on older people, the appointment of a minister to champion older people's issues within government, and the introduction of supported independent living for older people as a beacon council theme are positive messages that the government is listening.

The findings and recommendations of the Better Government for Older People programme are relevant to the whole spectrum of government, political activity and service provision because better government for older people means better government for all.

The most effective champions of the changes that are necessary will be older people. Without their continued contribution through generating new ideas, and monitoring progress, change is unlikely to be achieved and less likely to be sustained.

fields.headline: Flower power
fields.standfirst: Leslie Jerman on how a one-off garden open day became a hardy annual event
fields.trailText: Leslie Jerman on how a one-off garden open day became a hardy annual event
fields.body:
If I hadn't had a good lunch, I might not have agreed so readily. Perhaps too much wine had been taken when my neighbour showed me the letter. The village hall roof was leaking and we had to raise some £6,000 for repairs.

Would he open his garden to the public? He wouldn't. "Yours is better than mine," he said. "Oh, all right," I replied. Within minutes, he had the woman on the phone.

Mick Marchant, a retired plastics manufacturer, had come up with the idea. Our village association hadn't enough cash, so he suggested that we open our gardens to raise more.

Mine is a spring garden. The opening was to be in the summer. I had to do something about it. The patch full of tulips, daffodils, aconites, crocus, snowdrops, Algerian iris and winter-flowering shrubs had to make way for June.

I had long wanted a bowling green lawn. I took my time in clearing the building site that the garden once was. I laid land drains and brick drainage for the lawn area, because a lot of water flows over our garden from a slow Epping Forest slope.

I found the right sort of seed, sowed it and, in the rain, walked up and down to tread it in. Now we have a good lawn - so good that it has appeared several times in a seed catalogue. I planted dahlias, potted them in the greenhouse. I put out artichoke offsets and sowed a lot of annuals.

Twenty gardens were to open. Most are attached to semis, but one or two run to several acres, with fine views of the forest herd of black fallow deer in their sanctuary. Theydon Bois, although it is only 15 miles from London, is still a village.

I got involved in the publicity. We had three local radio broadcasts, put leaflets in every gardening book in the library and made posters. We even got into the "what's on" columns of the national papers.

The entry charge was small. For under a pound, paid at the village hall, you could see all of the gardens. Lunches and teas were also to be served in the hall.

The village association put up the initial float to pay for printing tickets and maps. Lists of the gardens included details of their specialities. The work was exhausting, as we all made sure the gardens were at the best they could be.

On the big Sunday, I lay on the settee, overcome by the tension of it all. Would people come? At 2pm they began arriving at the side gate. Cardboard fir trees at the gate indicated "Garden open today." By three, the garden was crowded.

"Where can I get an artichoke plant?" I was asked. "Leave your name and address at the gate and I will deliver one in April," I said -and I did.

"What is that tall yellow plant?" I had no idea except that the name I knew it by was the rocket. "My lilies are better than yours." What satisfaction that remark must have given. "Oh, you have a Drancunculus vulgaris!" I knew the plant, but not its name.

And still they came. The street from the village hall teemed with smiling, chattering people. Hundreds of cars parked on the village green. Out front, my daughter and son-in-law sold plants and seeds. They managed to off-load three aspidistras as well.

Mick Marchant came round. "It's been a great social success," he said, "but not a financial one". I told him he did not realise what he had started, and that we would be even busier next year. By the end of the day, we had had 567 visitors. Stragglers were still arriving at 6pm.

One garden has a pool. Its owner, Mick's wife, told me: "At one time there were a dozen youngsters swimming in it." Did they bring costumes? "No, they just stripped off and dived in."

One woman sold homemade jam. A baker who grows strawberries served strawberry teas. Another garden had an art show, yet another had a model railway. Some have waterfalls.

One of the broadcasts that morning brought two elderly women from nearby Romford. They had managed 15 gardens by the time they reached us. We sat them down and made them tea, before driving them back to their bus stop. Everyone seemed happy. Our garden looked so prim one man even asked if we could lend him an ashtray!

Next day, someone in the street said: "You'll have to do it again next year." And we did. Twenty years after that first day we open again this year on June 25. The organiser for several years has been Joy Wainwright, a village stalwart, who is in her early 80s, and has even organised a village website.

Tickets are now £3. There will be free minibuses to outlying gardens. People have written from Bury St Edmunds and Edinburgh to ask how it is done. Each year we have more than 3,000 visitors, and the village hall is in good nick. Garden visiting is now an industry. Thousands nationwide will be open this year.

webTitle: Growth is good for the poor

fields.headline: Growth is good for the poor
fields.standfirst: According to World Bank experts, an equation helps prove that when the rich get rich, the poor get rich. Oh, yeh?  Richard Douthwaite argues that it is a myth and that the poor will never catch up
fields.trailText: According to World Bank experts, an equation helps prove that when the rich get rich, the poor get rich. Oh, yeh? Richard Douthwaite argues that it is a myth and that the poor will never catch up
fields.body:
The protesters against the world trade talks in Seattle last December and against the World Bank and IMF in April succeeded in getting their main argument widely accepted: namely, that global free trade is widening the gap between rich and poor both within countries and between them.

There is overwhelming statistical evidence for this view. The United Nations Development Project has been saying it for several years. Its 1999 Human Development Report stated that the income gap between the fifth of the world's people living in the richest countries and the fifth in the poorest was 74 to 1 in 1997, up from 60 to 1 in 1990 and 30 to 1 in 1960.

Within countries, inequality had been rising since 1980 it said, citing China, the countries of eastern Europe and the CIS, and OECD countries, "especially Sweden, the United Kingdom and the United States" as examples.

But the free traders, led by the World Bank, are fighting back. Their new weapon, widely hailed in the financial press last week, is a long, detailed economic research paper full of equations and theory, called Growth is Good for the Poor, by David Dollar and Aart Kraay, of the World Bank's development research group.

The Financial Times said that the paper "provides what appears to be incontestable evidence" that sustained growth raises the real incomes of the poor and that growth is "helped along by just the policies many of the demonstrators oppose: by macro-economic stability and openness to trade".

Even the Guardian joined in. Mark Atkinson wrote on the economic pages that the report illustrated "the harm that would be inflicted on the poor if governments were to listen too hard to the protesters at Seattle and retreat from open markets".

It does no such thing. As Dollar and Kraay's purported conclusions seem set to become one of the myths of our time, to be used triumphantly whenever arguments about globalisation break out, it is worth looking at what their report actually says, and what its figures really show, rather than the spin which is being loaded on to them.

Labelled "preliminary and incomplete", their paper claims that 370 observations from 125 countries over four decades show that:

 When a country grows economically, the incomes of the poor - the bottom 20% of the population on the income scale - tend to rise at the same percentage rate as those of everyone else.

 The incomes of the poor do not drop by proportionately more than those of the better-off in economic crises. This applies to poor countries as well as richer ones.

 The relationship has not changed in recent years as countries have progressively opened themselves up to the free movement of goods, services and capital.

 Openness to international trade benefits the poor to the same extent as everyone else.

 Government spending on primary education and democratic institutions doesn't do anything to raise the share of national income going to the poor.

 Cutting government expenditure and curbing inflation raise the growth rate. They also seem to give the poor a larger share of the higher incomes that result.

 State social spending does not increase the growth rate. Nor does it increase the share of national income going to the poor.

The final three remarkable conclusions have been greeted with glee by economic fundamentalists and require an investigation by themselves. In the space available here, the best we can do is to look at the claim hard-wired to the paper's title, that growth is good for the poor because it raises their incomes by as much as those of everyone else.

Since the poorest fifth of the population in every country gets only a tiny fraction of total national income - in the US, for example, it gets 4.2% - one explanation for D&K's results could be that their data isn't accurate enough to pick up the real changes taking place. A 1% error, for example, could mean that the poor had lost a quarter of its income, without it showing in the figures.

"There's a lot of approximation," says Ray Thomas, who teaches statistics at the Open University. "Estimating the income of the bottom 20% [they way D&K have done] is defensible because of the lack of any alternative. But it is not really good enough when the aim of the exercise is to make generalisations about the average income level of the bottom 20%."

Especially, as Dollar and Kraay write, they know very little about what has happened to the distribution of income within the bottom 20%. Thomas thinks that as the bulk of the incomes received by the bottom 20% go to the richer members of it, their figures might well be missing what's happening to the poorest of the poor.

So the most likely explanation of the conflict between the UNDP statistics and Dollar and Kraay's is inadequate data. "For most countries, only one or a handful of observations are available," their paper admits.

Moreover, even if we accept the paper's finding that the incomes of the poor grew at the same rate as the rich in percentage terms, what this means in real life is that the absolute number of possessions the rich could afford was growing much faster than those of the poor. If the top 80% of the population had 96% of the income and the bottom 20% had 4% initially, 25% growth would have enabled the poor to acquire one more possession for every 20 acquired by the better off.

But this is playing the economists at their own game by measuring everything in money terms. This is a mistake because when economic growth takes place, almost everything in society and the economy changes, and even if incomes rise sharply it is impossible to say without a detailed social investigation whether the population of the country concerned becomes better off.

For example, because the growth statistics only measure the monetarised parts of the economy, they ignore those things that people do for themselves. Thus, if a child is cared for by its mother at home, that does not contribute to national income and hence growth. If it is placed with a childminder, it does. A meal in McDonald's adds more to gross national product than a meal cooked at home. Growth can therefore be generated by making people less self-reliant. Whether this indicates they are better off is another question.

Supposing, for example, that when a third world country opened up its economy to the world its agricultural workers were required to become more mechanised. If, as a result, fewer workers were needed in the countryside and they moved to city slums, growth could well be generated by such a change and the incomes of the people who moved could well be higher than they were in their villages.

However, as they would then have to buy all their food and fuel rather than producing it for themselves, and might have to pay rent and fares for the first time, they could easily be much worse off.

Dollar and Kraay's paper is not pure research. It is a political document written, as Dollar told me, because "we were afraid that the current debate on globalisation was losing sight of the basic fact that the status of the poor is linked to the overall health of the economy. If the economy is not growing, it is very unlikely that the poor are doing well."

That's true, but only because we have an economic system that, whatever damage it is doing to people's lives or to the environment, has to continue to expand if it is not to collapse, taking the poor, and the rest of us, with it.

Instead of acting as growth promoters, D&K would have been better employed investigating how the system has to be changed so that growth can be brought to a stop without costing millions of the poor what little income they have.

Indeed, if we turn its findings around, what their paper shows is that the impoverished are being used as the excuse for continuing with a growth process that is failing to make the poorest any better off in relative terms. After all, if the income of the poor rises only one-for-one with overall growth, they'll never, ever, catch up.

 Richard Douthwaite, a former Department of the Environment economist, is the author of The Growth Illusion: How Economic Growth Enriched the Few, Impoverished the Many and Endangered the Planet (Green Books, £12.95).

Dollar and Kraay's paper can be downloaded from the website www.worldbank.org/research

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor: How does it feel to be in your twenties and single?
fields.body:
How does it feel to be in your twenties and single? Those in this condition at least have the satisfaction of knowing that they are now statistically normal. But does this mean they are more inclined to regard their singleness as a positive way of living, or does singleness remain a provisional state that will readily be abandoned when circumstances change?

To find the answers, sociologist Lynn Jamieson and her colleagues at the University of Edinburgh interviewed 110 single young people between the ages of 20 and 29. Although more than half were not considering any sort of long-term commitment, there was little evidence that they regarded their singleness as a permanent state. Nearly all agreed that a committed relationship was the ideal long-term goal.

But some interesting gender differences began to emerge when Jamieson asked her interviewees their reasons for staying single. Men were far more likely than women to be negative about the whole idea of partnerships, stressing the lack of sexual freedom they entailed, and the constraints they placed upon one's ability to have a "laddish" good time. If they had been in a failed partnership, they were inclined to talk about it as "a lucky escape".

Some of the single women initially seemed as assertive as the men about the benefits of singleness but "they undermined themselves by a constant openness to finding Mr Right and an acknowledgement that he had not yet been found".

Neither did such women follow the men in regarding failed relationships as lucky escapes. Instead they stressed the chance that the failure had provided for them "to grow" and gain greater self- understanding.

Single women were also aware that any success they might have achieved in life reduced their marital prospects. "I feel a lot of people are threatened by my independence . . . I need to find somebody on an even scale . . . I want somebody like myself and there's not a lot of people out there like that."

But even this fussiness had its limits. "If you meet somebody and it's right, it doesn't matter what they've got, whether they've got 10 children and had three marriages, I think if it's right then it's right."

Singleness may now be the statistical norm for twenty-somethings but as Jamieson is forced to conclude: "Being young and single is still in the shadow of marriage."

fields.headline: Bridging the gap
fields.standfirst: With numbers of homeless, David Brindle reports that the main cause is the difference between private rent and housing benefit
fields.trailText: With numbers of homeless, David Brindle reports that the main cause is the difference between private rent and housing benefit
fields.body:
Reform of housing benefit may have gone on the government's backburner, but MPs remain concerned at problems with the £15bn system. The Commons social security committee is today launching an inquiry into these problems, including what it calls "restrictions on housing benefit, causing hardship and homelessness".

Albert Walker could tell the committee a thing or two about that. He is eking out his retirement in a ground floor maisonette in Croydon, south London. It has separate dining and sitting rooms, but it is small and otherwise unremarkable. Yet it has been declared officially a "luxury flat" with a rent significantly higher than that of similar properties in the area.

As a result, 73-year-old Walker's housing benefit is restricted to £298 a month - £152 short of his rent. He struggles to make up the rest from his state pension and a £150-a-month occupational pension from his former employment on the railways.

"I try not to overspend," he says. "I try to keep the rent clear because I don't care where I go during the day, I've got to have somewhere to lay my head at night. I'd rather go without food than owe rent."

Walker is by no means alone in his predicament. Research among private tenants in Brent, north London, has found that three in four housing benefit claimants surveyed face a shortfall between their rent and benefit. They either go without to pay the difference, or get into arrears and risk eviction and homelessness.

The research, by the London Housing Unit (LHU), also found that the benefit restrictions - introduced by the last government - are curbing the supply of private rented accommodation. Many landlords are setting their face against letting to claimants, as letting agents testify, and they are not responding to restrictions in the way originally hoped: two in three Brent tenants who had sought a rent reduction to help bridge the benefit shortfall had been rebuffed.

Problems caused by benefit restrictions are particularly acute in the south, where high demand for housing means landlords can pick and choose their tenants. Brinjinder Gobindpuri, head of the homelessness and advice service in Hounslow, west London, says: "This issue is very hot in Hounslow because homelessness in the private sector is rising every day. Evictions from assured shorthold tenancies are the biggest single reason for homelessness, and housing benefit shortfall is one of the main reasons for those evictions."

Tony Newman, chair of housing in Croydon, says: "Landlords need incentives to invest in homes and set more realistic rents, rather than already hard-pressed tenants being squeezed for money they just don't have."

Charlie Forman and Karen Elsmore, authors of the LHU research report, A Market of Desperation, believe such incentives should be combined with a system of penalties for landlords who overcharge for poor quality properties. They say the government needs to go further than it has signalled in its recent housing green paper in terms of rewarding and penalising landlords directly - though they do describe the discussion document as a "welcome foundation stone".

Forman and Elsmore note that the green paper is "interestingly quiet" on the subject of so-called shopping incentives. These, in theory, prompt tenants to shop around for cheaper or more suitable accommodation. But the researchers' findings in Brent suggest that such incentives may have little effect in practice.

The social security committee's inquiry, which is also looking at shopping incentives and issues including the notoriously poor administration of housing benefit, starts as the Chartered Institute of Housing's annual conference takes place this week in Harrogate.

The conference is calling on the government to give priority to housing in the comprehensive spending review this summer. According to new figures, prepared for the Institute for Public Policy Research's social housing inquiry, spending on housing needs to rise by as much as £1.5bn a year - up to £500m to achieve the government's target of improving all council estates, plus £1bn to ensure there are enough affordable new homes.

David Butler, the institute's chief executive, says: "In order to provide accommodation for those who cannot afford to buy, and to have the key workers needed in those areas where the economy is booming, it is vital that the chancellor recognises that affordable housing will only be built with government help."

 A Market of Desperation is available (price £10) from the London Housing Unit (tel: 020- 7428 4926 or visit www.lhu.org.uk The unit is part of the new Association of London Government.

fields.headline: Burden of youth
fields.standfirst: Thousands of teenagers have no chice but to take on the role of parent, but are given no credit in the labour market for their experience
fields.trailText: Thousands of teenagers have no chice but to take on the role of parent, but are given no credit in the labour market for their experience
fields.body:
At the age of 16, Melanie has already been exposed to a lifetime's experience. "I'm the more mature one out of me and my sister; I ended up taking on the role of the parent, trying to cook, trying to feed us," she says. "I mean it was mainly cereal and jam sandwiches, 'cause I couldn't cook 'cause I was only nine."

Melanie is one of the tens of thousands of Britain's young carers whose burden has come to be more widely recognised over recent years, thanks largely to the work of a research group at Loughborough University. But today, as part of national carers' week, the group publishes a study on a dimension still little appreciated: the impact of the experience on young carers as they move into adulthood and seek to make their way in the world.

Unsurprisingly, this impact is largely negative. Those who have been young carers are likely to have patchy school records, to have endured poverty and social isolation and to have found difficulty making space for themselves. But there is very often an upside: by having had to assume responsibility early in life, young carers tend to be mature beyond their years and to have practical and personal skills that ought to make them attractive propositions in the labour market. "Ought to", however, is very much the point.

As Anna, a 19-year-old carer, says: "I was inquiring about social work and social services and I know basically you've got to have this, you've got to have that, you've got to have the other. And I was like: 'Oh my god, I haven't got any of those.' "

Official estimates indicate there are up to 50,000 young carers who provide "substantial care on a regular basis" to others, usually family members. Many more under-18s are likely to do rather less than that, yet still suffer adverse effects. Today's study, being launched at the House of Commons at an event hosted by Malcolm Wicks, the minister for lifelong learning, suggests that while services for young carers have improved - there are now 115 local support projects, compared to 37 in 1995 and just two in 1992 - services for their families as a whole remain hit and miss.

Moreover, there appears little specific help on offer for young adults who have been carers since childhood or adolescence and are living with the consequences. They are too old for young carers' groups, but often do not identify with adult carers' networks.

Such is the apparent scale of this problem that the researchers found difficulty contacting over-18s for their study, funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. In all, the research team interviewed 60 current or past carers, 36 of whom were aged 16-18 and 24 aged 19-25. Half came from single-parent families and two-thirds were carers for their mothers. Almost all carried out domestic tasks, such as cleaning, cooking, washing and ironing, and almost half provided personal care such as washing, bathing or toileting.

Sixteen-year-old Graham is typical. He lives with his younger sister and mother, who has a muscle-wasting disease and is very weak. He lifts her, empties her commode and helps monitor her blood-sugar level. He does most of the cooking, helps with the housework and collects her benefit. The family has no outside services.

Graham has left school and is attending a college course three days a week to learn plastering. But he gets no income at all, explaining that "my Mum gives me £2 for those three days . . . that's enough".

Graham says he cannot recall his GCSE results, but he knows he had no passes at higher grades. Half the sample of young carers had missed some school, mostly on account of their caring duties, and in some cases they had done so with the collusion of teachers and education welfare staff. A quarter had no GCSEs and only a quarter again had a job.

While some of the sample felt they had been forced to grow up too soon, many believed their experience placed them well for the world of work - however few their formal qualifications. Many, too, were keen on a job in the caring professions. Yet in what the research report calls a "catch 22", they often found themselves barred from entry because of their lack of certificates.

"I originally wanted to do nursing and I talked to my careers thing and she said I had no chance of doing it because I've never passed my exams," says Kirsty, 16. "I was going to do health and social care, but I talked about it to the careers woman at college and she said: 'With your caring for your mum and all that you've done, it would probably just bore you to do the same thing again.' "

The report, Growing Up Caring, by Chris Dearden and Saul Becker, makes clear it is not acceptable for young people to have to learn skills in this no-choice way, in the absence of proper, professional services.

But it goes on to argue that given that young carers do acquire special abilities and personal qualities, rightly or wrongly, there should be some way of crediting them in the employment market against forgone formal qualifications.

As Sandra, 19, says: "I think I sort of became an adult when I were 15... like a woman might be running a house, I were doing all the things maybe a 22 or 23 year old would be doing. I think I became mature when I were 15."

Fighting mother's battle

If she had not been a young carer for her mother, Cassie Wragg doubts she would now be working in health care. "I always wanted to go into the media, actually," she says. "I don't think I would have had the interest if it hadn't been for Mum."

Mum is Liz Fletcher, who was diagnosed as a manic depressive about five years ago. Even before then, though, Cassie - now 18 - was acting as her carer. The formal services have never met their needs.

"It's mainly social services that are the problem," says Cassie. "They'll offer somebody to come and do the cleaning, or to sit and talk to mum, but that's not what we need. Anyway, I don't think it's appropriate to have somebody unknown to both us.

"What we need is an explicit guarantee that right away when mum gets ill, if she needs help we will get that help and care."

The mother and daughter, who come from Derby and have always lived alone, are happier with the service provided over the past two years by a community psychiatric nurse. "That does help: there is somebody to phone up and ask to intervene," says Cassie. But she is under no illusions that her caring role will be needed for the foreseeable future.

"I don't feel it is an obligation," she insists. "If mum is ill, I will look after her; if I'm ill, she will look after me. It's like teamwork."

Cassie is employed as a student healthcare worker by the Southern Derbyshire Mental Health trust. She is currently working nights at a unit for elderly mentally ill people, and she hopes to train as a mental health nurse.

Liz admits to being concerned at the multiple pressures her daughter faces. "I am worried about the emotional implications for her because it's such hard work, caring for people," she says.

"I run the local manic depression support group and I had a call last night, when I wasn't feeling too bright myself, from somebody slashing herself because she was raped five years ago and has never spoken to anybody about it. Cassie is facing people in distress every day of her working life."

On the other hand, Liz has no doubts about her daughter's caring skills. "She's absolutely amazing," she says. "She has an instinctive ability to know what I need, when I need it, and she is my best advocate. She fights for me when I can't fight for myself."

Cassie did not take part in the latest Loughborough study, but she and her mother are among advisers to the young carers' research group.

Unlike most of those in the study sample, Cassie says her school education did not suffer because of her domestic commitments. "For as long as I can remember, Mum has been ill," she says. "It's always seemed part of our life and we've just got on with it."

Can she envisage a time when she would move out of the family home, leaving her mother to cope on her own?

"Whatever happens, I would always be 100% for my mum," she insists. "I would keep coming back anyway to do my laundry."

For now, living with and caring for her mum does not seem to be cramping Cassie's style.

"Boyfriends? She gets through them at a rate of knots," says Liz. "She's a young woman like any other."

 Growing Up Caring is available from the National Youth Agency, 17-23 Albion Street, Leicester, LE1 6GD (0116-285-3700) at £12.95 inc. p&p. A summary is available free from JRF, The Homestead, 40 Water End, York, YO30 6WP, or at www.jrf.org.uk

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Research commissioned by an online pet shop has revealed that 20% of owners fed their animals a takeaway curry or kebab and 7% allowed them to drink wine or beer.
fields.body:
Pet likes:
Research commissioned by an online pet shop has revealed that 20% of owners fed their animals a takeaway curry or kebab and 7% allowed them to drink wine or beer.

Class act:
A pupil at a school in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, has been suspended for organising a strippergram to peel off for his classmates in the sixth form common room.

High road:
The ancient Ermine Street route between Swindon and Gloucester has been resurfaced so many times that it is now five feet higher than when it was originally built by the Romans.

Blazing row:
A woman who made a bonfire of her partner's belongings in the garden of their home in Hartlepool following a row accidentally set fire to the house.

Feedback:
A wildlife centre worker from Yorkshire has recovered the £500 engagement ring swallowed by a calf she was bottle-feeding.

Card shark:
Staff at a toy store in Plymouth called in the police when a nine-year-old boy tried to use his father's credit card to buy Pokémon swap cards.

Happy-clappy:
Guest of honour at a Beverley Sisters concert in Walton, Suffolk, is a man who once clapped so hard during a performance by the singing trio that he had to be treated in hospital.

Coughing up:
The woman driver of a bus in Manchester has been sacked following reports from parents that she was selling cigarettes to schoolchildren passengers for 40p each.

Low handicap:
Plans for a £150,000 golf training centre in Halesowen, West Midlands, are being threatened because rare Ballerina waxcap mushrooms grow on the site.

Going nowhere:
Durham county council has spent £3,000 installing a semi-circular stretch of cycle path in Consett that is only eight metres long.

Dress collection:
Fluff and hair collected from washing machines at a local launderette is being recycled by a Brighton arts student to make a dress as part of her degree course.

Shell shock:
A boat mechanic trawling an Oxford canal with a magnet to try to recover a spanner he had dropped hauled up a second world war incendiary bomb.

In the pictures:
A policewoman working undercover to catch pickpockets in Loughborough, Leicestershire, won two tickets to the cinema when she was circled on a photograph published in the local newspaper's 'Are you in the picture?' competition.
