Going nowhere: Durham county council has spent £3,000 installing a semi-circular stretch of cycle path in Consett that is only eight metres long. Dress collection: Fluff and hair collected from washing machines at a local launderette is being recycled by a Brighton arts student to make a dress as part of her degree course. Shell shock: A boat mechanic trawling an Oxford canal with a magnet to try to recover a spanner he had dropped hauled up a second world war incendiary bomb. In the pictures: A policewoman working undercover to catch pickpockets in Loughborough, Leicestershire, won two tickets to the cinema when she was circled on a photograph published in the local newspaper's 'Are you in the picture?' competition.

fields.headline: Agenda benders
fields.standfirst: Jo Williams warns that an NHS 'takeover' of sevices would undermine years of building up partnerships
fields.trailText: Jo Williams warns that an NHS 'takeover' of sevices would undermine years of building up partnerships
fields.body:
The call by the NHS Confederation for the health service to "take over" local authority social care services has been loudly echoed by the government since its health summit last week. It has spoken of a "single organisation" providing services for elderly and disabled people, modelled perhaps on the Northern Ireland example of integrated services.

Although there are some ambiguities in the government's stance, both it and the confederation are misguided. Imposing a major structural upheaval on both the NHS and local government, when both are beginning to make a reality of close, collaborative working, seems to be driven by acute sector pressures within the NHS.

And these in turn risk distorting the health and social care agenda by responding to headlines and concerns about waiting times and lists, rather than by taking a cool and thoughtful look at what is best for the users of the two services.

By introducing a "turf war" into social services' relationship with health, the government and the confederation threaten to destabilise the effective partnerships built up over the past years between health and social care staff.

Yet there is an alternative. There is a good case to be made for local authorities taking back those responsibilities for personal health care services at home which were taken from them in 1972.

This would almost certainly lead to better services and more investment. And, at a stroke, it would solve most of the problems caused by the health/social care divide that have afflicted us for some 30 years. Local authorities see services and support for older people as a key task. All the evidence is that, over the past 30 years, primary health care services have received neither the resources nor the priority they deserve.

Increasingly, because of acute sector dominance, the NHS has created the perception that older people are a burden and that age discrimination is widespread.

Ultimately those elderly people who look to social services not just for help at home, but for the contact it gives them with local authority-provided transport, housing, education and leisure services, will see those contacts severely impaired.

Yet it was the integration of community care services, local government-wide, which was so hotly advocated by the government while in opposition.

Just as worryingly, any number of national and local voluntary agencies that provide so much for elderly and disabled people will find their entire contracting relationships, currently negotiated by democratically accountable bodies, seriously disrupted.

The Association of Directors of Social Services simply does not accept that primary care trusts will ever be able to replicate our policies of empowerment, inclusivity, working with our users and provision of real access to meetings where decisions concerning their services are actually taken.

There is an increasing expectation from active, older people and from disabled people and their families about the role that local authorities should play in preventing health deterioration and promoting their independence.

These have important parts to play in taking the pressure off our health services, and any new commissioning arrangements would have to be closely scrutinised to ensure that those benefits were not lost.

On a strictly organisational level, any transfer of responsibilities would mean considerable disruption and loss of momentum. Should government not pause to assess whether the benefits for service users in the long term would outweigh the effects of such turmoil?

And, just as importantly, should not older people themselves pause to consider that, currently, most local authorities spend considerably more on their services than the government believes is justified?

Can anyone believe that once the government, via its unelected health service, takes complete control of spending, that it won't impose its financial will without any fear of a democratic backlash?

The association will give close consideration to any further proposals contained within the forthcoming national plan.

But, for all the reasons listed above, directors of social services will find it hard not to believe that this is an ill-judged bid to extend the NHS empire without either giving projects worked on together time to bear fruit, or thinking through carefully all the consequences of taking such precipitate action.

 Jo Williams is president of the Association of Directors of Social Services.

webTitle: Breaking up ain't so hard to do

fields.headline: Breaking up ain't so hard to do
fields.standfirst:
Just who is this telling Microsoft that it has stifled competition?

The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Included free with Windows 2000 will be a computerised edition of the game Monopoly. In this version, Microsoft already owns every property from Old Kent Road to Mayfair and you just go round and round giving the company lots of money. You try to tell yourself it is not fixed, but when Bill Gates wins second prize in a beauty competition you can't help being suspicious.
fields.body:
Included free with Windows 2000 will be a computerised edition of the game Monopoly. In this version, Microsoft already owns every property from Old Kent Road to Mayfair and you just go round and round giving the company lots of money. You try to tell yourself it is not fixed, but when Bill Gates wins second prize in a beauty competition you can't help being suspicious.

For the past two years, in a legal battle more difficult to understand than the Microsoft user's manual, the computer giant has been found guilty of anti-competitive practices and abusing its monopoly power. Considering how aggressively Microsoft has consistently stamped on any competition, its lawyers really should have seen this lawsuit coming, but then this is the company whose computers failed to foresee that the year 2000 would follow 1999, so you can't presume anything.

Now an American judge has ordered Gates to spell out, in detail, how he is going to break up his company - which should be interesting. After four hours the judge will stop him and say: "Sorry, just going back a bit there, can you explain what a mouse-mat is again?"

Since losing the case Bill Gates has seen his personal wealth drop by around $25bn, so he has had to postpone the loft conversion that he and his wife had been saving up for. Internet Explorer will probably no longer be given free with Windows, which means that the poor customer will end up having to pay more to look at hardcore pornography and white supremacist sites. It is of course true that Microsoft has stifled competition, but just a moment . . . who is it that is saying that this sort of behaviour is unacceptable? The United States government! This would be like Gates telling Clinton he's a bit nerdy. There are a number of monopolies in this world but the US has a monopoly of all of them.

Of course, this case is not really about free trade. It is a battle between the world's most powerful country and the world's most powerful company. It is the first flashpoint in the new cold war between nation states and corporations. More battles between the giants will follow; Japan versus Sony, Korea versus Daewoo, Britain versus Top Shop. America won the first cold war on behalf of capitalism. And what thanks do they get? Capitalism then proceeds to push America aside and the next struggle ensues.

Gates should now hit back by counter-suing the US for operating anti-competitive practices. He would have a very good case. As a government, the US has consistently stifled free trade. Tiny independent operators like Cuba and Nicaragua have been virtually forced out of business and all sorts of international laws broken in the process.

With the kind of breath- taking arrogance that you only get from the leaders of world superpowers and 17-year-old public school boys, America actually attempted to make it illegal for European countries to trade with Cuba; the case against America is even greater than the one against its richest citizen. Like Microsoft the US has a variety of operating systems; in the Balkans they used Nato, but the World Trade Organisation, the World Bank and even the United Nations itself have all been called into play at various times. This will probably be the last European football championship in which a team from Europe is allowed to win.

Any fair-minded judge would have to agree that like Microsoft, the US has abused its monopoly of power and must therefore be broken up. It has refused to operate a level playing field and so must be separated into its constituent parts. Dividing it between north and south is one option, but this was tried before apparently, and caused all sorts of problems. You could split it between Democrats and Republicans or Pepsi and Coke drinkers or between the pro- and anti-gun lobby, though this might be a bit unfair if another civil war broke out. But the American courts have ruled that monopolies should not be allowed to dominate and so the US must be as good as its word. If Microsoft Windows is not allowed to give you free bundled software, then each Americanised country should not automatically get a McDonald's in every high street and Jerry Springer repeats on their TV channels.

There must be a way of dividing America up so that we continue to get Seinfeld and ER, but are not compelled to get the rest of the American culture that is bundled in with it. Can we have the films without having to watch the speeches at the Oscars? Can we have the music without the graffiti on our subways? The break up of America will be such a complex job that somebody will have to design a computer programme to do it. If only Microsoft hadn't been fragmented. It probably had a free programme on Windows 2000 that could have done it all for us.

webTitle: Hillsborough survivor tells of his fight

fields.headline: Hillsborough survivor tells of his fight
fields.trailText:
A survivor of the Hillsborough disaster told a court today how
he fought for his life in the packed pens where 96 people were
crushed to death.
fields.body:
A survivor of the Hillsborough disaster told a court today how he fought for his life in the packed pens where 96 people were crushed to death.

Lifelong Liverpool fan Colin Moneypenny described how he was swept off his feet as he walked down a tunnel at Sheffield Wednesday's ground with hundreds of fans who flooded in before the 1989 FA Cup Semi-Final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest.

Mr Moneypenny, who was giving evidence at the manslaughter trial of former senior South Yorkshire police officers David Duckenfield and Bernard Murray, described the scene at the ground as "complete and utter chaos".

He told the jury at Leeds Crown Court that he went through a gate which was opened on the orders of Duckenfield to release pressure on the turnstiles eight minutes before kick-off.

He said that as he walked down the tunnel the gradient, plus the "sheer numbers" of people, led to him being "literally carried off my feet for 30 to 40ft".

Mr Moneypenny was carried to within 10ft of the perimeter fence at the front of Pen Three, where most of the victims died.

"I had no choice about staying in that position for the next 15 minutes," he said.

"I was fighting for my life, but I was dimly aware a football match had started."

Former chief superintendent Duckenfield, 55, who was match commander on the day, and former superintendent Murray, 58, one of his assistants, deny the manslaughter of John Anderson and James Aspinall at Hillsborough stadium on April 15, 1989.

They have also denied wilfully neglecting to carry out a public duty.

Alun Jones, QC, prosecuting on behalf of the Hillsborough family support group, said the tragedy occurred because Duckenfield ordered the opening of Gate C, allowing thousands of fans to flood down the tunnel into the pens, instead of taking the "simple and obvious" step of blocking off the tunnel.

Mr Jones stressed that the defendants' "critical omission" was not a spur of the moment decision, but took place over a period of 20 minutes.

"The prosecution doesn't have to prove exactly what was in the mind of these defendants," he said. "Was it they were simply indifferent and failed to give any thought to an obvious risk?

"These defendants appear to have regarded the spectators not as a group of individual, vulnerable men women and children, but a security problem."

He said Hillsborough was an "old, shabby, badly arranged and confusing" ground, but added: "Whatever the other causes, we say the primary and immediate cause of this was the failure to close the tunnel when the order to open the gates was given. "This, we say, amounts to manslaughter."

Earlier, members of the victims' families had wept as they watched a video film of the events leading up to the disaster. Film shot from police and club cameras showed the build-up of fans outside the ground and the moment when the gate was opened.

Other BBC footage showed the moment when supporters surged on to the crowded terrace.

Mr Jones told the jury that neither defendant had done anything to stop the game until 3.06pm when another superintendent had run on to the pitch on his own initiative.

He said that by then people in some distress had already been seen climbing out of the pens.

Around 20 witnesses who were in the ground would be called to give evidence, he said.

webTitle: Hirst generation missing from Turner prize 2000 shortlist

fields.headline: Hirst generation missing from Turner prize 2000 shortlist
fields.trailText: This year's Turner prize shortlist was announced today, signalling an end to the domination of the UK art world by the so-called Young British Artists typified by Damien Hirst.
fields.body:
This year's Turner prize shortlist was announced today, signalling an end to the domination of the UK art world by the so-called Young British Artists typified by Damien Hirst.

Art traditionalists will be comforted by today's nominations, with two painters included on the four-strong shortlist.

The only British-born nominee is Glenn Brown, 34, from Hexham, Northumberland. He is known for taking the works of others and reproducing them with an original twist - which could involve heightening their colours, or adding or subtracting details.

The other nominees include Michael Raedecker, from Amsterdam, whose paintings use thread and wool along with thick layers of paint, giving a three-dimensional quality to his work.

Tomoko Takahashi, from Tokyo, was also nominated. She is best known for her room installations, often consisting of discarded office junk, although her recent exhibition Word Perhect was web-based.

Completing the shortlist is the German-born photographer Wolfgang Tillmans, who documents contemporary life and whose spreads have been featured in magazines such as i-D and Interview.

The director of the Tate, Nicholas Serota, who is chairman of the Turner prize jury, pointed out that the shortlist signalled a move away from the generation of Young British Artists who had dominated the art scene since the early 1990s.

The winner of the prize will get £20,000 when the announcement is made at the Tate Britain gallery on Millbank, central London, on November 28. Work by the shortlisted artists will be exhibited at the gallery from October 25 to January 14.

The annual display has seen visitor numbers rise dramatically over the past few years. In 1996 56,000 saw the Tate exhibition, while last year's show drew 140,000 people. The event is again supported by Channel 4.

Mr Serota denied that British artists' exclusion from the list meant that they were not "up to scratch". "I think it's a question of recognising that the culture here is much richer than we could define by those who have simply been born in this country," he said.

He said that it was timely to include so many non-Britons "at a time when there is a great deal of public discussion about the contribution that economic and other migrants make to this country".

Mr Serota said artists such as Frank Auerbach and German-born Lucian Freud were not British-born but they had "contributed to ideas of what it means to be British and what it means to be part of this culture and society". He saw no reason why an artist such as the Italian Canaletto might not have been eligible for the Turner had he been around today because of the period he spent working in Britain.

fields.headline: Cannabis helps keep fans calm
fields.trailText: Dutch authorities yesterday revealed the secret behind the successful security operation for England's opening Euro 2000 match against Portugal - a combination of a quiet word, happy music and cannabis.
fields.body:
Dutch authorities yesterday revealed the secret behind the successful security operation for England's opening Euro 2000 match against Portugal - a combination of a quiet word, happy music and cannabis.

Despite the fallout between England fans and players following the 3-2 defeat there were no reports of any trouble outside the ground. Only five fans were arrested, all of them for minor offences, and not a single fan was arrested after the match.

England's disappointment on the field has been offset by temporary joy off it following one of the most peaceful matches involving its fans for over a decade, winning them rare praise from the police and city officials for good behaviour.

Johann Beelan, Eindhoven police spokesman, yesterday revealed the tactics that helped ensure peace in the city. He said police officers had toured the city with a list of names and photographs of known hooligans whom British authorities could not prevent from travelling to the Netherlands. The officers simply had a quiet word with them.

Around 100 known hooligans arrived in Eindhoven for the match.

"We told them that we were watching them and that we know who they are," a triumphant Mr Beelan said.

"We warned them they would be arrested and that they were being singled out for special attention. They were monitored throughout the day and even the hooligans told us that they would not create any trouble. They are probably saving themselves for this Saturday's match against Germany."

Police also claimed that the availability of cannabis in the Netherlands probably helped to defuse any violence. Scores of ticketless England fans gathered in coffee shops in Eindhoven, where cannabis is sold and smoked, to watch the game, greeting the defeat with mild disappointment and unusually, gentle applause. "It (cannabis) may have helped relax them," Mr Beelan added. "Even the hooligans enjoyed the party - and they told our officers. There were lots of things for fans to do and everybody had a good time."

The quiet word from the law was coupled with happy pop music, which blared out across the city in the run-up to last night's game in a deliberate ploy to pacify fans. The music drowned out many of the aggressive chants by England fans which often precede violence. Marieke Van Hoof of Eindhoven city council said: "We have found that playing loud happy pop music helps to calm people down and prevents them from gathering under constant chanting."

The decision to sell weak beer in the city centre also contributed to the peace, officials said. About 15,000 England fans were in Eindhoven, but nearly all left after the match or stayed in their hotels.

Police said almost three years of planning went into the security operation, which cost just over £650,000. More than 2,000 officers were on duty.

Belgian police officials were also in Eindhoven to witness the successful police operation and will be working closely with their Dutch counterparts for England's next match against Germany in Charleroi.

"It (cannabis) may have helped relax them," Mr Beelan added. "Even the hooligans enjoyed the party - and they told our officers. There were lots of things for fans to do and everybody had a good time." The quiet word from the law was coupled with happy pop music, which blared out across the city in the run-up to last night's game in a deliberate ploy to pacify fans. The music drowned out many of the aggressive chants by England fans which often precede violence. Marieke Van Hoof of Eindhoven city council said: "We have found that playing loud happy pop music helps to calm people down and prevents them from gathering under constant chanting." The decision to sell weak beer in the city centre also contributed to the peace, officials said. About 15,000 England fans were in Eindhoven, but nearly all left after the match or stayed in their hotels. Police said almost three years of planning went into the security operation, which cost just over £650,000. More than 2,000 officers were on duty. Belgian police officials were also in Eindhoven to witness the successful police operation and will be working closely with their Dutch counterparts for England's next match against Germany in Charleroi.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the latest transfer talk boiled in a bag and eaten with a nice knob of butter
fields.trailText: Everton want to end Chris Sutton's Chelsea nightmare, reports the Mail. They say that Walter Smith has already had a £5m bid turned down - but claim Chelsea will sell if Everton up their offer to £6m.
fields.body:
Everton want to end Chris Sutton's Chelsea nightmare, reports the Mail. They say that Walter Smith has already had a £5m bid turned down - but claim Chelsea will sell if Everton up their offer to £6m.

However, Teamtalk believe Aston Villa are the team most interested in Sutton - and predicts that John Gregory will tempt Chelsea with a straight swap deal: Gareth Southgate for Sutton.

Another player who could be on his way to London is Roberto Baggio. He's told his advisors that he wants to play in the Premiership and could join Chelsea or Arsenal on a free transfer, reports the Mirror. One stumbling block could be his £50,000-a-week wages.

But that's nothing compared to the £80,000-a-week Fiorentina have offered Portuguese midfielder Joao Pinto if he signs on a free transfer from Benfica.

Marcel Desailly has told Chelsea he wants a two-year extension to his existing deal - or he will seek a transfer. Manchester United, Lazio, Real Madrid and Marseille are all hovering in the wings, claims Teamtalk.

Rangers chairman David Murray has confirmed that Peter Reid is interested in signing Lorenzo Amoruso. Murray said: "We had serious negotiations with Sunderland and I left it with him. If the player is happy to go there then fine, if he's not then it's not a problem."

Newcastle have set their eyes on Argentinian striker Carlos Daniel Cordone. The 26-year-old currently plays for Racing Club Argentina and would cost around £2m.

webTitle: Comment: Turner shortlist resists shock of the new

fields.headline: Turner shortlist resists shock of the new
fields.standfirst: This year's list of nominees is lamentably un-sensationalist
fields.trailText: The Turner prize 2000 shortlist is decidedly un-sensationalist, laments Guardian art critic Jonathan Jones.
fields.body:
Since the opening of Tate Modern, an eerie hush has descended on the old Tate, as we are not supposed to call it.

But the museum has one big chance to pull the crowds back - it's the home of the Turner prize. So staff must be dejected at the announcement of a shortlist that is unlikely to spark tabloid controversy.

I can't see it provoking much excitement in the art world, either. None of the four artists - Michael Raedecker, Tomoko Takahashi, Wolfgang Tillmans and Glenn Brown - are anything other than established, fashionable figures in contemporary art, including three who are not British-born but live and work in London.

They're artists who do all the right things, who have very nice careers, thanks. But are any of them more than that?

Only Brown, a painter who appropriates the brushing styles and subject matter of other artists including Salvador Dali, Frank Auerbach and Arnold B?cklin, is likely to disturb anyone. He's an artist who questions the premise of originality on which an art prize rests - who is the artist, Brown or Auerbach?

Not the sort of controversy that's likely to get in the Sun, though, is it? More a heated debate in Prospect.

If there is a sensational aspect to this year's shortlist, it's the revelation that Charles Saatchi is still a very powerful man in the world of art. When Saatchi unveiled his Neurotic Realism exhibition last year, everybody laughed. But here's the show's star, Tomoko Takahashi, shortlisted for the Turner. Her sprawling assemblages of disgorged electronic circuits, toys, tools and wiring are exercises in organised chaos with an all-too-easy appeal. Hats off to Mr Saatchi for showing those critics.

Michael Raedecker featured among Saatchi's Neurotic Realists too. He's a painter who has returned to pre-modernist ideas of picture-making on canvases that depict landscapes and portraits. The twist is, he uses shiny thread stretched across the rough surfaces of his paintings and piled up to make clumps of vegetation. Raedecker's intriguing but not earth-shattering art has been over-promoted, and having won the conservative John Moores prize, he's too respectable to be an interesting Turner candidate.

Wolfgang Tillmans is one of those photographers you know are artists rather than photojournalists because their pictures are so studiously vacant. Tillmans takes pictures of everything from Concorde to the side of a house to a plate of food and pins them unframed to the wall, or publishes them in fashion magazines. His art pushes lots of buttons about the recent history of photography, and to his admirers he's an all-seeing Warholian recorder of his time. He'll probably win.

webTitle: Germany on verge of ditching nuclear power

fields.headline: Germany on verge of ditching nuclear power
fields.trailText: Germany is due to clinch a deal later today which aims to close down its 19 nuclear power plants. If it succeeds it will be the first major industrial nation to commit itself to withdrawing from nuclear energy, with incalculable implications for the rest of western Europe.
fields.body:
Germany is due to clinch a deal later today which aims to close down its 19 nuclear power plants. If it succeeds it will be the first major industrial nation to commit itself to withdrawing from nuclear energy, with incalculable implications for the rest of western Europe.

Talks were due to start late in the evening between chancellor Gerhard Schröder's government and the German energy industry.

The proposed closure of the 19 reactors, which cover around a third of the country's electricity needs, was driven by political realities for Chancellor Schröder. The Greens, the junior partner in his coalition had made it a key pledge in their manifesto.

But today's talks will not necessarily solve the Chancellor's political problems. The plans under discussion do not answer the Greens' original call for an immediate pull-out. The 18-month-long negotiations have instead centred on allowing a total 30-35 years' average working life for the reactors. Sources close to the talks expect a compromise which would see the country's last reactor shut down in the late 2020s.

The energy sector - which includes the country's four top nuclear providers, Veba, Viag, RWE and Energie Badenwuerttemberg - has pushed for a longer timeframe.

Government officials said the two hours of talks were scheduled on the basis that there was a good chance of agreement.

"We are working on the assumption that we will be successful," said an economics ministry spokeswoman. Industry officials have also expressed optimism, albeit more cautiously. The sticking-point is expected to be how long the move away from nuclear power should take.

The issue of nuclear power divides the country geographically as well as politically. The tension is acute enough for some Greens to have called for a break-up of the coalition if the exit from nuclear power is not swift enough. They have been dismayed by Schröder's insistence that the move be carried out in consensus with the energy industry to avoid potential compensation claims.

Opinion polls have suggested that many Germans supports the move. Over the years the issue has prompted pitched battles between police and protesters trying to stop nuclear waste shipments around the country.

But opposition conservatives, who rule the southern states where many of the job-providing reactors are located, say they will reverse the move if they get back into power.

The largest northern states where many of the main waste depots are situated are ruled by pro-government politicians who back the withdrawal.

There are also concerns over what Germany will replace the lost energy with. Environment-friendly "renewable energy" forms are the Greens' preferred option - but would involve huge investment.

Merely increasing the share of carbon-based fuel forms would, some argue, put Germany at risk of breaking international commitments to reduce emissions of globe-warming greenhouse gases. Purchasing electricity from elsewhere, on the other hand, would involve the dilemma of buying power possibly generated from nuclear plants in other countries.

fields.headline: Talks with Fiji rebels reopen
fields.standfirst: Red Cross allowed to inspect hostages, but differences remain
fields.trailText: Fiji's military rulers said today that negotiations were back on track with the rebels holding 31 political hostages, although there was no breakthrough on their release.
fields.body:
Fiji's military rulers said today that negotiations were back on track with the rebels holding 31 political hostages, although there was no breakthrough on their release.

Despite the military announcement, the martial law regime of Commodore Frank Bainimarama and attempted coup leader George Speight appeared as divided as ever over the makeup of Fiji's next government, a key sticking point preventing the hostages release.

Mr Speight, whose hostages include deposed prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry, renewed demands for Fiji's influential tribal chiefs to appoint a civilian government potentially including the coup leader, while Commodore Bainimarama insisted that he would name his own civilian administration without Mr Speight by the end of the week.

Mr Speight issued a new list of demands today, including that all members of his gang be granted amnesty from the storming of parliament 27 days ago to the day the hostages are released. But he also announced he would allow the international Red Cross to resume visits to his hostages, who are being held in the parliament in the capital Suva.

Since Monday, when soldiers opened fire at Mr Speight's car when it failed to stop at a roadblock, the rebel leader has refused to leave the parliamentary compound where he is holding the hostages.

One possible mediator for new talks is former vice-president Ratu Josefa Iloilo, whose assistant met Mr Speight Wednesday before Mr Iloilo held a meeting with Commodore Bainimarama. Afterwards it was suggested that the military may have shifted ground on one of Mr Speight's demands - widening an amnesty to include supporters from outside his hard-core group.

Commodore Bainimarama had previously offered Speight and a core group of six supporters amnesty if they surrender their weapons and release the hostages, but insists that all other criminal acts will be investigated by police. The amnesty offer now applies to all those within parliament, although it does not apply to crimes committed outside the grounds.

Since storming parliament with a gang of armed men on May 19, Mr Speight has been holding Mr Chaudhry and 30 other members of parliament captive.

He claims he is acting on behalf of Fiji's indigenous majority in his fight for a new government that discriminates against the ethnic Indian minority by denying it political power. Mr Chaudhry became Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister last year.

Commodore Bainimarama seized control of Fiji and imposed martial law on May 29 after a mob from parliament rampaged through the capital, Suva, killing a policeman and trashing a television station. Several houses near parliament have been ransacked and people robbed in other attacks.

The army also warned the public against driving close to parliament after three cars were hijacked by a mob believed to be Mr Speight's supporters. One of the drivers was hospitalised after being attacked in the latest outburst of violence near the compound.

fields.headline: Criminals' assets to be confiscated
fields.standfirst:
Liberty
National criminal intelligence service
fields.trailText: Controversial plans to seize the assets of criminals who escape conviction were unveiled today by home secretary Jack Straw.
fields.body:
Controversial plans to seize the assets of criminals who escape conviction were unveiled today by home secretary Jack Straw.

Financial experts will work with the intelligence services to target previously untouchable "crime barons living the life of Riley" on their ill-gotten gains, Mr Straw said.

The proposals were condemned by civil rights campaigners but welcomed by the police. The move would allow them to crack down on some of the 39 master criminals whose rackets have earned them £200m or more, a spokesman said.

Mr Straw said that the genuinely innocent would be safe and that the new powers would not deter officers from seeking convictions.

"What we are not proposing is for the agency to go on fishing expeditions, saying that person looks rich, where is the money coming from? That would be a gross invasion of privacy," he said.

"We have very substantial intelligence available about these individuals and we will make sure it works fairly."

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, warned that innocent people could end up falling foul of the new laws. "These proposals undermine the presumption of innocence," he said.

John Abbott, head of the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS), said the powers were needed to combat organised crime. "We must not lose sight of the fact that some major criminals distance themselves quite significantly from the action," he said. The new laws, similar to schemes already operating in the United States, Australia and Ireland, will allow the authorities to go after the assets of previously convicted criminals and those jailed abroad.

The home secretary also announced plans to tax out of business the "untouchables" who have proved impossible to convict.

NCIS estimates that organised crime costs the UK £18bn a year, 2% of GDP.

fields.headline: No 6: Adrian Mutu
fields.trailText: Status: "Romania's answer to David Beckham," claims the Mirror. "Romania's secret weapon" if you believe us.
fields.body:
Status: "Romania's answer to David Beckham," claims the Mirror. "Romania's secret weapon" if you believe us.

Stuff what you think, tell us why he's so similar to England's no.7Well, he is always on his mobile phone, loves driving fast cars, and - according to the Mirror's Jane Ridley - he even "has nifty skills to go along with his designer stubble.' But incredibly the similarities with Becks don't end there. Mutu's "even got his own Posh - he's been dating TV presenter Alexandra Dimu, a household name in Romania for two months."

Well I never! And like Becks, I'm sure he never plays away from homeOh you're so naïve. Mutu recently caused a scandal in Romania when an American model claimed he was two-timing her with his TV presenter girlfriend.

I suppose the model told Mutu not to mess with her toot toot? Look, this isn't OK magazine. Do you want to hear about his footballing exploits or not?

Go on then. I suppose it's another Romanian rags-to-riches taleIt certainly is. A year ago Mutu was trying to break his way into the Dinamo Bucharest first team - but a whirlwind season saw him score 18 goals in 20 games for Dinamo, which earned him a transfer to Serie A giants Inter Milan in January.

How has he performed there? On the pitch he's only scored only two goals in 14 appearances - and those were in the Italian Cup - but he seems to have made a good impression off it. During his first press conference at Inter for instance, he spoke Italian, and when he was asked about the restrictions on non-EU players, he just laughed and said: "I'm sure there's an Italian girl who can sort this out for me."

What a charmer! More like a big-head who is constantly talking about how he turned down a lucrative film contract to join Inter, reckons Jane.

But if he's that good why isn't he in the Romanian team? You're forgetting about the likes of Adrian 'The Cobra' Illie and Fenerbahce's Viorel Moldovan, aren't you?

Hang on a second! Isn't Ilie in Valencia's reserves and Moldovan a Coventry City reject who missed an open goal against the Germans? You've got a point. But it's worth remembering that Mutu only made his international debut in March against Greece and is still a relative newcomer.

So what are his chances of making an impression at Euro 2000? Good (ish). "Romania's senior players like Hagi, Popescu and Petruscu are known to wield huge power inside the team and crucially Mutu appears to have earned the respect of the 'golden generation'" claims Reuters man Simon Evans. But if you believe Ms Ridley, there are "tensions simmering under the surface" between young players like Mutu (think God's gift) and the sterner old guard.

What Mutu says in public: "It is a good feeling to play for Romania and to be here alongside great players like Hagi and Popescu. I feel a part of this squad but it is a matter for the coach whether I am in the starting 11 or not."

What he thinks in private: Move over Granddads, it's time for the new generation to take over.

Not to be confused with: Tom Cruise, David Beckham, Gheorgi Hagi.

webTitle: Slovenia hit by three goals in six minutes

fields.headline: Slovenia hit by three goals in six minutes
fields.trailText: In the most dramatic tie of the tournament so far, a 10-man Yugoslavia staged a comeback of heroic proportions even if the players are only heroes in their own country.
fields.body:
In the most dramatic tie of the tournament so far, a 10-man Yugoslavia staged a comeback of heroic proportions even if the players are only heroes in their own country.

Having seen the upstarts from Slovenia take a 3-0 lead, the Yugoslavs shrugged off the loss of Sinisa Mihajlovic to a red card and hit back with three goals in six second-half minutes to save face and rescue a point.

The controversial stadium where England play Germany on Saturday was only half full for this meeting, so the temporary skyscraper stand was not given a full test. As they will be on Saturday, the rival fans were situated at either end of this compact ground, the Slovenes slightly outnumbering the Yugoslavs.

Their joy at being in the finals of a major tournament for the first time was obvious. To be meeting the country from which they gained their independence in 1991 was a bonus; to take the lead after 22 minutes, a dream.

Slovenia's captain Zlatko Zahovic promised beforehand that the players would be "exhausting every atom throughout the 90 minutes".

His side piled forward from the kick-off, busy on and off the ball, desperate to make the best impression on their first outing at this level as they came at Yugoslaia down either wing.

Yugoslavia's first scare came after just three minutes when Zeljko Milinovic drove a 20-yard free-kick only inches wide.

Then came the Slovenia goal. Amir Karic swung in a tempting ball from the left and Zahovic, stealing a yard on his marker, stooped low to head the ball past a surprised Ivica Kralj. No wonder Tottenham are interested in him.

Eleven minutes later, Slovenia nearly extended their lead. Saso Udovic threaded a brilliant pass forward which split the Yugoslav defence and found Zahovic with only the keeper to beat. However the captain hit his shot too close to the advancing Kralj, who was able to block it much to the relief of his team-mates.

fields.headline: Iversen sinks aimless Armada
fields.standfirst: Spurs' striker and sturdy defence the key as Norway stifle Spain
fields.trailText: Norwegian commentators stopped short of announcing "Salvador Dali, General Franco, your boys took one hell of a beating". But then, Spain being Spain, it was difficult to know whether this really constituted a significant shock.
fields.body:
Norwegian commentators stopped short of announcing "Salvador Dali, General Franco, your boys took one hell of a beating". But then, Spain being Spain, it was difficult to know whether this really constituted a significant shock.

When Jose Camacho found his side touted as favourites before the tournament he was having none of it. "I would remind everyone," he said, "that Spain aren't great achievers in international football." Yesterday his players wasted no time in proving his point, their lavish talent punctured on the horns of Viking discipline.

A Steffen Iversen header midway through the second half was enough to give Norway a victory which confirmed that, if Spain are the world's great under-achievers, they belong at the other end of the scale. This scalp will sit happily beside that of Brazil from the last World Cup. A team containing seven Premiership players showed Kevin Keegan and Co how to go about this defending business.

As Spain trooped off, heads bowed, the familiarity of it all can hardly have escaped them. In France two years ago they were supposedly potential winners. Yet they began by losing to Nigeria, followed that with a goalless draw against Paraguay and beat Bulgaria 6-1 only when it was too late. When the going gets tough the Spanish have a nasty habit of getting going: on the first flight back to Iberia, that is.

Of course they can redeem themselves against Yugoslavia and Slovenia but it will need far greater invention and cutting edge than they showed here. The good news for Camacho is that neither of his next two opponents are likely to match Norway for sheer efficiency and hard work at the back. Erik Mykland was oustanding in midfield, Bjorn Otto Bragstad, who is coveted by Derby, impressed in the centre of defence. But, typically, this was a team effort.

Norway may not be attractive to watch but they are certainly effective. Pulling 10 men behind the ball whenever possible, they squeezed the life out of an increasingly frustrated Spanish side and struck on the counter-attack. Although Spain scored 42 goals in a qualifying group which included San Marino, Israel, Cyprus and Austria the suspicion was that they would struggle to break down tougher opponents. And so it proved.

Their dominance of possession was marked yet they created little. Raul was peripheral, unable to weave his magic. The one opportunity he had he wasted. Without his individuality Spain looked at best neat but uninspired, rarely achieving the width which might have offered their best chance of success.

Through the middle they were consistently suffocated. Norway were happy enough to allow the playmaker Pep Guardiola time in deep positions but once Spain reached the final third they found two great walls of white blocking their way. Unable to turn and constantly harassed, they ended up heading backwards, sideways or nowhere.

Egil Olsen left big wellies to fill but Nils Johan Semb, his successor as coach, has done so more than adequately. Iversen's goal was classic route one but there is more sophistication and neat passing about this Norway side without sacrificing the discipline, unity and selfless running which made them so effective.

"I'm very proud of the performance and the team spirit," Semb said. "It is a big achievement for a small nation like Norway to beat one of the favourites Spain in our first match."

In the first half Ole Gunnar Solskjaer headed against the bar from an Andre Bergdolmo cross and scuffed his shot after spinning on a Vegard Heggem centre. But Spain did have chances.

Joseba Etxeberria went close from long range and Thomas Myhre saved well from a header by the disappointing striker Ismael Urzaiz, who had neither the fleetness of foot nor the aerial strength to pose consistent problems. Raul went close, too, wastefully dragging his shot wide after an error by Henning Berg.

The significance of that miss was emphasised in the 66th minute when Iversen scored. Myhre lofted a free-kick towards the edge of the area and Iversen's flick header drifted over Jose Molina, who had raced rashly off his line.

For all their late pressure Spain came no closer to an equaliser than a near-post Gaizka Mendieta shot which Myhre saved. Yet Camacho resorted to disparaging comments about the Egyptian referee Gamal El Ghandour and insisted his team had suffered from "an enormous slice of bad luck on the counter-attack". An enormous slice of poor goalkeeping, more like.

"It was one of those things," Camacho said. "Sometimes the ball does not want to go in. I'm not worried because we are creating chances and trying to shoot at goal. I said to my players if we play with this attitude we can win our next two games."

Maybe. But with Spain in a major tournament it is always best to expect the unexpected.

fields.headline: About time, too
fields.standfirst: After years of prevarication, the BBC is finally planning a big-budget Dr Who film.  Adam Sweeting asks why it's taken them so long
fields.trailText: After years of prevarication, the BBC is finally planning a big-budget Dr Who film. Adam Sweeting asks why it's taken them so long
fields.body:
In the history of British sci-fi TV, Quatermass might have had more intellectual depth and Doomwatch more topical relevance, but neither of them ever had a hope of matching the longevity and cult appeal of Doctor Who. The sceptical observer might assume that the show's rickety sets, absurd space monsters and rather fey man in a long scarf - all crammed inside a telephone booth, if you will - would be an instant turn-off for anybody born after the end of post-war rationing. But thanks to the fantastic networking capabilities of the internet, new "Whovians" keep breeding like an alien plague.

Endless reruns on cable and satellite TV are already keeping the Doc alive, but it looks like he's due to be born yet again in a new feature film. Since no long-lost episode, morsel of trivia or piece of merchandising memorabilia is too insignificant to merit further investigation, the rumours of a new full-length Doctor Who movie to be made by the BBC have been minutely dissected by the Who cognoscenti.

Long experience has taught top Doc-spotters to treat stories of this kind with extreme caution. However, there seems to be something in the wind, whatever its final shape turns out to be. Stories of a new Who film project appeared in the press during 1999, suggesting it would be directed by Paul Andersen with some nvolvement from distributors Artisan Entertainment. That has apparently bitten the dust, but BBC Films now looks as though it's inching closer to committing itself to its own movie.

Whiskery Beeb supremo Greg Dyke is believed to have waved through a budget allocation of 15 million quid. Casting is rumoured to have been entrusted to Phillip Hinchcliffe, experienced producer of the TV series, while possible directors include John Glen, who has lensed a long list of Bond movies as well as Gerry Anderson's Space Precinct, Sidney J Furie (The Ipcress File and Superman IV), film and TV veteran Michael Apted, and erstwhile pop video director Russell Mulcahy. The smart money, if there is any such thing in cases as nebulous as this, has been placed temporarily on Mulcahy, but may have moved on by the time you read this. While Ephraim Katz's Film Encyclopedia comments acidly that "his background in music videos has been evident in his few less-than-refined feature films", Mulcahy's best-known celluloid excursion remains Highlander, that farcical farrago of a time-travelling immortal Scotsman (confusingly played by French matinee idol Christopher Lambert) engaged in violent hand-to-hand combat with his magical sword on the New York subway. Or something.

Still, we know that Mulcahy has no fear of making himself or his actors look ridiculous - he was also responsible for several Duran Duran videos in the 80s, and apparently has never felt any urge to make a public apology - so from that point of view he may be the perfect man for the job. Cybermen, Daleks, enormous man-eating woodlice and giant brains made of cellophane and lit up with Christmas fairy-lights would hold no terrors for Big Russ. Except that history tells us that series which have become cultish viewing on British television very rarely work on a cinematic scale, whoever is actually in charge.

The recent Hollywoodisations of The Saint and The Avengers are two perfect specimens of the way the wit, whimsy and campness of the originals has evaporated by the time they're uncrated out on the West Coast. And of course if they cast Val Kilmer as the Doctor, it'll be as good as putting Police Line - Do Not Cross tape around every cinema in America on opening weekend. However, Whovians can at least take some comfort from the fact that Val hasn't so far been mentioned in connection with the project. Nor has Paul McGann, who became the eighth Doctor Who when he starred in the less-than-auspicious 1996 Who movie.

On the other hand, grizzled ex-telly gumshoe Tom Selleck has been, although the cyberspies on the Dr Who newspages deem him an unlikely candidate. Meanwhile, some comments made by Russell T Davies, author of the Dr Who novel Damaged Goods as well as of Channel 4's Queer As Folk (which features Vince Tyler, the Manchester supermarket manager who also happens to be a Dr Who fan) have merely clouded the issue further. Davies was rumoured to be involved in writing the new movie, but he denied it in an interview with SFX Magazine. "It's so not true", he confessed. "I wish!" And, according to Davies, Mulcahy wouldn't after all be sitting in the director's chair. He claims it's all a misunderstanding, stemming from the fact that Mulcahy is actually directing the American remake of Queer As Folk. But whatever happens in Hollywood, Who-mania continues to bust out all over.

Russell Davies could conceivably be involved in developing a new TV incarnation of the series, possibly starring Alan "no relation" Davies in the title role, while Radio 4 is preparing a Who project for early next year, featuring Stephen Fry, Sylvester McCoy and Sophie Aldred. Whatever Gordon Brown might think, an old college scarf will never let you down.

fields.headline: Laugh, Bob, laugh!
fields.standfirst: Jamie Rainbow, our man stuck in front of the telly for a month, experiences the laughter of the mad
fields.trailText: The omens for last night's game weren't good, especially for those of you who had suffered Norway's charmless win over Spain earlier in the day. David Pleat, alone among the pundits, seemed happy with the outcome and in particular the performance of Steffen Iversen. Tottenham's Director of Football doesn't get many opportunities to watch one of his players impress at international level, or domestic level for that matter.
fields.body:
The omens for last night's game weren't good, especially for those of you who had suffered Norway's charmless win over Spain earlier in the day. David Pleat, alone among the pundits, seemed happy with the outcome and in particular the performance of Steffen Iversen. Tottenham's Director of Football doesn't get many opportunities to watch one of his players impress at international level, or domestic level for that matter.

Meanwhile, the BBC struggle on manfully with games that even Channel 5 would think twice about showing. Last night however they got an unexpected treat. A remarkable Savo Milosevic-inspired fightback (a novel conjunction I suspect) by Yugoslavia earned them a draw with Slovenia.

You could tell that John Motson was excited. At one point he started laughing - a sure sign that he's approaching footballing nirvana.

Clearly the laughter was contagious. Later, Bob Wilson presenting ITV's graveyard highlight slot, 'spontaneously' burst out laughing whilst trying to pronounce the names of some of the Slovenian players.

Few things seem to come naturally to Bob and laughing is no exception. I'm convinced his agent has encouraged him to try a new, more relaxed style to counteract the Des factor. His autocue probably read: "Giggle ' crease your face up so it look s like you've got no eyes - your natural expression Bob!! - think Des, think ladies man ' giggle and sparkle for the camera." By the way, someone should tell him that laughing at foreign names is so 20th century.

There was an unlikely feature on the news last night showing disappointed England fans shaking hands with Portuguese supporters and wishing them the best for the rest of the tournament. It reminded me of watching footage of policemen dancing with jolly fat black women at the Notting Hill Carnival. I suspect what we were actually seeing was the FA's 2006 World Cup bid promo video.

Sticking with the television theme, That's Life - and how dated that looks - is being re-run at the moment. Last night, the character Egg was recounting a dream in which he'd met Alan Hansen and wanted to be him. The implication being that Hansen was somehow the epitome of cool. See what I mean about the show being dated.

fields.headline: Supermarket will sell organic-only produce
fields.trailText: Supermarket chain Iceland has announced plans to make its entire frozen vegetable range purely organic, at no extra cost to the consumer.
fields.body:
Supermarket chain Iceland has announced plans to make its entire frozen vegetable range purely organic, at no extra cost to the consumer.

The company has bought nearly 40% of the world's organic vegetable crop to meet growing demand among supermarket shoppers.

Iceland's managing director, Russell Ford, said the investment was prompted by a survey suggesting that three out of four customers would prefer to buy organic goods if they were cheaper than current prices. The new scheme will set organic products at the same price as average supermarket own-label products. Frozen organic vegetables will be introduced first.

Organic farming body the Soil Association welcomed the news. The director, Patrick Holden, said: "Iceland have made a bold move today to make organic produce much more available to thousands of consumers who haven't had it before."

Malcolm Walker, chairman of Iceland, said: "At the moment Britain has minimal organic production due to lack of government investment in the organic industry in its formative years. We hope that our investment will help change this."

The move will require an extra annual investment of around £8m by December 2001. Iceland is also investing £1m in the National Trust's farming programme, which works with tenant farmers to develop environmentally responsible practices. At present, only 3% of UK agricultural land is organic and supermarkets are forced to rely on imports to meet the demand. Iceland, which has 760 stores in the UK, was also the first to ban genetically modified ingredients from its own brands.

The supermarket chain's move was welcomed by Liberal Democrat MP Paul Tyler, sponsor of a private member's bill on organic food which is presently before parliament.

But he warned that a flood of organic food into the UK from abroad would undermine environmentalists' efforts to cut pollution from transportation of goods and would make it more difficult to guarantee standards.

Mr Tyler's bill proposes targets of 30% of farmland and 20% of food consumed in the UK to be organic by 2010. He called on the government to encourage expanded organic production by incorporating the proposed measures in his private member's bill into the rural white paper, due for publication next month.

The director, Patrick Holden, said: "Iceland have made a bold move today to make organic produce much more available to thousands of consumers who haven't had it before." Malcolm Walker, chairman of Iceland, said: "At the moment Britain has minimal organic production due to lack of government investment in the organic industry in its formative years. We hope that our investment will help change this." The move will require an extra annual investment of around £8m by December 2001. Iceland is also investing £1m in the National Trust's farming programme, which works with tenant farmers to develop environmentally responsible practices. At present, only 3% of UK agricultural land is organic and supermarkets are forced to rely on imports to meet the demand. Iceland, which has 760 stores in the UK, was also the first to ban genetically modified ingredients from its own brands. The supermarket chain's move was welcomed by Liberal Democrat MP Paul Tyler, sponsor of a private member's bill on organic food which is presently before parliament. But he warned that a flood of organic food into the UK from abroad would undermine environmentalists' efforts to cut pollution from transportation of goods and would make it more difficult to guarantee standards. Mr Tyler's bill proposes targets of 30% of farmland and 20% of food consumed in the UK to be organic by 2010. He called on the government to encourage expanded organic production by incorporating the proposed measures in his private member's bill into the rural white paper, due for publication next month.

fields.headline: India's taxing problem
fields.trailText: India's saviour could be IT. Its much-lauded information technology sector is second only to Silicon Valley and a source of much chest-puffing. But IT, in the cricketing sense, means the Indian income-tax department. And good luck to them: paying taxes, or paying the right amount of tax, is not one of the pillars of South Asian society. Nonetheless, the men from IT are on a crusade and Indian cricketers are quaking. The logic is that if your wealth does not tally with your cricket earnings then you are as good as nabbed - damned as a fixer.
fields.body:
India's saviour could be IT. Its much-lauded information technology sector is second only to Silicon Valley and a source of much chest-puffing. But IT, in the cricketing sense, means the Indian income-tax department. And good luck to them: paying taxes, or paying the right amount of tax, is not one of the pillars of South Asian society. Nonetheless, the men from IT are on a crusade and Indian cricketers are quaking. The logic is that if your wealth does not tally with your cricket earnings then you are as good as nabbed - damned as a fixer.

Navjot Singh Sidhu is reportedly building a house that resembles Windsor Castle, and has the only swimming pool in his home town. He drives a Land Cruiser, the like of which has never purred over Punjabi tarmac. He owns shops and showrooms. Not bad for an average Test cricketer from an average background.

Then there is the intriguing case of Kapil Dev. According to India's The Week, old Paaji owns at least 10 buildings, a studio, an office, a hotel, and, most surprisingly, a timber factory. And don't forget Mohammad Azharuddin, who, like Kapil, has been the target of rumours. He owns some classy property in Mumbai and Hyderabad, has invested heavily in shops and malls, and can choose from about eight flashy cars when he fancies a drive into the old town for a legendary Hyderabadi massala.

Now India's cricketers are to the sub-continent what football stars are to Western Europe. They are at the top of a money pyramid that has a billion willing contributors below them. You would expect them to be filthy rich, wouldn't you?

Even whistleblower-in-chief Prabhakar cannot be given a clean chit. In fact, he is in trouble with the Indian authorities for an alleged scam that has swindled thousands of small investors in Uttar Pradesh and Madya Pradesh out of millions of rupees.

I don't know much about income-tax law in Asia even though, since birth, I have been the director of a Lahore firm of income-tax lawyers. I have never attended a company meeting though a quick glance at the name plate on the Naeem and Co office front in Syed Mauj Darya, or Edward Road as it was known in the days of the Raj, will confirm my position. That type of nepotism (from which, incidentally, I have not benefited) is typical of Asia.

On the occasions that I did sit with my grandfather and uncle it became clear to me that income-tax lawyers saved their clients hoards of money - by any means necessary. Pakistan's military regime is now getting tough with tax evaders, but it is a difficult task blighted by poor record-keeping. IT, it seems, is well ahead of its Pakistani counterparts in having some idea of cricketers' assets.

Investigating the finances of accused players is a useful tool but what India really needs is transparency. At present, leaks from sources within IT or the CBI, and unchecked scandalmongering by players and officials is as transparent as it gets. Qayyum and King have shown that there is nothing like a judicial inquiry to loosen the tongue. Pakistan even used their public disgrace to catalyse a resurgence in form. South Africa, too, are likely to emerge stronger after King's inquest.

That is the real lesson for India. There is no reason for the world's most populace and passionate cricketing nation to be languishing seventh in Wisden's World Test Championship. India's team is imploding in the same way that the Pakistanis did during the height of their controversy. And on-field performance will not improve until India goes the way of Pakistan and South Africa, who have shown that secret inquiries have no future and no confidence. A painful public exorcism is what India needs, and quick.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is editor of the Bulletin of the World Health Organisation. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. To read his previous column, about the Qayyum report, click here. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.

webTitle: Men in drag top funny movies poll

fields.headline: Men in drag top funny movies poll
fields.trailText: The American Film Institute's 100 funniest movies list, published yesterday, puts the classic 1959 Billy Wilder comedy Some Like It Hot at the top, and Sydney Pollack's Tootsie second
fields.body:
Men in drag are the best way to get audiences laughing, or at least it's what the American Film Institute finds funny. The Institute's 100 funniest movies list, published yesterday, puts the classic 1959 Billy Wilder comedy Some Like It Hot at the top, and Sydney Pollack's Tootsie (pictured), which has Dustin Hoffman as a actor who finds soap-opera success masquerading as a woman, at number two.

The list was voted by some 1,800 actors, directors, studio executives, critics and others in the movie industry, who were choosing from a list of 500 nominees compiled by the institute.

It was the organisation's third annual list. Two years ago, the group released their list of 100 best US films, which was topped by Citizen Kane, and last year, the institute ranked their top 50 male and female screen legends, lists headed by Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn respectively.

The highest British-based film was A Fish Called Wanda (number 21). Five of the top ten choices pre-date 1970, and the most recent movie is the 18-year-old Tootsie (1982). The Farrelly Brothers' gross-out comedy There's Something About Mary (1998) was the most recent movie to make the list, charting at no. 27.

 See the complete list here .

fields.headline: Frontier spirit
fields.standfirst: Once seen as bean counters, finance directors are increasingly working at the heart of operations in a rapidly changing world
fields.trailText: Once seen as bean counters, finance directors are increasingly working at the heart of operations in a rapidly changing world.
fields.body:
Public sector finance departments face some dramatic changes over the coming few years. New technology, different structures, greater use of outsourcing and the sharing of key services between different bodies and authorities will all make their mark. All finance staff are likely to have to learn new skills and accept that services will be provided in different ways. And the changes will go all the way to the top. Finance directors in councils, hospitals and other local service bodies will also have to take on new roles.

But as the public sector's most senior finance professionals congregate today in Brighton for the annual conference of the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy (Cipfa), you are unlikely to find many either surprised by or fearful of the future transformation of their territories. For in a world where the only things you can rely on are insufficient funding and constant upheaval, coping with change has become part of the job.

In the NHS the emergence of the private finance initiative as the only serious option for building new hospitals has demanded new skills of finance directors. Now they are thrown into high-level negotiations on multi-million pound deals with consortiums made up of banks, builders and facilities management experts. There are huge legal implications and enormous political pressures to close deals and get new hospitals open. "These are very complex financial arrangements," says Jim Birrell, the director of finance and performance of the NHS executive's north-west regionaloffice. "They are probably as complex as any arrangements in any walk of financial life."

But Birrell, who chairs the NHS executive's national finance staff strategy group, says the private finance initiative is just one of a number of areas where finance directors have had to learn new skills. Clinical negligence, with claims rising steeply, is another. "This is a new area for finance to get involved with," he says. "It just wasn't a big thing a few years ago."

The image of finance departments has also changed. The days of finance directors being seen as mere "bean counters" or the abominable no-men, stamping on innovation wherever they see it, are long gone. Finance is no longer just bolted on to frontline activities, but is an integral part of service delivery. And as this change has come about, finance directors have also broadened their roles into the general management arena.

Only 12% of the nearly 500 finance directors in the NHS now have a portfolio of finance alone. The rest boast a wide range of responsibilities including IT, performance management, primary care, fraud, purchasing, supplies, estates, transport, medical records and clinical coding. There are even finance directors with managerial responsibility for some clinical support services such as pathology.

But further changes will be required of finance directors. Health authorities are slowly relinquishing commissioning responsibilities to the new GP-led primary care groups, which are themselves starting to convert to primary care trust status, adding the provision of community health services to their commissioning role. For health authority finance directors this has meant developing a more strategic role, focusing more on producing health improvement programmes and performance management.

Advancing technology will also cause a major redesign of finance departments. The NHS executive is already examining how routine financial services could be run from a small number of shared service centres, providing initially payroll and accounts payable services to all their local health bodies. Other "back room" services such as human resources and estates could follow.

Although this approach may reduce the size of existing finance departments, Birrell says it is an opportunity, not a threat. "It should allow finance directors to move away from involvement with transactions, concentrate on their core role and emphasise their value-added approach," he says. And although some finance staff will be displaced, Birrell believes they will stay in the NHS, with their skills making them ideally suited for other important areas such as performance management, controls assurance and evidence-based medicine. A discussion paper will be published by the NHS executive this summer laying out a vision of the future finance function in the NHS.

In local government, finance directors with responsibility for just finance are also becoming a rarity. For instance, Sarah Wood, the director of finance and performance review at Birmingham city council, the UK's largest metropolitan council, boasts an impressive array of responsibilities including finance, property, neighbourhood offices and benefits, best value, performance and even press and public relations. And like their colleagues in the NHS, town hall finance directors have also had to learn new skills. They have had to become skilled negotiators, not just because of the private finance initiative, but also because more councils are turning to the private sector to provide services. With outsourcing deals becoming increasingly ambitious, finance directors have had to develop a commercial awareness that in the past was not needed . The continued downward pressure on funding has also forced the council finance director to evolve. "The treasurer now has to look at different avenues for funding," says Brian Smith, the chief executive of Stoke-on-Trent council and current Cipfa president. The single regeneration budget, lottery funds and Europe all have become essential sources of extra cash to support local projects. "This has demanded new attitudes and new skills," he says.

But perhaps best value and the government's modernising agenda present the biggest challenges for town hall finance leaders. According to Smith the requirement under best value to challenge rigorously the orthodoxy of how services are run and how money is spent is central to the role of the modern finance director. With town halls also being encouraged to investigate shared services and partnerships, finance departments could look very different in future. Already the landscape is changing. In April, Lincolnshire county council outsourced virtually its whole finance department, together with personnel, property, catering and IT functions. Nearly 800 staff transferred to Hyder Servies, the managed services arm of the utility company Hyder.

The decision was taken following a review of the council's finance and resources functions and Mark Spink, the council's then director of finance and resources, accepts that he effectively reviewed himself out of a job. "The finance job left in the county council was totally different from my role and so there was no job left for me," he says. He has since transferred to Hyder. The council has retained a basic strategic financial role around setting the framework for budgets, assessing the impact of government grant changes and some specific functions such as treasury management and internal audit. But most commercial activities are now provided outside the council. And Lincolnshire believes other councils will follow its lead. If they do, the future for town hall treasurers could be very different indeed.

webTitle: MPs and MEPs call for tougher cigarette warnings

fields.headline: MPs and MEPs call for tougher cigarette warnings
fields.standfirst: Read the full health select committee report
fields.trailText: Euro parliamentarians are proposing tough new measures to warn people against smoking on the day a committee of MPs called for cigarette packets to carry stronger health warnings - including the message that smoking can damage male potency.
fields.body:
Euro parliamentarians are proposing tough new measures to warn people against smoking on the day a committee of MPs called for cigarette packets to carry stronger health warnings - including the message that smoking can damage male potency.

A report by the all-party House of Commons select committee on health said all packs should state the addictiveness and damage to health caused by smoking, with "harder-hitting and more relevant" messages.

The MPs also urged a Department of Trade and Industry investigation into claims that British American Tobacco has been involved in large scale cigarette smuggling. If accusations of orchestrating, managing and controlling cigarette smuggling in Asia and Latin America in the early 1990s proved correct, the report called for criminal proceedings to be considered.

MEPs were today expected to back new shock tactics against smoking - including putting pictures of rotting teeth on cigarette packets.

MEPs are expected to vote in the European Parliament for a massive increases in the size of health warnings, with reminders of the risks of smoking to cover 40% of the front of every packet and 60% of the back.

They have also proposed a greater use of pictures, including smoke-stained and cigarette-damaged teeth, and young children imitating their cigarette-wielding parents, in addition to the tough new anti-smoking measures recommended by the European commission

EU rules already exist governing health warnings on cigarette packets, advertising, and the tar and nicotine content of cigarettes, but they currently only require health warnings on 4% of the surface of cigarette packets.

The UK government goes further, obliging companies to "advertise" the health dangers on 6% of the packet's surface. In contrast, Canada has already made health warnings compulsory on 90% of the surface of a cigarette pack and is expected to introduce shock pictures on packets by the end of the year.

MEPs are calling for the warnings to be printed only in black on a white background to give them more impact, instead of the present system which requires only "contrasting colours" on packets.

They are also demanding a new maximum tar content of 10 milligrammes per cigarette, with EU ceilings of one milligramme for nicotine strength and 10 milligrammes for carbon monoxide content.

But the latest assault on smoking is fiercely opposed by the tobacco lobby and the new demands will have to be approved by EU ministers after today's parliamentary vote.

The tobacco industry is fighting to limit the spread of health warnings to no more than 10% of the packet surface. It also challenges black-on-white labelling as unnecessary interference in existing pack designs.

It has warned that imposing the new health measures on exports will put a £4 billion industry at risk, threatening 8,000 jobs and encouraging a shift of manufacturing capacity to countries outside the EU.
