fields.headline: One nation united in hate
fields.standfirst: England fans never forget club loyalties for long - and then the abuse starts
fields.trailText: England fans never forget club loyalties for long - and then the abuse starts.
fields.body:
For the handful of England fans left in Eindhoven yesterday, disappointment combined with a dreaded feeling of deja vu; another defeat in a major tournament followed by another controversial David Beckham incident.

Despite two wonderful crosses, it was the United star's single finger that added bitterness to defeat among English football's various tribes who had gathered in the city for Monday night's match.

Even though most of them had not seen it, by yesterday they had all heard about it -news travels fast when it comes to Beckham. A tenuous bond holds the England football family together and for the masses that follow the national team, club and country sometimes collide particularly when things go wrong.

Midway through the second half of Monday night's match a small group began singing "Stand up if you hate Man U," and initially tried singling out Gary Neville, Beckham's best friend for abuse. Jeers were soon drowned out by chants of "Ingerland, Ingerland," but the insult was obviously not lost on the United duo.

"There were a lot of Scousers at the match and they were giving Neville and then Beckham a hard time," said Tony Armstrong, a Chelsea fan from Kent. "I thought he [Beckham] played really well. He put in two wicked crosses and it led to two wicked goals so I couldn't understand why some of the fans were having a go at him. I'm here for England, we should all stick together and get behind the team."

But, Armstrong confessed, when Beckham comes to Stamford Bridge it is a different story with country playing substitute to club. "I give him a caning," he said. "I always have a go at him. I mean, he prances around in a skirt, what do you bloody expect and he plays for Manchester United."

"I don't think it's right though that some fans single him out," said Joe, a Bristol Rovers fan. "It used to be John Barnes and now it's Beckham."

A carpet of England flags covered Eindhoven's market square in the run-up to the match with virtually every team in the four divisions represented in what has become one of the most visible rituals of the team's following wherever they have gone in recent years - a cross of St George with the name of your club emblazoned across it, provid ing a vivid demonstration of club and country loyalty.

But does club start to come before country when things go wrong, as happened on Monday night?

"Of course we all have different teams," said Mark, an Aston Villa fan who was mingling with some Nottingham Forest, Bristol Rovers and Reading fans. "I never heard Beckham getting any abuse when I was in the stadium but a lot of the Sunderland fans were giving Shearer a hard time."Everyone picks on him and I feel quite sorry for the bloke but a lot of the time he just brings it upon himself. I think this time we should just leave him alone. He had enough stick after the Argentina game so it would be unfair to start all that again."

Beckham however is not alone, although few England players have faced as much personal abuse as him.

Tottenham fans confess that they greet Arsenal players rep resenting England with mild applause while John Barnes was hardly a favourite with many England fans, although race had as much a factor in that as the Liverpool connection.Sunderland fans in Eindhoven were bitterly complaining that their man Phillips should have been leading the England line. "It's got nothing to do with Shearer playing for Newcastle, although obviously that doesn't help," protested David.

"He was getting a fair bit of stick yesterday from us and lots of other England fans but that's because he was crap. Most England fans get on pretty well and it doesn't matter which club you follow. I've met loads of different lads and had a drink with them, even some Newcastle fans."

Like fans from any club team, when things go wrong England's followers are only too willing to let the players and manager know how they feel and the bitter disappointment of surrendering a two-goal lead on Monday night probably had as much to do with the boos and jeers as Beckham's current position as the nation's favourite scapegoat.

"The fans were really disappointed and it's only just sinking in now," said Adrian Morris a Charlton Athletic fan.

"People become frustrated and want to take it out on the players. What's wrong with that? The same would happen at some clubs it just so happens that some England fans want to take it out on Beckham."

Despite the visible manifes tation of club loyalty, England fans are probably just as united as most other national teams, if not more so.

Cardiff and Swansea fans have been known to clash when Wales. Fans from the Argentine teams Boca Juniors and River Plate, for example, always watch their country play at home in separate areas of the stadium. But if you are feeling sorry for England's diverse tribes, then spare a thought for Feyenoord fans currently enduring Euro 2000.

"It's got nothing to do with us because the Holland team is controlled by Ajax," said John Hoogerwaard a Feyenoord fanatic and Dutch journalist who was covering the presence of England fans in Eindhoven. "We don't like cheering for the Holland team because Ajax has never given our players a chance to play in it."

fields.headline: Odds fellow
fields.trailText: Italy 's 2-1 victory over Turkey in their opening game has had little effect on their overall odds. Dino Zoff's men, who were lucky to be awarded a penalty, can still be backed at 7-1 with the Tote and Stan James to win the competition .
fields.body:
Italy 's 2-1 victory over Turkey in their opening game has had little effect on their overall odds. Dino Zoff's men, who were lucky to be awarded a penalty, can still be backed at 7-1 with the Tote and Stan James to win the competition .

Belgium , their opponents in tonight's Group B game, are now a top-priced 16-1 with Coral. With home advantage this evening they might just upset the Italians at Victor Chandler's quote of 11-5, compared with 7-4 with Ladbrokes. Italy are 6-4 with Hill and the draw is a best-priced 2-1 with Stanley.

Elsewhere, Monday's result in Eindhoven was a hugely profitable one for the bookmakers. Chandler laid England "to lose fortunes" and has cut Portugal from 16-1 to 10-1 to win the tournament , but Humberto Coelho's team are still on offer at 12-1 with Coral. Portugal, now odds-on in places to win Group A, are worth backing at Coral's marginally more generous price of evens.

England , out to 9-4 to reach the quarter-finals with Surrey, are 1-3 not to qualify with the same firm. But there has been little change to the odds on Saturday night's game with Germany. Kevin Keegan's side are still 6-4 generally, the Germans are 9-5 with Stanley and Ladbrokes offers 15-8 the draw.

The world champions France are the new outright competition favourites at 3-1 with Chandler and Surrey.

Sporting, which awards 50 points to losing semi-finalists on its 100 Index, has bumped up Portugal's quote from 18-21 to 33-36. The Portuguese could still reward a buy at the higher figure; they would be fancied to beat any Group B rival in a quarter-final.

webTitle: Keegan describes Beckham abuse as 'worst I've ever heard'

fields.headline: Keegan describes Beckham abuse as 'worst I've ever heard'
fields.trailText: England players were subjected to what Kevin Keegan described as the "worst abuse I've ever heard" after Monday's defeat by Portugal.
fields.body:
England players were subjected to what Kevin Keegan described as the "worst abuse I've ever heard" after Monday's defeat by Portugal.

Moments earlier David Beckham made a gesture with one finger after he had applauded the bulk of England fans from the centre of the pitch. It appeared to be directed at a small group who had either been barracking him during the game or were responding to his applause with unseemly gestures.

Uefa yesterday declined to take disciplinary action against the player but the Football Association is to make representations to the European game's governing body about security in tunnel areas, including a request that tunnel-covers should be opaque and not transparent like the one at the Philips stadium.

David Davies, the FA's executive director, said: "There is an issue regarding these Per spex tunnels. We will be raising it with Uefa."

It follows an incident as the players left the pitch which saw eight to 10 supporters clad in England shirts hurl abuse at the team. It is understood that several players reacted. Keegan said: "I take my hat off to the players that they didn't react more strongly. It was the worst thing I've seen in football. I've had plenty of abuse in my time but this was way beyond anything I've ever heard.

"Abuse is something we all have to put up with at times, but there is a limit to what every human being can take. And it got way beyond that limit. I think I would have struggled not to react."

Keegan appeared visibly shocked. "It was not just to David Beckham but to quite a number of the England players, and if you'd have heard that abuse and you'd have had to take it, your sons or daughters had to listen to that . . . it started at half-time but it obvi ously got worse at the end. It's got nothing to do with football. It was very, very personal."

What was said is unprintable, and Keegan expressed nothing but contempt for the perpetrators. "We're talking about eight to 10 people who have got an England badge with three lions on, and I don't understand them. I'm not going to try and understand them. I don't even know whether I want to understand them.

"The majority of fans were fantastic. We mustn't think that those few mindless ones should undermine what was a fantastic performance by our fans."

It seems no attempt was made to arrest the accused. Nobody at the FA was prepared to talk about the Beckham incident, though Keegan did refer to the abuse which the player has long been subjected to: "If David Beckham is getting even 50% of what was said in Eindhoven some days of his life, I think he handles it fantastically well."

fields.headline: Striker with score to settle
fields.standfirst: Filippo Inzaghi, stung by his Italian critics, is burning to light the Blue touchpaper in Brussels tonight
fields.trailText: Filippo Inzaghi, stung by his Italian critics, is burning to light the Blue touchpaper in Brussels tonight.
fields.body:
At the end of Italy's training session on Monday morning Filippo Inzaghi seemed less than enthusiastic about meeting the media. He had one foot on the team bus when he changed his mind and headed back to the "mixed zone" area to say his piece.

In essence the striker was expressing his frustration at the extent to which television critics back home had spent more time analysing his near misses in Sunday's 2-1 win over Turkey than his brilliantly struck penalty winner.

Just when "Superpippo" might have expected to be lauded as a national hero for the way in which he fired home his penalty in spite of a barrage of cans, bottles, cigarette lighters and whistling from the Turkish fans in front of him, he found the critics being less than generous.

"I'm delighted with my goal and I'm holding on to it," said Inzaghi. "As for the rest, that doesn't matter. I live to knock the ball into the back of the net. It's fine by me, even if I score with my hand. Have I made myself clear?"

The 26-year-old Juventus striker, the man who may represent the biggest threat to Belgium's defence when the sides meet in the King Baudouin stadium in Brussels tonight, has experienced a curious fate on the way to these Euro 2000 finals.

The army of 56m armchair critics back home worked up a furious - and ongoing - debate as to whether Alessandro del Piero or Francesco Totti should play, and the Rome-based media mounted a campaign in favour of the two Roma strikers Vincenzo Montella and Marco Delvecchio. Many ignored the coach Dino Zoff when he said two weeks ago in Florence that "certain track records" do not get overlooked in a hurry.

The track record in question was interpreted as being that of Inzaghi, who played in seven out of eight Euro 2000 qualifiers, scoring three goals in the process. He was Italy's joint top goalscorer with the currently injured Christian Vieri.

Inzaghi may not please all the critics or the fans but he is one of those players consistently used by coaches. Men as varied in their approach as the Juventus coaches past and present Marcello Lippi and Carlo Ancelotti and the Italy coaches past and present Cesare Maldini and Dino Zoff have all trusted Inzaghi's scoring ability.

They have all fastened on to something that has been evident since the early 80s when Inzaghi proved a prolific scorer with his under-11 parish side of San Nicolo, near Piacenza, in northern Italy, namely that if you give the boy the ball in or around the penalty area he will probably go for goal. Often he may miss. Yet often he will score, witness a record that has seen him feature at the top end of the Serie A goal chart for the past five seasons.

Inzaghi, though, has always had his detractors. On that memorable autumn night three seasons ago when Manchester United beat Juventus 3-2 in a Champions League first-phase game at Old Trafford, critics in Italy pointed the finger at both Inzaghi and Lippi. How could a Juventus side who had enjoyed the heavyweight presence of such as Gianluca Vialli, Fabrizio Ravanelli and Vieri in attack now trust this lightweight, they asked.

Wait until the end of the season for the answer, replied a furious Lippi in Inzaghi's defence. By the end of the season, of course, Inzaghi had played a more than full part in a splendidly successful run which saw Juventus win Serie A as well as lose the Champi ons League final against Real Madrid.

Dismissed alternately as a "poacher", "too lightweight" and "no good on the big night", Inzaghi has continued to defy his detractors. When he says he would happily score with his hand, he is not exaggerating. He is the classic self- obsessed, goal-obsessed striker who believes his role on earth is to whack the ball as hard as he can when and if he comes near the opponents' goal.

His Juventus team-mate Del Piero rediscovered this aspect of Inzaghi during a 4-0 Serie A win against Venezia in February. The incident in question came in injury-time, when Juventus were already home and dry, leading 2-0. Having rounded Venezia's goalkeeper, Inzaghi found himself wide, almost on the byline. Rather than pass to the waiting Del Piero in the middle he chose to go on a spectacular run across goal, slicing the ball in from a difficult angle.

The point about the incident was that at the time Del Piero badly needed to score. On the comeback trail last season after a 10-month lay-off, he went through to the penultimate game - a 1-0 win against Parma - before scoring a league goal from open play; the other eight of his nine goals were from penalties.

In the Venezia match, as Inzaghi climbed an advertising hoarding to celebrate his goal, Del Piero stood behind him, arms on his hips, patiently waiting. When Inzaghi finally turned, Del Piero delivered a sharp reprimand. Del Piero afterwards refused to reveal what he had said, admitting only that he had been annoyed and adding: "I'd just say this, though: it was a good job we were already 2-0 up and a good job, too, that he scored."

Inzaghi's misses against Turkey have to be seen in that light. The man lives to shoot. His record on Sunday, too, was not that bad, at least according to official Euro 2000 statistics. He had six shots on goal; three were wide, two on target and one a goal. If he maintains that strike rate, Belgium had better beware - and Inzaghi's critics, too.

webTitle: Gary and Phil - what a pair!

fields.headline: Gary and Phil - what a pair!
fields.standfirst: Why Euro 2000 should be proud to have the Neville brothers
fields.trailText: Lovely boys. Lovely . The best. Always done their parents proud, never forgotten their roots. They bought their grandmam a washing machine machine for Christmas. Shame the paddles beat her to death.
fields.body:
Lovely boys. Lovely . The best. Always done their parents proud, never forgotten their roots. They bought their grandmam a washing machine machine for Christmas. Shame the paddles beat her to death.

No, but seriously. Smashing lads. Mensches . There's big Gary, leading by example. Who would have guessed that the insipid and somewhat gormless young lad of yesteryear would turn into the great England right-back of today, the ferocious tiger who so nearly led England to victory on Monday night? ( Give us a big throw, Gaz! )

Then we have young Philip, so eager to please that he'll play on the left without a left foot. Dedicated beyond the call. And even better looking than Gary. ( Stop it, girls! ) Who would have thought the shellshocked lad of yesteryear would turn into the great bee-stung-lipped left-back of England today? If only those two shimmering faint-hearts, Becks and Scholesy, had left it to the sibling supremos on the wing, we could have been contenders. ( Lob it up the middle, Phil! )

Salt of the earth, Gaz and Phil. Appreciate good old-fashioned family values. In the early days, after a tiff on the playing field over a bad pass, Brian McClair wrote: "Phil says that Gary will be helping him get back at me, and they will be devising a plan over cocoa tonight - if their parents let them stay up after 8pm." Now McClair may have been taking the rip out of the Neville boys, but where was he last night when they were singing their hearts out for their country?

Back in Bury, the boys are rightly regarded as role models. Now neither Gary nor Philip will tell you they have the swerve, skill or pace of Roberto Carlos. But they will tell you what they are - fighters.

The Neville brothers are an inspiration to all. Old fashioned values again - decency, loyalty, friendship. Whenever Kevin Keegan considers dropping Gary, he remembers Gary is the best friend of Becks, and that Becks would be most miffed to find his mate booted out just because of a silly little footy issue.

And when Keegan thinks of dropping little Phil, he remembers that Gary would get upset, and when Gary gets upset Becks gets upset, and when Becks gets upset Posh gets upset, and then he'd really be for it. Team spirit? Unbeatable.

Gary, of course, was best man at the wedding. Terrific speech. They still talk about it in Bury. Gaz out-Becked Becks in his shimmering sarong and showed he could laugh at himself with the best of them. "Like I say, David is cockney, out-going, bubbly, while I'm a bit of a boring, miserable moaning sod."

The other day a lovely little lad came up to me. And he said, the thing about the Neville boys is nothing gets them down. Look at Gary. A couple of unlucky touches in Brazil and bang, United are out of the World Club Championship. Yet by the next game he was right as rain. Then, come the England match against Brazil, the blighter does it again. Loses his feet and bang, 1-1.

Phil's made of the same stock. Like his brother he doesn't score goals, can't pass, can't tackle. The only difference is that Phil can't get in the United team either. But he never lets it get him down. Why? Because he knows he's good enough for England.

The newspapers raved about his performance against Portugal - 4 out of 10, best game yet. As super dad Neville Neville said of his prize pair: "We are very proud of them. They are a pair to be proud of."

Now McClair may have been taking the rip out of the Neville boys, but where was he last night when they were singing their hearts out for their country? Back in Bury, the boys are rightly regarded as role models. Now neither Gary nor Philip will tell you they have the swerve, skill or pace of Roberto Carlos. But they will tell you what they are - fighters. The Neville brothers are an inspiration to all. Old fashioned values again - decency, loyalty, friendship. Whenever Kevin Keegan considers dropping Gary, he remembers Gary is the best friend of Becks, and that Becks would be most miffed to find his mate booted out just because of a silly little footy issue. And when Keegan thinks of dropping little Phil, he remembers that Gary would get upset, and when Gary gets upset Becks gets upset, and when Becks gets upset Posh gets upset, and then he'd really be for it. Team spirit? Unbeatable. Gary, of course, was best man at the wedding. Terrific speech. They still talk about it in Bury. Gaz out-Becked Becks in his shimmering sarong and showed he could laugh at himself with the best of them. "Like I say, David is cockney, out-going, bubbly, while I'm a bit of a boring, miserable moaning sod." The other day a lovely little lad came up to me. And he said, the thing about the Neville boys is nothing gets them down. Look at Gary. A couple of unlucky touches in Brazil and bang, United are out of the World Club Championship. Yet by the next game he was right as rain. Then, come the England match against Brazil, the blighter does it again. Loses his feet and bang, 1-1. Phil's made of the same stock. Like his brother he doesn't score goals, can't pass, can't tackle. The only difference is that Phil can't get in the United team either. But he never lets it get him down. Why? Because he knows he's good enough for England. The newspapers raved about his performance against Portugal - 4 out of 10, best game yet. As super dad Neville Neville said of his prize pair: "We are very proud of them. They are a pair to be proud of."

fields.headline: Euro 2000 Shorts
fields.trailText: • Holland's central defender Jaap Stam strained his groin while training yesterday and is doubtful for their Group D match with Denmark on Friday.
fields.body:
 Holland's central defender Jaap Stam strained his groin while training yesterday and is doubtful for their Group D match with Denmark on Friday.

The Manchester United man, who was substituted in his team's 1-0 victory over the Czech Republic on Sunday due to an eye injury which required four stitches, will be monitored for the next two days. "He has a groin strain," admitted Frank Rijkaard, Holland's manager. "But the stitching over his eye is no longer a concern."

Two-thirds of the Netherlands' population, 9.3m, watched the opening match on television. In 1998 a national record of 11.7m watched the World Cup semi-final, when Holland lost to Brazil on penalties.

 The whole Italy squad will lay wreaths at the King Baudouin Stadium before tonight's match with Belgium in memory of the victims of the Heysel disaster.

Dino Zoff's players will place flowers at the foot of the stand where 39 people, 31 of them Italians, died before the European Cup Final between Juventus and Liverpool in May 1985. It will be the first time Italy have played at the stadium since it was renovated and renamed.

"At a distance of so many years we still feel the pain and bitterness that those deaths caused on that evening in 1985," the Italian Football Federation said.

 Romania's captain Gheorghe Hagi is to stay with Galatasaray for another year . The 35-year-old midfielder, who will earn around £900,000 for the season, still intends to retire from international football after Euro 2000. The Uefa Cup winners have also announced that they will extend Gheorghe Popescu's contract until May 2003.

 Sweden's defender Roland Nilsson , concussed in his team's 2-1 defeat by Belgium, returned to training yesterday only to twist his ankle. He will now miss tomorrow's game with Turkey. Arsenal's midfielder Fredrik Ljungberg is also nursing an ankle he injured in the same training session but he says it is not serious. The captain Patrik Andersson is suspended after being sent off in the opening game.

 Tony Blair has called on England fans to continue to have faith in the team. The prime minister apparently joined an estimated 16m television viewers who watched Monday's defeat by Portugal. "He enjoyed the first 20 minutes more than the rest of it," a spokesman said."He thinks it's important everybody now gets behind the team for the match against Germany."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •Frank Rijkaard has instilled a typically Dutch ethos of relaxation in his side. He gave them a holiday after their first game. He said: "This is our third week together that we've been busy with football and training. We needed to relax." What exactly did he expect his players to be busy with in a football championship?
fields.body:
Frank Rijkaard has instilled a typically Dutch ethos of relaxation in his side. He gave them a holiday after their first game. He said: "This is our third week together that we've been busy with football and training. We needed to relax." What exactly did he expect his players to be busy with in a football championship?

Belgium compounded Swedish misery after their game on Saturday when, having won 2-1, their coach Robert Waseige let them see their families.

Players' wives came to the secluded retreat of the Red Devils - and brought their offspring with them.

Anja Peeters, wife of Belgium defender Jacky, said: "Almost every player's wife is pregnant or has just given birth. It was like a nursery."

Domino's, the home-delivery pizza company, reported a 35 per cent increase in sales compared with an average Monday this week, the peaks in demand coinciding with each Portuguese goal. Comforting to know that when England get stuffed, the English like to get stuffed with them.

 Those who made the journey to Eindhoven were treated to alternative therapy. Dutch porn actresses Tona, 31, and Kate, 26, hunted down disgruntled fans to encourage them to unwind. Tona said: "We set out to kiss people in order to calm them down. "We made a point of kissing those who looked most like hooligans."

You know Euro 2000 has hit fever pitch when pop idol Huey Lewis has to reschedule a gig for the event. Huey, together with The News, was due to wow Copenhagen on Friday night but the concert has been postponed by half-an-hour to fit in with Denmark's clash with Holland that evening. An organiser said: "The power of football is stronger than the Power of Love."

Kevin Keegan was right to reject criticism from Mark Lawrenson. Consider Lawrenson's managerial record. He managed Oxford for seven months in 1988 and won four matches. Then he moved to Peterborough where he spent the last 14 months of his managerial career. His only significant involvement since was coaching that defence of Keegan's at Newcastle that leaked even more goals than England's.

Fans, tiring of Lawrenson's punditry perhaps, have turned to the internet for all their Euro 2000 needs. Yesterday, the fifth most popular question put to Ask Jeeves, the website that seeks to answer every query thrown at it, was: 'Why did Kevin Keegan not pick Dennis Wise?'

Jeeves had no answer.

webTitle: Belgian beer is going to the head

fields.headline: Belgian beer is going to the head
fields.trailText: If the Belgian press is an accurate reflection of its nation, a quick scan yesterday suggested the country's masterly brewed beers must be on special offer.
fields.body:
If the Belgian press is an accurate reflection of its nation, a quick scan yesterday suggested the country's masterly brewed beers must be on special offer.

From slumbering apathy the co-hosts have been engulfed by sudden delusions of grandeur over the past few days. And the longer the giddiness continues, the worse the hangover will inevitably be.

Belgium has "gone into orbit," roared La Dernière Heure, and Het Nieuwsblad proclaimed that the nation had been gripped by "Europhoria".

Since Belgium squeezed past a lukewarm Sweden on the opening night Brussels has been swarming with back-slapping rowdies swigging bottles of Jupiler and honking car horns, occasionally at the same time.

Tonight the Diables Rouges will get a much better idea of their credentials when they meet Italy in the King Baudouin stadium.

Although the Italians suffered an embarrassing 3-1 home defeat by Belgium recently in a friendly, the suspicion persists that the only thing that can deny the Azzurri this evening is them selves. As Paolo Maldini said: "Sure the Belgiums have done well but we are Italy, the better team."

But the captain himself may not be part of it after suffering a calf injury in training yesterday. If he is fit, Italy will probably be unchanged.

Belgium's coach Robert Waseige made one alteration in his side, replacing his usual left-back Philippe Léonard with Nico van Kerckhoven. Apparently Léonard, of Monaco, has been pilloried in the Belgian press since turning up for training once in a Ferrari. Strong stuff, that Jupiler.

Belgium (4-4-2): De Wilde; Deflandre, Valgaeren, Staelens, Van Kerckhoven; Verheyen, Vanderhaeghe, Wilmots, Goor; Strupar, E Mpenza.

Italy (probable, 3-5-2): Toldo; Cannavaro, Nesta, Maldini; Zambrotta, Conte, Albertini, Fiore, Pessotto; Totti, Inzaghi.

webTitle: Adams is ruled out of group games

fields.headline: Adams is ruled out of group games
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan had his worst fears confirmed yesterday when injuries ruled Tony Adams and Steve McManaman out of the equation for Saturday.
fields.body:
As if Kevin Keegan did not have enough to think about before the group match with Germany, the England coach had his worst fears confirmed yesterday when injuries ruled Tony Adams and Steve McManaman out of the equation for Saturday.

The Arsenal captain, who has calf trouble, will also miss England's final game in Group A, against Romania on Tuesday. "The feeling is that Tony will not make the next two games," Keegan confirmed. "He still has a chance if we do progress through the group, so I don't want to write him off.

"As for Steve, it's a [knee] problem he's had before and he seems less worried about it than we do, but the Germany game will come too soon. But there's a chance for the last game, depending on his scan."

The Real Madrid midfielder limped off after 59 minutes of the Portugal defeat, to be replaced by Dennis Wise, after failing to run-off a knock he picked up when attempting a tackle. Adams hobbled off after 82 minutes.

The loss of Adams, who has a personalised training regime due to the chronic back problem which hindered his domestic season, is a serious blow to Keegan, who values the Arsenal captain's leadership qualities and tactical acumen.

The coach had been hoping that Adams would make it through Monday's game in one piece and on the winning side, after which he would almost certainly have been rested until the knock-out stages. Martin Keown took his place in defence against Portugal and is likely to do so again on Saturday.

Keegan, meanwhile, has offered his support to David Seaman, Paul Ince, Adams and Alan Shearer, the core England's Euro 96 and France 98 teams. "They remain our backbone," he said. "I still believe that spine is as strong as ever and that it has got the personality and strength to overcome the criticism it's going to get in the future or has had in the past.

"It's the backbone of our team. I'm not making excuses for these players as I don't have to. I thought Alan Shearer led the line very well. I felt sorry for Paul Ince. At times he had a bit of a price to pay because although we wanted to defend well we also put players in there [midfield] to cause them problems. So he had a bit of a price to pay.

"Tony Adams's leadership qualities and personality are very important to us, and I don't think David Seaman could have done much with any of the goals."

webTitle: New faces and fresh minds are the answer

fields.headline: New faces and fresh minds are the answer
fields.trailText: My golfing partner, a Portuguese lad, was one of the first people on the phone to me yesterday morning. As you can imagine, he's on springs. He reckons England will still qualify for the quarter-finals, but I'm not so sure.
fields.body:
My golfing partner, a Portuguese lad, was one of the first people on the phone to me yesterday morning. As you can imagine, he's on springs. He reckons England will still qualify for the quarter-finals, but I'm not so sure.

The good news is that Germany don't have the fluidity or the intelligence of Portugal. They're the sort of team we prefer to play and they look beatable. But things will have to tighten up a huge amount to give us a chance.

It amazed me how many people thought Portugal would be a stick-on, some sort of walkover. A lot of the talk was about who our front pair should be but my biggest concern was always the defence. In most of our previous five or six games we had looked like shipping goals and got away with it by the skin of our teeth. Scotland, Brazil, Ukraine - even Malta - could have had three. This time the luck ran out.

Portugal were a joy to watch; their invention was brilliant. But we backed off too much and gave them too much time. In midfield Paul Ince never got to grips with Rui Costa. And the defence was not alive to danger. The players paid to destroy didn't do their shifts.

Joao Pinto's equaliser was a classic case. Portugal came about 80 yards with the ball, played about 16 passes and there was not one challenge. Before the final ball Sol Campbell looked unaware of the space Pinto had got into. Someone like Terry Butcher would have seen that.

No doubt many will point to Kevin Keegan's Newcastle days and say "Told you so". But he must have expected his defenders to take responsibility and do basic jobs. These guys look good in the Premiership but maybe when they step up that extra notch in class they get caught out. Let's not forget that by the time England were 2-0 up Portugal could have had five.

So how best to avoid a repeat? First of all let's play three at the back and Nigel Martyn in goal. David Seaman flapped at a few crosses and got away with things. It was hard to pin the goals on him but Martyn played a blinder against Ukraine and deserves a go.

More radically, I'd opt for Gareth Barry at left-wing-back. Germany have no one in the Luis Figo class on the right and Barry brings a freshness of mind. Steven Gerrard, whom I'd play in the midfield anchor role, offers the same and that's important. A lot of the players have seen disappointment at Euro 96 and France 98 and it might be coming back to them. Gerrard and Barry are uninhibited.

The absence of Tony Adams is not disastrous. Instead, with Campbell, I'd play Gareth Southgate and Martin Keown, who I think has been the best defender all season. They offer agility and, in Keown's case, real pace.

Steve McManaman's injury loses us running in midfield but I think Dennis Wise is good enough to compensate. Some see Nicky Barmby as a natural replacement but Wise has had a fine season and has shown in Europe he has a great ability to nick goals.

So with Paul Scholes in a link role and Alan Shearer just about getting the nod up front, my team, lining up 3-5-1-1, would be: Martyn; Keown, Southgate, Campbell; G Neville/P Neville, Beckham, Gerrard, Wise, Barry; Scholes; Shearer.

The attacking midfielders were the plus against Portugal. I still think we need more quickness and brightness, but the players should feel they can beat Germany, who looked shaky and lacking in pace against Romania. At times Lothar Matthäus seemed to be playing not so much from memory as with amnesia.

Of course Germany will be organised, methodical and resilient but with little invention; there is nothing hidden. You know what to expect. It will come down to individual battles and a bit of luck.

The break until Saturday will do England good. They'll know how up for this game the nation will be. Germany is almost a derby match, and this time it must be won.

webTitle: Want to kill off the cast? It's your movie

fields.headline: Want to kill off the cast? It's your movie
fields.trailText: Viewers of Running Time, an interactive thriller gaining a cult following on the internet and billed as the world's first interactive movie will this week decide which of the protagonists is to meet a grisly end
fields.body:
As fans of Friends and Frasier sat glued to their televisions for the recent nail-biting series finales, viewers of a different medium were shaping the destiny of a new set of small screen stars.

Friends followers had no say in the romantic intrigue of Chandler and Monica, but viewers of Running Time, an interactive thriller gaining a cult following on the internet, will this week decide which of the protagonists is to meet a grisly end.

Four episodes of the highly stylised series, billed as the world's first interactive movie, have already been screened and the fifth is about to be posted on the site - www. itsyourmovie.com.

So far, the site has been accessed 1.5m times, and the success may mean the finished product is released in cinemas. "It's giving the power back to the audience," said the producer, Simon Rose, a film critic-turned-screenwriter.

The scriptwriters have no idea about how it will end: at the culmination of each episode, a viewer vote decides how the cliffhanger is resolved from a list of three options. A cast of 11 actors remain on standby, their services dependent on the whim of the audience.

Five-minute instalments are posted at the rate of around one a week. Voting takes place over about two days; the scriptwriters then spend a frantic 24 hours writing the next episode while production staff sort out filming locations and other logistics; shooting takes place over the following day. The schedule is tough. "It is exciting, and also rather scary," Mr Rose said.

The project is a collaboration between Mr Rose, creative director Simon Beaufoy (writer of The Full Monty), and the director Suzy Halewood. They have raised £1m from investors, and plan three more films.

Running Time's cast is relatively unknown: the lead character, KJ, a hip cycle courier who gets caught up in the disappearance of her oddball brother, is played by Anna Bolt. The mysterious Jed, a member of a direct action environmental group, is played by Gareth Miller. KJ is determined to find her brother but gets sucked deeper into the shadowy world of Terra Terror, while Jed is abducted by thugs from a biotech firm which the group had targeted.

Miller said the acting process was different from that employed for conventional films. "It is all off the cuff, which makes it very fresh."

So far, judging by the comments of viewers who can interact with the website in a chatroom, the idea appears to have caught on.

Miller said: "I really think this is the way it's going to go. It won't be long before Hollywood is doing this."

The project is a collaboration between Mr Rose, creative director Simon Beaufoy (writer of The Full Monty), and the director Suzy Halewood. They have raised £1m from investors, and plan three more films. Running Time's cast is relatively unknown: the lead character, KJ, a hip cycle courier who gets caught up in the disappearance of her oddball brother, is played by Anna Bolt. The mysterious Jed, a member of a direct action environmental group, is played by Gareth Miller. KJ is determined to find her brother but gets sucked deeper into the shadowy world of Terra Terror, while Jed is abducted by thugs from a biotech firm which the group had targeted. Miller said the acting process was different from that employed for conventional films. "It is all off the cuff, which makes it very fresh." So far, judging by the comments of viewers who can interact with the website in a chatroom, the idea appears to have caught on. Miller said: "I really think this is the way it's going to go. It won't be long before Hollywood is doing this."

fields.headline: Chinook crash inquiry call rejected
fields.trailText: Calls for a new independent inquiry into the cause of the Mull of Kintyre helicopter crash six years ago  were today rejected by the government.
fields.body:
Calls for a new independent inquiry into the cause of the Mull of Kintyre helicopter crash six years ago were today rejected by the government.

Armed forces minister John Spellar insisted the two pilots of the military Chinook which smashed into a hilltop on the Scottish peninsula had been rightly blamed for the accident. And he rejected claims that Scotland's top law officer, Lord Advocate Colin Boyd QC, had questioned whether the verdict was correct.

The families of the pilots have repeatedly criticised the Ministry of Defence's original finding that the pilots were grossly negligent by breaking flying rules in bad weather.

The accident killed 25 senior intelligence experts from Northern Ireland as well as Flight Lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Richard Cook, experienced pilots who had unblemished records until the crash.

In a letter to Kenny MacAskill MSP obtained by the BBC, Mr Boyd said Crown counsel had considered new evidence on possible technical malfunction. He said they had looked at information on the Full Authority Digital Electronic Control (Fadec) software fitted to the helicopter which had emerged after the fatal accident inquiry.

Mr Boyd said the lawyers had also considered the RAF Board of Inquiry's findings and a National Audit Office report into accepting equipment off contract and into service.

He wrote: "Having regard to the findings of the sheriff, Crown counsel considered that, even if the new information could be substantiated in an inquiry process, it is highly unlikely that the findings of the sheriff would be different.

"Indeed insofar as the new information about Fadec invites speculation as to another possible cause for the crash of ZD576 it may be thought to reinforce the sheriff's inconclusive determination as to the cause of the accident."

The sheriff had concluded that he could not be satisfied that the accident was caused by the crew's decision to overfly the Mull of Kintyre at cruising speed but selected the wrong rate of climb, which had been the RAF's finding.

Mr Boyd said he proposed to take no further action on new evidence. And he wrote: "As you know the terms of the RAF Board of Inquiry report and the determination by the RAF of the cause of the accident are a matter for the Ministry of Defence and not for me."

But Mr Spellar told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that there was no new evidence that changed the MoD's original verdict.

Insisting the pilots had been responsible, he said: "By flying too fast and too low in fog and in a hilly area they were breaching safe flying rules."

However, Mike Tapper, the father of Flt Lt Tapper, said the MoD dismissed any new evidence out of hand.

"It seems that the government would rather protect the elite within the MoD than to protect natural justice," he said.

Liberal Democrat defence spokesman Menzies Campbell questioned whether the Lord Advocate's letter represented a genuine step forward for those calling for the inquiry into the crash to be reopened.

Mr Campbell, a Scottish QC, said: "The Lord Advocate's letter does not challenge in any way the conclusion of the separate board of inquiry held by the RAF. It is that last decision which was flawed.

"It is essential to guard against over-enthusiastic interpretation of events, which could easily damage the cause of putting right the injustice suffered by these pilots and their families."

fields.headline: At the ambassador's party
fields.trailText: Tactical tinkering won't get Keegan anywhere; Slovenia's strategic goals; and Karel Poborsky's great escape
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"I certainly believe that getting the two wins we need to go through is not impossible. Against Portugal we looked like scoring every time we went forward." Gary Neville hopes that a spot of positive thinking will keep his place in the England side

THE EURO-TORIAL

Whenever England lose, the pathologically patriotic tabloid press never accept the blindingly obvious - sometimes Johnny Foreigner is better than us. Instead they must hunt down a scapegoat, a sacrificial lamb - something to justify why the unthinkable happened. And today is no different.

However, with the usual suspects (Shearer, McManaman) playing reasonable well on Monday night, and our national heirlooms (Adams, Ince) having stinkers, it's Kevin Keegan's naïve 4-4-2 formation which has taken all the flack. Today's papers are full of it. We were swamped. It was 4 v 5 in midfield - and how was old Incey supposed to cope? To a man they agree: only 3-5-2 can save us.

But if 3-5-2 is so much better than 4-4-2, why isn't every club in the Premiership playing it? And why, when Manchester United play the likes of Aston Villa and West Ham aren't they over-run the same way England were on Monday night? The simple fact is that England defended poorly. All of the back four made elementary mistakes, and in midfield Scholes, Beckham and Ince hardly made a tackle between them. When that happens a team will always have problems - whether they are confronted with an alien 4-5-1 formation with two free men swarming all over the place, or a bog-standard 4-4-2.

England also seemed to be in football limbo after they went 2-0 ahead. Part of them wanted to press for more goals. Part of them wanted to hang back and defend their lead. In the end they did neither. As Portuguese striker Nuno Gomes admits: "After we scored our first goal and started to go through them England just sat back. They become afraid of taking the game to us again. It would have been much harder for us had England continued to play like they did for the opening 20 minutes."

But it's not all doom and gloom. Anyone who saw Lothar Matthaus crassly wandering between midfield and defence like an senseless American tourist doing the Europe thing, knows that Germany aren't invincible. That's why England don't have to play 3-5-2 to beat them. They just have to play well.

THEY'RE SLO CRAZY!

It's party time for Slovenia. Three goals against former overlords Yugoslavia and a point in Euro 2000. No wonder the leaders of this former Communist state are going crazy bananas! Just listen to Dr Boris Frlec, Slovenian ambassador to the Netherlands: "Slovenian national team is a very good promotion of our state and undoubtedly, it will increase the transparency of Slovenia in Europe and this is also in accordance with our strategic goals."

Wooahh, take it easy cat!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. And £200 behind the bar. perfect. Win a £200 bar tab for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Lothar Matthaus looks set to play for Germany against England this Saturday, despite the fact that he has an appointment with the chiropodist that evening and Michael Barrymore's on telly. German coach Erich Ribbeck said of the 39-year-old German talisman: "Lothar is still important to my plans. He is a favourite of mine - but that is not why he is in the team. I cannot allow my subjective opinions on individuals to get in the way of team matters." Ribbeck then cancelled training to show the press some lovely photographs of Lothar as a child.

In a development which will warm the heart of home secretary Jack Straw, the Dutch police have found the solution to the hooligan problem: drugs. The Eindhoven fuzz reckons that smoking loads of pot helped England fans to calm their violent instincts before Monday's game with Portugal. "The cannabis may have helped relax them," said a police spokesman. "There were lots of things for fans to do and everybody had a good time." Eindhoven authorities believe the decision to show episodes of Pingu on giant screens in the city square proved particularly effective.

Italy are concerned over the fitness of captain Paolo Maldini ahead of tonight's Group B match with Belgium. Maldini was kicked in the calf by teammate Luigi Di Biagio during training, but the Milan defender remains confident of playing. "It's just a knock," he said. "It's annoying because it's on the calf." "You're telling me," said the calf when asked for comment.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Uuhh... Where am I? It's Karel Poborsky here and, thanks to my naughty teammates, I think I've spent the best part of the last week tied up in a basement in Rotterdam. I've heard some people pay a lot of money for this, so mustn't grumble.

Anyway, here's my latest bunch of transfer rumours brought to you by me.

Joao Pinto could be set to replace Gabriel Batistuta at Fiorentina. The Portuguese striker, sacked by his club Benfica, has been offered a contract believed to be worth £80,000-a-week.

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan wants to sign Swedish international Niclas Alexandersson from Sheffield Wednesday. The Scot will offer cash-strapped Wednesday £3m.

That's all today folks, I'm off to get some well-earned kip. Hang on, what's that big metal cage falling out of the sky?

CLANNGG!

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC 1: MoTD Live! (7.30pm) It's Italy v Belgium! It's the only game on telly today! What's going on!

ITV: Baddiel and Skinner Unplugged (10.30pm) Not this, that's for sure.

Euro 2000: today (11.30pm) Sideshow, do your thing.

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live Five (7pm) More Italy v Belgium! Could we not have Slovenia again instead?

fields.headline: Blood and votes
fields.standfirst: How do you turn the Blair era into Jacobean revenge tragedy,  Fiachra Gibbons  asks poet-turned-playwright Sean O'Brien
fields.trailText: How do you turn the Blair era into Jacobean revenge tragedy, Fiachra Gibbons asks poet-turned-playwright Sean O'Brien
fields.body:
"Watch it. Oh we're hard because we're hard
Because by being hard we're being kind.
Because one day a world ago
The Leader read a book and lost his mind"
- Jacky Jackson, home secretary

The morning the massed revolutionary ranks of the Women's Institute humbled the Great Leader, the final chapter in his demise was being played out in a rehearsal room in Newcastle. It is the summer of 2004, and New Labour is facing certain electoral defeat. The "project", whatever that was, is long forgotten. Survival is all that matters now. Prime minister Richard Tallow, "in a nod towards tradition", retreats to Whitley Bay to make his conference plea for four more years.

The TV news reports how "The PM spoke of struggling for the souls/ Of the excluded and the rich alike./ Equipped with nothing but a mike," while his home secretary, Jacky Jackson, a rebel in his youth - who is "hard as fuck on evil nowadays/Since that's the only policy that plays/Down where the Morlocks read the Daily Mail" - mutters at the screen in his hotel room. "So no one really wondered what this shit meant./After ideology comes noise/So, on the count of three, then, girls and boys."

Had it been about any other sub ject, Laughter When We're Dead is the sort of play that would give David Blunkett multiple orgasms. It's a Jacobean revenge tragedy that Webster would have been proud of, written in iambic pentameters and rhyming couplets. Traditional values in a modern setting, precisely the worthy-sounding roughage on which to blunt young minds. But as you may have guessed, Laughter When We're Dead won't be making the school syllabus, not for a while anyway.

It is not so much the home secretary's appetite for snack sex that is likely to keep it off, or that he prefers football to Daisy Gates, his fragrant and willing PPS - "Later. I've got tickets for the match/But then I'll drink ambrosia from your snatch." No, this is the first piece of drama, and arguably the first piece of writing, really to get under the skin of the government.

Last month Trevor Nunn, the director of the National Theatre, complained that no one was prepared to take on the big state-of-the-nation plays. He should get himself up to Newcastle quick and beg an introduction to Sean O'Brien. Where all those revues churned out by the usual suspects of superannuated establishment dissidents joke unfunnily about the nothingness within New Labour, here it scares the hell out of you. But the most dangerous thing of all about Laughter When We're Dead is that it's entertainment. This is the last thing you might expect from a verse play, had it not come from O'Brien or through Live Theatre, the Newcastle stable from which sprang Peter Flannery (Our Friends in the North) and Lee Hall (Spoonface Steinberg and Cooking With Elvis).

Poets are not supposed to rattle governments, even those like O'Brien whose hefty physical presence seems ideally suited to rocking the pillars of the temple. His verse, which has won him the Forward and every other paltry prize that keeps poets off the streets, is just as muscular. You can hear its strength and his trademark dactyls in the work of the many younger poets he has influenced.

Still, O'Brien is an unlikely nemesis. He's no firebrand class warrior ("Private school and Oxford, actually") nor Old Labour nostalgic either. It's a hatred of cant that drove him towards drama. "The intellectual impoverishment of politics in this country is shameful, and it is getting worse. It's all gesture and no policy or real analysis," he says. "I was standing at the bus stop this morning in what happens to be Stephen Byers's constituency thinking he may as well be on the moon for all he has to do with my life, or anyone else's who lives here. Despite Gordon Brown's occasional railings against upper middle-class bias at Oxford and Cambridge, it's there in politics too. What we now have in this country is a permanent political class, a caste even - and I am not just talking about political advisors here - who owe no allegiance to anyone, least of all the people who voted them in.

"You get curious reversals of normal polarities in such circumstances. You get Blair going to address the WI, and getting himself heckled by the most well-behaved people outside the synod of the Church of England. He thinks they are all mugs. They know he thinks they are all mugs and they are not having it any more."

At the heart of O'Brien's play is the tragedy of the wayward, increasingly reactionary Jackson and his wife Elizabeth, a human rights lawyer, who has sacrificed her own happiness for his and the party's sake. "A partnership of principle outlives/Mere human error: partnership forgives," she says.

"Jackson is like many in New Labour who started out on the left but who have travelled a long way since," says O'Brien. "As distinctions of left and right have collapsed, no one knows why they are doing it anymore. So staying in power becomes the only objective. When Elizabeth tells him it's a wonder he's not bugging people's dreams, he jokes back that that's the 'first among my post-election schemes'."

Jackson's real agony is that he once believed in something better, but now no longer can. All that's left is what O'Brien calls the "Stalinist instincts you'll find in many old left-wingers". And so when one of his constituents mistakes him for a Tyne Tees weatherman during the fateful night of his return to the Toon, Jackson vents his frustration on the "Neds" who blindly vote in him:

"You're old, you're pissed, you're ignorant, you're poor,
The son of a dole-wallah and a hoor.
I've spent my lifetime hoping for the best
From twats like you. You've failed the fuckin' test"

O'Brien said he was attracted to Jacobean revenge tragedy by its atmosphere of corruption and repression. The internal politics of New Labour, he says, is essentially the politics of the medieval court, where the spin-doctor courtiers pull all the strings.

"We have had effectively one-party rule here locally in the north for a long time. Newcastle has had a reputation in the past for corruption. As with anywhere else, when there's money to be made, you can be sure there will be people willing to take the opportunity. I wanted to set it against that kind of backdrop just when everything is coming apart at the seams, as they will eventually."

Director Max Roberts, who has already brought Cooking With Elvis to the West End this year from his small theatre in the shadow of the Tyne bridge, said Laughter When We're Dead demands a national audi ence. "It may be written in iambic pentameters, but it is also written to be seen by a lot of people. It's a great story. Like Flannery's work it is not just for the bourgeois radical elite. When was the last time you went to the National and saw a play about Liverpool or Newcastle or Glasgow that spoke to the whole nation? I don't want to sound like a bitter northerner, but good plays are universal. Just because they come from the regions doesn't make them any less good."

Laughter When We're Dead is a staggering piece of poetry. Tonight will decide if it hits the same heights as theatre. But one more thing is sure. For the cabinet, if they can bear to look, it stands as a terrible warning. Whether, like the great jam-maker's revolt, it will be heeded, is another thing.

 Laughter When We're Dead previews from tonight at Live Theatre, Quayside, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-232 2224). Till June 29.

And so when one of his constituents mistakes him for a Tyne Tees weatherman during the fateful night of his return to the Toon, Jackson vents his frustration on the "Neds" who blindly vote in him: "You're old, you're pissed, you're ignorant, you're poor, The son of a dole-wallah and a hoor. I've spent my lifetime hoping for the best From twats like you. You've failed the fuckin' test" O'Brien said he was attracted to Jacobean revenge tragedy by its atmosphere of corruption and repression. The internal politics of New Labour, he says, is essentially the politics of the medieval court, where the spin-doctor courtiers pull all the strings. "We have had effectively one-party rule here locally in the north for a long time. Newcastle has had a reputation in the past for corruption. As with anywhere else, when there's money to be made, you can be sure there will be people willing to take the opportunity. I wanted to set it against that kind of backdrop just when everything is coming apart at the seams, as they will eventually." Director Max Roberts, who has already brought Cooking With Elvis to the West End this year from his small theatre in the shadow of the Tyne bridge, said Laughter When We're Dead demands a national audi ence. "It may be written in iambic pentameters, but it is also written to be seen by a lot of people. It's a great story. Like Flannery's work it is not just for the bourgeois radical elite. When was the last time you went to the National and saw a play about Liverpool or Newcastle or Glasgow that spoke to the whole nation? I don't want to sound like a bitter northerner, but good plays are universal. Just because they come from the regions doesn't make them any less good." Laughter When We're Dead is a staggering piece of poetry. Tonight will decide if it hits the same heights as theatre. But one more thing is sure. For the cabinet, if they can bear to look, it stands as a terrible warning. Whether, like the great jam-maker's revolt, it will be heeded, is another thing.  Laughter When We're Dead previews from tonight at Live Theatre, Quayside, Newcastle upon Tyne (0191-232 2224). Till June 29.

fields.headline: Korean leaders share historic joke
fields.standfirst: Closer ties discussed as warmth continues on second day of summit
fields.trailText: North Korean leader Kim Jong-il today opened the first formal meeting with the president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, with jokes and laughter.
fields.body:
North Korean leader Kim Jong-il today opened the first formal meeting with the president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, with jokes and laughter.

On the second day of the historic three-day summit between the leaders, Kim Jong-il questioned the way he has been portrayed as a villain by the west. The United States has long described his heavily armed country as a dangerous, rogue nation.

"The western media wonder why I am leading a reclusive life, and they say a recluse made his first public appearance" yesterday by greeting Kim Dae-jung at its airport, Kim Jong-il said at the summit in the North Korean capital Pyongyang.

"But I have visited China and Indonesia in the past, and also made many unofficial visits overseas. So, I don't understand why I was described as reclusive."

"Western news reports say President Kim's visit helped me out of seclusion," he added, causing his counterpart and the other North and South Korean officials sitting at the conference table to explode in laughter, as South Korean television cameras sent his comments around the world.

The two leaders also discussed a range of serious issues. These included reopening roads and railways across the heavily armed border, reuniting tens of thousands of Korean families separated during the Korean war, and creating a telephone hotline for discussions during crises.

The peninsula's rail and road lines were closed around 1948, when the two Koreas formed their own governments and sealed their border. After the 1950-53 Korean war ended, the two sides turned the border into the most heavily armed one in the world, including the 37,000 US soldiers who are stationed in South Korea to protect it against possible attacks by the North.

By reopening these routes, the two countries could promote trade and business deals that are desperately needed by the North's ailing economy and eventually reunite many Korean families.

Since the 1990s, North Korea has been dependent on food aid from its traditional foes: South Korea, Japan and the United States. Desperation for economic aid is believed to be a major factor in driving the North to agree to the summit.

Despite repeated warnings by Seoul officials not to expect too much from the talks, the unexpectedly warm welcome for the South Korean leader led to speculation that the North may finally be willing to shed its self-imposed isolation, or even to follow the lead of China in beginning to opening up its economy to global capitalism.

However, no formal agreements were reported by the 50 South Korean journalists who were allowed to travel to Pyongyang for the summit and were providing the only information available to hundreds of foreign journalists who were restricted to covering the meetings from Seoul, South Korea.

Korea's leaders have a host of thorny issues to resolve, including the North's long-range missile and nuclear programmes and the 37,000 US troops deployed in the South. Reunification - the goal of both Koreas - is likely to be a lengthy, difficult process.

Some international observers said Kim Jong-il may simply have used the elaborate welcoming ceremony to play down his reputation in the west as a reclusive communist, in a bid for further economic assistance.

Nevertheless, applause broke out at offices and in homes across South Korea the moment that Kim Dae-jung set foot on North Korean soil, with some people shedding tears of joy.

UN secretary-general Kofi Annan saluted "the vision and wisdom" of the two leaders in opening the historic dialogue, the UN spokesman Fred Eckhard said.

webTitle: No split on euro, Blair tells MPs

fields.headline: No split on euro, Blair tells MPs
fields.trailText: Tony Blair told MPs this afternoon that there was no cabinet divide on joining the euro in the face of William Hague's claim that Labour factions were "at each other's throats" over the issue.
fields.body:
Tony Blair told MPs this afternoon that there was no cabinet divide on joining the euro in the face of William Hague's claim that Labour factions were "at each other's throats" over the issue.

At a stormy prime minister's question time, Mr Blair insisted that the government's policy on the European single currency remained "in favour of joining a successful single currency" in principle, but "in practice, the economic conditions have to be met".

The Conservative party leader used Gordon Brown's well-trailed Mansion House speech, in which the chancellor is expected to stress that there will be no dash to join the euro, to accuse a "divided" Labour cabinet of fighting over the issue "like ferrets in a sack".

Mr Hague named the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, the agriculture secretary, Nick Brown, and the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, as one group who wanted the government to back immediate entry into the euro zone. Another group, including the chancellor, the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the education secretary, David Blunkett, wanted to "join by stealth", the Tory leader said.

Asking Mr Blair which cabinet "faction" he was going to follow on the issue, Mr Hague claimed the Conservative policy was settled "because I lead my party, and you now follow yours".

Mr Blair argued that the Labour government's policy - keeping Britain's options open and giving the electorate a choice in a referendum - was the correct approach.

He added that the Conservative party had been "bought" by someone who wanted to take Britain to the margins of Europe - a reference to today's news that the Eurosceptic millionaire Paul Sykes has offered £20m to the Tories' "keep the pound" campaign. The prime minister also claimed that Mr Hague did not have the strength to stand up to Tory Eurosceptics.

The insults then came thick and fast, with Mr Hague warning the prime minister: "You are running out of steam, you are running out of time, and if you carry on like this you will be run out of office."

Mr Blair won cheers from the Labour backbenches by quoting focus group views on Mr Hague which described the Tory leader as "boring, false, greatly irritating, a pathetic drip and a non-entity".

fields.headline: Brown rebuke to euro zealots
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will tomorrow deliver a dressing down to cabinet critics of the government's policy on the euro with a warning that they risk a repeat of Britain's long history of economic failure if they persist in their campaign to fast-track UK entry into the single currency.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will tomorrow deliver a dressing down to cabinet critics of the government's policy on the euro with a warning that they risk a repeat of Britain's long history of economic failure if they persist in their campaign to fast-track UK entry into the single currency.

The chancellor will use one of his biggest speeches of the year - the address to the City's elite at Mansion House - to face down calls for a rethink of strategy on the euro and stress that official policy will remain unchanged until after the next general election.

With the strains in the government's "prepare and decide" policy over monetary union becoming increasingly apparent over the past week, the chancellor's first direct intervention in the renewed public debate was being billed as a call for the cabinet to close ranks.

Two of Mr Brown's cabinet colleagues - Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and the leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett - responded to increased Tory attacks on the single currency yesterday by stressing that government policy had not changed.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, sought to exploit a newspaper article written jointly by Tony Blair and the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, which said the single currency was "changing the face of Europe".

Mr Portillo said: "The cabinet is split on the euro, but only over tactics. They are united in their aim to con the electorate into scrapping the pound." He said Mr Brown shared the commitment to "join the euro by stealth" but was not disclosing the government's real intentions.

But Mr Brown's aides said he would strongly reject the idea that the government should try to join the single currency for political reasons before it had delivered economic stability. "Unless the economics are right, the politics will never be right," one said last night.

The chancellor will say that he can see benefits from Britain joining a successful single currency, but only after the five economic tests laid down in October 1997 have been met. In a snub to trade union leaders calling for entry into monetary union as a way of bringing down the value of the pound, Mr Brown will stress the dangers of mistaking exchange rate stability for stability in the economy as a whole.

"Mistaking exchange rate stability for stability in the whole economy is something that has happened time and time again," said one Treasury source. "We are not going to allow it to happen again."

Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, appeared to throw his weight behind the chancellor's cautious line on the euro when he said yesterday that there was no evidence that the City had suffered as a result of Britain's decision not to join monetary union.

The impact of monetary union on the City is one of Mr Brown's five tests, but Mr George said: "There were those who argued that the City would suffer if the UK failed to join from the outset. That clearly has not happened -quite the reverse.

Kenneth Clarke told BBC Radio 4's The World at One that he was pleased to see Mr Blair make a stronger case for the benefits that would come to Britain if we went into the euro. The former Tory chancellor said: "I think, or I hope, that he has seen the folly of the tactics of remaining quite silent in the face of a Eurosceptic onslaught.

"They do have a problem with the chancellor of the exchequer. Gordon Brown is as strongly in favour of the single currency as I am, but I think his preferred tactics were just to keep talking about his five economic conditions and otherwise to keep quiet about it until after the election. I don't agree with those tactics. I think the article today shows that Tony Blair doesn't either."

Mr Portillo told the Institute of Economic Affairs that Mr Blair's opinion on the issue varied from day to day.

"Some days we are told that he has taken personal charge of the campaign for the euro. On other days, he agrees with Gordon Brown that secrecy is the best policy. Occasionally, particularly before an election, we hear of his deep, heartfelt love for the pound.

"The prime minister's answer to the divisions in the cabinet about the euro is simple: he agrees with everyone."

Mr Byers, announcing 1,200 new jobs in Nottingham created by US inward investment, denied any cabinet rift over the single currency. He said: "The cabinet are of one view over the euro."

Mrs Beckett also insisted that there was no row, saying: "I don't accept there is an argument raging."

webTitle: Chirac visit adds to euro pressure

fields.headline: Chirac visit adds to euro pressure
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to meet the French president Jacques Chirac tomorrow night in Downing Street in a bid to test the extent of Franco-German determination to run the euro, and the European economy, without formally consulting the British.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to meet the French president Jacques Chirac tomorrow night in Downing Street in a bid to test the extent of Franco-German determination to run the euro, and the European economy, without formally consulting the British.

Mr Chirac is also expected to outline plans to extend the principle of majority voting within the EU and allowing an inner core of countries to cooperate more closely using the community's institutions.

The president, fresh from last week's successful Franco-German summit, will set out his country's plans for the presidency of the EU, starting next month.

Both the French and Germans are pressing for big changes to prepare the EU for enlargement to the east.

The Germans also favour making majority voting the norm and want an increase in the size of its vote on the council of ministers.

But the Foreign Office hopes that the French are not going to accept the full federalist agenda, recently set out by Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has been delighted by an article in Le Monde by his French counterpart, Hubert Vedrine, seen as a delicate slap-down to Mr Fischer. Mr Vedrine insisted Europe had to exist by concensus and there was no point tabling proposals that merely exacerbated divisions within the EU.

Mr Chirac is also expected to report on plans for closer Franco-German cooperation in military satellites and on heavy military air transport.

Mr Blair has set great store by discreetly breaking up the traditional Franco-German axis at the heart of the EU, but he has found his efforts increasingly constrained by the British government's indecision over the euro.

The French, along with the Belgians, are pressing for the 11 countries inside the euro - the euro 11 - to take more decisions not just on the single currency, but also on the European macro-economy.

Lionel Jospin, the French prime minister has told his parliament: "We must strengthen the role of the euro-11 and focus on coordination of our economic policies in an endeavour to improve the visibility of economic policy of the eurozone.

British diplomats said last night that no formal proposals have been put forward by the French. But one controversial idea is that when a country outside the euro holds the EU rotating's presidency, it could be asked to give its observer status at meetings of the European Central Bank to a country from inside the single currency area.

fields.headline: Solomon Islands' leader quits
fields.trailText: The prime minister of the Solomon Islands, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, has tendered his resignation in advance of tomorrow's parliamentary vote on a confidence motion against him. He had been the target of an attempted coup a little over a week ago.
fields.byline: William Foreman  in Honiara, Solomon Islands
fields.body:
The prime minister of the Solomon Islands, Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, has tendered his resignation in advance of tomorrow's parliamentary vote on a confidence motion against him. He had been the target of an attempted coup a little over a week ago.

Mr Ulufa'alu told the Associated Press that rebels who seized the capital last week were threatening his government and the only safe option was to step down.

He said he would stay on the job until tomorrow's parliamentary vote on his leadership. He called the vote a "sheer mockery of democracy" because the well armed militants forced the special session of parliament to give their coup a veneer of legitimacy.

There are fears that the resignation could instead ignite a new round of fighting in the South Pacific nation.

Mr Ulufa'alu was placed under house arrest on June 5 when the Malaita Eagles Force militia staged an attempted coup, seizing control of the capital, Honiara, closing its airport and raiding police armouries. The militia was demanding that Mr Ulufa'alu step down.

A rival militia, the Isatabu Freedom Movement, took on the Malaita Eagles and fighting ensued.

Mr Ulufa'alu was released last Friday, pending the parliamentary vote scheduled for tomorrow, and a 14-day truce was declared.

The vote was the result of a deal with rebels who seized the prime minister at gunpoint and demanded that he resign. A few days later, they released him and allowed him to stay in office until parliament decided his future.

"I don't want to be part of the new government," he told AP in his small office in Honiara. "This [the vote] is an insult to my integrity, to my family and the people in my constituency."

Chain-smoking and looking despondent with his shirt half untucked, Mr Ulufa'alu said he came from a big tribe and his people were "not going to just sit back".

Tensions have been growing for 18 months since indigenous Guadalcanal residents, called Isatabus, began forcing out migrants from the nearby island of Malaita. They were part of the group that sought the prime minister's overthrow last week. AP

fields.headline: Party revolt on Blair manifesto
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night faced a revolt over Labour's election manifesto after a comprehensive challenge was launched within the party to a range of government policies.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night faced a revolt over Labour's election manifesto after a comprehensive challenge was launched within the party to a range of government policies.

The prime minister is heading for a showdown with trade union leaders and constituency activists who have tabled hundreds of hostile amendments to documents intended to form the basis of his election platform.

His critics intend to use the party's policy-making process in an attempt to commit him to everything from a higher minimum wage and pensions to ditching directly elected mayors and retaining first-past-the-post elections.

The offensive is the most sustained drive to change the direction of New Labour policies since he succeeded John Smith six years ago and reflects growing rank-and-file unease with Mr Blair.

The detailed amendments to six internal party policy papers drawn up with the involvement of ministers will be discussed by Labour's national policy forum in Exeter on July 7. The documents are supposed to represent a draft of Labour's manifesto but Mr Blair will be opposed to a number of proposals that have widespread backing.

A party loyalist on the forum said last night: "It looks horrific. I can't see how they can get him round it. This threatens to be the first time they have turned him over big time.

"He's going to say, 'Come on lads, behave, it's the last conference before the election.' They're saying they know that, and that's why they think they can get something out if him."

Ministers and senior offi cials in Labour's Millbank HQ are expected to launch a counter-offensive before next month's meeting to get amendments withdrawn or rally support for more acceptable versions.

The revolt looms as Mr Blair struggles to assert his authority and end a series of splits, rows and disasters such as the handbagging last week by the Women's Institute.

Six policy documents are up for debate in Exeter: the economy; Britain in the world; education and employment; democracy and citizenship; industry, culture and agriculture; and the environment, transport and the regions.

Opposition to proposals to hold a referendum on proportional representation to appease the Liberal Democrats, seen as potential coalition partners by Mr Blair, is spearheaded by the GMB general union and Usdaw, the shopworkers. Both argue for the retention of the existing system and Usdaw also proposes the rejection of Lord Jenkins's modified PR system, though some constituencies support a referendum.

Big increases in the state pension and restoration of the linking to average earnings, opposed by Gordon Brown, are championed by Unison, the TGWU transport workers and the GMB.
