webTitle: Last roar for the lion of Damascus

fields.headline: Last roar for the lion of Damascus
fields.standfirst:
Chaotic scenes but mixed emotions at funeral of Syria's long-time leader

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Hafez al-Assad, the "Lion of Damascus", returned last night to his home village of Qurdaha in the mountains that overlook the Mediterranean. His burial in the family mausoleum marked the end of 30 years of rule in which he kept Syria one of the most closed societies in the world and opened the way for a new and potentially forward-looking generation led by his son Bashar.
fields.body:
Hafez al-Assad, the "Lion of Damascus", returned last night to his home village of Qurdaha in the mountains that overlook the Mediterranean. His burial in the family mausoleum marked the end of 30 years of rule in which he kept Syria one of the most closed societies in the world and opened the way for a new and potentially forward-looking generation led by his son Bashar.

The homecoming of the late president, 69, to the green heartland of his Alawite sect - now a potentially vulnerable minority if Bashar fails to consolidate power - was accompanied by chaotic and frenetic scenes as mourners broke through a security cordon to prostrate themselves across the coffin.

The Qurdaha ceremony came after a day-long state funeral that had transformed Damascus into a sea of black flags and banners. Tens of thousands had taken to the streets to pay their last respects to a politician who had been ruthless but provided the country with a semblance of stability.

While the turnout was substantial, however, there was not the huge swell that might have been expected for such a long-lasting leader - a reflection, perhaps, of his mixed legacy among Syrians.

His portrait remained on display just about everywhere, but often draped in black sashes. And now proliferating were pictures of the 34-year-old son he hoped would hold on to power, Bashar al-Assad.

For much of the route through Damascus a sprawling army of mourners, dressed all in black, marched alongside the coffin. Their wailing was mingled with chants of support for Bashar.

Thirst for change

In heat that was brutal even in the early morning, mourners were constantly fainting and being lifted away to safety. Some men tore open their flesh in a manic show of support.

But spite of such sporadic displays of intense grief, the mood in the crowd towards Assad was for the most part respectful rather than warm. A student in a black headband said he had lined the route because "Assad had been Syria's leader throughout my lifetime". Others in the crowd spoke cautiously about change and hoped Bashar could provide stability.

Wearing a dark suit and sunglasses, Bashar the shy president in waiting, followed the coffin, which was covered in the red, white and black of the Syrian flag. The gangly young man towering over soldiers and other mourners following the coffin had led a quiet life until called back to Syria from his training in Britain as an ophthalmologist after the 1994 death in a car crash of his elder brother Basil, the political heir apparent.

The only public opposition so far has been from Bashar's exiled uncle, Rifaat, 63, though yesterday there were some conciliatory sounds from that quarter when Rifaat's son in London spoke to the Guardian. But once Syria's political class emerges from mourning, Bashar will face the challenge of holding dynastic power in a state that is not a monarchy.

Representatives from more than 50 governments queued for five hours to pay their respects as the coffin lay in state yesterday in the so-called People's Palace on a hill overlooking Damascus. Bashar bent to have a word with each of them, occasionally breaking off to sit down for a slightly longer chat. He appeared nonplussed by his sudden immersion in the world of diplomacy but the US state department said it was excited about the possibility of real change. The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, described him as poised for leadership.

Some Syrians complained that President Clinton's failure to attend the was a snub and wondered why he had passed up the opportunity to get off to a good start with Bashar, and possibly revive the Middle East peace process. Assad, one of Israel's most implacable opponents, had failed to reach a settlement with Jerusalem in talks spanning nine years on the disputed Golan Heights.

Leaders absent

Apart from President Chirac of France, few western leaders attended yesterday's funeral, though many Middle Eastern leaders were there, including Yasser Arafat, head of the Palestinian authority who had once been imprisoned in Damascus by Assad.

From the People's Palace the coffin was carried on a gun carriage and flown part of the way north on a Syrian Airlines plane before going on by road on to Qurdaha. Assad had been brought up in the village in relative poverty, the ninth in a family of 11 children. Thousands turned up from all over Syria to line his final route.

Close to sunset beneath a minaret, Assad was placed in the mausoleum beside Basil, the tough-minded son who had been groomed to take over.

The crowds on the road to Qurdaha seemed bigger and the feeling among them more intense than in Damascus. With Assad in power, the Shia Muslim Alawite sect from which he emerged felt protected despite Syria's large Sunni majority. With his death, some must be wondering what will happen to them if Bashar fails to retain power.

Now Bashar is left to face the first conference of the Ba'ath party for 15 years, due this weekend, and the challenge of reviving a stagnant economy, a closed society and a peace process.

Last Post

For the moment, western journalists in Damascus and Qurdaha were surprised to find themselves virtually free yesterday to go where they liked and speak to whomever they wanted without the usual ministry minders from a government that had been paranoid about foreign media.

It may have been that the regime was too distracted by the funeral to worry, or there were just too many journalists for the machinery to cope. Optimists were hoping that it was the first sign that the government under Bashar is going to take a more relaxed view of the outside world.

The day ended 12 hours after the coffin left President Assad's modest house in Damascus to travel to his northern home. There military commanders formed a line on one side of the square outside the mausoleum in Qurdaha, the holy men in their black gowns and white caps formed another and Assad's political colleagues, in dark western suits, yet another.

As the last rays of the sun turned the stone of the mausoleum pink the white, the Last Post was sounded for the man who had been the first member of his family to leave the village.

fields.headline: GM 'pollution' unstoppable says Meacher
fields.standfirst:
Ministers order review of distances between crops

GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: The environment minister, Michael Meacher, yesterday conceded that there was no way of preventing GM crops contaminating conventionally grown neighbours in an admission that will increase the government's difficulties in trying to prove it can manage the introduction of the new technology.
fields.body:
The environment minister, Michael Meacher, yesterday conceded that there was no way of preventing GM crops contaminating conventionally grown neighbours in an admission that will increase the government's difficulties in trying to prove it can manage the introduction of the new technology.

Ministers have ordered a review of separation distances between crops following the recent fiasco over imported contaminated rape seed but Mr Meacher told the House of Commons yesterday: "It is false to pretend that there is any distance which is going to prevent some contamination.

"The question is how we can absolutely minimise that to a level which is acceptable to those buying the product, because it is they who buy the product which will have to determine what degree of GM in a non-GM food is acceptable to them."

Ministers have known this for at least a year, since a government commissioned report from the John Inness centre in Norwich warned them that both easy and reliable methods of quantifying and identy ing GM contamination would be difficult and that there was no system even with traditional seeds that could guarantee absolute genetic purity.

But the political stakes have been raised by the furore over the Advanta seeds episode which saw farmers unwittingly grow two rape seed crops from seed grown in Canada and, according to the company, polluted by GM pollen from at least a kilometre away.

Pete Riley, spokesman for the anti-GM Friends of the Earth, said: "A rambling debate over crop separation distances would be a complete waste of time."

The Conservative agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, said Labour was losing control of GM issues. "This makes a mockery of all the government's previous assurances that the environment can be protected."

Mr Meacher told MPs that traditional farming practices had established separation distances where "99.5% of the pollen would not get beyond those distances"

He added: "The problem is that small and sometimes vanishingly small amounts of pollen may and indeed can get considerable distances and the problem is to know exactly where we draw the line...."

There have been concerns, even on the pro-GM side, that the separation distances agreed with the biotech industry for field trials of GM crops may be too small. All are much smaller than the 800 metre barrier between GM and non-GM seed growing plants in Canada for instance. Organic farmers and many bee farmers want buffer zones of six miles to protect their crops and honey.

There was more trouble for the government last night when it emerged that only 48 sites now remained for this year's trials of maize, rape and sugar beet. Several farmers who originally volunteered have dropped out following pressure from anti-GM groups.

Government scientific advisers have said a minimum of 44 sites were needed this year for trials to be valid, only four fewer than the total. Two crops to be tested are now down to the minimum dozen each.

Mr Meacher has previously said there would be at least 66 sites and up to 80 available. Greenpeace, another anti-GM group, said one did not have to be a rocket scientist to see the trials were on the edge of collapse.

webTitle: Challenger backs off - for the moment

fields.headline: Challenger backs off - for the moment
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Rifaat al-Assad, the exiled brother of Syria's late president, is not seeking to take control, his son said yesterday. "I know my father and he is not somebody who wants power," Soumar al-Assad told the Guardian.
fields.body:
Rifaat al-Assad, the exiled brother of Syria's late president, is not seeking to take control, his son said yesterday. "I know my father and he is not somebody who wants power," Soumar al-Assad told the Guardian.

"If he is sure that security has returned to Syria and that power is in the hands of the people he will rest quietly at home."

This sign of conciliation runs counter to the earlier insistence of a spokesman at Rifaat's home in Marbella that Rifaat "represents legitimacy in Syria" and is "awaiting the appropriate moment" to return. The apparent absence of wide support in Syria may have persuaded the Rifaat camp to cool its pronouncements for now.

Soumar, who runs Arabic News Network, a London-based satellite TV station transmitting to the Middle East, described yesterday's Damascus funeral for President Hafez al-Assad as "completely inhuman".

"They [the regime] are trying to profit from the crying of the people to create some kind of political gain. Now they are trying to make the people of Syria pay the price of creating an inexperienced leader [the dead president's son, Bashar] purely because he's the son of his father," he said. "They are doing this by jumping over the will of the people. This is very dangerous for the stability of Syria and the stability of the Middle East.

"The people of Syria are mostly in favour of Rifaat, not because he has beautiful eyes but because he has fought all his life for what they want."

Syria's authorities are reported to have ordered that Rifaat be arrested if he tries to return. Soumar refused to say where his father is - usually he is to be found in Spain or France - other than saying "he's in Europe".

Soumar said his father believed that democratic elections for the Syrian presidency should be held. "But before that, you need to restore democratic institutions, freedom of speech and stability based on institutions and not on a man."

Asked how his father's 1983 coup attempt squared with talk of democracy, Soumar said: "The coup attempt was against my father. Rifaat had a different idea from the Ba'ath party - he was against power being held in the hands of a few people."

On Rifaat's attitude to peace talks with Israel, his son said: "It's a complicated issue and my father's priority is to internal affairs."

fields.headline: The needless operation
fields.trailText: Michelle McHugh felt a mixture of anger and elation when she learned that she had been misdiagnosed by the histologist at the centre of the Swindon blunders as having a pre-cancerous cell condition, writes Geoffrey Gibbs .
fields.body:
Michelle McHugh felt a mixture of anger and elation when she learned that she had been misdiagnosed by the histologist at the centre of the Swindon blunders as having a pre-cancerous cell condition, writes Geoffrey Gibbs .

Elation that there was nothing medically wrong, but anger that she had had to endure the pain and humiliation of intimate laser treatment at the hospital.

The 19-year-old sociology student's distress began two years ago when she was sent for a smear test by her GP. Two months later she received a letter saying it had shown abnormal cells.

After a second smear test she was sent to the Princess Margaret hospital for a biopsy which she was later told showed a pre-cancerous condition classified as CIN3. In January last year, a few days after her 18th birthday, Michelle went back to the hospital for laser treatment to remove cells she had been told could become cancerous.

Day surgery was carried out under general anaesthetic. Last week she received a letter saying none of the treatment had been necessary and that the hospital was reviewing the work of one of its pathologists. It said she had had the treatment "largely because of the findings reported by the pathologist. However as a result of the review it is felt you did not have any form of pre-cancer."

She was in tears when she read the letter. "I was elated but then I wondered why I had to go through all that pain and humiliation."

webTitle: Wake up, London mayor tells PM

fields.headline: Wake up, London mayor tells PM
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday issued a "wake-up call to Labour", warning that the hierarchy's "self-inflicted wounds" risked bringing to power the "most obscurantist Conservative government" of the last 100 years.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday issued a "wake-up call to Labour", warning that the hierarchy's "self-inflicted wounds" risked bringing to power the "most obscurantist Conservative government" of the last 100 years.

Complaining that the government was sticking to "too many policies of the old John Major agenda", the London mayor called on the prime minister to reposition Labour to the left of centre in the run-up to the general election, rather than "seek enemies" to define himself against.

After more than a month of quiet coalition building - punctuated with emollient speeches to City audiences - Mr Livingstone launched himself into the debate on the government's difficulties.

The challenge from a Conservative party that was set on imitating the Austrian neo-fascist Jorg Haider was a threat to everyone, he declared, advising Tony Blair to build a "broad social coalition" that would deliver real improvements in people's quality of life.

Downing Street said the mayor was "perfectly entitled to his view". But at Millbank headquarters one official said: "The man is in permanent opposition," adding that Mr Livingstone's consensual approach reflected his need to put together a team and a programme for London.

In interviews during the day, the mayor played down any suggestion that his remarks, first made in a newspaper column, were part of an attempt to seek a confrontation with Mr Blair. He would be encouraging people to vote Labour, he said, adding: "Does anyone really believe the Tories will give London more money than this government?

"People wouldn't believe how close the government and I are on the issues we are discussing. We are near to seeing a large increase in transport spending in London."

This is a reference to his talks with the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the London minister, Keith Hill, over this year's transport spending bid. Both sides say the discussions have gone well, though there have been conflicting noises off from the Treasury.

webTitle: Theatre bombed by IRA faces cash row with builders

fields.headline: Theatre bombed by IRA faces cash row with builders
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The award-winning Royal Exchange Theatre in Manchester is facing "financial disaster" because the builders who restored it after an IRA bomb attack are demanding to be paid three times what they tendered, its artistic director claimed last night.
fields.body:
The award-winning Royal Exchange Theatre in Manchester is facing "financial disaster" because the builders who restored it after an IRA bomb attack are demanding to be paid three times what they tendered, its artistic director claimed last night.

The £17m complex - the Barclay's Theatre Of The Year - which was extensively damaged in the blast four years ago, is unable to pay the £3m bill it claims its builders, Birse Construction, have landed them with.

Artistic director Braham Murray warned that the Royal Exchange could not afford to go to the high court to defend an action taken by Birse which is due to be heard in October.

Mr Murray, who claimed that the Royal Exchange Theatre only owed Birse around £1.2m, said that the situation was a potential financial disaster.

He added: "The worst case scenario is very bad indeed, although I don't think that it will happen. A judge has already thrown out an interim claim by Birse so I hope that they are sensible enough to settle now before this gets silly."

However, if the theatre were to lose, he admitted that they had no reserves to fall back on. "There is an emergency fund but it will not cover it," he said.

The two space age theatres which sit within the listed former Royal Exchange building are among the most successful in the country. With both its main 750 seat theatre-in-the-round and smaller studio equipped with cutting edge gadgetry, it is arguably the most advanced theatre of its type in the world.

The Royal Exchange is also one of the country's most daring touring companies, taking its productions to the sort of places theatre is not normally supposed to reach, like leisure centres and community halls in deprived and isolated communities.

"We simply do not have the money to spare to fight lengthy court actions," said Mr Murray.

But a spokesman for Birse denied that the company was suing the theatre as such. "We are engaged in ongoing and amicable discussions to try and resolve the issue.

He added: "Yes, there is a date in October set aside, which if all else fails, we could go to court, but it is not Birse's wish to go that far.

"We do not want to sue the Royal Exchange or do anything which might hurt it. We want to work this out with as little fuss as possible."

He denied that the firm was trying to make a killing. "Birse is only interesting in recouping the money it has spent. The Royal Exchange made many changes to what was originally tendered and they have to be paid for."

The spokesman added: "But the figures that are being bandied are nowhere near reality - they are way, way out of line."

webTitle: Victims: the women whose lives have been turned upside down

fields.headline: Victims: the women whose lives have been turned upside down
fields.standfirst: The wrong diagnosis :  The needless operation
fields.trailText: A knock on the door late last Wednesday afternoon brought the shattering news that has turned Rosalind Clarkson's world upside down once more, writes Geoffrey Gibbs .
fields.body:
A knock on the door late last Wednesday afternoon brought the shattering news that has turned Rosalind Clarkson's world upside down once more, writes Geoffrey Gibbs .

Ms Clarkson, 56, a college lecturer with three grown-up children, was diagnosed with breast cancer in the summer of 1996 and had surgery at the Princess Margaret hospital in Swindon for the removal of a lump. Her lymph nodes were also removed during the operation to see if the cancer had spread.

The treatment she received was standard for the condition: a course of radiotherapy and doses of the anti-cancer drug Temoxafen. A few days after the operation she saw her consultant again. To her relief he told her that tests showed the cancer had not spread to the lymph nodes.

She was overjoyed. "I decided I was going to put it all behind me and went back to work as a teacher. I was determined to get over it and not let cancer dominate my life."

She did not think about the illness again until last week when her GP turned up at her door looking worried. "She was beside herself. She said it was her duty to say that a check-up on samples now indicated that two of the lymph nodes were cancerous.

"It was a shattering piece of news. It has brought it all back. I have been com pletely unable to concentrate, I didn't stop trembling for two days and I'm near to tears at times. I am also deeply upset for those who are even less fortunate than me, the dozens and dozens of people who are perhaps too unwell or disturbed to come forward."

Ms Clarkson has been reassured that the treatment she received four years ago is what she would have been given had it been known that the lymph nodes were cancerous.

There are no symptoms to suggest that the cancer has passed into her system but she is anxiously waiting for a bone and liver scan.

"My family and friends and I have got to start all over again coming to terms with a disease I thought I had put behind me."

fields.headline: Telecity float back on at £580m
fields.trailText: Telecity, the internet infrastructure company which cancelled its flotation less than three weeks ago, is understood to have revived plans to join the stock market, with trading set to kick off as early tomorrow.
fields.body:
Telecity, the internet infrastructure company which cancelled its flotation less than three weeks ago, is understood to have revived plans to join the stock market, with trading set to kick off as early tomorrow.

The move bolsters hopes that investor confidence is returning to the high-technology sector after the sharp stock market sell-off during April and May.

Telecity, which provides facilities for housing hardware and high-performance inter net connections, is expected to be valued at around £580m by Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank handling the public offer - some £110m less than the value indicated last month.

The company operates internet exchanges that provide customers such as QXL.com and UUNet with web connections through a choice of telecommunications carriers including British Telecommunications, Cable & Wireless and NTL.

Its six exchanges, spread between Manchester, London and a number of European cities promise 24-hour engineering support to prevent websites from being forced offline.

Mike Kelly, the former Manchester University computer scientist who established the company in 1998, is believed to want to raise cash to fund European expansion with a long-term target of opening up to 40 new exchanges across Europe. Just over 20% of the company will be offered to investors.

It is estimated that each new exchange, housing banks of servers and routers, costs around £7m to open, while the European market for internet exchanges is said to be worth at around £3bn.

American rivals, such as Exodus Communications and Abovenet Communications, can command multi-billion dollar valuations.

Analysts point out that while investors have remained leery of business-to-consumer internet businesses, hi-tech infrastructure companies have continued to draw interest from fund managers.

The flotation of Telecity will also come as a relief to venture capital group 3i, which owns about 40% of the company.

webTitle: Doctors' errors cost NHS £2bn a year

fields.headline: Doctors' errors cost NHS £2bn a year
fields.standfirst: Doctors' mistakes cost NHS £2bn each year
fields.trailText: One in 10 people who are admitted to hospital will be damaged by medical errors which cost the health service £2bn to put right, it was acknowledged yesterday as the government unveiled ambitious proposals to transform the blame culture inside the NHS and learn from mistakes.
fields.body:
One in 10 people who are admitted to hospital will be damaged by medical errors which cost the health service £2bn to put right, it was acknowledged yesterday as the government unveiled ambitious proposals to transform the blame culture inside the NHS and learn from mistakes.

Every year around 850,000 patients admitted to hospitals suffer some sort of harm - usually of a minor nature but sometimes serious - according to a report published yesterday by Liam Donaldson, the government's chief medical officer. Preventable tragedies include the deaths of children wrongly given injections in their spine and babies who were stillborn because the monitor that should have registered their distress was recording the mother's heartbeat and not that of the foetus.

Proposing a new early warning system, which will have a computerised central register of error, Professor Donaldson said the scale of what nearly goes wrong was even greater, but the NHS was failing to learn from its mistakes.

"For every major injury, there are 30 minor ones, but 300 that could have ended in injury and don't," he said. Those 300 he likened to aircraft near-misses and said they represented a wasted opportunity. Like the aircraft industry of several decades ago, the NHS ignored the "free lessons" that could be learned from what were almost tragedies.

The admission of the scale of medical error - which has been estimated by outsiders but not acknowledged by government - and Prof Donaldson's proposals to lift the veil of secrecy and fear among medical staff which has hidden it in the past, came as government inspectors were sent in yesterday to investigate the hiring of locum doctors at four NHS trusts which employed James Elwood.

A review of the work of the 78-year-old pathologist found an unacceptably high rate of error in the laboratory tests he did to confirm diagnoses of cancer. It found that seven patients were wrongly diagnosed and suffered serious conse quences. Another patient whose case is being reinvestigated may require "further significant" treatment. The diagnosis for 215 others has been revised but the consequences are said to be less serious.

The commission for health improvement - the government's health inspectorate - will examine why the NHS trusts employed the retired doctor. The MSF union that represents pathology staff yesterday blamed staff shortages. "With graduate trainees in pathology laboratories starting on as little as £9,700 it is no wonder that the NHS is facing a recruitment crisis."

Prof Donaldson said the Elwood affair highlighted the need to ensure that the NHS learned from errors. "While the majority of clinical care provided by the NHS is of excellent standard, too often, as these recent reviews show, we have seen tragedies which may have been avoided if the lessons of the past had been properly learned," he said.

The Elwood scandal follows other prominent cases in which doctors have failed their patients, from the murdering GP Harold Shipman to the blundering gynaecologist Rodney Ledward whose operations on hundreds of women in Kent went wrong. A second gynaecologist, Richard Neale, faces being struck off by the General Medical Council, which has just begun hearing the allegations of 14 patients relating to botched operations, incompetence and arrogance.

Dr Elwood was condemned yesterday for refusing to help investigators who had been asking him from July last year to provide details of where he had worked and why he had opted to remove himself from the medical register, which means he cannot be disciplined. Last night he issued a statement saying he was now prepared to cooperate.

Prof Donaldson said yesterday that he wanted to get away from the culture of blame within the NHS. "The culture of the past has not encouraged reporting and analysis of adverse incidents," he said. When things go wrong - whether serious or minor - he hopes doctors, nurses and other staff will report them confidentially to the central register. If a pattern of poor performance or avoidable error becomes plain, the inspectors would be sent in.

Information that emerges will be put together with the data from 15,000 litigation cases that the NHS has outstanding. "Nobody has bothered to look in the past at what we can learn from them," he said. "It is a rich seam for the NHS." Other information will be added from the reporting systems for the side effects of drugs and medical devices, together with the confidential inquiries that are compiled into aspects of surgery.

Targets will be set to ensure persistent errors are ruled out. By 2001 Prof Donaldson wants to see no more patients dying or paralysed by spinal injections, while suicides by mental patients using shower curtain rails must end by 2005.

The British Medical Association said yesterday it supported the proposals. "Such a system could well have stopped some of the problems that have recently come to light," said its chairman, Ian Bogle.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, gave an enthusiastic welcome to what he called an "excellent report", saying he had asked Prof Donaldson to put his recommendations into effect immediately.

"The issues are complex, but patients, staff and the public have the right to expect the NHS to learn from its mistakes so we can ensure the alarm bells ring when there are genuine concerns so they can be nipped in the bud."

webTitle: Safety ideas 'left out of Paddington signals'

fields.headline: Safety ideas 'left out of Paddington signals'
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Safety precautions which could have prevented or lessened the impact of the Paddington train crash were not built into the development of the track outside the mainline station, the public inquiry into the accident was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Safety precautions which could have prevented or lessened the impact of the Paddington train crash were not built into the development of the track outside the mainline station, the public inquiry into the accident was told yesterday.

At one point in a risk assessment of Paddington signalling arrangements, managers used pennies on a diagram because computer generated equipment refused to work.

This happened just over a year before the Paddington tragedy last October, in which 31 people died and 400 were injured when a Thames Turbo train collided with a London bound Great Western express.

The details were described to the inquiry's chairman, Lord Cullen, by Colin Bray, Railtrack's signalling engineer, who said that he had come up with two "flank protection" schemes as far back as 1995, following a serious accident.

The scheme involved one train being directed on to a parallel track so that they passed each other, rather than colliding head on. But management at Railtrack decided not to accept the idea.

Mr Bray said that while at first it appeared obvious that passengers would be better off if trains passed, there was no evidence that trains travelling slowly would suffer less damage if trains hit end to end.

Another scheme could have linked signals so that if one was passed at red, the next would also turn red. But managers failed to adopt either idea. Linking signals would be "straightforward" but this could invoke safety risks in other areas.

Family and friends of the crash victims jeered at the inquiry when Mr Bray said that a decision on changing signal 109, one of the key pieces of evidence, was unlikely to be made before the end of the inquiry.

The inquiry continues.

webTitle: Mandelson at centre of Ulster dirty tricks row

fields.headline: Mandelson at centre of Ulster dirty tricks row
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, was yesterday at the centre of a dirty tricks row over claims that he wanted to suppress information linking the recent murder of a Catholic drugs dealer to the IRA for fear of upsetting the fragile institutions of devolved government.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, was yesterday at the centre of a dirty tricks row over claims that he wanted to suppress information linking the recent murder of a Catholic drugs dealer to the IRA for fear of upsetting the fragile institutions of devolved government.

The allegation came as the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, admitted that intelligence reports indicated the IRA was behind the shooting dead last month of Edmond McCoy, 28, the day after David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, narrowly persuaded his party to return to government with Sinn Fein. But Sir Ronnie emphasised the RUC was still keeping an open mind on who was responsible.

Mr Mandelson's supposed comments fuelled hardline unionist suspicions that the government was eager to turn a blind eye to IRA violence to avoid upsetting the peace process. The comments were said to have come in a letter to the first minister, Mr Trimble, leaked to the Democratic Unionist Party, which opposes the Good Friday agreement.

But the Northern Ireland Office said it had no record of the letter, and suggested it did not exist. Mr Trimble's aides called the note a malicious forgery.

But Ian Paisley Jnr, a DUP assembly member, who claimed the letter was leaked to him from Mr Trimble's office, said: "They are engaged in damage limitation spin, wanting us to focus on the forgery allegations, rather than on the material it contains. I have no doubt it is kosher."

The row underlines the unease surrounding devolution. There are fears about whether the IRA's initiative on arms, which unlocked the decommissioning impasse, is still on the table as the row over policing reform continues.

Sinn Fein has warned that the IRA's offer to put arms beyond use was based on implementation of Chris Patten's recommendations on RUC reform. The inference is the offer could be withdrawn because the policing bill dilutes the Patten proposals.

NIO sources concede there will be a mood of panic if the IRA fails to allow the weapons inspectors, Cyril Ramaphosa, ex-ANC secretary general, and Martti Ahtisaari, former Finnish president, access to the first of its arms dumps by the end of June. Mr Trimble would then come under pressure to again quit the executive.

Sinn Fein had made it clear it was unable to back even the Patten proposals, but is now pushing hard for them to be adopted in full.

Mr Mandelson said in a statement last week that he would have no hesitation in acting if there was evidence of IRA involvement in the attack on Mr McCoy, executed in Dunmurry, close to south Belfast, on May 28. He raised the prospect of halting the early release of IRA prisoners under the agreement.

Mr Trimble sought a halt to the early release of convicted IRA terrorists last July when the IRA killed the informer, Charles Bennett. But for him to call for sanctions now would be to threaten the future of the executive he leads.

Sinn Fein was kicked out of the all-party talks for six working days in February 1998 after the IRA murdered drugs dealer Brendan Campbell. But it also shot dead the following day a leading loyalist Bobby Dougan, 38. Its temporary exclusion flowed more from that assassination than the targeting of one of its own community.

The same IRA gang which killed Dougan is believed to be responsible for Mr McCoy's assassination.

Sir Ronnie's comment, as he left the Police Federation annual conference in Templepartick, Co Antrim, made it clear there was no evidence to confirm IRA involvement in the McCoy murder. Under the standards he set out in his statement last week, that meant there was no need for Mr Mandelson to act.

The allegation came as the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, admitted that intelligence reports indicated the IRA was behind the shooting dead last month of Edmond McCoy, 28, the day after David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, narrowly persuaded his party to return to government with Sinn Fein. But the Northern Ireland Office said it had no record of the letter, and suggested it did not exist. Mr Trimble's aides called the note a malicious forgery. But Ian Paisley Jnr, a DUP assembly member, who claimed the letter was leaked to him from Mr Trimble's office, said: "They are engaged in damage limitation spin, wanting us to focus on the forgery allegations, rather than on the material it contains. fields.headline: 'IRA arms' trial ends in confusion
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A case once said to threaten the Ulster peace process ended in confusion last night as three men were convicted of buying weapons in the United States and sending them to Ireland, but not to arm the IRA.
fields.body:
A case once said to threaten the Ulster peace process ended in confusion last night as three men were convicted of buying weapons in the United States and sending them to Ireland, but not to arm the IRA.

The court at Fort Lauderdale, Florida, heard that Conor Claxton,27, from West Belfast, Martin Mullan, a 30-year-old handyman in Philadelphia, and Anthony Smyth,43, a Fort Lauderdale car salesman, opposed the peace process and sent dozens of firearms through the mail listed as toys, video recorders and computers.

All three were cleared of conspiracy to aid terrorists and to commit murder. They will be sentenced in August on the less serious smuggling convictions. The three could have faced life in jail had they been found guilty of the conspiracy charges.

Smyth's fiancee, 35-year-old former stockbroker Siobhan Browne, had pleaded guilty to one of 33 charges against her and could be jailed for up to five years for conspiracy. Police in New York and Ireland intercepted 23 packages containing 122 guns and ammunition mailed by the group, the court was told. The weapons had been bought in Florida.

Claxton said during the month long trial that he was the only one who knew about the gun smuggling and that he did not know it was illegal. He claimed that militant Irish-Americans pushed him to buy weapons because they feared the peace deal would leave defenceless Catholics to face armed Protestant paramilitaries and police.

fields.headline: Case history
fields.standfirst:
Errors that killed a boy
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: For every Harold Shipman who goes around killing his patients there are thousands of well-intentioned, competent doctors and nurses who make the occasional mistake. Sometimes these have very serious consequences.
fields.body:
For every Harold Shipman who goes around killing his patients there are thousands of well-intentioned, competent doctors and nurses who make the occasional mistake. Sometimes these have very serious consequences.

In the past, the chief medical officer's report published yesterday points out, there has been no reporting system and no central analysis of what goes wrong and how it might be prevented. And so history repeats itself.

There have been 13 cases of people, mainly children, being killed or paralysed after drugs were wrongly injected into the spine. Twelve involved the injection of a group of anti-can cer drugs called vinca alkaloids, given to leukaemia patients, which are almost always fatal if they go into the spine instead of the arm.

An analysis of the death of one of these children reveals a catalogue of mistakes. The child was allowed to eat and drink before his chemotherapy, which was to take place under general anaesthetic, when he should have been fasted. There were no beds available on the cancer ward, so he had to go to a mixed-speciality area. His notes were lost. There was no cancer nurse on the ward because of shortages so a housekeeper brought two drugs to his bedside, one for spinal injection and the other into a vein, that should have been kept apart.

A junior doctor used the confusing abbreviations IV and IT for intravenous and intrathecal (into the spine) on the prescription. Because of the fasting problem, the treatment was postponed and a different doctor took over, who had not been briefed.

The senior registrar was called to give the chemotherapy was unable to leave his ward and told the anaesthetist to go ahead, not realising two drugs had been delivered. The inexperienced anaesthetist injected the wrong drug , vincristine, into the child's spine. The boy died five days later.

webTitle: Doctor blundered in more than 200 cases

fields.headline: Doctor blundered in more than 200 cases
fields.standfirst: Some patients received treatment they did not need and others face further cancer tests because of consultant pathologist's mistakes
fields.trailText: James Elwood, the 78-year-old consultant at the centre of the latest health service scandal, was employed by the Swindon and Marlborough NHS trust to provide holiday cover for other consultants in the hard-pressed histopathology department of Princess Margaret hospital, Swindon, when there were only two full-time consultants working there.
fields.body:
James Elwood, the 78-year-old consultant at the centre of the latest health service scandal, was employed by the Swindon and Marlborough NHS trust to provide holiday cover for other consultants in the hard-pressed histopathology department of Princess Margaret hospital, Swindon, when there were only two full-time consultants working there.

His work as a histopathologist involved the interpretation of tissue samples taken from patients' bodies allowing doctors to confirm or alter their diagnosis of the patients' condition.

In March last year worried staff at the hospital decided to carry out a review of 400 cervical biopsies after concern was expressed within the gynaecology department about an apparent mismatch between what was being seen in the outpatient department and reports coming back from the lab. The decision triggered a nationwide investigation into Dr Elwood's recent work involving a review of 10,358 cases at hospitals in Sussex, Surrey, Bath and at Swindon .

The 15-month Swindon review was completed last week when shocked patients, some of whom had received unnecessary treatment, were told of the blunders by letter or in more serious cases by a visit from their GP.

Some patients received treatment they did not need. Others were shattered to learn last week that they might need further cancer checks when they thought they were clear.

Sonia Mills, chief executive of the Swindon and Marlborough trust, said yesterday that seven patients had been identified who had suffered "serious consequences" as a result of an incorrect reading of their histology samples. Another patient might need further "significant treatment".

"Each of these patients has been informed of the situation, reviewed by their consultants and offered further care. It is clear that this has been immensely traumatic for all the patients concerned and their families and the trust deeply regrets that these errors have occurred," she said.

Dr Elwood was recruited through what the hospital says was a reputable agency and came with appropriate references from a 34-year career working in the NHS and the military. But since the delicate review of his work at the PMH began 15 months ago he has until now refused to provide any information about his recent employment history.

Health service executives, who have condemned his refusal as reprehensible and unethical, were forced to send out an alert letter to all NHS trusts in the UK as well as hospitals in Ireland to find out if he had been employed as a locum elsewhere.

They are unable to bring disciplinary proceedings against the consultant because he removed himself from the GMC's medical register in January after he was confronted with accusations of his mistakes.

Separate reviews were conducted into his work at the Mid Sussex hospital in Haywards Heath and Frimley Park hospital in Surrey. Two cases were discovered in Sussex where follow-up care should have been different although doctors say there were no clinical consequences as a result of the wrong interpretations. Three cases are being reviewed at Frimley Park.

A hospital in Tralee, Ireland has confirmed that Dr Elwood worked there as a locum for several summers. It is understood that a serious problem was identified there last year.

Concerns had also been expressed about Dr Elwood's performance while he was working at the Royal United Bath hospital.

In a review of all specimens reported by Dr Elwood on the 22 occasions he worked at Swindon between February 1995 and February 1999, independent consultants looked at 8,630 cases - of which 223 were misdiagnosed.

The Princess Margaret hospital would not go into details of how the worst affected patients had suffered as a result of the bungle. But they were the only ones among the 223 cases identified who had been given the wrong surgical treatment, radiotherapy or chemotherapy or who had not received such therapy or the correct operation. The life of one of the patients is said to be threatened. But the hospital said there was doubt whether that is a result of the misdiagnosis.

Among less serious cases, examples included one patient who was told he had residual cancer after a prostate operation when tests later confirmed that he did not. They also included a woman who was told a womb condition was due to a hormonal imbalance, but has now been told she is in danger of developing a malignancy.

Ms Mills said the hospital had contacted everyone who had been adversely affected by the review and that patients who had not been contacted had no cause for concern.

Dr Elwood said last night: "I am deeply sorry if I have been the cause of distress and suffering to patients as a result of my work at the Swindon and Marlborough NHS trust. I will be cooperating fully with the trust in their review of this matter."

fields.headline: Hillsborough police 'sent fans to death'
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The 96 victims of Hillsborough were funnelled to their death by two criminally negligent police officers, a long-awaited private prosecution was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The 96 victims of Hillsborough were funnelled to their death by two criminally negligent police officers, a long-awaited private prosecution was told yesterday.

The senior commander then lied and tried to lay the blame for the tragedy on fans when Football Association officials confronted him while bodies were still being removed from the crush, Leeds crown court heard.

"Men, women and children had surrendered responsibility for their personal safety to the officers as completely as we do to a pilot and co-pilot when we board a plane," said Alun Jones QC, prosecuting on behalf of the families of those killed in the FA Cup semi-final disaster in April 1989. But failure to take obvious precautions forced hundreds down tunnels into caged terrace pens where they were trapped in "a hideous crush".

More than 40 relatives of the victims watched as former chief superintendent David Duckenfield, 55, and retired superintendent Bernard Murray, 58, stood to deny charges of manslaughter and misconduct in public office. The familiar but terrible events of April 15 - "a wonderful, sunny spring day", said Mr Jones - were then rehearsed again, focusing on eight calamitous minutes after gates were opened to relieve a crush in Leppings Lane outside the Sheffield Wednesday ground.

"Mr Duckenfield's decision to order the opening of the gates was understandable as an urgent crisis measure," said Mr Jones, but it was followed by a criminal lack of measures to cope with the sudden surge. South Yorkshire police policy of allowing fans to "find their own level" - with no police or stewards to guide them to less crowded terrace pens - was catastrophic.

Mr Jones said that Mr Duckenfield was rapidly aware of this, because he "deceitfully and dishonestly concealed the fact that he had ordered the opening of the gates" when aghast officials raced to his control box.

The then FA chief executive Graham Kelly and his head of external affairs Glen Kirton, who will both give prosecution evidence, were "given to understand by the chief superintendent that a gate had been forced and there had been an inrush of supporters".

"Mr Duckenfield had realised very quickly the causes of the disaster and that he was responsible," Mr Jones told the jury of four women and eight men. "He realised that a man like Graham Kelly would be likely to talk within minutes to the media, and he sought immediately to deflect the blame from himself and place it on the spectators."

The jury, who were shown pictures of the dead and dying Liverpool fans crushed in two pens behind the goal, heard that Mr Duckenfield had also failed for half an hour to admit what had really happened to an assistant chief constable who was at the match as a spectator. He had made a public apology six weeks later and had acknowledged that the fans were not to blame and that he had called them "a happy crowd".

Mr Jones said: "The disaster was not caused by crowd trouble, rioting or hooliganism. Violence and vandalism have disfigured our national game from time to time over the last 30 years and more. It may be tempting to some people to assume that hooliganism caused these deaths, but it is not so.

"The spectators were a normal, large, big-city, modern football crowd. Some were boisterously singing and chanting. There were a few showing visible signs of drink as you get on any large sporting occasion like this."

The jury, which will watch video footage of the disaster this morning, was advised not to follow media coverage of the case by Mr Justice Hooper, who earlier tested potential jurors with a questionnaire on the hugely emotive case. The panel was reduced from 100 to 20 after written replies to questions about recollecting the Manic Street Preachers' album This Is My Truth Tell Me Yours, which featured a track about the disaster, or having seen the 1996 Granada TV documentary Hillsborough.

The case has been brought by the Hillsborough Family Support Group, which represents the majority of victims' families, after dissatisfaction with the results of a public inquiry, an inquest and a judge's review of evidence. Mr Jones told the jury: "We ask you not to speculate why this case has been brought now, or why no prosecution was brought, by us or others, nearer the time. Your task is to decide the case on the evidence."

The trial is expected to continue for between four and six weeks.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Gun theft PC faces jail
fields.body:
Gun theft PC faces jail

A police officer who gave away a pistol handed in during a guns amnesty following the Dunblane school massacre was yesterday convicted at Hull crown court of stealing a .22 semi-automatic pistol and told to expect a jail sentence.

Desmond Pearson, 53, a constable with South Yorkshire police, was also found guilty of stealing two other guns, and stealing cash. The trial was adjourned for sentencing.

Haig telegraph up for auction

The telegraph sent by Sir Douglas Haig, commander- in-chief of British forces in France, ordering troops to advance on the Germans in the closing months of the first world war, is being auctioned today in Swindon, with his original telegraph ordering the armistice on November 11, 1918.

Farmers urge 'buy British'

A red and blue tractor logo was unveiled yesterday by Tony Blair as part of a "buy British" campaign by the National Farmers' Union. The logo will appear on home grown produce that meets hygiene, environmental and animal welfare standards in an effort to stave off the threat of cheap foreign imports.

Murder inquiry as body found

A murder investigation was launched yesterday after a woman's body was found near the royal palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh. Detectives believe the body could be that of Margaret Donoghue, 48, who disappeared from her home near Holyrood Park last February.

Branson apology to Mr Virgin

Roger Virgin, a carpenter, from Tongwynlais, near Cardiff, yesterday received £5,000 and an apology from Sir Richard Branson, whose Virgin empire had threatened to sue unless Mr Virgin changed his company name, Virgin Building Services. Sir Richard's lawyers had argued that Mr Virgin's business could be confused with Virgin's property development company.

30 seconds that may save jelly

Food scientist Peter Barham, of Bristol University, and restaurateur Heston Blumenthal have created a jelly which sets in 30 seconds, an innovation which could reverse the slump in jelly sales caused by the demand for quick and easy foods.

webTitle: Jails inspector backs US policy to halt suicides

fields.headline: Jails inspector backs US policy to halt suicides
fields.trailText: Prisoners are committing suicide in record numbers while ministers drag their feet on implementing a prevention scheme which has succeeded in the US, the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Prisoners are committing suicide in record numbers while ministers drag their feet on implementing a prevention scheme which has succeeded in the US, the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, said yesterday.

Record numbers of inmates killed themselves for the second year running last year, with the toll rising from 82 to 91.

Sir David warned at the launch of his annual report on jails in England and Wales that the total could be higher this year. A Home Office spokesman said later that the number so far this year was 37.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, had promised a pilot scheme last September but it had not yet materialised, said Sir David.

"America had the same situation we are going through here and they solved it through a very imaginative piece of work," he added. "Why not give it a go. What we have now is not working."

Under the US scheme a mental health nurse was on duty at every prison 24 hours a day, officers were trained to spot mental health problems and prisoners were paid to act as observers, reporting problems among fellow inmates.

Sir David said there were only five suicides last year in US federal prisons, which hold 123,000.

In New York prisons only two inmates killed themselves. The chief inspector launched a renewed attack on prison officers' attitudes towards prisoners and the role played by their union, the Prison Officers Association.

Prison culture was changing, he said. Four years ago good staff had stood out from the bad, but now the bad stood out from the good.

The last year had seen some of the worst examples of unacceptable behaviour such as officers ruling by fear at Wandsworth prison, south London, and others facing criminal assault charges at Wormwood Scrubs, west London. By failing to condemn such behaviour the POA "gives the impression that it is in favour of it".

Questioning of prisoners revealed that many feared for their safety in prison and reported that they had been badly treated on entry. In Wandsworth, only 42% reported that they never feared for their safety.

Sir David also used his report to renew his attacks on prison drug policy and the scarcity and inconsistency of education and training.

With 60% of inmates at some prisons using heroin when they were admitted, taking the percentage testing positive for cannabis as a measure of drug problems was not an adequate response, he said.

A prison service spokeswoman said one of the recommendations on suicide prevention from Sir David's review last September was being piloted.

webTitle: Disabled people still face exclusion, finds poll

fields.headline: Disabled people still face exclusion, finds poll
fields.trailText: Three years of Labour government have failed to make any appreciable improvement to the lot of disabled people, a survey today suggests.
fields.body:
Three years of Labour government have failed to make any appreciable improvement to the lot of disabled people, a survey today suggests.

Fifty-five per cent of the population thinks disabled people "tend to be excluded and not allowed to be useful members of society", the survey found, in results which are little different from those of polls in previous years.

As many as 79% of the respondents to the survey for the charity, Leonard Cheshire, thought it unfair that most disabled people in paid work have to meet the costs of community care services from their income.

The findings come as John Hutton, the social care minister, today hosts a summit to help shape the statutory guidance he has promised to end the glaring discrepancies between local authorities in their policies on charging for care services. The survey, by NOP, was carried out in March. It found that only 14% of the population works with somebody who is disabled and 40% has no contact with any disabled people.

Ian Christie, who has analysed the findings for the Leonard Cheshire charity, said that the government must take steps to promote familiarity with disability.

Mr Christie, senior research associate with the Demos think tank, said that ministers needed to do far more to counter the general misapprehension that making adjustments for disabled people was expensive.

More than 6.5m people have a long term disability, including 2.6m who are out of work and claiming benefits. However, only 2,700 people have so far been found work under the government's New Deal programme for the disabled.

fields.headline: Try-out for US-style public defenders
fields.trailText: Plans for US-style public defenders to represent people charged with criminal offences will be tried out in six areas in England and Wales next year.
fields.body:
Plans for US-style public defenders to represent people charged with criminal offences will be tried out in six areas in England and Wales next year.

But details unveiled in two consultation papers yesterday make it clear that defendants will not be forced to use the service. Instead, they may choose to be represented by a private law firm with a contract to do legal aid work.

The plans are part of a shake-up of legal aid under which only the new criminal defence service or law firms which meet quality controls and secure a contract with the legal services commission will be allowed to handle defence work paid for by the state.

Critics, especially the bar, have attacked the idea of a state salaried service and warned that it would fail to attract the best lawyers.

They cite public defender systems in some parts of the US, which are underfunded, swamped with cases and seen as delivering a third rate service. But in other areas, where funding is adequate, public defence services function well.

Bruce Houlder, public affairs spokesman for the Bar Council, said: "We hope and expect that for persons arrested the choice of a lawyer will be real rather than illusory."

Robert Sayer, president of the Law Society, said: "Our concern is that clients should be guaranteed a quality service and freedom of choice between the salaried service and a private solicitor. The government must ensure that creating a salaried defence service does not undermine those firms which provide most of the publicly funded legal services."

The decision to allow defendants a choice of public defender or private lawyer will appease some critics. Under a pilot scheme, which is already under way in Scotland, most defendants born in certain months are obliged to use the public defender scheme if they want the state to pay for their defence.

The lord chancellor's department will consult with researchers to decide where to set up the initial six offices. Most are expected to be in large cities. The scheme will be phased in gradually and will be evaluated by the researchers over four years.

Plans are for at least three offices to start providing services to the public from next April.

Salaried defenders will be expected to recruit their clients through duty solicitor schemes in magistrates courts and police stations, where they will give initial advice alongside lawyers working in private practice.

Clients advised by a salaried defender will have seven days to decide whether to change to a private law firm. Once the decision is made, change will be possible only in limited circumstances.

Public defenders will be able to represent clients from the police station through to trial in the crown court, including defending them in court if the defender has crown court advocacy rights. The service will also include a budget for the hire of independent barristers or solicitors.

The service will handle all types of case with limited exceptions such as serious fraud.

The government hopes that the plans, replacing the legal aid system under which the state has paid for any lawyer that a defendant has picked, will drive up standards, and eventually cut costs.

David Lock, parliamentary under secretary to the lord chancellor's department, said the scheme would allow defence lawyers to concentrate on their job.

"If lawyers wanted to run a business they would have become a businessman or businesswoman," he added. "If what they wanted to do was dedicate themselves to representing their clients without going to business, they would choose to work as a salaried defender."

fields.headline: Decaying tomb on endangered list
fields.trailText: The World Monuments Fund in Britain yesterday declared a marble column in Ireland, set up by an English landlord to celebrate the victory over Napoleon in Egypt, and a decaying marble tomb in Rutland carved by Grinling Gibbons, as among the world's most endangered historic sites.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The World Monuments Fund in Britain yesterday declared a marble column in Ireland, set up by an English landlord to celebrate the victory over Napoleon in Egypt, and a decaying marble tomb in Rutland carved by Grinling Gibbons, as among the world's most endangered historic sites.

They are typically quixotic choices for a heritage organisation whose annual list of these sites has often provoked astonishment - and gratitude, since listing often implies lavish grants backed by American Express.

WMF, based in New York, is a private, non-profit organisation with independent affiliates in Britain, France, Italy, Portugal, and Spain. Previous British campaigns have included a decaying Victorian redbrick church in Manchester, and medieval barns in Kent owned by an Oxford college.

The Irish conservation charity, An Taisce, regards the Browne-Clayton monument as one of the most important neo-classical structures in Ireland, but the granite column in county Wexford has stuck out like a sore thumb in a county with a long tradition of militant nationalism.

It was built in 1839 by General Robert Browne-Clayton, modelled on Pompey's Pillar in Alexandria, to commemorate his commander, General Sir Ralph Abercromby, and the English victory in Egypt in 1801. It has been in danger of collapse since it was struck by lightning five years ago. It has various local nicknames, including Browne's Nonsense.

The county council chairman, Sean Doyle, an IRA member until he resigned in the 1980s in protest at the Harrods bombing, now supports the campaign to restore the monument.

The Grinling Gibbons tomb is a less controversial choice. The huge tomb of Viscount Campden is regarded as his best work in marble. It dominates the church at Exton in Rutland, heaving with figures representing the viscount, one of his wives and his 19 children by four wives.

Last night the fund announced a string of grants to projects around the world, including £6,400 for repairs to the Grinling Gibbons tomb. No grant has been decided yet for Browne's Nonsense.

fields.headline: Campaign to increase organ donation
fields.trailText: A campaign to increase the number of people who donate their organs after death and strengthen transplant services was launched by medical organisations, charities, and patient groups yesterday.
fields.body:
A campaign to increase the number of people who donate their organs after death and strengthen transplant services was launched by medical organisations, charities, and patient groups yesterday.

The British Medical Association, which is spearheading the effort, supports the introduction of an "opt out" donor scheme in the UK, where people who die suddenly will be assumed to have agreed to having their kidney or heart removed unless they have previously logged their objection with a central register. But Michael Wilks, chairman of the BMA's ethics committee, stressed yesterday that the campaign was broad based, involving many organisations such as the Royal College of Nursing, which does not support what is also known as presumed consent.

"Presumed consent is only one part of the jigsaw," he said. "If public opinion moves towards a change in the law, I think it could be a valuable contribution to increasing the number of organs available, but there are so many aspects of the transplantation system that need improving and boosting, that a radical review of the whole organ donation system seems the logical next step and one around which we can all unite."

There is a serious organ shortage in the UK, and it is getting worse. In 1998, 7% fewer transplants were carried out than in 1997, while waiting lists increased by 3%. Last year there was no change in the number of the transplants, but the waiting list grew by 3%.

Part of this is due to fewer fatal car accidents because of seat belt legislation. But efforts to increase the donor pool by advertisements urging people to carry donor cards have not been successful. At the same time, transplant technology has improved, allowing more people to have the operation.

But patients and their doctors are now frustrated by long waiting lists, which for many means a steady deterioration in their condition. From 1995-1999, about 1,000 patients died while waiting for a heart, heart and lung, lung or liver transplant. Many more will have died before even reaching the waiting list - and the number does not include those who die because there are insufficient dialysis facilities, says the BMA.

The situation contrasts with some of Europe's success stories, notably Spain. Robert Sells, a transplant surgeon in Liverpool, said Spain had transformed its transplant service from having a shortage to exporting surplus organs to neighbouring countries.

"In 1985 a nephrologist [kidney specialist] who was politically very active pointed out to the government that Spain was lagging behind not only in health care but was practically the lowest supplier of donated organs and huge numbers of people were dying.

"In 1986, a law was passed that allowed obligatory donation unless a refusal was registered in the national computer. That was converted to a a veto from a family in serious distress being allowable."

The kidney specialist became health secretary, and has instituted a system of transplant co-ordinators based in Spain's hospitals that is the envy of UK doctors. The result, said Professor Sells, is that Spain leads Europe, having increased its organ donation from five per million to 31. Other countries with opt-out donor schemes are close behind - the Czech Republic is second with about 28 per million, then Belgium with 26. In the UK there are 15 per million.

But although the BMA voted in favour of an opt-out system at its annual conference last year, its leaders feel public opinion is not ready for the change. It also points out that there are shortages of surgeons to perform the transplants and, critically, of intensive care beds. Unless these problems are overcome, an opt-out scheme would not solve anything.

fields.headline: Villagers reject refugees
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Residents of a Somerset village with no shop, pub or post office expressed disbelief yesterday as the head of a religious charity claimed their hamlet was the perfect place in which to integrate 74 asylum seekers into British society.
fields.body:
Residents of a Somerset village with no shop, pub or post office expressed disbelief yesterday as the head of a religious charity claimed their hamlet was the perfect place in which to integrate 74 asylum seekers into British society.

The public gallery of a Bridgwater planning inquiry filled with muffled laughter as the Rev Martin Blakebrough, director of the Baptist charity Kaleidoscope, said he believed the refugees would readily "find acceptance" in the 314-population village of Over Stowey.

The reaction came on the first day of the two day inquiry into why the local council rejected plans to house asylum seekers in Quantock Lodge, a former boarding school in the village.

In January, Sedgemoor district council rejected the proposal. But Kaleidoscope launched an appeal.

webTitle: MI5 under fire from MPs over Norwood spy case

fields.headline: MI5 under fire from MPs over Norwood spy case
fields.standfirst: More about Melita Norwood and the Mitrokhin archive
fields.trailText: MI5 was yesterday severely rebuked for misleading ministers over the Melita Norwood spy saga in a report which raised serious questions about the agency's lack of accountability.
fields.body:
MI5 was yesterday severely rebuked for misleading ministers over the Melita Norwood spy saga in a report which raised serious questions about the agency's lack of accountability.

Parliament's cross-party intelligence and security committee chastised MI5 for deciding not to prosecute Mrs Norwood after she was identified by Vasili Mitrokhin, a KGB defector, in 1992. That decision was a matter for the government's law officers, and not for the security service, it said.

The committee was told by MI5 the decision was taken by an unidentified relatively junior officer on the grounds of her age and that her offences had been committed 50 years earlier. The committee described MI5's decision not to refer her case to the attorney general as a "serious failure".

Astonishingly, it said Dame Stella Rimington, then head of MI5, was never told about the Norwood case. In MI5's words, it had "slipped out of sight" between 1993 and 1998.

Nor was she told about John Symonds, a KGB contact codenamed Scot who had been given immunity from prosecution relating to a separate investigation into police corruption.

So great was the extent to which ministers were kept in the dark that the US president may well have learned about MI6's success in obtaining information about past KGB activities from Mr Mitrokhin before the British prime minister, the committee said.

The Norwood case returned to MI5's sights after MI6 drew up a careful plan for the publication of a book by Mr Mitrokhin with the help of Christopher Andrew, a Cambridge professor regarded as a "safe pair of hands" who had signed the Official Secrets Act.

The committee described a catalogue of mistakes as a "muddle", and what it called "a failing in the system". Tom King, its chairman and former Tory cabinet minister, said yesterday: "Very few people knew anything about Mrs Norwood".

Jack Straw was not told about the book project until late 1998. Nor was he told about MI5's decision to decline to interview Mrs Norwood.

In March 1999, Robin Cook was told that both the home secretary and the attorney general were vetting the book. "This was not the case," the committee said.

It added: "Officials failed to provide ministers with the necessary support and advice ... Failures by officials, some at senior level, caused ministers to make decisions on the basis of incorrect information."

The plans for a "controlled and unsensationalised" publication of the Mitrokhin book went badly wrong after a BBC reporter, David Rose, identified her as a Soviet spy.

Mr Rose yesterday insisted he discovered her from information gleaned in the US.

However, the committee revealed yesterday that MI6 passed him "material" in April last year, five months before the book was published.

BBC plans to identify Mrs Norwood in a documentary enabled Mr Mitrokin to reveal her name in his book, leading to what the committee called "misleading stories" which sabotaged Whitehall's plans.

Despite media claims that Mrs Norwood was one of Moscow's most significant agents in Britain, MI5 told the committee her value as an atom spy was "at most, marginal".

Mrs Norwood, 87, was secretary of the British Non-ferrous Metals Research Association after the second world war. According to MI5, she provided the KGB with intelligence on cladding material used in British nuclear reactors.

The committee said Mr Mitrokhin walked into the British embassy in a Baltic state capital in 1992 after the CIA turned down his offer. He handed to MI6 10 envelopes containing over 2,000 closely typed pages of notes with information culled from KGB files.

MI6 described the material as "not only illuminating past KGB activity against western countries but also promising to nullify many of Russia's current assets". The FBI described it as "the most detailed and extensive pool of counter-intelligence ever received".

The government yesterday accepted the committee's criticisms.

webTitle: Blair spin chief retires to shadows

fields.headline: Blair spin chief retires to shadows
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's embattled press secretary, Alastair Campbell, is moving his role away from daily dealings with the media towards a backroom concern with strategic planning as the general election looms.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's embattled press secretary, Alastair Campbell, is moving his role away from daily dealings with the media towards a backroom concern with strategic planning as the general election looms.

Mr Campbell's absence for the fourth successive Downing Street briefing this week prompted speculation that he is lying low in the wake of the Mr Blair's controversial speech to the Women's Institute conference at Wembley.

That pattern has occasionally been detected during turbulent periods of the Blair regime, especially with some MPs believing the government's current troubles stem from too much spin.

Downing Street rejects such talk and even claims that its handicap is the lack of a strong narrative message to offer voters, either directly or via what officials regard as a jaded and hostile press, radio and TV.

But a lower profile for his spokesman would also be consistent with Mr Blair's promise at Wembley to "trust people more. We don't need to fight over every headline".

It will be interpreted as a signal to MPs and activists that ministers acknowledge their complaints. But officials revealed yesterday that Mr Campbell is now in charge of the strategic communications unit at No 10.

The SCU is one of several units set up in the Blair years to help create what amounts to a prime minister's department in all but name. It writes speeches and works on the coordination of government themes and messages.

Mr Campbell's press office deputy, Godric Smith, is constrained by civil service rules when he stands in for his boss.

"I have been doing more briefings but [Mr Campbell] will continue to talk to you," he assured reporters yesterday. Mr Campbell has already signalled he will resign before the election to help the campaign.
