fields.headline: U-turn by Portillo over employment
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo yesterday embarked on one of the most spectacular U-turns of his career when he stole the language of post-war Keynesians to declare that the Conservatives were now in favour of full employment.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo yesterday embarked on one of the most spectacular U-turns of his career when he stole the language of post-war Keynesians to declare that the Conservatives were now in favour of full employment.

In an appeal to voters on the centre ground, the shadow chancellor deployed moderate language to say that the Tories wanted everyone to enjoy the "fruits of civilisation". His remarks, to the rightwing Institute of Economic Affairs, marked his third big policy U-turn since he took over as shadow chancellor this year.

But there was no talk last night of another challenge to the authority of William Hague because Mr Portillo was standing in for the Tory leader, who was ill. Tory aides said he delivered Mr Hague's speech virtually word for word.

Mr Portillo acknowledged that his audience might be concerned to hear a senior Tory call for full employment, a phrase which strikes terror into the hearts of diehard Thatcherites, who regard such language as the embodiment of the "failed" British postwar political consensus.

The shadow chancellor said: "Now in the august company of the IEA some of you may raise an eyebrow at a Conservative leader setting 'full employment' as a goal for the economic policy of the next Conservative government."

However, Tories were now conscious of the social respon sibility that governments faced in running the economy. Repeatedly using the word society, in contrast to Margaret Thatcher, who denied its existence, he said that by the goal of full employment "I mean the right of people to expect their government to create the conditions in which enterprise can flourish."

Tory sources said the speech was designed to show that the leadership was determined to reach out to voters across the political spectrum. Mr Hague indicated to "wet" Tories recently that he would balance his rightwing interventions on crime and asylum with moderate speeches.

One source said: "This speech shows there are no no-go areas for us. We are taking the fight to the enemy."

It revived memories of last year's attempt by Peter Lilley, then deputy leader, to distance the party from its Thatcherite past when he said the market did not provide all the answers.

But Mr Portillo made clear he opposed the "disastrous demand-management policies and half-understood Keynesian fine-tuning implemented in the name of full employment".

He said: "I hope you would raise both eyebrows at a Conservative politician who thinks you can put the goal of full employment above all other economic goals, including price stability. Of course you cannot."

But his speech does mark a u-turn which will disappoint Lady Thatcher, who once declared: "You turn if you want to; the lady's not for turning." He was a big admirer of her in the late 1970s and 1980s when her kitchen cabinet drew up the anti-inflationary policies that led to record unemployment.

Labour dismissed Mr Portillo's speech as blatant opportunism. One source said: "It took real guts for us to say we were committed to full employment, so Portillo's intervention is cheap rubbish."

Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, said: "Mr Portillo should come clean about the extremist Tory plans to abolish the New Deal which has helped 200,000 young people into jobs ... Mr Portillo's Tories will, as they did in 18 years of Tory rule, push unemployment upwards."

Borrowed policies

Minimum wage

Two days into his appointment as shadow chancellor, Portillo dropped Tory opposition to the minimum wage

Bank of England independence

In his same Commons appearance, Portillo abandoned Tory opposition to the operational independence of the Bank of England

Tory tax guarantee

Days later, he gave only lukewarm support to William Hague's plan to cut taxes as a share of national income regardless of the state of the economy

fields.headline: 'Raw deal' for women
fields.trailText: The government's new deal programme for the unemployed is discriminating against women, according to new research.
fields.body:
The government's new deal programme for the unemployed is discriminating against women, according to new research.

A study for the Blairite thinktank the Institute for Public Policy Research finds that the design of then New deal has led to a significant imbalance of participants.

The paper, by Katherine Rake of the London School of Economics, is the latest in a series of evaluations of the £3.5b programme, which is designed to find work and training for a range of groups, including 18- to 24-year-olds, lone parents and the long-term unemployed.

It emerged this week that government officials running the programme have privately admitted it has serious failings, including returning too many young people to the dole after finishing a work placement or training.

The latest study, to be published in IPPR's journal New Economy, concludes that the new deal fails jobless women.

The new deal for young people and the new deal for the long-term unemployed both require participants to have been registered unemployed and claiming job seeker's allowance for six months. However, women, especially those in couples, are much less likely than men to claim the benefit or to claim for the full period required.

As a result, women made up only 27% of participants in the scheme for young people and just 16% of participants in the scheme for the long-term jobless, the paper argues.

fields.headline: Whitehall fails to embrace IT
fields.trailText: Whitehall departments are still failing to take full advantage of the information technology revolution that would allow them to talk directly to voters and provide faster services - often at much lower cost, MPs will warn today.
fields.body:
Whitehall departments are still failing to take full advantage of the information technology revolution that would allow them to talk directly to voters and provide faster services - often at much lower cost, MPs will warn today.

The department of social security is singled out for special concern in the latest report of the Commons public accounts committee because it has millions of annual transactions with the country's benefit claimants each year.

The report says the department would save £7.7m if just 2% of the 160m telephone calls it receives every year could be shifted into inquiries over a dedicated website.

Such a move requires better websites with more informa tion and superior design, says the committee, which chaired by the former Conservative minister, David Davies.

In theory, filing taxes on the internet, now in its infancy, could be extended to a host of services including state benefits, passports, driving licences and 24-hour access to official information. But the results are "hit and miss", the committee says.

Its report also takes ministers to task for not developing compatible computer systems that would allow them and their officials to talk directly to each other via intranet, another money-saver. Few ministers have IT skills themselves.

The prime minister - who has recently had IT training - is constantly urging Whitehall departments to raise their information technology game. He recently brought forward the target date for making 50% of governmental transactions accessible electronically - from 2008 to 2005.

But the public accounts committee learned to its "surprise" that telephone calls via web-based technology are being included as "electronic".

Mr Davies said last night: "Government on the web has the potential to revolutionise the relationship between the citizen and the state and ... could transform the quality of public services."

It also had the potential to save money, he added.

The committee did not examine the government's plan, announced in April, to create a vast public service jobs website, advertising up to 4,000 jobs a day - and presenting a huge saving on advertising costs.

webTitle: Ex-ally threatens to put SNP chief in dock

fields.headline: Ex-ally threatens to put SNP chief in dock
fields.trailText: As fallings-out go, even by the standards of the political world, it has to rank as one of the most spectacular. The Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, is facing the prospect of being served with a writ for defamation by the man he ousted as his party treasurer.
fields.body:
As fallings-out go, even by the standards of the political world, it has to rank as one of the most spectacular. The Scottish National party leader, Alex Salmond, is facing the prospect of being served with a writ for defamation by the man he ousted as his party treasurer.

After consulting lawyers yesterday, Ian Blackford is preparing to sue Mr Salmond over comments he allegedly made at a weekend meeting which saw a vote of no confidence against him.

But as Mr Blackford conferred with counsel, the SNP took rearguard action in a public round of internecine warfare. Mr Blackford was suspended as party treasurer, pending a meeting of the national executive in July.

This, however, is not the only disciplinary woe before Mr Salmond. As the Scottish press awaits the prospect of an embarrassing court case with barely concealed glee, the SNP is also preparing to discipline one of its most high-profile backbenchers for dissent.

Margo MacDonald, an ally of Mr Blackford, will tomorrow face allegations that she publicly criticised an SNP group decision in remarks to a newspaper. A two-thirds majority would be required to give Ms MacDonald a final warning and it is unlikely that she will be dealt with so harshly, but her supporters claim it may be the start of a campaign to de-select her.

Both Ms MacDonald and Mr Blackford are part of the fundamentalist wing of the SNP, a grouping opposed to Mr Salmond's gradualist approach to independence.

This has led to suggestions that the party leadership has begun a purge against dissidents.

It is an impression not lost on the SNP hierarchy and the party yesterday moved to counter it by appointing Kenny MacAskill, another leading fundamentalist, as replacement to Mr Blackford.

But there is undoubtedly more trouble to come. Mr Blackford commands only limited support among the upper echelons of the SNP, but yesterday he hinted that he is preparing to bypass that grouping and take his fight directly to the party ranks at conference in September.

With Mr Blackford also accusing Mr Salmond of political cowardice and control freakery, the portents are for a summer of discontent - which could even result in a leadership challenge in the autumn.

The ill-feeling between Mr Salmond and his one-time treasurer is deep-rooted. Mr Blackford was unhappy about the low priority given to independence in the Scottish election campaign and critical of the SNP's vote-losing plan to put a penny on income tax.

But the latest round of animosity stems from allegations about the SNP's financial state.

The SNP has an overdraft of around £400,000 and it is sell ing off its Edinburgh headquarters.

Last Saturday morning, Mr Blackford says, he received a telephone call from the SNP leader informing him that he was planning to propose a motion of no confidence at a meeting of the party executive.

Mr Blackford was unable to attend the meeting and the SNP will not discuss what was said during it. But it is alleged that Mr Salmond decried Mr Blackford as being responsible for the overspend at the Scottish elections.

Mr Blackford claims these comments harm his professional reputation as a banker.

Whatever was said in the meeting, the motion against Mr Blackford was passed 18-3. The treasurer, however, refused to resign, and the motion meant little more than a calculated insult.

It was not until Mr Blackford was suspended for conduct inimical to the party that things really began to hot up.

A leadership challenge to Mr Salmond has been predicted since the SNP's less than spectacular performance in the Scottish elections - and the ousting of Mr Blackford might prove to be the catalyst which sparks it at the party's conference in September.

fields.headline: Minister bars export of picture
fields.trailText: The arts minister, Alan Howarth, last night stepped in to bar the export of a picture by John Russell, the last of the great Georgian pastel painters.
fields.body:
The arts minister, Alan Howarth, last night stepped in to bar the export of a picture by John Russell, the last of the great Georgian pastel painters.

Portrait of one of the porters at the Royal Academy, above, was described as a work of "major importance which provides a remarkable insight into the Royal Academy at the height of its popularity, as the principal institution of Georgian England".

John Russell (1745-1806) was the last of the great English painters of the period who used the medium. When he died, pastel died with him. It did not become popular again for almost a century.

It is believed the porter is John Withers, who was given the job in 1770 with an annual salary of £25. But he could earn an extra 2/6 "each night he sits as a model".

Unless a British buyer can come up with £102,000 by September, the picture will go abroad.

fields.headline: Five admit abducting toddler
fields.trailText: Police praised Bradford's Asian community yesterday for helping to end the kidnapping of a toddler whose mother was sprayed with gas by a gang as they snatched the child from his pushchair.
fields.body:
Police praised Bradford's Asian community yesterday for helping to end the kidnapping of a toddler whose mother was sprayed with gas by a gang as they snatched the child from his pushchair.

Five men admitted child abduction at Bradford crown court, where the judge warned that the plot's organiser, the toddler's father, was still at large overseas.

The uncle of Daniel Grimshaw, who was 14 months old when he was bundled into a car last November, admitted intending to pervert the course of justice.

Mohammed Arshad, 30, told the court that he had helped Daniel's father Muhrzar Mahmood to leave the country for the Indian sub-continent.

Daniel's mother, Amy Grimshaw, who is 19, said after the hearing that she was relieved and delighted.

She said: "We're both still scarred by the events - Daniel was away from me for nearly two months. The pain we all went through will never be forgotten but I have got to be happy we are able to be together forever."

Sentences will be passed on Friday on Arshad, and on Khalid Khan, 27, Christopher Kellet, 26, and Denis Hunter, 40, all from Bradford, who admitted abduction. At an earlier hearing Barrington Depass, 19, and Lloyd Ruddock, 36, both from Bradford, also admitted kidnapping.

Child abduction carries a maximum seven year term but the negotiations which led to Daniel's safe recovery from a local shop are expected to have a bearing on sentencing.

Detective Inspector Paul Taylor of West Yorkshire police said: "Our priority was always to get Daniel reunited with his mum. We're very grateful to members of the Asian community in Bradford for their great assistance."

webTitle: Road death of Q actor accidental

fields.headline: Road death of Q actor accidental
fields.trailText: The actor Desmond Llewelyn, who played James Bond's gadget inventor Q, died in a head-on car crash while overtaking another vehicle on his way to a book signing session, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The actor Desmond Llewelyn, who played James Bond's gadget inventor Q, died in a head-on car crash while overtaking another vehicle on his way to a book signing session, an inquest heard yesterday.

Mr Llewelyn, 85, of Bexhill, East Sussex, who starred in 17 Bond movies, was killed when his Renault Megane collided with a Fiat Brava on the A27 at Firle, near Lewes, on December 19 last year.

The inquest at Eastbourne heard how he tried to overtake a car at the end of a mile-long straight stretch but crashed into the Fiat, driven by Rhys Morgan, from Stuttgart, Germany, who was driving his partner, Claudia Zetzche, to Heathrow.

The East Sussex coroner, Alan Craze, recorded a verdict of accidental death.

After the hearing Mr Llewelyn's son Justin, 47, said: "We are slightly surprised by the evidence, but we are glad it is all over. Now we can finally draw a line under this awful business. We have [received condolences] from every one of the Bond actors. It was planned that Roger Moore was the only one at the memorial service. He worked with dad the most."

fields.headline: Head denies slapping 'unruly' boy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Staff at a south Wales school were left in a "state of shock" after a headteacher admitted hitting a 10-year-old boy, Abergavenny magistrates heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Staff at a south Wales school were left in a "state of shock" after a headteacher admitted hitting a 10-year-old boy, Abergavenny magistrates heard yesterday.

Marjorie Evans, 56, is said to have told colleagues the unruly pupil "wouldn't be doing that again" after slapping him across the face.

She denies common assault.

Special needs teacher Sandra Cutler told the court Mrs Evans had admitted to staff over lunch at the Gwent school that she had slapped him. "She raised her right hand over the table and said 'Yes, I did. I hit him and he won't be doing that again'."

Mrs Cutler said: "We were all in a state of shock."

She added: "She said it with a tone of arrogance."

Mrs Evans, of Usk, south Wales, is alleged to have hit the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, in September last year after he became unruly.

Prosecutor Christopher Rees said the headmistress, who is suspended, had "lost her temper" with the boy, who has learning difficulties.

Mrs Evans denied she hit the boy or admitted to staff that she had done so. She said the youngster, who was on medication to control attention deficit disorder, had been uncooperative and aggressive after being told he could not go swimming.

She said while walking through the school with him and three other boys he tried to push her and then tried to punch and head butt her. She was forced to restrain him.

She added: "I frequently say to staff remember do not touch pupils and I specifically mentioned never to touch him because if there are any problems we might be sued."

She said she told colleagues she had had to restrain the boy but did not say she had hit him.

Two staff members in the room at the time said they could not remember her saying she had assaulted the pupil.

The trial continues on Friday.

She added: "She said it with a tone of arrogance." Mrs Evans, of Usk, south Wales, is alleged to have hit the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, in September last year after he became unruly. Prosecutor Christopher Rees said the headmistress, who is suspended, had "lost her temper" with the boy, who has learning difficulties. Mrs Evans denied she hit the boy or admitted to staff that she had done so. She said the youngster, who was on medication to control attention deficit disorder, had been uncooperative and aggressive after being told he could not go swimming. She said while walking through the school with him and three other boys he tried to push her and then tried to punch and head butt her. She was forced to restrain him. She added: "I frequently say to staff remember do not touch pupils and I specifically mentioned never to touch him because if there are any problems we might be sued." She said she told colleagues she had had to restrain the boy but did not say she had hit him. Two staff members in the room at the time said they could not remember her saying she had assaulted the pupil. The trial continues on Friday.

fields.headline: Hammock collapse kills boy, 12
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old boy was killed when a garden wall collapsed on him as he played in a hammock at his home in Surrey.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy was killed when a garden wall collapsed on him as he played in a hammock at his home in Surrey.

One end of the hammock had been tied to the wall and Duncan Reade-Hill had been swinging in it when the brickwork came crashing down.

Three friends who were with him cried out as the wall gave way, bringing his mother Pamela and sister Elspeth, 16, running out of the family home in Weybridge.

The boy was freed by firefighters and paramedics but despite efforts to revive him, was certified dead on arrival at St Peter's hospital, Chertsey, on Monday evening.

A neighbour, Camelia Rothenburg, told yesterday how she saw Duncan trapped under the wall.

"It was horrifying. He had been swinging in the hammock when the end attached to the wall suddenly gave way.

"Duncan had only had the hammock for a few days. I watched him playing in it for the first time at the weekend.

"He was such a delightful little boy, who was always playing in the garden with friends."

Duncan's mother, a production assistant at Shepperton film studios, was being comforted by his grandmother, who lives on the same Weybridge estate.

webTitle: Military honours: Brigadier's body brought home

fields.headline: Military honours: Brigadier's body brought home
fields.trailText: The body of Stephen Saunders, the British diplomat murdered by a terrorist gang in Athens last Thursday, arrived back on home soil yesterday as the Greek government doubled its reward to £1.75m for information on his assassins.
fields.byline: Sarah Hall and Helena Smith in Athens
fields.body:
The body of Stephen Saunders, the British diplomat murdered by a terrorist gang in Athens last Thursday, arrived back on home soil yesterday as the Greek government doubled its reward to £1.75m for information on his assassins.

The 52-year-old brigadier, the first Briton to be killed by the November 17 group, was flown out with full military honours after a red carpet ceremony at Athens airport. Before leaving Greece, his wife Heather, and daughters Nicola, 15, and Catherine, 14, placed a flower on the wreath that now marks the spot in the Greek capital where he was shot last week.

They then accompanied the coffin on a British Airways jet to Gatwick.

The brigadier's coffin was greeted with military honours (pictured above) by members of his regiment, the Royal Gloucester, Berkshire and Wiltshire, as the Foreign Office minister Lady Scotland, the defence minister Lady Symons, and chief of staff General Sir Michael Walker, waited on the tarmac.

The brigadier's funeral will take place at Salisbury Cathedral next Tuesday.

fields.headline: Rebel paymaster loses EU aid
fields.standfirst:
EU blocks £35m package for Liberia as warning against funding Sierra Leone's war

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Britain succeeded in blocking a £35m European aid package to Liberia yesterday, an act designed to force its president, Charles Taylor, to stop supplying the rebels in Sierra Leone with arms and funds in return for diamonds.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Britain succeeded in blocking a £35m European aid package to Liberia yesterday, an act designed to force its president, Charles Taylor, to stop supplying the rebels in Sierra Leone with arms and funds in return for diamonds.

It was strongly opposed by the European Commission, which believes that it will be ordinary Liberians and not Mr Taylor who will feel the pain.

Keith Vaz, the British minister for Europe, persuaded a meeting of EU foreign ministers in Luxembourg to put the aid "on ice" after several days of intense lobbying by the Foreign Office in EU capitals.

Mr Vaz, who stepped in at the last minute after Robin Cook was called upon to attend President Assad's funeral in Syria, ran into French opposition when he raised the possibility of threatening to suspend EU aid to Liberia altogether.

Other EU members did agree to sign a strongly worded statement expressing "deep concern" about Liberia's involvement in Sierra Leone and condemning its illicit diamond trade with the Revolutionary United Front (RUF), which is believed to be fuelling the war.

EU diplomats in the Liberian capital, Monrovia, will now draw up a report on the extent of Mr Taylor's involvement in Sierra Leone and warn him to behave in "a responsible and consistent" manner.

EC officials made it clear that they would have preferred Britain not to have used EU aid as a political football.

"The thing is that this money is to help poor people and not the government of Liberia, so there is some regret that there may now be an overdue delay in getting the money to those who need it," one said.

It is unclear how long the aid package, whose delivery was unanimously approved by EU member states last month, will be kept on ice.

French diplomats said that they were happy to go along with Britain up to a point but had balked at the suggestion that the EU should consider opening consultations with Liberia under the Lomé convention,which could lead to the suspension of all EU aid.

UK diplomats argue, however, that this was not the main issue and claim that the overall decision to delay the aid package sends a clear signal to Mr Taylor that "it is not business as usual", and spells out the fact that EU aid is not immune to politics.

"Other member states supported us by their silence and were very supportive once they had seen the dossier we had compiled," a British diplomat told the Guardian, referring to a confidential British report detailing Mr Taylor's role in supplying the RUF with arms.

A copy of the report, obtained by the Guardian, shows that Mr Taylor has been providing money, arms and advice to the RUF for some time.

It is one of the most devastating attacks on a foreign head of state by the British government in recent years.

The report claims that Mr Taylor does not want to see the RUF defeated, in spite of his efforts to help secure the release of 500 UN peacekeepers held hostage by the group.

Mr Taylor, it suggests, wants to install Sam Bockarie as the new leader of the RUF to replace the captured Foday Sankoh and is allowing rebel forces to train in Liberia.

"President Taylor is motivated by a need to maintain his personal wealth and political position in Liberia. Taylor's game-plan is to maintain his control and influence over eastern Sierra Leone by making it lawless."

Britain plans to use the report to persuade other international organisations, such as the World Bank and the UN, to make Mr Taylor's life difficult.

It clearly identifies diamonds as being at the heart of the conflict. Although Liberia's annual production is no more than 100,000-150,000 carats, exports have rocketed to 6m carats thanks to illegal supplies from Sierra Leone. The report concludes that Mr Taylor's behaviour "will improve if he is threatened with embarrassing exposure and sustained sanctions" but adds: "He has proved highly adept at maintaining his position in the face of past difficulties".

British marines in Sierra Leone were ferried by helicopter to HMS Ocean yesterday as the UK continued to scale down its involvement in its war-torn former colony. A separate force of 200 soldiers, who will help train the Sierra Leone army, has arrived.

Government forces and rebels clashed near the town of Lunsar, which was captured by loyalists last week on the road to the RUF stronghold at Makeni.

Military sources said an army patrol exchanged fire on Monday with rebels, who had sent out a reconnaissance mission. There were no immediate reports of casualties.

Captain Daniel Yanka told Reuters that the rebels appeared to be about five miles from Lunsar.

webTitle: Russian war dead lost to bureaucracy

fields.headline: Russian war dead lost to bureaucracy
fields.standfirst:
Relatives of Chechnya's victims 'treated like criminals'

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: When it comes to the grisly business of identifying Russia's war dead in Chechnya, Svetlana Shpigun has only contempt for the investigators and officials in charge of tracing the victims and giving them a decent burial.
fields.body:
When it comes to the grisly business of identifying Russia's war dead in Chechnya, Svetlana Shpigun has only contempt for the investigators and officials in charge of tracing the victims and giving them a decent burial.

More than a year after her husband Gennady, a general in the interior ministry forces, was abducted in the Chechen capital, Grozny, and 10 weeks after a corpse believed to be his was recovered from a gorge in southern Chechnya, Mrs Shpigun has received no help, no information and no support from the authorities.

"It's deeply improper that they haven't asked me or any of our relatives to help identify the corpse," she complained. "This investigation has been conducted by people with no feelings at all," she told the newspaper Trud.

Mrs Shpigun's pain at her husband's disappearance and her bitterness at the way she has been treated by officialdom since the kidnapping are common in Russia, where the relatives of the hundreds of men missing in action get short shrift from the military, the government and the courts in their often vain quest to find and identify loved ones.

"In the war in Afghanistan, you had coffins sent home and families were warned not to look inside, simply because they were burying the remains of someone else, not their relative," says Valentina Melnikova of the Soldiers' Mothers' Committee pressure group.

"The same thing is happening now in Chechnya. This is a state that has no scruples or conscience when it comes to treating the war dead decently."

At Mozdok in the northern Caucasus, headquarters for Russia's Chechen campaign, police sources say that battlefield dead are regularly mutilated when they are recovered and packed into zinc coffins which may not be big enough for the body.

Official Russia's cavalier attitude to its dead servicemen has a long pedigree. There are still hundreds of unidentified dead from the 1994-96 Chechen war, and from the nine-year Afghan war.

The scale of the unidentified dead from the second world war is staggering. The official figure for the Soviet war dead is 27m, including almost 12m servicemen. Of the latter figure, according to Russian defence ministry historians, half died unidentified.

The Kremlin's traditional response to such suffering has been to turn to ritual and symbol while ignoring the practical work required to trace the missing and identify the dead.

By the Kremlin wall there is the eternal flame and the shrine to the unknown soldier, where foreign dignitaries and Kremlin grandees regularly pay tribute to the war dead.

There are scores of such memorials throughout the country.

But in all Russia there is only one military forensic centre engaged in the work of identifying disfigured or unknown corpses. It is the 124th central laboratory in the southern town of Rostov, run by Colonel Vladimir Shcherbakov, a former naval officer.

The laboratory was established in 1995 and is starved of funds, equipment and staff, though the financier and philanthropist George Soros has just given it £40,000.

The Rostov centre takes delivery of unidentified dead from Chechnya every day. Its refrigerated containers still house the bodies of 254 unidentified soldiers from the previous Chechen war.

But despite the tireless efforts of Col Shcherbakov and his staff to put names to the casualties, there are many war dead who never get taken to Rostov.

Margarita Yanik, a nurse and single mother from the Siberian town of Tyumen, has spent the past five years wandering the brutal bureaucratic maze of officialdom seeking news of her son Dima.

It seems that he was incinerated in a tank in Grozny on New Year's Eve 1994. She did not even know her son was in Chechnya. Seeking news of his whereabouts, she was told by his military unit that Dima had been posted to Samara on the Volga.

In Samara they had never heard of him.

Finally she received notification that he had been reported missing in Grozny.

His remains have not been found. She has been to the military courts, to the prosecutor's office, and to the local authorities seeking compensation and a pension.

She has received nothing and says she has been treated like a criminal and told she was due nothing because she "has not buried" her son.

But Russian law stipulates that after two years missing in action, the victim is considered dead.

A civil court in Tyumen has just accepted that her son is dead, but now she has to return to the military courts to have that ruling validated before she can obtain any redress.

"Shcherbakov in Rostov, he's a real hero," Mrs Melnikova says. "But he's an exception. Generally our officers see their soldiers as dirt under their feet."

The Shpigun case is different because the interior ministry general is the most senior Russian officer kidnapped in Chechnya and the case is highly political. He was abducted in March last year at Grozny airport and held for ransom. The corpse thought to be his was found on March 31 this year.

Leaks to the Russian press suggest that the body is not disfigured and easily identifiable, but Mrs Shpigun and her family have not been allowed to see it.

Even the whereabouts of the corpse are a mystery. The government is expected to announce any day whether the corpse is indeed Shpigun's, after 10 weeks of obfuscation.

"It's all very strange, incomprehensible," says Georgy Rozhnov, a Moscow journalist who has followed the case closely.

"The examination and the analysis were complete ages ago."

Mrs Shpigun said the forensic experts told her that the body could be identified but that she was being shielded for her own good.

"What nonsense," she told Trud. "That attitude is more traumatic than the truth, even if it is a bitter truth. But no one's come near us and all this bother with the experts is dragging on.

"The fact is that no one has been dealing with the fate of my husband for the past six months.

The sole Russian general in captivity and the brave interior ministry was powerless to do anything.

"They're indecent, unfeeling people."

webTitle: Putin's most influential media critic held for embezzlement

fields.headline: Putin's most influential media critic held for embezzlement
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian authorities arrested one of the most influential men in the country last night, the media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, who owns Russia's biggest private television station and has been the most consistent critic of President Vladimir Putin for the past six months.
fields.body:
The Russian authorities arrested one of the most influential men in the country last night, the media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky, who owns Russia's biggest private television station and has been the most consistent critic of President Vladimir Putin for the past six months.

The prosecutor's office confirmed that Mr Gusinsky was detained last night on suspicion of embezzling state funds, two months after squads of masked paramilitaries raided the headquarters of Media-most, the nerve centre of his business empire, and carried off crates of documents and tapes.

The arrest will inevitably bring protests and put Moscow liberals in fear for their decade-old liberties.

Mr Putin was out of the country at the time, visiting Spain and Germany.

The prosecutor's office has 10 days to bring formal charges against Mr Gusinsky. Russian news agencies said he was suspected of having embezzled $10m (£6.6m) of state funds. Mr Gusinsky values his overall business assets at £1.5bn.

During his recent visit to Moscow, President Bill Clinton made a point of implicitly supporting Mr Gusinsky against Kremlin pressure by appearing on his Ekho Moskvy radio station for a phone-in.

Mr Gusinsky's television and radio and his main newspaper, Segodnya, have been under strong pressure in recent months to toe the official line on the Chechen war, but have consistently pursued a critical line.

Since using his assets to secure Boris Yeltsin's re-election in 1996, Mr Gusinsky has fallen foul of the Kremlin power-brokers and has been engaged in a long and bitter feud with the other key media magnate and Kremlin insider, Boris Berezovsky.

Mr Gusinsky, who has an Israeli passport as well as a Russian one, is also head of the Russian branch of the World Jewish Congress, and is currently embroiled in another battle with Mr Berezovsky over the leadership of Russia's Jewish communities.

He is one of the few public figures in Russia who supported Nato's campaign against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia last year.

Earlier this month he told a group of foreign reporters in Moscow that he was "really alarmed" at political developments in Russia.

"Only totalitarian countries can solve problems that way, by pure force," he said, discussing the Chechen war.

He last met Mr Putin in October when, he said, he found himself in a "dialogue of the deaf".

"I told him you can't secure peace with guns. You can destroy Chechnya and then be president of a different Russia, one I don't want to live in."

fields.standfirst:
It was nearly all pain again in the technology sector yesterday.
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Computacenter saw nearly 36% wiped off its market cap as it fell 225p to 417.5p after the group issued a full year profits warning, which it blamed on the slower than expected post-millennium recovery in European markets . Brokers were unhappy with the IT reseller - which only weeks ago made soothing noises on current trading in the wake of its bid for rival Compel. House broker HSBC Securities has cut its rating to "hold" from "buy".

Computacenter saw nearly 36% wiped off its market cap as it fell 225p to 417.5p after the group issued a full year profits warning, which it blamed on the slower than expected post-millennium recovery in European markets . Brokers were unhappy with the IT reseller - which only weeks ago made soothing noises on current trading in the wake of its bid for rival Compel. House broker HSBC Securities has cut its rating to "hold" from "buy".

Freeserve shed 19p to 500p as investors failed to find excitement in its plans for an online health channel, in conjunction with Superdrug, Planetmedica.com and ThinkNatural.com.

Games maker Eidos was also falling, 19p to 375p, as final results were accompanied by yet more cautious comment on the short-term outlook for the games software market.

Widening full year losses and prospects of continued heavy investment took their toll on Atlantic Telecom </B, down 32p at 510p.

Other second line technology stocks suffered: Morse Holdings lost 45p to 345p, InterX shed 62.5p to £12.12, and Kewill Systems fell 50p to 869p.

But Powerderject bounced back after the previous day's post-results decline, climbing 15p to 397.5p as Goldman Sachs reiterated its "market outperformer" rating, with a 680p price target.

Sema fell 68p to 852p, Baltimore shed 36p at 528p, Misys was 38p lower at 509p and ARM Holdings fell 12p to 675p.

Reuters dropped 64p to £10.30 after the company announced that it had invested $35m in Pedestal, an internet based secondary mortgage market place operator.

Celltech bucked the trend, gaining 45p at £11.80 as Goldman Sachs repeated its "recommended list" rating and set a £20.50 price target.

Lloyds TSB suffered after Salomon Smith Barney and Schroder cut current year pre-tax estimates. The downgrades - understood to reflect the increased spending required for the bank's internet plans - pushed the shares 4p lower to 668.5p.

Reed International topped the list of risers, up 47p at 562p.

National Power added 25p to 420p, and BAT gained 15.5p to 411p.

Cable & Wireless firmed 34p to £12.14 after a resolution at an egm approved the sale of its Hong Kong Telecom unit. Railtrack was 19p higher at 913p following revelations that its chief executive, Gerald Corbett, has given up his £100,000 bonus.

fields.headline: IT slowdown hits Computacenter
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Computacenter, the IT systems and services supplier, saw its shares fall by over 35% yesterday to a year-low of 417p after the company warned that second and third quarter profits would fall short of expectations. Shares had peaked in February at £15, but dipped following the recent falls in technology stocks.
fields.body:
Computacenter, the IT systems and services supplier, saw its shares fall by over 35% yesterday to a year-low of 417p after the company warned that second and third quarter profits would fall short of expectations. Shares had peaked in February at £15, but dipped following the recent falls in technology stocks.

Analysts had projected that annual pre-tax profits would increase from £75m in 1999 to £88m, but have now revised their forecasts for the year to £63m. First-half profits are expected to be just over £20m compared to £40.7m for the same period last year.

Mike Norris, chief executive of Computacenter, confirmed that the second quarter had been difficult and that April in particular was a "disaster". He said the third quarter would also be affected but there were indications of a gradual growth for the rest of the year.

The company cited a slower than expected recovery of the IT market across Europe following millennium bug fears and delays in the roll-out of Windows 2000 technologies to later in the year as key reasons for falling profits.

However, Mr Norris conceded that delays of this kind were not unusual in the IT services industry.

Computacenter predicts that its long term recovery will be aided by a move away from services based around Microsoft software to a broader set of e-commerce services - at present 16 to 18% of total business - particularly from larger clients such as Sun Microsystems and Cisco. But Mr Norris attibutes the company's short term problems in part to this development.

Moving from Microsoft-based solutions to e-commerce was, he insisted, "making it much more difficult for IT directors to decide where to spend their budgets".

"People are being careful. They are taking their time and contracts get delayed.

"Whatever the difficulties," Mr Norris said, "we now have to rebuild our credibility".

fields.headline: Barak faces coalition ultimatum
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was faced with the collapse of his coalition government yesterday when his most powerful - and unruly - ally voted to quit.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was faced with the collapse of his coalition government yesterday when his most powerful - and unruly - ally voted to quit.

The decision by the elders who pull the strings of the Shas religious party could bring down the curtain on Mr Barak's government after only 11 months.

It could also torpedo the peace process. Without the 17 votes of Shas, which is sympathetic to the peace process, Mr Barak would no longer have the parliamentary support to endorse a deal with the Palestinians before they declare their state on September 13.

The peace talks were to resume near Washington late last night. But that presumes that neither Mr Barak nor Shas will bite the bitter pill of surrender.

Shas, which combines ultra-orthodox theology with representing Jews of Middle Eastern origin, has embarked on a game of brinkmanship to extract millions of dollars in extra funds for its corrupt system of religious schools.

A surrender to Shas's arm-twisting would be particularly humiliating to Mr Barak, who has tried to present his government as above sordid deal-making.

Despite the vitriolic exchanges of recent days, in which Shas has called its opponents Nazis,all parties in the fragmented parliament are united by the desire to avoid going to the polls. Although Mr Barak said last week that he would not flinch from the polls, he knows Israel's peculiar electoral system would deliver the same paralysing outcome he is grappling with now.

Shas's decision does not come into effect until after the next cabinet meeting on Sunday. Leaders of Mr Barak's One Israel party were huddled in emergency session yesterday trying to find a solution.

"The decision is absolute as of today," the Shas health minister, Shlomo Ben Izri, said yesterday. "But if he brings us a solution before Sunday, and manages to convince us, maybe we will change our mind."

But it is increasingly difficult for Mr Barak to give in to Shas without antagonising the secular majority, who are appalled by its anti-modern and theocratic vision of the world, and scandalised by the corruption in its organisation.

For its part, Shas has made it plain that the priceof its acquiesence is rising by the day. After several months in which Mr Barak ignored growing rifts in the coalition to concentrate on making peace with the Palestinians and Syria, they may regard any gesture now as too little, too late, or as paternalism from a member of Israel's European Jewish elite.

fields.headline: Letter leads to nuclear stash
fields.standfirst: Korea special report
fields.trailText: A mildly radioactive letter sent to the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, led police to a warehouse full of a material associated with the extraction of uranium yesterday.
fields.body:
A mildly radioactive letter sent to the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, led police to a warehouse full of a material associated with the extraction of uranium yesterday.

The discovery of 15 tons of monazite came after an anonymous tip-off that dangerous radioactive material was being smuggled from Japan to North Korea.

The claim was made in a letter sent on June 6 to Mr Mori and the heads of eight government bodies, including the police and defence agencies.

Each envelope contained three grams of monazite, a mineral phosphate mined and processed to recover uranium.

Monazite, which is not controlled by international treaties, also includes thorium, which can be used in nuclear bombs and reactors.

The sand-like yellow substance was found to be radioactive, though officials said the level was not harmful.

According to the Kyodo news agency, a hand-written note in the envelope warned: "Uranium is being sent to North Korea and police should investigate because it is dangerous."

The sender said the smuggling was being carried out by the president of an education ministry foundation, whose name has been withheld.

The police found the monazite stockpile during a search of properties owned by the foundation near Tokyo and in central Japan. According to science agency officials, there were no harmful levels of radioactivity at the sites.

In interviews with domestic media, the president said he had imported 50 tons of monazite from Thailand about 20 years ago with the intention of selling it on to hot-spring resort operators, who strive to offer unique mixes of minerals in bath waters.

The president said he had sold most of his original stock and the remaining 15 tons was securely stored.

The police are investigating whether he broke nuclear-related laws by importing or storing the monazite.

Attention is also focused on the intentions of the sender of the radioactive letters. One theory is that the warning was designed to raise fear about the North Korean capital Pyongyang's nuclear weapons programme before yesterday's historic summit between the leaders of North and South Korea.

fields.headline: Koreans bask in summit's warmth
fields.standfirst:
Historic moment for north and south as leaders meet for first time, bridging 55 years of division

Korea special report
fields.trailText: Koreans from north and south celebrated their common ancestry yesterday for the first time in 55 years as the long-awaited summit in Pyongyang got off to a sensational start.
fields.body:
Koreans from north and south celebrated their common ancestry yesterday for the first time in 55 years as the long-awaited summit in Pyongyang got off to a sensational start.

The North Korean leader, Chairman Kim Jong-il, took centre stage immediately by personally welcoming the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, at the airport before escorting him to a televised meeting in town.

"Don't worry, I will not disappoint you," he told Kim Dae-jung. "The world is now watching and I have to respond during [your] three-day stay here."

"June 13 will be recorded in history," he told his guest from the South, who replied: "Let's make history from now on."

After reviewing a high-stepping guard of honour, they travelled into town from the airport in the same car, chatting for half an hour and - said South Korean officials - sometimes holding hands.

Hundreds of thousands of Pyongyang citizens lined the streets from the airport. Most of the women wore traditional Korean dress while the men were dressed in formal suits and ties.

Waving red vinyl flowers with choreographed enthusiasm, they cried out " mansei " (long life) and "protect Kim Jong-il to the death!"

South Korean officials claimed that there were also some shouts of "Kim Dae- jung". In a land where one man counts for everything, Kim Jong-il's performance transformed the day. Often described as reclusive, he spoke freely to the cameras and was heard and seen at greater length in a few hours yesterday than in all his public appearances in the past 10 years.

Relaxed in his army-style khaki trousers and tunic, he smiled, gestured and did not seem to tire - although he is evidently overweight.

He showed no signs of the nervous strain (and worse) that had been attributed to him by South Korean propaganda in the past.

Kim Jong-il raised a laugh by saying he had heard that Kim Dae-jung started the morning with only half a soft-boiled egg. "Coming for sightseeing," he enquired, "why did you have so little to eat for breakfast?"

His guest responded with the obvious punch-line: "Because I knew I would have a good meal when I got to Pyongyang."

The banter and the bunting does not mean that this is a lightweight encounter. The real punch-line for the outside world is the signal sent by both leaders yesterday that Koreans now intend to act for themselves.

Kim Dae-jung spoke of "taking the initiative on our own".

By congratulating his southern counterpart on his "courageous visit to the North", Kim Jong-il implied that the US and other powers, no doubt including Japan, might take exception.

A senior western diplomat in Seoul acknowledged last night that there was some truth in this.

"It needed President Clinton to bring about the Middle East summit," he commented. "But the Koreans are proud of having done it by themselves."

The portrayal of Kim Dae-jung as defying the outside world reflects North Korea's inner rationale for dealing with Seoul after decades spent denouncing it as a lackey of US imperialism.

The personal reception at the airport was an unprecedented break with North Korean protocol.

The North Koreans as hosts were able to stage-manage the proceedings to their own purposes. Kim Dae-jung was whisked away from the airport without having delivered a prepared speech - though the text had already been distributed in Seoul.

The southern leader had hoped to say that he had "come to Pyongyang to lead the effort for peace, cooperation and unification".

Perhaps the North felt this would be claiming too great a share of the credit for the mission, which Kim Jong-il is supposed to lead single-handedly.

The cheering crowds were hardly spontaneous, even though many South Koreans watching on public TV screens in Seoul were moved by the sight.

A North Korean guide pointedly told a South Korean journalist: "It only takes a few hours for all [our] citizens to be mobilised". He then asked: "Did such big crowds turn out in Seoul when he [President Kim] departed?"

Although the 27-minute chat before the cameras was instantly billed by South Korean officials as the "first summit meeting", some watchers in Seoul remained sceptical whether the occasion will deliver much of substance.

"They [the North Koreans] are giving Kim Dae-jung a ride," commented one veteran South Korean journalist. "It's all going their way."

But the South Korean president ended the day with a plea for positive steps "to solve the mountain of tasks pending between North and South".

"Let us open up the road that has been blocked off for half a century," he said in his banquet speech. "Let us unite and relink the broken railway. Let us open new sea lanes of communication and air routes too."

The North Korean leader acknowledged that they must deliver something.

He said that people were asking "why President Kim came to North Korea and I accepted. We have to give the answer."

A partial answer may come tomorrow before Kim Dae-jung returns home along the blocked-off road through the Demilitarised Zone at Panmunjom.

Yesterday the road surface of Unification Bridge on the southern side of Panmunjom was being scrubbed clean by more than 100 workers and tank traps and spikes were being repainted.

South Korea as much as the North wants everything to look as gleaming as possible for this first summit since the end of the Japanese war.

Kim Jong-il is now being presented by the Seoul press in a highly favourable light and the mysterious last-minute delay in the summit, which remained unexplained yesterday, has been forgotten.

"Chairman Kim gave southern visitors a good impression," reported the South Korean press pool from Pyongyang.

"He paid due respects to President Kim, who is many years older. His confident behaviour seems to indicate his firm power-base in the North."

A polite tabular comparison in the Korea Times describes the character of Kim Dae-jung, 75, as "elaborate and precise" and that of Kim Jong-il, 58, as "bold and surprising".

fields.headline: Amnesty report says torture increasing
fields.trailText: The number of countries practising torture and conducting unfair trials of political prisoners is rising, according to figures released by Amnesty International.
fields.body:
The number of countries practising torture and conducting unfair trials of political prisoners is rising, according to figures released by Amnesty International.

The human rights organisation counted 132 torture countries in 1999, up from 125 in 1998, and 51 countries conducting unfair trials, compared with 35 the previous year.

"Torture is a hell of humanity's own making for thousands of ordinary people around the world," said Kate Allen, Amnesty's UK director, commenting on the annual report published today. It high lights a number of torture countries which are either western allies like Turkey or lucrative trading partners like Saudi Arabia and China.

"The Saudi Arabian government spares no effort to keep its appalling human rights record a secret, and other governments have shown themselves more than willing to help maintain the silence," the report says.

"Secrecy and fear permeate every aspect of society in Saudi Arabia. There are no political parties, elections, trade unions or human rights organisations. Torture is endemic."

In China 1999 brought the most serious and wide-ranging crackdown on peaceful dissent for a decade. Torture and ill-treatment of prisoners were widespread and thousands of people were sentenced to death.

Amnesty recalls that it urged governments at the annual meeting of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in Geneva not to turn a blind eye. "But China's political and economic importance ensured that it again escaped criticism," the report says.

Turkey's brutal repression of Kurdish civilians is given prominent treatment by Pierre Sane, Amnesty's secretary general, in his foreword to the report. Mentioning the 3,000 Kurdish villages, the thousands of civilians killed by Turkish security forces, and the three million internally displaced people, he criticises the lack of action by the international community and the unabated flow of western arms to Turkey.

Amnesty sees some changes for the better in 1999. Extrajudicial executions were confined to 38 countries compared with 47 in 1998, and fewer countries held prisoners of conscience. The global trend towards abolition of capital punishment continued, with 14% fewer countries executing people last year.

Report 2000 is available online at www.amnesty.org.uk/library/

webTitle: France to crack down on sects

fields.headline: France to crack down on sects
fields.trailText: France is to defy President Bill Clinton's appeal to be more tolerant of religious sects and introduce draconian laws, including an offence of "mental manipulation" - brainwashing - which will carry a two-year prison sentence.
fields.body:
France is to defy President Bill Clinton's appeal to be more tolerant of religious sects and introduce draconian laws, including an offence of "mental manipulation" - brainwashing - which will carry a two-year prison sentence.

President Jacques Chirac has told Mr Clinton that religious freedom will no longer be a subject for bilateral presidential talks, in the light of what has been officially described as "shocking" White House support for Scientologists and Moonies.

The French government has also complained that Congress's introduction of laws protecting religious freedom internationally is "an unacceptable intrusion into internal affairs".

The chairman of a French ministerial mission to combat the influence of cults, Alain Vivien, said many observers believed that Mr Clinton was making his peace with big religious movements "because they offer an indispensable source of political financing".

MPs on both the left and the right are expected to vote in favour of authorising the courts to forcibly dissolve sects after two complaints, and to forbid them operating in the neighbourhood of schools, hospitals and rest homes.

They intend to make such movements responsible for acts considered to be a provocation to suicide or incitement to abandon families.

France's war against mainly American-sponsored movements, including the Jehovah's Witnesses, has been running for at least 20 years. It has prompted the accusation, particularly by Scientologists, that it is indulging in "collective hysteria" and preparing to ban religious freedoms.

"No one can forbid us to take action against sects in the interests of human rights. This point of view is particularly absurd when these movements flout the most elementary rights."

He claimed that, headed by Scientologists, sects were infiltrating UN and European human rights associations, financing some of their work, and collaborating on reports that condemned France "with virulence".

fields.headline: Panama Canal surrenders its past
fields.trailText: The industrial past tends to relinquish its secrets in small, often nugatory, fragments, but last month a Panama Canal salvage crew raised a complete French steam engine, together with 15 wagons.
fields.body:
The industrial past tends to relinquish its secrets in small, often nugatory, fragments, but last month a Panama Canal salvage crew raised a complete French steam engine, together with 15 wagons.

Staggered by the magnitude of their find, officials of the Panama Canal Authority (PCA) have parked the mud-caked locomotive at its industrial division yard in the Caribbean city of Colon while they decide what to do with it.

Hailed by the director of the Panama Canal museum, Angeles Ramos, as "a very important example of French-era technology", the relic has attracted inquiries from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute and conservation tips from engineers in Australia.

"Right now it's just standing in the yard while we wait for suggestions," the industrial division manager, Collins Corrigan, said. "We don't know whether to preserve it as it is or try and restore some of the wagons to their original condition."

The train was used for several years by the receivers called in to run the French Compagnie Universelle du Canal Interocéanique after the French bid to build a canal across Panama collapsed in 1889. It was buried 14 metres (45ft) beneath the surface of Lake Gatun when triumphant US engineers flooded the waterway in 1914.

Conscious that its recent exposure to the damp tropical air could hasten their corrosion, diligent yard engineers have unbolted the cast-iron nameplates from the rolling stock and put them in two trays of canal water in the yard's safe.

The scarcely legible words identifying the train's manufacturer, the Societe Anonyme Franco Belge, and the date Paris, 1885, bring into sharp focus the epic French quest to push a canal across Panama, described by a historian as "a sweeping human drama not unlike that of war".

The French diplomat and builder of the Suez Canal, Ferdinand de Lesseps, promised millions of investors that he could force a sea-level canal through the rugged, jungle-covered isthmus to link Atlantic and Pacific trade routes.

Raising more than 1bn francs with a series of bond and stock issues during the 1880s, De Lesseps threw France's industrial might at the endeavour.

Beginning with a shipment of 50 steam engines and 80 miles of track in 1882, a "mechanical Noah's Ark" comprising every imaginable kind of high Victorian steam plant was unpacked from crates at Colon.

The army of locomotives, aided by heavy steam shovels, hauled earth from the steep-sided cut until landslides and yellow fever brought the Compagnie Universelle to financial collapse at the end of the decade, almost 20 years after the project was initiated.

The failed bid left 22,000 dead, many of them buried in the still neatly tended French cemetery in the canal-side village of Paraiso - Paradise - and a legacy of French Hotel-de-Ville architecture that still reigns over Panama City's old quarter.

Standing more than a century later on a crust of rust and freshwater clamshells on the engine's footplate, Domiciano Broce, a PCA engineer, paid tribute to his long-dead colleagues' efforts.

Pointing to the gravity-tilt action of the hopper carts and the elegant leafsprings of their rusted suspension, he beamed with appreciative empathy.

"It's a machine as simple as a crowbar," he said. "All the basic principles of mechanical engineering are reflected here."

But rich as the find may be, it is only the tip of the iceberg. During a drought caused by El Nino in 1998, a small cross on the top of a church spire inched its way clear of the surface of Lake Gatun, showing the location of one of the 12 French workers' towns scattered along the drowned Chagres river valley.

Those communities, Mr Ramos said, might include warehouses, machine shops, locomotive roundhouses and a vast inventory of heavy industrial plant.

It seems that the tepid waters of the Panama Canal still have much to surrender.

webTitle: Russian money laundering case may fall apart

fields.headline: Russian money laundering case may fall apart
fields.standfirst: 'Lack of US co-operation' threatens Swiss inquiry
fields.trailText: Swiss magistrates believe they are close to establishing fresh evidence of a link between top-level Russian money laundering and the alleged diversion of International Monetary Fund aid, but their case could fall apart because of a lack of co-operation from the United States and Russia.
fields.body:
Swiss magistrates believe they are close to establishing fresh evidence of a link between top-level Russian money laundering and the alleged diversion of International Monetary Fund aid, but their case could fall apart because of a lack of co-operation from the United States and Russia.

Laurent Kasper-Ansermet, a Swiss investigating magistrate, told the Guardian that he could not elaborate on the Bank of New York-IMF link because his inquiry was at a critical stage and he needed evidence from the US and Russia.

But he confirmed a report of "well-founded suspicions" after tracing $5bn (£3.3bn) from Russia which was then split up through banks in Switzerland.

It is a large amount for a transaction - even by the usual standards of Swiss money laundering.

It is said to include $1.4bn which was subsequently transferred to the Bank of New York. But Mr Kasper-Ansermet has only frozen accounts worth $18m in at least 10 Swiss-based banks since he began the inquiry last September.

He has not received any response to a formal request for legal assistance lodged with the New York district attorney's office dealing with the Bank of New York case in February and reminders since then have also gone unanswered. That documentary evidence is regarded as crucial to any criminal prosecution for money laundering.

By late summer Mr Kasper-Ansermet must also justify maintaining the freeze on Swiss-based assets.

A former Bank of New York executive, Lucy Edwards, and her husband, Peter Berlin, pleaded guilty in a US court last February to being involved in a $7bn international money laundering scheme, allegedly detailing how Russian banks used the US bank mainly for tax evasion.

Investigators from the national crime squad have questioned the couple - who lived in Britain - in connection with accounts they set up at two British banks.

Allegations that IMF aid was siphoned off first surfaced with the affair last year but were denied by Russia.

The former US treasury secretary, Robert Rubin, told Congress that much of a $4.8bn loan in 1999 may have been misused, leading the G7 group of industrialised nations to put pressure on Moscow to co-operate with cross-border money laundering investigations.

Last month the Swiss magistrate asked the Russian deputy state prosecutor to question officials at Russia's central bank. The trail is said to extend to three Russian commercial banks - DKB, Flamingo and Sobibank, as well as Sinex, an offshore bank in the Pacific island of Nauru.

Despite regular meetings, Swiss judges fear their Russian counterparts are unable to go very far because of the political ramifications.

Mr Kasper-Ansermet said he was tracing transactions of Benex International, Becs International LLC and Lowland Inc, three companies cited in the US case against the Bank of New York executives.

Several people in a separate case, which involved a Swiss construction company and corruption in the Kremlin, are due to be formally charged in Geneva later this month with money laundering and participation in a criminal organisation. The affair has been linked to credit cards which were given to former President Yeltsin's daughters.

fields.headline: Public sector grows again
fields.standfirst:
More teachers and NHS workers as spending boost reverses years of decline

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour's boost to government spending has delivered the first rise in public sector employment since the winter of discontent in 1979 ushered in the Conservatives' 18-year campaign to slim down the state.
fields.body:
Labour's boost to government spending has delivered the first rise in public sector employment since the winter of discontent in 1979 ushered in the Conservatives' 18-year campaign to slim down the state.

In the first signs that frontline services are feeling the benefit of Labour's spending plans, figures from the office for national statistics yesterday showed that public sector jobs rose by 44,000 in 1999, driven by increases in education and NHS spending.

But the main public sector union warned yesterday that a creeping "culture of privatisation" still threatened governement services. Delegates at Unison's annual conference called on Labour to increase the top rate of tax and invest the proceeds in better health and education.

The ONS said the vast bulk of the increase came in education, with 16,000 more teachers and 19,000 more support staff. The teaching workforce now totals 533,330, a rise of 3% on last year.

However, one of the main teachers' unions said that while the extra numbers had gone towards fulfilling the government's policy of cutting class sizes for six-year-olds, more teachers were still needed.

"The government's own policies requires more teachers," said Olive Forsyth from the National Union of Teachers. "We still have a situation where more teachers are needed because class sizes are rising for the over-sevens. There are classes with more than 40 children in them."

Ms Forsyth added that there were still not enough young people training to be teachers.

Employment in the NHS rose by 8,000 in 1999 but the ONS was not able to provide a breakdown between medical and non-medical staff. Vacancies are running at 12,000, according to the Department of Health's estimates. The TUC says the NHS needs 2,000 more doctors, 7,000 nurses and 3,000 other staff.

Public sector employment totalled 4.759m last year compared to 7.135m when the Conservatives came to power in 1979. Employment has fallen by a third over the past 20 years as the impact of state sell-offs, contracting out and a "private good, public bad" ethos cut into jobs.

Over the same period, employment in the private sector rose from 16.483m to 19.275m. The ONS said 243,000 more private sector jobs were created last year, driven by fast growing sectors such as business services.

Central government jobs fell by 1.5%, partly because of some government institutions such as the ordnance survey and the forensic science service being reclassified as public non-financial services.

Between 1989 and 1999, total jobs in industry decreased by 14%, to 6.8m, according to the ONS. The proportion of public sector employees working in industry fell from 16.5% to 8.8%, largely as a result of privatisations.

Yesterday's report came hard on the heels of a call from Unison, the public sector workers' union, for the government to raise the top rate of tax to 50% and invest the proceeds in better public services.

Delegates at Unison's conference accused the government of sitting on a war chest of tens of billions of pounds while public services were starved of cash and social problems, such as child poverty and a low state pension, remained.

"We're hoping that by putting these issues forward to the government, perhaps Gordon Brown and the prime minister will be bolder in the future," said Unison's general secretary Rodney Bickerstaffe.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pardon for 1981 Pope hitman
fields.body:
Pardon for 1981 Pope hitman

The Italian president has pardoned Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish gunman who wounded the Pope in a 1981 assassination attempt, the Ansa news agency reported yesterday.

President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi's office refused to comment immediately on the report.

Agca shot the Pope in the abdomen in St. Peter's Square. he was caught minutes after the shooting and has been in prison ever since. AP, Rome

Supporter of Mugabe killed

Political violence in Zimbabwe claimed another life in a tavern brawl, police said yesterday, bringing the death toll to at least 32 since February.

A ruling party supporter, who was not identified, was stabbed in the chest after refusing to take off a party T-shirt in a bar in Chivi, 200 miles south of Harare, on Sunday. AP, Harare

Fijian cabinet to be named

Fiji's military ruler, Commodore Frank Bainimarama, said yesterday that he would name a civilian government within days, and it would not include the coup leader George Speight, who is holding 31 hostages, or his supporters. AP, Suva

webTitle: KS Biomedix chief to step aside

fields.headline: KS Biomedix chief to step aside
fields.trailText: Kim Tan, one of Britain's wealthiest biotechnology entrepreneurs, will step down as chief executive of KS Biomedix, the firm he founded to develop cancer drugs based on antibodies from sheep.
fields.body:
Kim Tan, one of Britain's wealthiest biotechnology entrepreneurs, will step down as chief executive of KS Biomedix, the firm he founded to develop cancer drugs based on antibodies from sheep.

Dr Tan is today expected to hand over the top job to Steven Powell, who joined the business as chief operating officer at the beginning of the year.

The change comes after a successful year for the company, which is carrying out phase three clinical trials of treatments for arthritis and osteoarthritis.

KS Biomedix's capitalisation approached £400m at the height of this year's boom in hi-tech shares but has since fallen to £245m.

Dr Tan will remain on the board as an executive director and intends to keep his 60% stake in the company, which is worth nearly £150m.

He described himself yesterday as a "scientific entrepreneur", saying that he wanted to concentrate on finding partnerships and alliances to bring in new technologies for KS Biomedix.

"People who are entrepreneurial often don't make good chief executives," he said. "I want to concentrate on doing the things I enjoy - life's too short."

Dr Tan is also chairman of an Ofex-listed company, Gene Medix, where his majority stake is worth about £140m. He intends to devote more time to this, and to charitable activities - he is involved in a number of Christian relief organisations operating in developing countries.

Dr Tan insisted his change of roles was "a happy move", saying: "I know a lot of management changes in the biotech industry have been pretty difficult, but I'm very relaxed about handing over to Steve."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
GWR extends radio licences
GWR, which owns Classic FM, yesterday agreed a £146m deal to acquire the radio interests of its largest shareholder, Daily Mail and General Trust.
fields.body:
GWR extends radio licences
GWR, which owns Classic FM, yesterday agreed a £146m deal to acquire the radio interests of its largest shareholder, Daily Mail and General Trust.

The deal sees GWR take control of a further eight British radio licences, the largest commercial station in Hungary and a 25% share of 58 local Australian stations.

The British stations trade under the Breeze AM, Mercury FM, Vibe FM and Essex FM names and are concentrated in eastern England.

Dutch pave way for ING
Dutch banks and the Amsterdam stock exchange are willing to pay more than $132m (£87.5m) - more than five times the amount they first offered - to settle claims they helped the Nazis steal bank accounts and stocks from Jews, a source said yesterday.

If an accord is reached, this could clear the way for ING, Europe's fifth largest financial institution, to buy a Minnesota-based insurer called ReliaStar Financial Corp and the international and financial assets of Connecticut-based Aetna, the top US health insurer.

Ryanair takes case to EC
No-frills airline Ryanair said yesterday that it had filed a formal complaint with the European commission against Deutsche Lufthansa over predatory pricing. The company claimed the German airline was engaging in below-cost pricing on those routes between Germany and London on which it competed with Ryanair - specifically Frankfurt to London Stansted and Stansted to Hamburg. Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said he hoped the commission would take swift action on complaints by his company and by BA's low-cost Go subsidiary in respect of Lufthansa's "abusive behaviour".

Nasdaq opens up trading
Nasdaq said on Tuesday that three electronic communications networks, Bloomberg Tradebook, BRUT, and MarketXT, are to join its electronic market for trading exchange-listed stocks, including those listed on the New York stock exchange. The three will be able to post quotes and execute trades within Nasdaq InterMarket, previously called the Third Market.

Ford should talk, says union
A call for Ford to discuss ways of saving car production at Dagenham was made yesterday at the AEEU engineering union's industrial conference at Blackpool. Duncan Simpson, the union's national officer for the motor industry, said the US car group should look at other options, including the production of Volvo or Mazda cars at the east London plant.

fields.headline: Oxford gets its sums wrong
fields.trailText: Shares in Oxford Instruments plunged in early trading yesterday after it reported an £800,000 annual loss. Three months ago its management predicted the company would break even.
fields.body:
Shares in Oxford Instruments plunged in early trading yesterday after it reported an £800,000 annual loss. Three months ago its management predicted the company would break even.

Analysts are used to nasty surprises from this group. Over the past two years Oxford has issued four profit warnings including one in March.

Yesterday morning the stock was marked down 11p at 159p, close to its all time low, but it recovered to end the session at 166p, down 4p.

The company blamed a big order backlog in its superconductivity business for the latest disappointment. A year earlier it posted a pre-tax and pre-exceptionals profit of £12.7m.

The City was not impressed by the latest figures, even though many analysts had predicted the results would be considerably worse than the company expected.

Oxford, which makes medical instruments and research products, said it had new risk management procedures in place for its superconductivity business.

The company held its yearly dividend at 8.4p and chief executive Andrew MacIntosh explained that two out of three of Oxford's business streams had returned to profitability in the second half of the financial year.

"While I am disappointed with this year's outcome, we are making real progress with the TopFlight reorganisation programme which is on track to deliver the forecast improvements in performance."

An exceptional charge of £7.3m had been taken last year and a further £1.6m would be taken in the coming year. This would cover ongoing restructuring which is expected to produce savings of £4m during 2000-2001.

Around 10% of the workforce has been cut following a study by PricewaterhouseCoopers which also urged it to reduce its six business streams to three.

The company has been gradually quitting its higher-cost Oxfordshire bases. Next week it will transfer its medical business from Abingdon to Woking while the analytical division will switch from Abingdon to High Wycombe.

But the legacy of profit warnings might take longer to depart.
