webTitle: It's time for Byers to stub out this cancerous company

fields.headline: It's time for Byers to stub out this cancerous company
fields.standfirst:
Today's health committee report will be a challenge to act against BAT

Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians with the power to make a difference can paradoxically face intense pressure to do nothing. BBC TV's cult sitcom Yes, Minister still strikes a chord at the top of New Labour nearly two decades on, but the Jim Hacker-Sir Humphrey Appleby confrontations are less funny on the inside than on the small screen.
fields.body:
Politicians with the power to make a difference can paradoxically face intense pressure to do nothing. BBC TV's cult sitcom Yes, Minister still strikes a chord at the top of New Labour nearly two decades on, but the Jim Hacker-Sir Humphrey Appleby confrontations are less funny on the inside than on the small screen.

Stephen Byers, the Blairite trade and industry secretary, will today be requested by an all-party committee of MPs to do something he knows is right but which may be opposed by officials in his department and will certainly resisted by one of Britain's biggest corporations. A unanimous report from the Commons health select committee will recommend a DTI inquiry into serious accusations that British American Tobacco has actively encouraged and profited from cigarette smuggling around the world. "The allegations need to be looked at independently and therefore we call on the DTI to investigate them," will declare the Labour, Liberal Democrat and Tory MPs.

Mr Byers can send in inspectors under section 432 of the 1985 Companies Act to discover whether the London-based company committed fraud abroad and unlawfully withheld information from shareholders. Whether he seizes the opportunity, or is persuaded to do nothing by nervous Sir Humphreys and lobbying by BAT, will be another one of those defining moments for New Labour.

A pro-business member of a pro-business government, Mr Byers either ensures that big business complies with the highest standards of integrity or he effectively allows it to operate above the law. To describe as serious the accusations levelled against BAT is no understatement. Senior executives - including current managing director Ulrich Herter and finance director Keith Dunt - are alleged to have been implicated in smuggling on a grand scale.

Documentary evidence shows billions and billions of "sticks" have been provided to wholesalers and distributors in South America and Asia, knowing they were likely to be smuggled across international borders to avoid duty. The "white van men" smuggling an estimated £2.5bn of tobacco into Britain across the channel look little more than a cottage industry compared to the scale of the international evidence disclosed in the Guardian earlier this year, in an analysis of 11,000 pages of BAT's own documents which were obtained by the Washington-based International Consortium of Investigative Journalists.

The pressure group Action on Smoking on Health, protected by parliamentary privilege, went further in evidence to the health committee, alleging BAT "exercised control on illegal distribution channels". In Colombia, said ASH, tobacco smuggling "almost certainly involves the laundering of illegal 'narco- dollars' - proceeds of cocaine and heroin trafficking."

BAT's PR department at the time refused to answer questions and then issued blanket denials. But apparent inconsistencies emerged. Kenneth Clarke, the former Tory chancellor now picking up £100,000 a year as BAT's vice-chairman, admitted the company was "faced with a dilemma" over smuggling and, while acting "within the law", wanted its brands "alongside those of our competitors in the smuggled as well as the legitimate market".

He and Martin Broughton, BAT's chairman, were subsequently called before the committee. Mr Clarke said he had not actually read the damning documents but the allegations were nevertheless untrue. Mr Broughton publicly tore up one memo and labelled the committee a "kangaroo court".

BAT, while protesting its innocence, has appointed UK and US law firms to prepare a defence and instigated an internal inquiry by its audit committee. What is needed is an independent investigation. DTI inspectors have the power to question staff and former employees on oath as well as demanding current documents. There are rumours circulating about BAT whistleblowers, who are now ready to come forward and testify before inspectors.

Tobacco companies, still reeling from hugely expensive defeats in US health cases, now face anti-racketeering claims from Canada, Ecuador and Colombia. Mr Byers can do his bit in Britain or be left looking impotent as more evidence emerges (ASH is studying BAT papers on Europe and Africa) of complicity in cigarette smuggling on a massive scale.

The trade and industry secretary would win significantly more friends than enemies if he sends in a team. Alan Milburn, the health minister, is pressing for curbs on smoking, despite the threat to jobs at a tobacco factory in his Darlington constituency.

Since the late 50s, about 6m British smokers have died prematurely and 60m worldwide. The projected global toll in the 21st century is 1bn. Even arms manufacturers will struggle to compete with the tobacco industry's body count. Anti-smoking campaigners calculate there are nine tobacco-related deaths a year in Britain for every job in the industry. Thousands of jobs have also gone through automation, yet the industry still enjoys a cosy relationship with trade unions prepared to defend smoking to protect their incomes and the Labour conference may be a non-smoking affair, but MPs recently received their cordial invites to a Brighton bash this autumn organised by the Tobacco Workers Alliance.

Last year The Insider, the film detailing how Jeffrey Wigand, an executive of BAT's US subsidiary, was targeted for retribution after exposing how nicotine levels were raised to increase addiction, told a true story about corporate irresponsibility. Yet it was only a tiny part of what goes on in an industry which systematically lied to the public for decades by denying that tobacco kills. BAT was part of "Project Whitecoat", a 1988 covert operation to "set up a team of scientists" to combat evidence about the harmful affects of passive smoking.

The industry's PR is now more subtle, focusing on smoking as being a personal choice for adults. Militant smokers, led by Lord Harris of High Cross, even denounce a "new apartheid", in which smokers are the victims of fascist health laws.

BAT now pledges to work with the government, calling for a tobacco version of the third way to polish its tarnished image and convince the gullible that, in Mr Broughton's words: "Big tobacco is responsible tobacco." Labour has had its fingers burned by tobacco once before in the shape of Bernie Ecclestone, the Grand Prix mogul who popped into Downing Street for a cosy chat to seek a money-spinning formula one exemption from the tobacco advertising ban. Millbank was required to hand back Mr Ecclestone's £1m donation to party coffers after details of the gift leaked out - one of the less honourable incidents in the life of the Labour government.

But Mr Byers today has the opportunity to do the honourable thing and prove that UK-based multinationals cannot treat the laws of other countries with contempt.

fields.headline: House of Fraser
fields.trailText: If life is as good for all retailers as it appears to be for House of Fraser then all that high street meltdown talk may have been premature - or maybe it is just as House of Fraser has been claiming, that it is winning the latest skirmishes in the fashion wars.
fields.body:
If life is as good for all retailers as it appears to be for House of Fraser then all that high street meltdown talk may have been premature - or maybe it is just as House of Fraser has been claiming, that it is winning the latest skirmishes in the fashion wars.

Shares in House of Fraser rose immediately after the group's trading statement at its annual meeting revealed its like for like sales growth is moving ever onward and upward. The 51-store chain said in the 19 weeks to June 10 2000, like for like sales were up 6.1% on the same period in 1999, reinforcing a trend at the eight week stage, when a like for like growth of 5.7% was trumpeted.

HoF further claimed that its market share is growing. Chief executive John Coleman said: "Like for like sales have now been at around the 6% level since the end of last October." Richard Ratner, an analyst at Seymour Pierce, thinks it is part of a trend for the sector: "Most department stores are doing quite well at the moment. The inclement weather is much better for the department stores than it is for the multiple retailers."

Analysts believe backroom improvements to the supply chain made by Mr Coleman may soon bear fruit and that HoF is now stealing market share from rivals.

In February its share price had fallen as low as 42p, although a month later they were back up to as high as 58p. Yesterday they rose 2p to reach 51p. Mr Coleman, with brands such as Army & Navy, DH Evans, Rackhams and Dickens & Jones under his control, has certainly halted the company's share price slide, though he has yet to oversee a restoration in the company's share value.

The chain is valued at somewhere around £130m - about half its value of a year ago.

Recently the signals from analysts have been mixed, and there has been little consensus among the investment community about whether to get into HoF or to leave it alone.

fields.headline: Neither left nor right
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair has a political philosophy, thank you. What he does not want is yet more advice on what it should be

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has a political philosophy, thank you. What he does not want is yet more advice on what it should be
fields.body:
Like every new parent, Tony Blair is getting more advice than he needs. There's the mother-in-law on the right, urging him to tilt the baby her way. There are the grandparents on the left, wishing Tony would do things the way they used to. And all around there are the candid friends, shaking their heads, tutting that young Mr Blair has not lived up to the enormous hopes they all had for him.

The prime minister says he takes no notice these days of the newspaper claims that he's experienced "the worst week of his premiership". They have said it too many times before. But as he wakes, twice a night apparently, to rock baby Leo to sleep, his mind must race with the torrent of criticism (and worse) that has been pouring his way - especially these last seven days.

He's had bad notices since the very start of the year, when the fiasco of the dome's opening night was followed by the NHS crisis, the civil war over Ken Livingstone in London, bad local election results and a run of media successes for William Hague on asylum and crime. But the culmination came exactly a week ago, with that now infamous mauling at the hands of the Women's Institute. Their slow handclap and mini-walkout has been variously described (in ascending order of hyperbole) as Blair's Sheffield rally, his Black Wednesday and even (a classic, this) his "Ceausescu moment". Just as Neil Kinnock was finished when he punched the air in Sheffield, just as John Major was doomed once Britain was ejected from the ERM, and just as Romania's communist dictator faced the abyss when the Bucharest masses began to boo - so Tony Blair saw his undoing in the scowling faces of the WI.

It was that moment of visible weakness in the once all-conquering Labour leader, that slipping of the halo, which triggered the latest deluge of unwanted advice. On the left, a brigade of trade unions is bombarding next month's National Policy Forum with hostile resolutions while Ken Livingstone - clearly straining after a month of self-discipline - has returned to newspaper punditry to tell the PM to be more like him. Ken and the unions urge Blair to stop trying to appeal to everyone and to forge instead a centre-left coalition with unabashedly progressive views. They want Labour to write off the right; to make instead the left case for spending, activist government and, yes, even for higher taxes.

Meanwhile the right whispers an opposite message. They say the problem is not with disenchanted Labour activists. Rather what matters is the aspirational, Sierra-driving, Basildon man who deserted Labour for four elections on the trot - but who came back in 1997. These are the people Blair must keep, and who have been turned off by the government's perceived softness on asylum, crime and Europe. The prime mover of this view is focus group king Philip Gould who, thanks to a handy leak, has been revealed as the sage who warned the PM his WI speech would turn to ashes. (Blair, incidentally, claims never to have seen that Gould memo.)

So the hapless Tony is left standing in the middle, pushed and pulled in opposite directions, clutching the baby that is the Labour government. Which way will he jump? Where are his instincts, to tack left where Ken and the unions want him - or further right as Gould and most of the press demands?

The answer is that Blair will stay just where he is: neither left, nor right but straight down the middle. He has never wavered from the strategic calculation he made years ago: that elections are won on the centre ground and whoever owns that territory owns power. That's why he's not too bothered by Hague's recent run. The Tory leader may be mobilising his own core vote but, Blair believes, Hague's prescriptions are too rightwing for the rest of the country. The golden path runs through the middle - and that's where Blair plans to stay.

But, and this may be hard for Blair's detractors on both left and right to swallow, it's not just calculation. The Labour leader actually believes what so many dismiss as third way guff and blather. It is not pure electoral positioning, which could be junked overnight. The prime minister genuinely believes his actions are rooted in a political philosophy - and that we are the dim ones for not seeing it.

T he core idea is that for the entire post-war era politics was organised in a simple, binary fashion. Ranged on the left were the advocates of a good society. On the right, the champions of a strong economy. What neither realised is that a country needs both - and that you cannot have one without the other. That may sound like a cop-out and a fudge. But for Blair, that's the only place a smart government can be.

The result is that Tony Blair can seem oddly lonely. Privately, he says he feels like a man ahead of his time: everyone around him is stuck in an 80s timewarp, still seeing the world on left/right lines. By 2030 everyone will see the world his way, wondering how it could have taken us all so long to cotton on. To him it is so obvious. Not the plea for opportunity voiced by the left, nor the demand for responsibility lodged by the right - but a "synthesis" of both. It's still about principles, says Blair: it's just that his principles include two which have been pitted against each other, mistakenly, for nearly a century.

The trouble is a shortage of political glue. For some reason that third way idea refuses to stick to any part of the national cortex. So does the long list of Labour achievements, which Blair can rattle off in his sleep - and which set the provisional wing of the WI heckling last week. Why does that refuse to gel?

The Blairite answer is simple: "absence of struggle". In the Tory years, every new proposal saw the Conservatives line up their troops on the battlefield, Labour would then follow them - and lose. The contest would convince the nation that something had changed. So Margaret Thatcher's trade union reforms were valued because the miners' strike proved they had been hard won. Blair's own achievements - the minimum wage or the new deal - have come without struggle. And so they are valued less.

There's a connection here with Blair himself. The PM seems aware that the British people have not taken him to heart; that they respect rather than like him. Apparently he wonders if that's because things seem to have come to him too easily: the gilded career through public school, Oxbridge and the law; the squeaky clean family; even the new baby. Blair's progress looks so smooth; no one, say his friends, sees "the little legs paddling away under the surface".

The government is the same: we haven't seen the struggle. Picking random fights on the right or left won't quite be enough. For Blairism requires an almost unique piece of political story-telling: to take an inclusive, centrist synthesis of left and right, old and new - and depict it as a passionate struggle, in which voters have to take sides. We have seen the smooth sailing: now we want to see those legs, paddling furiously.

The Blairite answer is simple: "absence of struggle". In the Tory years, every new proposal saw the Conservatives line up their troops on the battlefield, Labour would then follow them - and lose. The contest would convince the nation that something had changed. So Margaret Thatcher's trade union reforms were valued because the miners' strike proved they had been hard won. Blair's own achievements - the minimum wage or the new deal - have come without struggle. And so they are valued less. There's a connection here with Blair himself. The PM seems aware that the British people have not taken him to heart; that they respect rather than like him. Apparently he wonders if that's because things seem to have come to him too easily: the gilded career through public school, Oxbridge and the law; the squeaky clean family; even the new baby. Blair's progress looks so smooth; no one, say his friends, sees "the little legs paddling away under the surface". The government is the same: we haven't seen the struggle. Picking random fights on the right or left won't quite be enough. For Blairism requires an almost unique piece of political story-telling: to take an inclusive, centrist synthesis of left and right, old and new - and depict it as a passionate struggle, in which voters have to take sides. We have seen the smooth sailing: now we want to see those legs, paddling furiously. jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Atlantic opts out of auction
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Atlantic Telecom said yesterday it might not bid for fixed wireless licences to be sold by the government in September because it fears the auction process will inflate the price.
fields.body:
Atlantic Telecom said yesterday it might not bid for fixed wireless licences to be sold by the government in September because it fears the auction process will inflate the price.

The company already has national licences for fixed wireless operations, but these are run on a different frequency to the new concessions.

Atlantic Telecom is viewed as a market leader in this area and built its strategy around attracting small to medium-size businesses with the technology, which promises to deliver high speed internet connections.

"We don't like to play in auctions," said Graham Duncan, executive chairman of the Aberdeen-based company. "We have won all our licences up until now in beauty contests."

The government is expected to auction up to 60 licences for 20 regions for transmission in the 28GHz spectrum, which targets mainly medium-size to large business.

Some analysts have estimated this could raise at least £2bn for the Treasury's coffers.

Fixed wireless delivers fast internet and multimedia access by transmitting signals from base stations to microwave dishes.

It is attractive to telecoms companies because it is cheaper, offers fast connections and means that operators can bypass both BT and the cable networks to provide services.

Atlantic Telecom shares fell 90p to 510p yesterday as the company reported its losses had almost doubled to £33.4m in the year.

The increase followed the company's investment in expanding its network, acquisitions and the capital injected to attract new customers.

Atlantic Telecom bought First Telecom Group for £350m last month - which has given it additional residential customers in Britain, France and Germany, and access to digital subscriber line technology.

The company is reviewing the use of the First Telecom and Atlantic brands in its overseas markets.

Revenues leapt by 43% in the year to £21.3m, with telecom revenues up more than 63% to £15.2m, benefiting from continued geographic expansion of the business.

Mr Duncan said: "We look forward to expanding our network reach both in the UK and Europe during this financial year and intend to deliver the very best portfolio of services to our expanding customer base."

fields.headline: Heatwave blowing in from France
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Trooping the Colour on the monarch's birthday, England at Charleroi, and outdoor dining prospects are all expected to benefit from a brief outbreak of summer when temperatures nudge up into the mid-20s Celsius (high 70s Fahrenheit) this weekend.
fields.body:
Trooping the Colour on the monarch's birthday, England at Charleroi, and outdoor dining prospects are all expected to benefit from a brief outbreak of summer when temperatures nudge up into the mid-20s Celsius (high 70s Fahrenheit) this weekend.

A wind blowing in from southern France will send the mercury creeping up, even in Scotland, where wide swaths of the country were yesterday in the grip of gales.

A Met office spokesman said: "Saturday should be above 20 degrees in most inland areas. In the south it will reach the mid-20s, if not higher." Across the Channel, the fans and players at Charleroi will enjoy temperatures "well up in the 20s, dry and warm."

However the wind bringing warmer temperatures will shift westwards by the middle of next week, leaving an unsettled mix.

Northern Scotland, meanwhile, yesterday experienced gales of up to 80mph, prompting warnings for seafarers and road-users. Strong south to southwesterly winds increased to severe gale force across the Highlands, Western Isles, Orkney and Shetland Islands.

fields.headline: Auction of Vivaldi treasures
fields.trailText: Perfectly preserved manuscripts of unknown works by Vivaldi and other masters of baroque music's golden age will be auctioned in Rome today.
fields.body:
Perfectly preserved manuscripts of unknown works by Vivaldi and other masters of baroque music's golden age will be auctioned in Rome today.

From the private collection of a family of Piedmontese aristocrats, the 80 manuscripts will add a new chapter to the history of 18th century composition.

"This is the peak period for the history of music. If you imagine that this period influenced Bach, influenced Mozart, you can imagine the importance of Italian music in the 18th century," said Fabio Bertolo, who is organising the sale at Christie's.

Most interesting is the unpublished manuscript of Antonio Vivaldi's L'Improvisata - The Pleasant Surprise.

The work for strings was played in public for the first time in three centuries in Christie's auction room on Monday. It is one of the most important discoveries in the Vivaldi oeuvre, Mr Bertolo said. "Not only Vivaldi but all this collection has never been played."

The Italian state archive is expected to bid for manuscrips, which will be sold together with a reserve of £60,000.

"Compared with the historical importance of this music it's nothing," said Mr Bertolo.

fields.headline: Jury duty: it's aptly named
fields.standfirst: Trial by jury: special report
fields.trailText: Rosie Millard: Tony Blair and I were called up for jury service on the same week. He, being prime minister and perhaps because of the imminent arrival of Baby Leo, managed to be excused. I did not. Not that I wasn't encouraged to wriggle out of it.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and I were called up for jury service on the same week. He, being prime minister and perhaps because of the imminent arrival of Baby Leo, managed to be excused. I did not. Not that I wasn't encouraged to wriggle out of it. The instant reaction from colleagues and friends was that it was a bit of a joke. The summons looked severe, but could easily be kissed off with a strong letter on headed paper. "Just say it's inconvenient for work," said a friend.

Except the truth was that it wasn't. As things stood, jury service arrived at a good time, and much to the amazement of everyone, not least my boss, I went along.

Lord Justice Auld is conducting a review of the criminal justice system; with particular regard for juries. And it's not before time. Apparently he has found that juries are "unrepresentative". My jury was highly representative: of people with time on their hands. Where were the teachers, the professionals, the City bankers, the chattering classes? Where were the Guardian readers? Er, bunked off, m'lud. Lord Auld's findings suggest that juries are largely made up of housewives and the unemployed. Everyone else is too busy in the office.

The woman in my crown court who ran the jury waiting room with an iron grasp and a very loud public address system explained that the court calls 600 people a week: "We have to call 600; 400 get out of it every week."

Housewives and the unemployed are not necessarily going to do a bad job. But English law depends on 12 average people sitting in the jury box - of different backgrounds. Juries are supposed to represent a true cross-section, but in my experience, they didn't. A straw poll of 12 average people might well contain a bit of everything, but not if the vast majority of the educated middle class wriggles out.

One of the juries I sat on contained someone who could not read the oath. After three attempts she was gently told by the judge to repeat the words after the court official. Maybe she had a great understanding of human nature. But if I was the defendant, or a witness, I would be a lot more confident if I knew the trial was being heard by a jury that was literate. Particularly as the tricky word in question was "verdict".

One suggestion of why jury service is so unfashionable is that people apparently don't want to shoulder the responsibility of sending people down. In my experience what one might call the "woolly liberal" constituency was largely absent. In one case most of my counterparts appeared to have been born and bred in Texas. "Prison's too good for him," she opined in the lounge after our case had finished. "He should be executed by lethal injection. Or castrated." There then followed the hoary old chit-chat about taxpayers' money being wasted, the astonishing luxury of prisons and so on. After which outburst, she got back to her 5,000-piece jigsaw puzzle of the Queen Mother.

Of course, a jury made up of official quotas would be impossible to pull off. But as the accused can be anyone in society, so should the juries who sit in judgment. The Auld report has suggested that as in America, jury service should be virtually compulsory, with penalties for those who cry off. I suggest the problem doesn't lie so much with the courts as with office politics. It is now so unfashionable to take any time off work, that the idea of doing jury service for a fortnight is, in many people's lives, simply impossible.

Forget the fusty concept of public duty, of citizenship. Like those other public services, transport and education, the fire behind this particular rocket went out with the Ark. The only citizenship that is important now is the one you owe to your company. Most people are so hell-bent on performing 60-hour office marathons every week that leaving their desks for anything other than the death of a relation (close) or the birth of a child (yours), is unthinkable. But why?

Paradoxically, while 21st century business practices now dictate the desk should be more familiar than the home, bosses are also very fond of reminding people they are not indispensable. Fine. So drop the get-out clauses. For those of us who are not operating on sick people, or not actually running the country, two weeks of immersion in our legal system might be a good thing.

The responsibility of being a juror is not only important, and dutiful, in a strangely attractive, outmoded way; but it also allows a fascinating insight into how other people live. And I'm not talking about the defendant. Can you seriously imagine going to work every day in a black suit, wearing a wig and gown and peppering every other phrase with "Your Honour"?

 Rosie Millard is arts correspondent of the BBC.

fields.headline: NTL to be Rangers' agent
fields.standfirst:
Cable firm embarrassed to be seen snubbing Celtic
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: NTL, Britain's largest cable company, yesterday announced a £31m agreement to act as media agent for Glasgow's Rangers football club and in doing so risked a backlash from supporters of its historic rival Celtic.
fields.body:
NTL, Britain's largest cable company, yesterday announced a £31m agreement to act as media agent for Glasgow's Rangers football club and in doing so risked a backlash from supporters of its historic rival Celtic.

The agreement with Rangers, which is planning a stock market flotation, will see the establishment of a joint venture to operate a prospective television channel, internet and e-commerce ventures. The deal is structured as a £10m payment for the media rights plus another £21m injection into the joint venture.

The announcement though was not as NTL had hoped. The cable company has been working on deals with both Rangers and Celtic in parallel and had aimed at disclosing both at the same time.

NTL, which owns the Glasgow cable franchise, has in the past been careful to avoid upsetting either side of the city's highly partisan community by sponsoring both clubs.

Geoffrey Hamilton-Fairley, chief executive of NTL-subsidiary Premium Television, said an offer to Celtic had been made and remained on the table.

"We have always maintained a stance of total impartiality and we have pursued discussions with both about a long lasting media partnership," he said. "We have reached a conclusion with Rangers and have offered the same deal to Celtic, which will remain open until the end of the year."

Celtic said NTL was just one of a number of potential media partners. A statement from the club said it was "considering all the options that may be available covering its media rights".

NTL has been rapidly buying up stakes in football clubs and last week announced the acquisition of a share in Leicester City. It also has investments in Aston Villa, Middlesbrough and Newcastle.

Rangers commercial director Martin Bain said the relationship would harness plans to build the club into a global brand along the model of Manchester United. The cash would be used to clear debt, invest in players and for the club's youth development programme.

The deals are a sideshow to today's main event when final bids for the broadcasting rights to the English Premiership will be submitted. Favourites for the main package of 66 live games are BSkyB, NTL and potentially OnDigital.

According to the rules any companies making the shortlist have already passed the quality test and the rights will be awarded on a purely financial basis. To win, a bid has to have a clear 5% margin from the nearest competitor.

fields.headline: Sharpshooter rides into wine country
fields.standfirst: Californian growers do battle with vine bug
fields.trailText: It is only half an inch long, but scientists say it is the greatest threat ever to Californian grapes and thus to one of the world's leading wine-producing areas . Now a battle is on to defeat the carrier of a disease which could devastate the $30bn (£19.8bn) industry.
fields.body:
It is only half an inch long, but scientists say it is the greatest threat ever to Californian grapes and thus to one of the world's leading wine-producing areas . Now a battle is on to defeat the carrier of a disease which could devastate the $30bn (£19.8bn) industry.

The glassy-winged sharpshooter is an insect with a sharp proboscis which sucks the nutrients from plants. More pertinently to the vineyards of California, it carries the bacterium that causes Pierce's disease, which kills plants by clogging up their water-carrying tissues.

The disease has plagued the grape industry in the past but never to the extent now feared in California.

"Growers are scared of it. It could wipe them out," said Susan Kegley, a staff scientist at the Pesticide Action Network, which is monitoring the threat. "It is extremely unpre dictable. There is no plan in place. It might not be possible for the grapes infected to survive. The only thing the politicians can do is throw money at it, and that's not a good control strategy."

A congressional bill authorising a further $7m to fight the disease is awaiting President Bill Clinton's signature.

"We are very aware of the issue," said Mora Cronin of the Berringer Vineyards in St Helena, Napa Valley, one of California's most famous wine-making areas.

"Pierce's disease has been around for decades but this vector is new. We are very watchful of it, but we are very encouraged by the attention being given to it by both the federal and state authorities. We are not panicking."

Others are less sanguine, but for different reasons. Some environmentalists fear that because of the sharpshooter's potential commercial impact there could be pressure to use pesticides that might damage the environment. "Many, many people are very upset about taxpayers' money being used [on pesticides]," said Ms Kegley. People in the Fresno area were objecting to the authorities entering their backyards to spray plants when it was still unclear what effect the chemicals might have.

She added that the concentration in California on grape production to the exclusion of a more balanced form of agriculture left the vineyards more vulnerable.

"The crops are produced for the highest yield and having so much of one crop anywhere makes it easy for the disease to spread."

The authorities are examining the possibility of using parasitic wasps to fight the sharpshooter.

The wasps, which eat sharpshooter eggs, are being tested at the University of California Riverside and, if the experiment proves successful, they will be released in grape-growing areas in their millions. The main problem is that it may take years to develop them. In the meantime, some growers are using a pesticide called Admire, whose results are not yet known.

At present the sharpshooter is in Central Valley. Growers in Napa Valley, to the north, a popular region for tourists visiting vineyards, are anxiously watching attempts to contain the insect.

It has already caused $40m-worth of damage in the Temecula area of southern California.

The pest can be difficult to find; scientists are reduced to placing a net below a plant which they beat with a stick.

Robert Louis Stevenson, who stayed in Californian wine-growing country 120 years ago, wrote presciently of the then experimental wine industry that "the smack of Californian earth shall linger on the palate of your grandson".

The next few months will give an indication how much damage may be caused by the arrival of the smallest sharpshooter ever to bring fear to the west.

fields.headline: Metal makeover
fields.standfirst:
Trading ring under threat
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The world famous dealing ring at the London Metal Exchange, above, could disappear under sweeping proposals to modernise its trading systems, chairman Lord Bagri said yesterday.
fields.body:
The world famous dealing ring at the London Metal Exchange, above, could disappear under sweeping proposals to modernise its trading systems, chairman Lord Bagri said yesterday.

Yesterday's blueprint for change at the LME lays down that the screen trading platform, to be operated in parallel with the ring, ought to have the capability to replace it altogether "should the market so desire".

At present it is envisaged that screen trading will take place only when the ring - the trading floor at the exchange in Leadenhall Street in the City - is closed. And "there is no demand for us to abolish the ring," Lord Bagri said.

The LME, the hub of world metal trading, is proposing to end 15 years as a mutually owned organisation and revert to its previous status as a limited company. But there is no question of the exchange becoming a full-blown profit making organisation. Shareholding will be restricted to members and each member, whether or not a ring dealer, will need 250,000 shares as a "ticket" into the LME.

New members will be able either to buy such a block of shares from a member wishing to leave the exchange or buy new shares from the LME board.

The proposals are going out for consultation; members have until June 30 to make their views known.

webTitle: Judge to decide who is lord of The Dance

fields.headline: Judge to decide who is lord of The Dance
fields.trailText: The grandson of a Russian art collector is asking an Italian court to stop Henri Matisse's masterpiece The Dance returning to the Hermitage museum in St Petersburg, more than 80 years after it was seized by the Bolsheviks.
fields.body:
The grandson of a Russian art collector is asking an Italian court to stop Henri Matisse's masterpiece The Dance returning to the Hermitage museum in St Petersburg, more than 80 years after it was seized by the Bolsheviks.

A judge will tomorrow investigate claims that the museum stole the painting and "prostituted" it during a visit to Rome for an exhibition, One Hundred Masterpieces from the Hermitage.

Andre-Marc Delocque-Fourcaud, the grandson of the art collector Sergei Shtukin, says the painting was taken without compensation in 1918 after the Bolshevik revolution.

Mr Delocque-Fourcaud, who lives in Paris, also claims the museum forfeited ownership of The Dance during the exhibition by using its image to sell wrapping paper, scarves and ashtrays. His grandfather's collection was for the pleasure of art lovers, not profit, he says. "The Dance scorned, The Dance dishonoured, The Dance prostituted," he told the French newspaper Le Figaro.

"The Dance is a stolen work of art, according to the law in force in democratic countries. The fact that the thief was Lenin in person doesn't justify the theft," said Mr Delocque-Fourcaud.

The Dance was among 80 paintings and 20 drawings from the Hermitage which went on display last December at the Quirinale Palace. Visited by Pope John Paul II and thousands who queued for hours, the show closed on Sunday.

Mr Delocque-Fourcaud waited until the show's end to spring his surprise. The Hermitage said international regulations had been followed and the use of the painting's copyright had been cleared with the Henri Matisse Foundation.

Judge Francesca Sangiovanni is expected to deliver a judgment on July 11.

fields.headline: 4,000 jobs in Transco pipeline
fields.standfirst: Credit card company doubles British workforce
fields.trailText: Transco, the BG subsidiary pipeline operator, is to invest £350m in 20 high-pressure pipeline projects and create around 4,000 new jobs throughout Britain, it will announce later today.
fields.body:
Transco, the BG subsidiary pipeline operator, is to invest £350m in 20 high-pressure pipeline projects and create around 4,000 new jobs throughout Britain, it will announce later today.

The investment, the biggest UK gas project since privatisation, is designed to meet an expected 30% increase in demand for the fuel in the five years from 1998 to 2003 and will lengthen the 6,300 kilometre national transmission system by 8%.

But Transco, due to be floated off from its parent later this year, is likely to seize the opportunity to lay fibre-optic cable alongside the pipes under its £235m scheme to move into data transmission and telecommunications.

The extra 528km of pipeline will traverse some rural areas of outstanding beauty, and the company has in the past run into opposition to its plans, most notably last year in the Brecon Beacons.

But Transco said each new pipeline route - the longest of which is 70km from St Fergus to Aberdeen - would be agreed with dozens of groups, from local authorities and farmers to wildlife trusts, in order to ensure the least environmental impact.

"We were the first west European utility to meet international environmental standards and see the need to strike a balance between meeting the growing demand for gas with environmental considerations," officials said. They pointed out that the pipelines are buried underground and the area restored to its original state.

Chief executive Phil Nolan said: "This large investment is in addition to ongoing investment in replacing and extending the 268,000km of medium and low-pressure pipes."

Transco has so far awarded 11 of the 20 projects to contractors, including Murphy, McAlpine-Preussag and Amec, with the remainder due to be handed over in the coming months for commission this year and next.

The company said underlying growth in demand for gas was more than 10% this past winter and further growth is expected through the European Interconnector, exports to Ireland and new gas-powered stations once the moratorium to protect the coal sector is lifted.

Earlier this year it laid plans to embrace the telecoms revolution, setting up a joint venture with US group Spectrasite to build towers for third generation mobile phone networks on its sites. Transco has 700 of the UK's 10,000 towers on its property but expects total UK build to rise to as much as 50,000 in the coming years.

Meanwhile in the new economy, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said CapitalOne, the US-based credit card company, would create 1,200 new jobs through a £60m expansion of its European head office in Nottingham, doubling its workforce.

Mr Byers said that the government had provided £6.6m in regional grants to encourage the company to choose Nottingham rather than other European sites. The aid has yet to be approved by the European commission.

webTitle: Who's behind the murders, ask India's Christians

fields.headline: Who's behind the murders, ask India's Christians
fields.trailText: Brother George stood no chance of escape. His killers moved silently through the school compound to where he was sleeping in the open on a folding bed. His assailants started beating him - methodically and deliberately -over the head with iron rods. He struggled, briefly. The next morning his body was found by the school cook.
fields.body:
Brother George stood no chance of escape. His killers moved silently through the school compound to where he was sleeping in the open on a folding bed. His assailants started beating him - methodically and deliberately -over the head with iron rods. He struggled, briefly. The next morning his body was found by the school cook.

"He was a perfect gentleman, a very mild person," Brother Julius Vattavayalil said yesterday, pointing to the bloodstains on the floor where the priest had died. His bed was still there, in front of a half-constructed school building, which will be the Assisi boys' home.

"He was only 43 years old. He was committed to the welfare of the poor and underprivileged," Brother Julius said. "People here cannot believe such a person could be murdered."

The killing last week of Brother George Kunjhikandam, a Catholic priest in Mathura, in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, was not an isolated incident. Instead, it was part of a sinister and evolving pattern.

Four weeks before Brother George's killers struck at St Francis's school in Mathura, another priest was severely beaten and left for dead in the nearby town of Kosi Kalan. At the Sacred Heart school in Mathura, its Carmelite principal, Sister Maria, was forced to hide in a classroom while a mob of 200 people tore through her school. A second priest was also attacked.

The state's tiny Christian community has found itself terrorised during the past two months. The contentious and politically explosive question is by whom?

Uttar Pradesh's Christians are not alone in their fear. Last week four bombs exploded simultaneously - two outside churches in the south Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, one in neighbouring Karnataka, and a fourth in Goa. Over the weekend, a second priest - this time in the Punjab - was murdered and then burnt.

Though India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, has declared that so far no motive for the attacks has been established, all the evidence points to the involvement of extreme Hindu gangs with embarrassing links to Mr Vajpayee's ruling Hindu nationalist government.

The crisis has become so serious that two days ago a delegation of Christian leaders called on Mr Vajpayee at his official residence in Delhi and urged him to intervene. Speaking afterwards, Archbishop Alan de Lastic said India's Christian community now faced its "gravest challenge" in the 53 years since the country's independence.

It was facing a "well-orchestrated campaign of hate and calumny", he said. "People are really frightened. They don't feel they can come to a church and pray."

Christians have been attacked in the past, but since Mr Vajpayee's pro-Hindu Bharatiya Janata party came to power in March 1998, the attacks have increased; there have been 35 recorded incidents this year alone.

The fundamentalist Hindu organisations linked with the attacks have denied involvement. They include the Vishwa Hindu Parishad and its militant youth wing, the Bajrang Dal, part of a collective Hindu movement known as the Sangh Parivar.

Detectives investigating the attacks have refused to draw the obvious conclusion - that they are the systematic work of local Hindu gangs acting with impunity.

Sister Maria, whose school was ransacked, yesterday recalled how the mob chanted: "We are Hindus. You are foreigners."

"The police just stood and watched the fun," she said.

fields.headline: Currency lessons from the Republic
fields.standfirst: Tales of euro land travails
fields.trailText: Ireland should act as a salutary lesson to those who are gung-ho for Britain to join the single currency. Whereas Britain's annual inflation rate - after eight years of steady growth - is 2.0% on the government's preferred measures, Ireland's is 5.2% and rising. Measured on the same Europe-wide basis, Britain's cost of living is going up by 0.5% a year, Ireland's by 5.0%.
fields.body:
Ireland should act as a salutary lesson to those who are gung-ho for Britain to join the single currency. Whereas Britain's annual inflation rate - after eight years of steady growth - is 2.0% on the government's preferred measures, Ireland's is 5.2% and rising. Measured on the same Europe-wide basis, Britain's cost of living is going up by 0.5% a year, Ireland's by 5.0%.

The reason for the disparity is simple: UK interest rates have been set by the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to meet the needs of the UK economy while Ireland's have not. Interest rates in the Republic were slashed to 3% when Ireland joined the euro, despite the fact that the economy was already growing at an unsustainable rate.

Monetary policy is now far too loose, and needs to be tightened aggressively to prevent the economy from full-scale overheating. But, having handed over the levers of policy to the European Central Bank, the Irish government is being forced back on exhortations to union leaders to show pay moderation.

Britain would have faced precisely the same problem had it joined monetary union in 1999. Irish inflation has increased from 2.1% to 5% since January 1999 and it is probable that a similar fate would have befallen Britain had the government been obliged to cut interest rates - a decision which would also have led to a big fall in the value of the pound. One senior City economist, Geoffrey Dicks of Greenwich NatWest, estimates that inflation in this country might be 7% if Britain had joined the single currency.

While it is true that the interest rate differential between the UK and euro land has narrowed slightly over the past 18 months, the gap is still a hefty 1.75 percentage points.

There could be a time over the next two or three years when rates converge but, given that Britain's economy is structurally different from those in euro land, this period is likely to be short-lived. Real and lasting convergence will only be achieved at a considerable cost, as the Irish are about to find out.

City drain

Speaking of Britain and the euro, it was always assumed that the City would be the thin end of the wedge when it came to persuading the government to take the plunge. London's dominant role in European financial markets would be jeopardised, it was said, by Frankfurt and there would be a steady draining of business out of the Square Mile.

According to Eddie George, not only is there no sign that this has happened but there is also no sign that it is going to happen. The governor said it was possible that barriers would be put in Britain's way should the pound stay outside the euro, but that it would be illogical because of the contribution that the City has made to the development of euro financial markets. London had benefited rather than lost from the euro's arrival - but not at the expense of Frankfurt or Paris.

Mr George, to be sure, is no great fan of the single currency. It is conceivable that any detrimental effects on the City from prolonged UK non-membership will only become apparent over time. However, it appears more likely that London is one of the few real examples of industrial clustering, rather like Silicon Valley, which will thrive independently of the national - or even European - policy framework.

Crude squeeze

Oil prices yesterday continued to bounce along above the $31 a barrel mark. There is a serious squeeze under way in the crude market, with traders panicked that Opec will not be increasing production volumes at the oil producer club's meeting next week.

US pressure is once again being brought to bear on its important Opec allies such as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to give a decisive lead at the Vienna summit and open the supply taps. But the irony here is that the US itself is to blame for much of the surge in prices.

New anti-pollution measures have been introduced in many parts of the US with little warning. There are shortages of the reformulated petrol required in 17 cities. US motorists are paying the price of that as much as any stubbornness from Opec on production quotas.

But Opec has also exacerbated nervousness in the crude markets by failing to pull the trigger on the self-correcting mechanism that was meant to come into play if prices rose above $28.

This problem is partly a Saudi one. The mechanism was dreamed up by hawkish Venezuela negotiators but was undermined by Saudi doves who did not like political control of something as important as pricing being handed over to a computer. Opec ministers will now decide on the matter on June 21.

The assumption has to be that Opec will effect a cutback. But either way it is hard to believe you could buy Brent blended crude for $10 a barrel less than 18 months ago.

fields.headline: Bankrupt logic of permissive society
fields.standfirst: Fear that creditors would lose as failed entrepreneurs keep £20,000 to start new businesses
fields.trailText: This week, a group of financial and legal professionals huddled into a cinema in the Barbican centre in London. Rather than sit back and enjoy the latest Hollywood offering, they set about an earnest symposium, the topic of which may be best summed up as the cost of free lunches.
fields.body:
This week, a group of financial and legal professionals huddled into a cinema in the Barbican centre in London. Rather than sit back and enjoy the latest Hollywood offering, they set about an earnest symposium, the topic of which may be best summed up as the cost of free lunches.

Despite Milton Friedman's best efforts, policymakers never tire of searching for that elusive midday meal with no bill to follow. And among the favourite luncheon vouchers is insolvency law reform, a field of activity that - by being labelled an attack on a "cultural" rather than an economic problem - is assumed to be cost free.

By removing the "stigma" of corporate and individual bankruptcy, the powers that be will unleash the sort of entrepreneurial dynamism that has made the United States economy the greatest on earth. Or that's the theory.

The symposium, arranged by the insolvency practitioners' professional body, known as R3, was convened to discuss proposed changes to the regime governing individual bankruptcy. A consultation paper on this topic is doing the rounds of interested parties and will be back with the Department of Trade by June 30.

That this latter document is entitled Bankruptcy - A Fresh Start gives a good idea of the thinking behind it and indeed behind the current wave of reform in general. In our moralistic age, insolvency law reform remains the last great bastion of the permissive society, still blasting salvos in the direction of "outdated Victorian morality" which says that bankrupts must be cast down.

R3 and allied professionals, however, have their doubts, to put it mildly. Should those doubts prove justified, everyone will end up paying, because the cost of credit to all borrowers - good, bad or indifferent - will rise.

The story so far. Peter Mandelson, during his time at the DTI, set the ball rolling in November 1998, when he told the Confederation of British Industry: "In the US some of the most successful entrepreneurs are those who have failed once or twice. Banks and society as a whole don't write people off as failures.

"They see them as people who have learned. That is why the government needs to carry out two reviews: one looking at corporate rescue procedures and the second looking at whether the law can be changed to reduce the stigma of financial failure."

The corporate side has been bundled up into an insolvency bill, currently before Parliament. It allows troubled companies a 28-day breathing space during which they can try to reorganise their affairs without the threat of creditors putting them into receivership or liquidation. This brings Britain nearer to the US chapter 11 insolvency regime.

But the second part of the equation is seen as the key to creating an energetic, risk-taking business environment. Entrepreneurs, even when they set up limited liability companies, are likely to have guaranteed their company's borrowings personally, and the vast majority by number of business failures are recorded as personal bankruptcies rather than company receiverships, administration orders or liquidations.

The insolvency profession has long been careful not to present a heartless "repo man" image to the public, and this is reflected in the caution with which it criticises any liberalisation of the insolvency laws. But the consultation paper has alarmed R3, whose president Stephen Gale, of solicitors Herbert Smith, warned in April that the proposals were "beset with problems".

R3 has focused on the two most radical plans for change. Firstly, the suggestion that someone who has invested their own money in a business (and has been neither reckless nor culpable) ought to be allowed to rescue - pound for pound - up to £20,000 from the wreckage either to start a new business or buy a family home.

But R3 is concerned that, as in four out of five cases the debtor has less than £20,000 in assets, this reform will benefit debtors at the expense of creditors - often small businesses themselves - who will get nothing.

The second proposal is for six-month bankruptcies, against the current three years, for those judged to have been unfortunate rather than culpable in the matter of their bankruptcies. Roger Oldfield, R3 vice-president and partner at accountants KPMG, warned: "The very process of differentiating between culpable and merely unfortunate bankrupts presents substantial difficulties and may well result in litigation where bankrupts fell wrongly adjudged."

Finally, R3 is concerned that, increasingly, personal bankruptcies are unconnected with business failure and result simply from consumers going too heavily into debt. The association warned "there is a chance that Britain is starting to follow the US trend", where bankruptcies actually rise during an economic boom.

That, presumably, is one aspect of the American system that the government has no desire to import here.

R3 and allied professionals, however, have their doubts, to put it mildly. Should those doubts prove justified, everyone will end up paying, because the cost of credit to all borrowers - good, bad or indifferent - will rise. The story so far. Peter Mandelson, during his time at the DTI, set the ball rolling in November 1998, when he told the Confederation of British Industry: "In the US some of the most successful entrepreneurs are those who have failed once or twice. Banks and society as a whole don't write people off as failures. "They see them as people who have learned. That is why the government needs to carry out two reviews: one looking at corporate rescue procedures and the second looking at whether the law can be changed to reduce the stigma of financial failure." The corporate side has been bundled up into an insolvency bill, currently before Parliament. It allows troubled companies a 28-day breathing space during which they can try to reorganise their affairs without the threat of creditors putting them into receivership or liquidation. This brings Britain nearer to the US chapter 11 insolvency regime. But the second part of the equation is seen as the key to creating an energetic, risk-taking business environment. Entrepreneurs, even when they set up limited liability companies, are likely to have guaranteed their company's borrowings personally, and the vast majority by number of business failures are recorded as personal bankruptcies rather than company receiverships, administration orders or liquidations. The insolvency profession has long been careful not to present a heartless "repo man" image to the public, and this is reflected in the caution with which it criticises any liberalisation of the insolvency laws. But the consultation paper has alarmed R3, whose president Stephen Gale, of solicitors Herbert Smith, warned in April that the proposals were "beset with problems". R3 has focused on the two most radical plans for change. Firstly, the suggestion that someone who has invested their own money in a business (and has been neither reckless nor culpable) ought to be allowed to rescue - pound for pound - up to £20,000 from the wreckage either to start a new business or buy a family home. But R3 is concerned that, as in four out of five cases the debtor has less than £20,000 in assets, this reform will benefit debtors at the expense of creditors - often small businesses themselves - who will get nothing. The second proposal is for six-month bankruptcies, against the current three years, for those judged to have been unfortunate rather than culpable in the matter of their bankruptcies. Roger Oldfield, R3 vice-president and partner at accountants KPMG, warned: "The very process of differentiating between culpable and merely unfortunate bankrupts presents substantial difficulties and may well result in litigation where bankrupts fell wrongly adjudged." Finally, R3 is concerned that, increasingly, personal bankruptcies are unconnected with business failure and result simply from consumers going too heavily into debt. The association warned "there is a chance that Britain is starting to follow the US trend", where bankruptcies actually rise during an economic boom. That, presumably, is one aspect of the American system that the government has no desire to import here.

fields.headline: Losing streak continues for Eidos
fields.trailText: Eidos, the computer games maker which suffered a spectacular fall from grace at the start of the year, warned yesterday that market conditions would get worse over the next 12 months before they get better.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games maker which suffered a spectacular fall from grace at the start of the year, warned yesterday that market conditions would get worse over the next 12 months before they get better.

The gloomy forecast was made as the company best known for its Tomb Raider games featuring schoolboy pin-up Lara Croft reported operating losses of £26.8m for the year to March 31 against a £39.2m profit in the previous year. The results followed two profit warnings earlier this year.

Eidos shares, which reached £13.20 at the end of last year, continued their slide and were off another 19p at 375p.

Mike McGarvey, chief operating officer at the company, said the games market would contract by 20-25% this year as players hold off purchases until the next wave of hardware led by Sony's PlayStation 2 hits the shelves. Last year the market shrank by some 15%.

"We need to get the message across that this is not Eidos in transition but an industry in transition. But this is still a very exciting place to be."

PlayStation 2 is due to arrive in the US and Europe on October 26 and Nintendo's Dolphin and the hotly anticipated Microsoft X-Box games consoles should reach retailers towards the end of next year.

Mr McGarvey said market growth would be double-digit by 2001 and reach 25-30% again by 2003.

Eidos still relies heavily on the Tomb Raider franchise, which accounts for around 40% of group revenues. The fourth instalment has sold 3.5m units and Tomb Raider V is due out in the autumn.

A heavier release schedule means, however, that in the coming year Tomb Raider should be down to about 20% of total revenues.

New titles on the stocks include versions of the movies Chicken Run and 102 Dalmatians, hit TV show Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and the Olympics.

An 80% increase in titles from the company in the coming year could only be expected to translate into a 10-15% increase in revenues, Eidos said, a problem that reflected the state of the market place.

Eidos's troubles were compounded by the company's admission at the start of the year that delays in development of new titles had caused some to miss the lucrative Christmas period, a defect it claims has now been rectified.

"People are waiting for Eidos to start proving themselves - the profit warnings were partially the market and partially Eidos's own fault so the confidence in Eidos is still going to be low for a while," one media analyst said.

Advertising costs were also higher during the year at £25.2m against £20.7m in the previous 12 months, to contend with the weaker market, while research and development costs were up from £36.8m to £45m.

Revenues were 14% lower at £194.8m.

Mr McGarvey said the Tomb Raider franchise "remains a powerhouse" and shrugged off the regular headlines which suggest the Lara Croft character has seen better days.

Oscar-winning actress Angelina Jolie has been cast in the lead for the film version of the game which is expected to begin shooting this year.

"Anyone who scoffs at Tomb Raider doesn't really have a very good grasp of this business," Mr McGarvey said.

fields.headline: Face to face at last
fields.standfirst:
The Korean summit is just a beginning
Korea special report
fields.trailText: The sun smiled down on South Korean President Kim Dae-jung's "sunshine policy" yesterday as the reclusive leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-il, broke cover and showed up at the airport to greet him at the start of a ground-breaking, three-day summit in Pyongyang. The gesture of welcome was unexpectedly gracious, and was followed by much grinning and hand-holding during a ride into the capital aboard a vintage Lincoln Continental - an odd choice of car given North Korea's top billing on America's list of "rogue states". But then almost everything about North Korea is worryingly odd, a principal reason why Seoul's Mr Kim is so anxious to engage the mystery man behind the personality cult.
fields.body:
The sun smiled down on South Korean President Kim Dae-jung's "sunshine policy" yesterday as the reclusive leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-il, broke cover and showed up at the airport to greet him at the start of a ground-breaking, three-day summit in Pyongyang. The gesture of welcome was unexpectedly gracious, and was followed by much grinning and hand-holding during a ride into the capital aboard a vintage Lincoln Continental - an odd choice of car given North Korea's top billing on America's list of "rogue states". But then almost everything about North Korea is worryingly odd, a principal reason why Seoul's Mr Kim is so anxious to engage the mystery man behind the personality cult.

This first-step summit, unprecedented since the peninsula divided along cold war lines in 1948, is about building trust, reuniting families, opening communication links, enhancing trade, and increasing economic and food aid for the North. What it is not about is more problematic. This subliminal agenda includes North Korea's nuclear programme, which it has still not submitted fully to international inspections; its missile-building, which frightens not only neighbours like Japan but also the US (which has used it in part to justify its proposed, destabilising $60bn national anti-missile system); the US military bases in the South; and reunification which, while nobody's official policy, is the ultimate, logical outcome of a successful rapprochement. China and Russia also have a strong interest in Korean stability. Vladimir Putin will next month become the first Russian leader to visit Pyongyang. He will doubtless use the occasion to sow more doubts about Washington's star wars fantasies. But all that is for the future. The mere fact the two leaders have finally met face to face is a hopeful start. As South Korea's Mr Kim said sunnily: "We will not be able to resolve all at once the bitterness that has accumulated over the past half century. But well begun is half done."

fields.headline: A rural distraction
fields.standfirst:
The foxes' fate is a stunning sideshow
The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: In the wider scheme of things - childhood poverty, school under-achievement, waiting lists, let alone jobs, technological risk and the survival of the planet - the fate of the fox is a stunning sideshow. The proverbial visitor from Mars would be nonplussed. How many parliamentary hours stand to be consumed; how much political energy dissipated? This is time that might have been spent making a difference to the life chances of the town-dwellers for whom blood sports are an abstraction, however repugnant. The government now faces revolt in the Lords and demos on the streets, litigation, even the West Lothian chestnut (why should Scottish MPs at Westminster determine whether the fox should be chased north to Kershopefoot but English MPs have no say whether it is pursued on to Newcastleton).
fields.body:
In the wider scheme of things - childhood poverty, school under-achievement, waiting lists, let alone jobs, technological risk and the survival of the planet - the fate of the fox is a stunning sideshow. The proverbial visitor from Mars would be nonplussed. How many parliamentary hours stand to be consumed; how much political energy dissipated? This is time that might have been spent making a difference to the life chances of the town-dwellers for whom blood sports are an abstraction, however repugnant. The government now faces revolt in the Lords and demos on the streets, litigation, even the West Lothian chestnut (why should Scottish MPs at Westminster determine whether the fox should be chased north to Kershopefoot but English MPs have no say whether it is pursued on to Newcastleton).

Perhaps the government had no choice. Lord Burns's study was a way of buying time. His moderate estimates of rural job losses have only served to reinforce the belief that the time left before the general election must be used for foxes. Jack Straw is a juggler. Here he proffers an illiberal ball. Behind his back he keeps ready an object much more attractive to those of us who keep on, against the evidence, expecting a Labour government to favour freedom and civility in Home Office affairs. On fox-hunting he is offering a sop to the rumbling backbenches - it is not often they call him a hero. Someone must have calculated how over coming months Labour could turn the excesses of the countryside lobby to advantage. The hedgers and ditchers who make up the still extravagant Tory numbers in the Lords (themselves overstating fox-hunting's importance) will disrupt the public business. Labour will label them enemies of progress, forcing William Hague to back them or sack them.

But the public at large may be left puzzled. What does fox-hunting say about the priorities of the government. It exposes inconsistency. Once the Countryside Alliance had the government mobilising Michael Meacher and Bernard Donoughue, wellies on feet and straw in their teeth. Now, it seems, ministers want a pitched battle. But previous backsliding might be forgiven if, or how, the government could offer some story about its motives in giving this issue such salience at this stage in its life. Where does hunting fit into the rubric of Blairism? Opposition to hunting could, conceivably, be seen as an aspect of much-needed rural modernisation and diversification. The farmers of England and Wales, struggling to recover their reputation, have just launched a new branding scheme, emphasising the quality and safety of the food they produce. Simultaneously to come across as gory brush-brandishers does not quite fit. The government might seek to marry abolition with a package of better services for people who live in rural areas, more diverse employment and, yes, more and better housing. The rejection of John Prescott's housing scheme by the Tories of the south-east has nothing to do with "countryside" and a lot to do with amenity values in the suburbs and affluent towns.

But so far fox-hunting has not been made to fit. It looks like an expedient, another gesture by a government blown hither and yon by the winds of opinion and the compass bearings of election tacticians. Making precious time for a principled measure central to the Blairite "project" is one thing; careening across the political seas on a whim or for fear of backbench rumblings is something disreputably else.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: A fair assessment
fields.body:
Cornwall

Traffic by Chapel Amble grinds slowly towards the Royal Cornwall Show, past verges thick with meadow buttercups and skylarks singing above uncut grass. Small fields above the Camel estuary are packed with cars and people flock into the showground overlooked by St Breock's windmills. Cornish King beef, lamb and potatoes, farmhouse ice cream and cheeses, real sausages, strawberries and cream draw crowds into the food marquee. The flower tent is another favourite meeting place. Banks of sweet peas, ferns, bonsai, foil-backed waterfalls, orchids, topiary of leaping horse and deer as well as futuristic flower arrangements all compete for attention.

The essence of this pastoral county is on show in the cattle ring - continental breeds now more common than the native. Huge, beefy Charollais dwarf short-legged Dexters and dainty Jerseys, and the overall beef champion is Greenbank Osirus, a young Limousin bull. Chancellor's Rebecca and Priscilla, prize Belgian Blues, are rated as "excellent breed cows, very correct, clean-boned and well-balanced". Stewards in white coats and bowler hats keep order as immaculate beasts are led in for judging, tail tassels fluffy, attendants busy with curry combs, unlike some French shows where cattle are brought from the fields splattered with mud and dung. In the covered yard the morning's winners sport rosettes, watched over by owners' families. Glossy-flanked South Devons, Devon Ruby Reds with curly coats and white-faced Herefords lie placidly in deep straw. Adjoining large-uddered bony Friesians and Holsteins - today's nationwide milk machines - contrast with the solitary Longhorn in the rare breeds section, the type used by Robert Bakewell for his breeding programme in the 18th century. The sheep section still includes Devon and Cornwall Longwools and Grey-faced Dartmoors but there are also exotic Texels, Bleu du Maine, Roussin and Rouge de l'Ouest.

There is more rain in the night. Farmers were justified in missing the first day, having stayed home to harvest part of their silage crop.

fields.headline: No: 1655
fields.standfirst: JMW Turner
fields.trailText: JMW Turner
fields.body:
Full name: Joseph Mallord William Turner.

Status: Celebrated English watercolourist and oil painter; born 1775, died 1851.

Curious if not overly pertinent fact: He spent large parts of his life living in London pubs.

Typical work associated with Turner (1840s): Shifting gradations of light play subtly off the waves of a storm-filled sea, blending realism and sublimity in a masterpiece of proto-impressionist art.

Typical work associated with Turner (1990s): A messy bed covered in shabby pillows, urine-stained sheets, cigarette ends, soiled underwear and a pregnancy testing kit.

But that's not Turner! That's . . . Precisely: it's Tracey Emin, who last year failed to win the prize established by the Tate gallery in Turner's honour in 1984.

I've got a bad feeling about what's coming next. Yes indeed, art lovers: barely minutes after the row over the last one died away, the shortlist for the 2000 Turner prize, with a prize of £20,000, is to be announced today.

More elephant dung, cameras in washing machines and Buster Keaton remakes, I presume? Enough cynicism. The artists hotly tipped for this year's list prefer radically different kinds of work to Emin: cryptic messages in neon lights (Martin Creed); a video of a blind man reciting from the Bible in the London Underground (Mark Wallinger); and Bob Dylan lyrics written on walls (Fiona Banner).

No watercolourists or oil painters like the great man himself, then? Easy there! We musn't get too radical all at once, you know.

What's that whirring sound? That'll be Turner spinning in his grave. Or maybe it's an innovative new ambient sound sculpture from some budding conceptualist fresh out of art school.

Don't say: "I don't know much about art, but I know what I like."

Or: "I don't know much about art but, then again, maybe that's why I've been selected to judge this year's Turner Prize . . ."

fields.headline: Jobs for everyone
fields.standfirst: Conservatives espouse full employment
fields.trailText: It is not often that we have been able wholeheartedly to endorse Conservative economic policies in recent years, apart from a brief period when Kenneth Clarke was chancellor. But yesterday's espousal by shadow chancellor Michael Portillo of full employment as the goal of the next Conservative government must be unreservedly welcomed. It may look to some less like a U-turn than looping the loop - but that doesn't matter because it means that the Conservatives have emerged from the economic dark ages into the daylight. If anyone needs reminding of the distance that has been travelled, think back no further than to the remarks of Tory chancellor Norman Lamont that unemployment was a price well worth paying for lower inflation.
fields.body:
It is not often that we have been able wholeheartedly to endorse Conservative economic policies in recent years, apart from a brief period when Kenneth Clarke was chancellor. But yesterday's espousal by shadow chancellor Michael Portillo of full employment as the goal of the next Conservative government must be unreservedly welcomed. It may look to some less like a U-turn than looping the loop - but that doesn't matter because it means that the Conservatives have emerged from the economic dark ages into the daylight. If anyone needs reminding of the distance that has been travelled, think back no further than to the remarks of Tory chancellor Norman Lamont that unemployment was a price well worth paying for lower inflation.

During Mrs Thatcher's administration, unemployment climbed to 3.4m (in 1986). At both ends of that decade the country suffered unnecessarily steep recessions - shared by no other industrialised countries - as the government presided over high unemployment to subdue the unions and sweat inflation out of the system. Yesterday is probably the nearest the Conservatives will ever come to apologising for the excesses of those years. Gordon Brown also has a goal of full employment but he is too canny a politician to put a percentage figure on what he means. Mr Portillo also avoids percentages but he actually seems to have a lower figure in his mind because he comes close to thinking that it is possible to eliminate all unemployment. He said: "There are as many job vacancies in this country as there are people unemployed. The reasons why those people and those jobs are not matching up are in the government's sphere of action, if not in the government's gift". Wow. Can anyone imagine Mrs Thatcher blaming unemployment on the government?

In practice it is not possible to achieve full employment (except in certain booming regions) because lots of people are always in transition between jobs or unable to work . But there is no reason why very low unemployment isn't achieveable. Unemployment during the 1950s and 1960s was regularly below 500,000. It is quite possible that the huge rise in oil and commodity prices in the 70s and 80s triggered an exceptional period of inflation from which we are only now emerging. If this is true then low unemployment may occur whether it is part of Conservative policy or not.
