Gordon Brown also has a goal of full employment but he is too canny a politician to put a percentage figure on what he means. Mr Portillo also avoids percentages but he actually seems to have a lower figure in his mind because he comes close to thinking that it is possible to eliminate all unemployment. He said: "There are as many job vacancies in this country as there are people unemployed. The reasons why those people and those jobs are not matching up are in the government's sphere of action, if not in the government's gift". Wow. Can anyone imagine Mrs Thatcher blaming unemployment on the government? In practice it is not possible to achieve full employment (except in certain booming regions) because lots of people are always in transition between jobs or unable to work . But there is no reason why very low unemployment isn't achieveable. Unemployment during the 1950s and 1960s was regularly below 500,000. It is quite possible that the huge rise in oil and commodity prices in the 70s and 80s triggered an exceptional period of inflation from which we are only now emerging. If this is true then low unemployment may occur whether it is part of Conservative policy or not.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Richard Adams
fields.body:
Once upon a time it was Peter Mandelson who used to snarl at journalists and Labour party members who displeased him. But after the unfortunate home loans business Mandy won his way back into the hearts of the nation by adopting Bobby, the golden retriever that he uses to break the ice at delicate Northern Ireland peace negotiations ("Ooooh bad Bobby, don't sniff Dr Paisley there!"). But it seems that O'Mandy has used the dog trick once too often. During a tense visit yesterday to an RUC station in Ballymena, Co Antrim, Mandy bent down to stroke a drugs sniffer dog called Sky, and the black labrador bitch snarled back at him. "She can be a wee bit cross if you get too close and I think the secretary of state found that out when she bared her teeth at him," according to Inspector Tom Crawford. Oh dear. Mandy should remember that these are working dogs, and are not there to be played with.

Speaking of dogs: gratuitously offensive racial stereotypes, part 857. Travelling to China this week, David Blunkett left Lucy behind because of our quarantine laws, not "to protect her from predatory Chinese chefs", according to the Times diary. Oh ha ha.

Still on dogs, what a wonderful performance by Lord Bassam of Brighton, the Home Office minister who ummed and ah'ed his presentation of the government's hunting statement in the Lords on Monday. It brought back memories of his lordship's extraordinary performance at a fringe meeting during the last Labour party conference. When asked about the effects of closing rural magistrates' courts, his lordship launched into a tirade about how he "didn't care" if criminals suffered by having to travel further. It was left to Keith Vaz (of all people) to point out that closures would hurt lots of other people, including victims, witnesses, magistrates and court workers.

To give the England football team a chance to salvage something from the Euro 2000 tournament, my colleague Esther Galan rang the Donkey Sanctuary in Sidmouth, Devon, and said she knew of a broken down old donkey called Alan that was well past his best but was still being cruelly made to gallop up and down foreign paddocks. Nessie at the sanctuary said that in urgent cases they could collect the donkey within seven days. "Of course there are some instances where we drop everything to go and help a donkey in distress," said Nessie. Was this one of those cases? Yes, after watching Alan Shearer's performance against Portugal, I rather think it is.

Mr Tony Blair's performance at the Women's Institute last week leaves a warm glow when one reads the marshmallow "interview" he did for July's Prima magazine, well before his humiliation. You obviously like working with women, the interviewer says. "I think women can be more steady in certain situations, and a lot stronger. I also believe mature women bring experience, common sense and integrity," said Mr Tony, with smarm mode set to full. Older women "are a major resource that we waste sometimes, but they're the ones with that little bit of savvy". Enough to see through you, mate.

The Washington Post holds an invitational contest called Merge-Matic Books, where readers are asked to combine the works of two famous authors, and write a brief description. One of the winners of this year's competition was Green Eggs and Hamlet, a stunning combination of Shakespeare and Dr Seuss: "Would you kill him in his bed? Thrust a dagger through his head? I would not, could not, kill the King. I could not do that evil thing. I would not wed this girl, you see. Now get her to a nunnery." Surely Diary readers can come up with something just as good? Entries to the usual address, and fame and a bottle of something tasty could soon be yours.

fields.headline: Reality remixed
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Romney on Asylum

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney on Asylum
fields.body:
We get only a brief initial flash of lucidity with Asylum, which screens next week on Channel 4: the opening announcement that we're about to see real people and real places, but in a fictional context. After that we're on our own. Asylum's subject, conceivably, is "the grand curvature of everything", to choose a formula at random from co-director Iain Sinclair. That sounds like a phrase you might use at a pitching meeting with Channel 4, just before being politely shown the door. The marvel is that Sinclair and his collaborator, Chris Petit, weren't shown the door, that Asylum did get made. But it's a desperate, last-chance, skin-of-their-teeth enterprise: hence the ominous subtitle, The Final Commission.

Asylum is the latest work from two specialists in the borderline and the cultivatedly shady. Sinclair, poet, novelist and cultural entrepreneur, has made a career of mapping the occult myths and paranoias of the urban landscape, while Petit, former critic, born-again thriller writer and briefly an art-house auteur, has spent several years dismantling his own career. His first film was Radio On (1979), a relatively mainstream attempt to invent the British road movie, but he eventually decided that British roads were too short and linear: hence his recent Radio On (Remix), which scrambled the original's straight track into a maddening digital knot.

Sinclair and Petit last collaborated on The Falconer, a scabrous hybrid (part essay, part thriller, part scandal sheet) built around British 60s film-maker Peter Whitehead. Asylum again turns real people into fictional figures: the cast includes novelist Michael Moorcock, once Notting Hill's resident apocalyptic visionary, who now lives in Texas, thriller writer James Sallis, the late American poet Ed Dorn, and mythologist Marina Warner. Petit himself figures as a shadowy presence, a doomed film-maker named Kaporal; Sinclair is a spymaster lurking in a bookshop basement. The ostensible heroine, Emma Matthews, is not only a real person, but the film's editor and sound recordist.

Scraps of "plot" (a lysergic salad of Le Carré, Ballard and Burroughs) propose that, in a future "year zero + 14", a search of files at "Channel 40" unearths the remains of a TV project called The Perimeter Fence, undertaken before the world virus that wiped out all cultural history. One Françoise Lacroix (heroine of The Falconer, and another real-life member of the Petit-Sinclair circle) has been found dead; Matthews starts collecting sonic clues to her fate - aeroplane noise, rattling supermarket trolleys, the rantings of cultural gurus.

But Asylum is interested less in story than in the pretence of story - plot is a pretext for a strange form that's at once scrapbook, travelogue, fanzine essay and cloak-and-dagger role-playing game. Petit and Sinclair drag in people who fascinate them because of their personal history or cultural resonance, or because, like Ed Dorn, they have a certain arresting Ancient Mariner gleam in their eye. Their words and looks are sampled and scrambled, along with a mass of other visual or sonic "evidence" and atmospherics. Different textures flicker by as the digital and Super-8 footage is treated or disintegrated, or sometimes fed through digital 3D sculptures by artist Dave McKean. Words, sounds and pictures become part of the same continual remix.

But Asylum isn't just a stew of electronic obfuscation - there's something old-fashioned, even nostalgic beneath it. Petit and Sinclair use technology in as dazzlingly terroristic a fashion as any culture-jamming kids. Yet Asylum is not made by young men, but by grizzled combatants who have seen a few films, handled a few crumbling Penguin paperbacks in their day, and are willing to play the crazy, teeth-grinding ancients. In his guise as Kaporal, Petit exudes dissolute melancholy, speaking in the suavely weary tones of a man who has been round the block and seen the block gradually demolished. Meanwhile, wayward old coots Moorcock and Dorn figure as voices from a lost past, but also as prophets of a more imaginative, engaged future.

Asylum's serious proposition is to remind us of a forgotten avant-garde project, an amorphous utopia in which everything explodes into a chaos beyond recognisable genre - in this case, a chaos that evades the grids and menus of TV arts commissioning. Asylum is haunted by the improbability that anyone in British TV would ever fund something like this again, although the film's sense of its own desperado heroism would be confounded if arts bosses suddenly decided that this was just the sort of stuff they wanted to commission for late nights. In reality, Asylum may well be the last broadcast from this parallel universe that Sinclair and Petit have pieced together. The word "asylum", of course, suggests both sanctuary and imprisonment - you may feel that this is exactly where you want to be at 11.50 of a weekday evening, or you may find yourself screaming to be let out. Either way, you'd be mad to miss it.

Asylum is on Channel 4 on June 22 at 11.50pm.

webTitle: He used to fight the Palestinians. Now he plays with them

fields.headline: He used to fight the Palestinians. Now he plays with them
fields.standfirst: John Fordham  meets saxophonist Gilad Atzmon
fields.trailText: John Fordham meets saxophonist Gilad Atzmon
fields.body:
'Some people I work with say they think I'm a power freak," says Gilad Atzmon. "They don't realise I suffer from massive anxieties. I'm a very, very, very worried person."

A first meeting with Atzmon suggests something quite different. He is rugged, striking, opinionated, and increasingly revered for the intensity and passion of his saxophone and clarinet playing. In his sunny house in Kilburn, north London, with its bulging boxes of CDs (which testify to an old enthusiasm for DIY distribution), scattered musical instruments, sheet music, children's toys and all the paraphernalia of a freewheeling, positive life, it looks as if Atzmon's worries could be worse.

His work as a pop producer - which has helped bring him something like prosperity as jazz players go - has not been his only alternative to playing. An academic career beckoned, but he was distracted from an M Phil in aesthetics by the hyperactive pleasures of delivering firebreathing bop sax to the audiences at the Red Lion in Kilburn High Road. He also briefly attended film school in Israel in his 20s, when he was driven by the desire to make a film about his early experiences in the Israeli army.

As well as learning to play swing in a military band, as a soldier he developed a fervent anti-Zionism. Tomorrow his Orient House Ensemble, a world music band of jazzy intensity mixed with klezmer, east European folk forms and at times an almost ambient stillness, plays at the London International Jewish Music Festival with Palestinian oud virtuoso Adel Salameh as a guest. The following evening he's in the Blockheads for the Ian Dury memorial gig in Brixton. Atzmon toured with the Blockheads during Dury's last months, and calls it the nearest thing to a musical family he's ever been in.

But though Atzmon has built a reputation and a following in the five years since he came to the UK, he is a career worrier, living a life that ricochets between contradictions. He is loyal to old playing partners (to a point that has hampered his development, some have suggested) and says he needs "to feel comfortable", yet dislikes the cosy insularity of the jazz scene. He wants artists to resist fashions and the materialism of a commodity culture, but distrusts public arts funding. His music has a force and conviction that have made it a blast of fresh air in the UK, yet the urge to improve obsesses him.

"Though I've made a lot of friends here, there are things that make it hard for artists. For one, everything has to be put into boxes - hip hop, bebop, world music, pop. It's very conservative, very restrictive, and it's not the way most musicians think.

"For another, it's very difficult to get hard criticism. I'm an ex-soldier and I think like a soldier. I'm against what the Israeli army has stood for big-time, but I think the fact that I was in the army turned me into a clever man. You understand once you're in the army that the world is stupid. But there is a good side to it - you're under severe criticism all the time. Tough. It has made me want my music to be strong and enthusiastic. I want my musicians to look down on me when I don't perform well."

But the Israeli army's purposes in Palestine eventually filled Atzmon with the desire to escape. "I got to a point where I was ready to shoot my leg. But I'd had a serious injury before I joined, and it turned out to be a disability I could use to lower my profile and get into the band instead. It was a kind of swing band, and it was my music school.

"In the band we all felt the same - we wanted to fuck the army. It was often very depressing and often very funny. Our conductor died in a car accident, so they put the bus driver in to run the band. He had a mental breakdown trying to do it, so they got this poor woman who was a kind of sex slave for some of the senior officers to be our commander because they had to keep her in the army to keep her from talking. We'd go to a gig, 15 of us, and people would jump out of the bus on the way, so by the time we got there there would be only two people left."

Atzmon called his new quartet Orient House after the beleaguered Palestinian headquarters in Jerusalem. The name indicates a shift away from the mainstream bebop he has principally played in London, toward the multi-cultural music he had lacked the confidence to showcase. The band's drummer, Asaf Sirkis, shares Atzmon's background, "which got me back into playing Jewish and Arabic and Balkan music, and I decided I wanted to try this mixture again. Then when the two British members (pianist Frank Harrison and bassist Oli Hayhurst) joined and seemed to hear what we were doing so easily, it just took off. I was amazed.

"My only instruction to Frank Harrison, apart from 'Play whatever you feel like', was 'When I play, don't play if you don't have to'. Jazz is a music - and I'm one of the people who can be blamed for this - that's very intense. Too many notes. And music can be very soulful by being very empty. What we play now is often empty but it still talks. It's sometimes important to listen rather than play."

Atzmon certainly listened closely to Ian Dury during the singer's last months with the Blockheads. Though the energy of the band is still there, Atzmon knows it won't be the same without Dury. "Because I'd been a paramedic in the army, he used to show me how they were treating him. He'd talk about it a lot, but he didn't complain. And though he was getting much weaker when he was working two weeks or so before he died, he would still go for it. He was still that giant figure when he was on stage.

"That's the way he struck me - somebody who wasn't a great singer who was a great singer, you know what I mean? Big voice, big presence, big influence. Like Louis Armstrong. That's the way I thought of him. Those people make music come alive. And that's what I do this for."

The Orient House Ensemble plays the Union Chapel, London N1 (020-7960 4242), tomorrow. Gilad Atzmon performs with the Blockheads at Brixton Academy, London SW9 (020-7771 2000), on Friday.

fields.headline: What a glorious screening
fields.standfirst: Plagued by creaky sets? Technology has the answer, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Plagued by creaky sets? Technology has the answer, says Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
At the start of the 21st century, theatre is at last beginning to face up to new technology. The past month alone has produced Blast Theory's Desert Storm, a performance/installation piece on the Gulf war in which audience members are active participants inside a computer game; Fuzzy Logic, a play written entirely on the web; the multimedia spectacle of Laurie Anderson's Moby Dick, and Ulysses's journey re-created via images, light and the interactive movements of a robot and a performer in Marcel Li Antunez Roca's digital performance Afasia.

Later this month multimedia moves into the mainstream with the arrival at the National Theatre of Jude Kelly's exuberant version of the MGM classic Singing in the Rain. This light-hearted, all-singing, all-dancing story about the birth of a technology that was to revolutionise movie-making in the 20s (the ability to put sound on film) has been enhanced with modern multimedia technology that embraces graphics, animation and film. Kelly has created a many-layered performance in which the screen and live action comment upon each other, often to comic effect. The result is an evening that snakes backwards and forwards on itself; the 50s musical about the birth of the talkies in 20s Hollywood also appears very sharp, ironic and modern.

Apart from its swagger and expertise, there is nothing particularly new about the way that Singing in the Rain uses multi-media. Experimental theatre group Forkbeard Fantasy has spent 20 years melding film and live action in which actors interact not just with each other but also with projected images on a screen. Station House Opera's disturbing Roadmetal Sweetbread presents two lovers whose Miss Julie style power relationship is given a vicious new twist by the constant presence of their on-screen alter-egos.

What marks out Singing in the Rain, Forkbeard Fantasy and Station House Opera's work is that they never subjugate the live component to the filmed. The exhilaration is in the head-on smash between one form and another, which creates not a hybrid but something entirely new.

What is interesting is that Singing in the Rain emerged not from the more experimental fringes of theatre, but from West Yorkshire Playhouse, a regional theatre often perceived as a bastion of conservatism. Perhaps we should also take heart from the fact that 50 miles away in staid Scarborough you can catch Alan Acykbourn's new comedy Virtual Reality, which takes a jaundiced, but not Luddite, look at our hi-tech world where everyone is plugged in but nobody communicates any more.

It was the much-vaunted scene of cyber-sex in Patrick Marber's Closer at the National in 1997 that heralded the internet as a new force in drama. The entirely silent scene in which two men - one posing as a woman - talk dirty on the net, their communications projected on to the back wall, hinted that the virtual world, with its possibilities of disguised identities and lies, might provide a fertile ground for drama.

It has not happened yet. The net may have made it into Shakespeare - Lindsay Posner's production of The Taming of the Shrew featured a Christopher Sly slumped in front of a computer, and ATC's multimedia version of the Tempest hinted at a Prospero engaged on both an imaginative and cyber journey - but playwrights seem reluctant to explore the increasing dominance in our culture of new technologies. The gulf between those perceived as techies and those who see themselves as creative seems to be as wide as ever.

It seems likely that for the foreseeable future the net's main contribution to theatre will be as a tool for creating work. In 1997 the seven-hour-long, site-specific show Bytes of Bryant Park was created by some of the 50,000 people who visited the Webbed Feats website.

There are of course wider ten sions between live performance and cyberspace, theatre and new technologies. If theatre began the 20th century as the dominant art form and the major source of entertainment for most people, it begins the 21st in a much less happy position. Some claim that the new digital technologies will sound the death knell for theatre.

This seems as absurd as the idea that the replacement of candlelight with gaslight would destroy all the magic of the stage. After all, old technologies were once new technologies. There was a time when the stage revolve was considered a thing of wonder.

Jude Kelly agrees that theatre can look dowdy by comparison with "sexy" media such as film and the visual arts, but points out that theatre has always embraced technology to some degree, whether it's the trap door, flying apparatus or computer- ised lighting systems. She believes that while theatre shouldn't try to emulate film, directors need to be more daring in their use of technology. "Theatre audiences adapt very quickly and there is no reason why they shouldn't adapt to digital technology." Kelly is preparing a project with Julian Crouch that involves live actors and cartoon characters. "The technology is there waiting for ideas. We shouldn't be asking, 'What can the technology do?' but rather, 'What can I do with it?' "

The question needs to be addressed. In a world where interactive is the buzz word, theatre seems to have a huge advantage over its competitors, since it is a medium that creates a community out of isolated individuals and blurs the boundaries between spectator and participant. Harnessed to technology, theatre could perhaps once more take centre stage in our culture. The moment is here; the question is whether theatre has the courage to seize it.

fields.headline: A piece of her heart
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Last night's TV: Reputations/Can You Live Without Make-up?
fields.body:
By the time she'd reached her senior year in high school, Janis Joplin already had a number of nicknames, among them "pig", "whore" and "nigger-lover". This alone should have made it apparent to any of her contemporaries in Port Arthur, Texas, that she was destined for greatness, and when the moment came to slip away to California, there was little doubt that her lungs would take her far.

However far she went, though, she could never escape from the shame of those early years, nor from the near-death experience of her first California sojourn, when intravenous amphetamine-use reduced her to skeletal thinness and sent her running home to her horrified parents. These traumas were presented as Joplin's motivating force in Christopher Morris's Reputations profile (BBC2), which revis ited the highlights of the singer's life, with added insight from family, friends and lovers. There's little left to discover among the ruins of that great talent, and certainly some of the footage was over-familiar. That said, it's hard to tire of her 1967 performance of Ball And Chain at the Monterey Festival, and there was a telling footnote to that career-making moment. Joplin, apparently, had already performed one set, dressed in her usual rags with chicken-bone accessories. When the cameras started rolling, however, she whipped on that strange gold lamé skirt-trouser combo and did it all over again. Joplin knew that Monterey could be the turning point, and she didn't want to go down in history dressed like a tramp.

Her taste in lounge wear wasn't the only thing that set Joplin apart from her hippy peers. While all around her were dropping acid, she preferred a quart of Southern Comfort. While others were content to address themselves to their equally stoned west-coast pals, Joplin craved broader acclaim and longed to go professional - to sell out. Dylan's manager Albert Grossman helped her do just that, and the guilt of leaving behind her flower-child roots added to an already-considerable burden of misery.

Happily for the Joplin fans in the audience, Morris's film was affectionate rather than revisionist. There was no suggestion that Joplin was anything other than a superstar, a force of nature and, in her own muddled way, a trail-blazer for a generation of women. She also came across a sharp cookie, at least in earlier interviews before the Judy Garland mannerisms came to dominate her persona. By 1969, however, she'd mutated completely into the character she called "Pearl", a hard-drinkin' mamma with half a dozen feather boas pinned into her hair. A defiant trip home to Port Arthur to freak out her classmates at a high school reunion ended in disaster, Joplin caught in the hostile glare of local news coverage, groping for answers and falling to pieces in front of the very people she wanted to knock dead. Sadly, it was Janis who was knocked dead by the experience. Increasingly dependent on heroin, she repaired to LA, cut one more great album and joined Jimi Hendrix and Brian Jones in death.

Janis Joplin got her security from audience adoration, from the bottle and the needle. Newcastle businesswoman Alison Edgar gets hers in little pots and tubes, and went into voluntary cold turkey for Channel 4's Can You Live Without Make-up? The answer was a pretty resounding no. Emerging from her cosmetic mask looking 10 years younger, Edgar struggled to keep it together at work, and went completely to pieces during a night on the town. Newcastle, we were told, is a city that sets great store by personal appearance - little wonder, then, that even a successful woman like Edgar feels the need to spend £5,000 a year on make-up. Her friends weren't much help. "The more make-up the better", said one, a woman who certainly looked as if she'd followed her own creed for a lifetime. The girl at the Versace counter in Fenwick's had applied so much maquillage to her small face that there was barely any room left for features. "Aubergine - it's the new black!" she chirped, as Edgar slavered over the testers like an addict. One au naturel week completed, she returned to her old ways, but no longer felt the need to don full war-paint in order to buy a newspaper. In subsequent weeks, more men have shown an interest in her toned-down look, although it seems unlikely that George Clooney, beside whose picture Edgar sleeps, will ever notice the difference.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
A vintage Hollywood kick-off to thrill and entertain this week, with popular Canadian comic Mike Myers (pictured) being sued to the hilt by his erstwhile buddies at Universal Studios for abandoning their movie Dieter, based on an old skit of his from Saturday Night Live concerning an inept German talk-show host. With Myers recently announcing his decision to exit the project, claiming the script was "unworkable", Universal wasted little time in slapping the sometime Austin Powers with a $5 million suit for damages and - some hope - banning him from film work for as long as Dieter would have been in production.

"Mike Myers does not do any movies until he approves a script", stormed his lawyer Martin Singer, before accusing Universal of attempting to "bully" his client. Threatening to countersue his former paymasters, Myers then weighed in himself, announcing that "I cannot in good conscience cheat moviegoers who pay their hard-earned money to see my work by making a movie with an unacceptable script." Didn't stop The Spy That Shagged Me, but that's another story.

Meanwhile, Jan-Michael Vincent , famously boisterous onetime star of Airwolf, is back in trouble after a prosecutor in Laguna Niguel, California filed notice of his latest violation of probation. Sadly, the hapless Vincent - already on probation for three public drunkenness arrests back last March - was nabbed by a cop for behaving in a disorientated manner in a park in Santa Monica; according to Deputy DA Michael Hernandez, the actor had around three times the legal blood-alcohol level at the time, being discovered shouting and rolling around in the grass. Due in court last Friday, Vincent failed to show - sending his lawyer Sharon Morris instead - but is due for a return engagement in July, with Hernandez saying he wants a jail term of at least six months for his unfortunate nemesis...

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Frontiers/Seven Days That Rocked The World
fields.body:
Studies of people living with high levels of natural radiation have found no evidence that they are more prone to cancer than the rest of us. Inevitably, as Peter Evans reports in Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4), this has brought a fierce reaction from scientists who argue that there can be no safe level of radiation. With users wondering if their mobile phones are secretly killing them, pressure is mounting for someone to provide a reliable answer.

Stuart Maconie's history of Seven Days That Rocked The World (10.0pm, Radio 2) recalls one of the darker moments in the Rolling Stones' history, when they staged a free concert at the 1969 Altamont Festival in Cali fornia. Brian Jones's recent sacking and subsequent death had cast a general pall over the event. Then the Stones made the bizarre decision to give some Hell's Angels $500-worth of beer to act as security guards. The bikers interpreted that as a licence to kill.

fields.headline: Gold Fields cements $2bn global merger
fields.trailText: Plans for a $2bn merger to create the third biggest gold producer in the world were outlined yesterday by Gold Fields Ltd of South Africa and Franco-Nevada Mining of Canada.
fields.body:
Plans for a $2bn merger to create the third biggest gold producer in the world were outlined yesterday by Gold Fields Ltd of South Africa and Franco-Nevada Mining of Canada.

Gold Fields International, as the new group will be called, would embark on a series of further mergers and acquisitions as the gold sector restructures under the impact of falling prices.

GFI will be quoted on the Toronto exchange and have a secondary listing in New York, meaning five large South African companies have recently moved their listings abroad.

South Africa's powerful National Union of Mineworkers said it had been told employment prospects would be enhanced. But it is aware that 500,000 jobs have been lost in gold mining worldwide in the past five years.

Gold Fields Ltd is South Africa's second largest gold miner. The new company will aim to take a third of its revenues from there, with another third coming from North America. Chris Thompson, president designate of Gold Fields International, said parts of Africa and Australia were attractive areas for expansion. Platinum mining would also be an "easy fit".

GFI would have an output of 4.4m ounces a year, the third largest globally, and be the fourth largest miner, in terms of market capitalisation, at $3.7bn.

Mr Thompson described the deal, which he valued at $2bn, as a reverse takeover but warned it still required the approval of the South African finance ministry.

Gold Fields shareholders will receive 0.35 Franco-Nevada shares for each of their units, with Franco-Nevada issuing 159m common shares.

Franco-Nevada, the world's leading metals royalty company, said it needed to move into new areas where it could grow. Less than two weeks ago it denied speculation of a tie-up with Gold Fields.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What witches watch on TV
fields.trailText: What witches watch on TV
fields.body:
Bill: "People think being a witch is all that Bewitched stuff, but that's nothing like it. We don't wiggle our noses and a donkey appears or anything, although some of us have cats. I've got a broomstick I sweep up with too, hahaha. What do I watch? I like Jools Holland, I think he's great, actually. But I wish they had more characters on TV, it's very bland. Not everyone is as boring as Sid Owen... but Daniella Westbrook - I like her."

Carol: "Did Bill just say Daniella? I think she follows the laws of wicca, I really do. She's magicked her nose away because she didn't need it. I think we could get a witch on EastEnders. Their rituals of pub and argument are very stifling. They need some proper stuff. Then they might all stop complaining."

Therèse: "I'm not so sold on TV. I haven't had a set in the house for years and I don't miss it. I think it has a damaging influence, I really do. Turns the brain into mush. Do I remember seeing witches on TV? No. A couple of terrible films... oh, but I liked Rosemary's Baby. The Craft was awful, though."

David: "TV reminds me of Sunday afternoons with my old mum. Dad's Army, Songs Of Praise... depressing! I think TV's a pile of bollocks now. It makes my blood boil, really does. Richard And Judy, the symbol of married stability? Our icons? Give me a break!"

Jeena: "I've not seen TV since I was five and... I'd like to! I live in the country and would be interested to see what crap they're feeding people."

Sin Pattenden contacted witches through Mysteries of Covent Garden.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Eat Drink Man Woman/Bad Boy Bubby/Glory/Absence of Malice
fields.body:
Eat Drink Man Woman

(Ang Lee, 1994)

8pm, FilmFour

Succulent celebration of the spices of life - food and love - in this witty romantic comedy. It's set in his homeland of Taiwan and stars Sihung Lung as a widowed master chef and father of three unmarried daughters. As their romances begin to threaten his world, he continues to express his love via the wok. Watch, and drool.

Bad Boy Bubby

(Rolf de Heer, 1993)

10.15pm, FilmFour

In an age where cult has become a mainstream category, undiscovered gems are thin on the ground, but this Australian one-off has the credentials. Newcomer Nicholas Hope is our retarded hero, who's lived a one-room existence for 35 years as his mother's sex slave. The arrival of his long-lost father reveals that the outside world is not contaminated by poisonous gas after all. Then the fun begins.

Glory

(Edward Zwick, 1989)

11pm, Bravo

A powerfully accurate account of the first black regiment to fight in the American civil war, and the stirrings of black consciousness it aroused. It's a sombre, harrowing film that marches bravely against the racism on all sides. Matthew Broderick (pictured) plays the novice Union Colonel Shaw who leads the fighting 54th; Morgan Freeman and Oscar-winning Denzel Washington are among those called up. Cinematographer Freddie Francis also won an Oscar, mainly for the battle scenes: Gettysburg and Fort Wagner are stunning.

Absence of Malice

(Sydney Pollack, 1981)

3.30am, Carlton Cinema

Pollack's exploration of press freedom and responsibility has Sally Field as an unscrupulous Miami reporter all but ruining mobster's son Paul Newman when she wrongly implicates him in the disappearance of a union man. An absorbing drama that provides an interesting counterpoint to the scrupulous journalism of Pakula's All The President's Men, though the issues get a little clouded by the stars' emotional wrestling match.

Cinematographer Freddie Francis also won an Oscar, mainly for the battle scenes: Gettysburg and Fort Wagner are stunning. Absence of Malice (Sydney Pollack, 1981) 3.30am, Carlton Cinema Pollack's exploration of press freedom and responsibility has Sally Field as an unscrupulous Miami reporter all but ruining mobster's son Paul Newman when she wrongly implicates him in the disappearance of a union man. An absorbing drama that provides an interesting counterpoint to the scrupulous journalism of Pakula's All The President's Men, though the issues get a little clouded by the stars' emotional wrestling match.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A long-lens photograph of Prince William and Tiggy Legge-Bourke, page 15 of G2's royal issue, June 12, should not have been used. Although it was taken more than four years ago, in April 1996, its use is against the guidance on privacy now included in the PCC code to which the Guardian adheres. Apologies.
fields.body:
A long-lens photograph of Prince William and Tiggy Legge-Bourke, page 15 of G2's royal issue, June 12, should not have been used. Although it was taken more than four years ago, in April 1996, its use is against the guidance on privacy now included in the PCC code to which the Guardian adheres. Apologies.

Our correction, page 23, yesterday, stating that the US is not a member of the OSCE, the organisation for security and cooperation in Europe, was wrong. It is.

In a review of an exhibition, Warning Shots, at the Royal Armouries, Leeds (where it continues to September 3), page 4, Saturday Review, June 3, we described the catalogue as "overdesigned, mendacious and uncertain how to pitch itself". Mendacious was not an appropriate word and we withdraw it. We did not intend to imply that the catalogue or the exhibition itself had been compiled in anything other than complete good faith.

In a brief report of a test case brought by the disability rights commission, page 8, June 10, we incorrectly said the appeal court had ruled that Pravin Kapadia, an accountant, should not have been forced to retire from Lambeth council because of depression. The court, in fact, ruled that Mr Kapadia's depression meant he was disabled under the provisions of the Disability Discrimination Act 1995. Mr Kapadia now has to go back to an employment tribunal to get a ruling on whether he was discriminated against and therefore whether he was unfairly dismissed.

In a correction, page 21, June 9, we said that Malta achieved independence in 1974. In fact, Malta became independent on September 21, 1964. It became a republic in 1974.

In our list of RIBA award winners, page 5, yesterday, we mentioned the Orangery, Strumpshaw, Norfolk, but lost the credit for the architects, who were Deborah Saunt and David Hills. Apologies.

In an article A new angle on an old problem, Education, page 4, yesterday, we referred to a useful device for sailors, a "rubber angle indicator for visually impaired and wheelchair-bound people". That would be "rudder angle indicator".

On page 16 of G2's royal issue, June 12, we quoted the views of "Dickie Bird, ex-cricket commentator". Ex-umpire we should have said.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Some ethical suggestions to add to the manifesto

fields.headline: Some ethical suggestions to add to the manifesto
fields.trailText: Your call for Labour to strengthen the United Nations (Time for truly ethical policies, June 12) is welcome. Perhaps the most important step is to give the UN powers to hold the leaders of all international agencies accountable for their actions against the standards of the UN Charter, Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international agreements.
fields.body:
Your call for Labour to strengthen the United Nations (Time for truly ethical policies, June 12) is welcome. Perhaps the most important step is to give the UN powers to hold the leaders of all international agencies accountable for their actions against the standards of the UN Charter, Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international agreements.

Until the world's most powerful rulers are answerable to all the world's people, decisions will always be made in the interests of powerful minorities. Millions suffer from war, abuse of human rights and lack of economic opportunities. They have no say in the UN security council, G8, the Bank of International Settlements, the Paris Club, World Bank, IMF and other exclusive institutions which decide global priorities, including debt, trade, aid and arms control.

Charter 99's call for accountability and democratic reform of international decision-making now has supporters in over 100 countries and 30 parliaments. Labour's manifesto should make a firm commitment to work for a strong, democratically accountable system of global governance under international law, centred on the UN. The UN summit in September is an opportunity for the government to start the transformation.

Titus Alexander
Chair, Charter 99 info@charter99.org

 Simon Tisdall and Richard Norton-Taylor suggest that the next Labour government should "unilaterally withdraw from the sanctions regime against Iraq if no solution to the current impasse is found within six months of the election".

UN sanctions on Iraq have caused the deaths of hundreds of thousands of children. Continuing with them for even one more day is far from ethical. That aside, UN member states are not allowed to "unilaterally withdraw" from UN resolutions; the only way to get around this would be for the British government to openly violate the sanctions.

Should Robin Cook be interested in pursuing this suggestion, voices in the wilderness uk - which has sent six sanctions-breaking delegations to Iraq since February 1998 - would be happy to offer him the benefit of its experience. If Mr Cook is concerned about how he might cope with incarceration (breaking sanctions carries a maximum five-year prison sentence), he could get his feet wet by joining the mass non-violent civil disobedience in Whitehall on August 7 to mark the tenth anniversary of the imposition of sanctions.

Andrea Needham
voices in the wilderness uk voices@viwuk.freeserve.co.uk

 You fail to mention a role on the most pressing global issue of all, the environment. Britain and Labour could have two related roles. The first is as an environmental advocate at international negotiations, the second is through action at home demonstrating how a greener economy can be a vibrant and competitive one.

Tony Juniper
Friends of the Earth

fields.trailText: I was amused by Charlotte Raven's rather churlish examination of our cover featuring Kylie Minogue, although it's quite unfair to infer that Kylie is a moose (G2, June 13). Or is it a horse she's meant to look like? Seeing as Ms (I assume she's a Ms) Raven is such an expert on female sexuality I wonder if she might be prepared to pose nude for GQ?
fields.body:

Or is it a horse she's meant to look like? Seeing as Ms (I assume she's a Ms) Raven is such an expert on female sexuality I wonder if she might be prepared to pose nude for GQ? Our Kylie issue seems to be selling extraordinarily well though I would imagine one with Ms Raven on the cover would sell even better.

Dylan Jones
Editor of GQ

 Raven says there's no word for the tawdry smut taking over popular culture. New Smut is perfect for our time: third-way, third-rate, intended not to offend, nor excite. We get the porn we deserve, as well as the politicians.

Graham Padden
New Duston, Northampton

 Roy Hattersley (Endpiece, June 12) writes of new Labour: "the tent is now so big that all we hear is canvas flapping in the wind". Surely he means flannel?

Paul Hartmann
Otley, West Yorkshire

 The Palace claims the Queen is entitled to a state pension (How much is she worth? G2, June 12). This presupposes that she has paid National Insurance contributions. Has she? Or do they mean that she is entitled to a reduced married woman's pension based on her husband's NICs?

Pamela Evans
London

 Yesterday's 30-minute crawl for the five-station journey from Waterloo to Canary Wharf allowed ample time to reflect (Jubilee Line celebrates after troubled start, June 13) that maybe some of the millions lavished on the architecture should have been spent providing a tube service that works.

Martin Booth
London

fields.headline: ...and other animals
fields.trailText: The call by more than 100 eminent scientists for less bureaucracy in conducting animal experiments in the UK is to be applauded.
fields.body:
The call by more than 100 eminent scientists for less bureaucracy in conducting animal experiments in the UK is to be applauded.

The UK-based pharmaceutical industry wants to continue developing new and better medicines to help ease people's suffering, pain and distress. The fact is that the research necessary to produce these medicines cannot be conducted without at least some study of the medicine's effects in animals.

But it is important that the message does not become distorted. I should like to emphasise that the industry is not seeking to reduce the regulation on the use of animals - just the amount of form filling and the time involved.

Researchers already use the smallest possible number of animals in their work and advances in biological knowledge and new technology have led to big reductions in the number of animals needed. Over the past 20 years, the number has fallen by nearly half.

But there is no getting around the fact that, at some stage, experimental medicines have to get from the laboratory bench into human patients. For at least the foreseeable future, this cannot be done without animals - unless society is prepared to accept very different standards of human safety.

Britain is a world leader in the care and welfare of animals in research. But delaying the research process through bureaucratic red tape benefits neither the development of modern medicines, the patients who so desperately need them, nor even the animals themselves.

Prof Trevor M Jones
Director general,
Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry

webTitle: Out of step on the bridge

fields.headline: Out of step on the bridge
fields.trailText: The Millennium Bridge problem (Millennium bug strikes again, June 13) has little to do with crowds walking in step: it is connected with what people do as they try to maintain balance if the surface on which they are walking starts to move, and is similar to what can happen if a number of people stand up at the same time in a small boat.
fields.body:
The Millennium Bridge problem (Millennium bug strikes again, June 13) has little to do with crowds walking in step: it is connected with what people do as they try to maintain balance if the surface on which they are walking starts to move, and is similar to what can happen if a number of people stand up at the same time in a small boat. It is possible in both cases that the movements that people make as they try to maintain their balance lead to an increase in whatever swaying is already present, so that the swaying goes on getting worse.

Is it true that "the bridge is never going to fall down", or at any rate get damaged, as a result of the swaying? That has been said about bridges before, and those responsible for this one need to understand, before making such pronouncements, that the problem involves more than engineering principles.

Prof Brian Josephson
Department of Physics
University of Cambridge
bdj10@cam.ac.uk

webTitle: A hue and cry over foxes

fields.headline: A hue and cry over foxes
fields.trailText: I read Leanda de Lisle's article with a mixture of contempt and amusement (Hunters at bay, June 13). Contempt that, as usual, the hunting fraternity have to knock down an Aunt Sally of their own creation in order to make a supposed valid point: "Every country person knows that a fox wounded with a bullet takes hours to die".
fields.body:
I read Leanda de Lisle's article with a mixture of contempt and amusement (Hunters at bay, June 13). Contempt that, as usual, the hunting fraternity have to knock down an Aunt Sally of their own creation in order to make a supposed valid point: "Every country person knows that a fox wounded with a bullet takes hours to die".

Really? Since when did a 12 bore shotgun fire single bullets? Apparently it is possible to shoot pheasant and partridge on the wing but difficult to kill an animal the size of a small dog with one shot.

My father killed a dog and vixen with rapid shots as they returned to their den, the vixen didn't have time to react before the second barrel hit her. Any competent shot could do the same. The story of two Welsh working-class hunters purports to indicate a large following. Again there is nothing to back this up - one swallow doesn't make a summer and two Welshmen don't make a hunting fraternity.

No, the real reason that hunters oppose shooting is that it is more effective and would make the hunt redundant, as was made clear to me when living in Norfolk. A group of farmers, tired of foxes killing their chickens, held a successful fox shoot - only to have the local master of foxhounds and magistrate descend upon them, warning them never to do it again, or else.

The majority of country people just want these arrogant people to go away and let them get on with their lives.

John F Bailey-Smith
Caterham, Surrey

 I have long considered Kate Hoey one of the more sensible members of the current administration (Anti hunt bill distracts from main issues, claims sports minister, June 12). It is no surprise that, when questioned by pollsters amid the suburban sprawl that this government has encouraged, most people are in favour of banning hunting. After all, a ban would cost them nothing.

However, Labour may find that illiberal legislation based on lazy responses to loaded questions does not translate into votes.

I voted Labour in the past precisely because I expected a Labour government to use parliamentary time to tackle the huge problems created by the Tories in areas such as health and education. I did not expect them to squander that time on irrelevancies such as hunting.

Come the next election, voters will be judging the government on what they have achieved in terms of waiting lists and class sizes and not on an improvement in the vulpine mortality rate.

David Joyce
Lancaster

 At last, a simple way to spare all the trauma to Leanda de Lisle and her ilk. The problem can be magicked away simply by amending the Dangerous Dogs Act to include foxhounds. Thus muzzled, they and their human friends can rush about the countryside to their hearts' (and the foxes') content. And there'll be hundreds of new jobs in making, fitting and repairing all those muzzles.

Dr Alan Maryon Davis
London

 If I had the luxury of deciding between death from the gun of a skilled marksman or being chewed alive from the bollocks up, I know which I'd choose.

Is the Guardian trying to be controversial, or just offend its faithful followers? I don't recall any similar articles extolling the virtues of, for example, the death in detention of a political prisoner as opposed to the terrors of being shot by a passing patrol car.

Louise Chase
Croydon

webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: null
fields.body:
I have been reminded this week of a much loved phrase from my student days. I'm a bit hazy about its genesis - I think it was a bungled translation from a German text by some hopeless literalist (or a deliberate humorist). The phrase was "meatly longings" and it still carries for me the nostalgic charge of past hilarity.

The week started out with a conference with some important folk from a chain of butcher's shops. They had sacked a manager after an investigation into his activities. Basically meat was going missing, in mysteriously modest but regular quantities. It was always good quality cuts - nice bits of steak mostly. The papers I had been sent indicated, disconcertingly, that the employers' surveillance cameras had not shown the manager taking the meat home. Instead, my written instructions suggested in strangled fashion that "he was making use of and disposing of the meat".

Me: "When you say he was making use of the meat, are you saying he was eating it in the shop?"

A bank of middle-aged men stared back in silent embarrassment. My solicitor intervened: "Perhaps it would help if you saw the video?"

I think I must not be getting enough sleep these days because it really didn't occur to me until I saw the fuzzy figure in the video removing a nice piece of steak from the cabinet and conveying it to his crotch that what we were dealing with in this case was vileness of the Portnoy's Complaint variety. If I'd twigged sooner, I could have saved the butchers at least some of their mortification. As it was, we were all so paralysed with horror that I didn't manage to get the video paused until the manager was halfway through pleasuring a free range chicken.

Now, you may think discovering someone having sexual relations with the produce was a pretty sound reason for sacking him. I find it hard to think of any tribunal, even the very mad ones, that would decide otherwise. So I was confused as to why the clients seemed determined to settle.

Me: "I cannot see that he has any realistic prospect of success."

Solicitor: "We are hoping he will accept £10,000."

Me: "But I don't think he's got any chance of winning."

Solicitor: "Ahem, well, there's the public relations aspect. "

Me: "?"

Solicitor: "Well, people might not realise that all the meat that was, umm, used subsequently made its way into the bin."

fields.headline: Poll positions
fields.standfirst:
Analysis: The longest honeymoon in history may be coming to an end, but will the Tories be able to capture disaffected swing voters?
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: What has spooked Labour? The polls may all show a narrowing of the gap between the two main parties but Labour would still win a new election. ICM Research confirms the trend. Our latest poll indicates a new election would produce a Labour victory albeit narrower than the last one, though not as narrow as suggested by the Mori poll published at the weekend. So if Labour looks set to walk it, why does it appear so worried?
fields.body:
What has spooked Labour? The polls may all show a narrowing of the gap between the two main parties but Labour would still win a new election. ICM Research confirms the trend. Our latest poll indicates a new election would produce a Labour victory albeit narrower than the last one, though not as narrow as suggested by the Mori poll published at the weekend. So if Labour looks set to walk it, why does it appear so worried?

Of course we all remember 1992, when we pollsters failed miserably to predict the Conservative victory. Most hardly improved on this performance in the 1997 election. What worries Labour strategists is that on both occasions, and in various elections in between, the polls tended to overstate their party's advantage.

Moreover, less than half the people saying how they would vote in an immediate election say they are certain that is how they will vote when the real election is held, in one to two year's time. The chart shows this. While 61% of Tory supporters are certain of their intentions, only 43% of Labour supporters are sure they will support the party whenever the election is held. The poor Liberal Democrats can only count on 28% of those who would vote for them tomorrow.

It is therefore dangerous to predict the outcome of the election on the basis of the polls this far away from the event and foolish to convert percentages into seats Labour might win. The real level of support each party might get in the next election is much less certain, and Labour knows it.

So what is the use of the polls? Imperfect though they may be, they do measure a trend over time. And that trend points to growing problems for Labour.

Further evidence of looming problems came in the most recent local elections. A post-election survey by ICM suggests that only 31% of 1997's Labour voters turned out for the party in the local elections, whereas 54% of 1997's Tory voters supported the party again. Furthermore, 43% of Labour's 1997 supporters stayed at home while only 29% of 1997's Tories failed to turn out. This follows the pattern of other recent elections: promised levels of support for Labour as expressed in the polls seem to melt away as the actual votes are counted.

One interpretation may be that Labour voters are not motivated to go and vote in elections they think the party is bound to win. As a result some say Labour would prefer that the polls suggest a much narrower advantage, to bring differences between it and the Conservatives into sharper relief and thereby encourage higher turnout among its supporters.

But a more plausible reason for Labour's concern is offered by the focus groups. The participants Labour is most concerned about are those who voted Labour in 1997 for the first time. These people are generally unlikely to be interested in politics and will pay attention to political news stories only if the issues look as though they will affect them directly. They are largely dependent on the NHS and state schools. They were swayed to vote New Labour by simple slogans and promises, not by any detailed understanding of exactly what Labour was offering. The slogans "time for a change", "education, education, education" and "48 hours to save the NHS" sum up why these people voted Labour.

Immediately following the general election such respondents expressed satisfaction with New Labour. Ex-Tories were pleasantly surprised, as they seemed to have elected another Conservative government with a tad more compassion. Others, keener on change, expressed hope for the future and were prepared to accept it would take some time to achieve. All had bought what they believed were Labour's election promises on health and education as indicated by the simple slogans. They believed Labour had undertaken not just to tinker with these services but to sort them out. Labour's present problems can be traced right back to pre-election promises swing voters heard, but in truth Labour could not deliver. Present-day problems are not a bolt from the blue but part of a gradual change in the attitudes of people initially willing to give Labour a try. Early hope and contentment has gradually given way to feelings of frustration and finally to disillusionment. Three years into its term, Labour appears to have failed on health and education and voters dismiss each new announcement of extra funds as hot air; the health service consultation exercise as yet another spin by the PR boys. Swing voters demand to see the results now of what Labour promised three years ago.

The longest honeymoon in polling history persisted because the Conservatives offered an even less attractive alternative. They appeared to be irrelevant, out of touch and fractious with only one policy on Europe supported by less than half the party. Until recently, disillusionment with Labour may have accounted for low turnout among its supporters, there being no attractive alternative. The problem for Labour is that William Hague seems to have hit his stride with policies that appeal directly to swing voters on issues that they feel have a direct impact on them: asylum seekers, law and order and pensions.

The real challenge for the Tories, if they are to close the gap on Labour even further, is to capture swing voters' imagination with new plans for health and education. Labour has a traditional advantage in these areas. The perception they have failed may yet damn them more completely.

Nick Sparrow is managing director of ICM Research nick.sparrow@icmresearch.co.uk

fields.headline: Tex Beneke
fields.standfirst: Bandleader who ensured the Glenn Miller sound swung on for 50 years:  From drawing room comedies to Hitchcock thrillers
fields.trailText: Bandleader who ensured the Glenn Miller sound swung on for 50 years:  From drawing room comedies to Hitchcock thrillers
fields.body:
Tex Beneke, who has died aged 86, was linked for nearly all his career with the music of the Glenn Miller Orchestra. As their main tenor saxophone soloist, virtually from the start of the band, he got the kind of exposure that led to him winning more than one poll on his instrument. He also sang on some of the band's biggest record hits and, after Miller's death, led a band devoted to the Miller sound that, in one form or another, lasted almost to the present day.

Born in Fort Worth, Texas, Gordon Beneke played in a local band led by Ben Young and eventually made an impression upon fellow-saxophonist Sam Donahue, then a sideman with Gene Krupa. Equally impressed, it was Krupa who recommended Beneke to Miller, who had just taken up bandleading.

Beneke joined Miller in 1938, a year before the band recorded Moonlight Serenade. If one regards Count Basie's as the ideal jazz orchestra in which to display improvisational skills, then Miller's, with its emphasis on arrangements and vocals, was the opposite. Beneke did record several solos, fluent enough on the more swinging items without displaying a particularly strong personality, but when things calmed down, as on the band's potted version of Rhapsody In Blue, he could rhapsodise effectively in the manner of Coleman Hawkins.

But his best-known legacy is his voice. Whatever his technical limitations, Beneke exuded an optimistic good cheer that appealed to Miller, who invariably featured him on novelty numbers, often alongside the Modernaires vocal group. The contrast between Beneke's guileless tones and the spot-on professionalism of the Modernaires made them huge sellers and attractive to this day. Among the biggest hits were Chattanooga Choo Choo, Kalamazoo, Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree and Juke Box Saturday Night.

As a key member of this most popular of all swing bands, Beneke also featured with Miller in the films Orchestra Wives and Sun Valley Serenade.

When Miller broke up the band in 1942 to join the Army Air Forces, Beneke toured with the Modernaires before enlisting and running a Navy Band. In 1946, the Glenn Miller estate authorised a band based on Miller's AAF ensemble, which combined the usual brass, reeds and rhythm sections with strings and a French horn player. The leadership was offered to drummer Ray McKinley, formerly with Miller in the AAF, who had started his own band. When he declined, Beneke took the job.

The public still went for the Miller sound, and the band was both in demand and sold plenty of records. By 1950, the string section had been dropped and Beneke, rebelling against the musical control exercised by the Miller estate, reached an agreement to break the official ties. In the long term, the break may seem largely symbolic: although traces of bebop crept into a few early scores, the band soon became identified exclusively with the "Miller sound" and stayed that way for the next 50 years.

However, Beneke was now free to stray from the absolute letter of the original arrangements. He also grew in confidence as a front man in a way that suited his film-star looks - a cross between Fred McMurray and Lee Marvin. Even his singing improved, and a splendid later version of Chattanooga, replete with train effects, had a lengthy whistling introduction by the leader.

Beneke eventually gave up the saxophone to concentrate on singing and leading the band.

 Gordon "Tex" Beneke, musician and bandleader, born February 12 1914; died May 30 2000

fields.headline: Bernard Tricot
fields.standfirst: De Gaulle's adviser who helped set Algeria free
fields.trailText: De Gaulle's adviser who helped set Algeria free
fields.body:
When General de Gaulle returned to power in 1958, he had two very close advisers from the Auvergne, Georges Pompidou and Bernard Tricot, who has died aged 79. Men from that province are often said to be distinguished by their ability to succeed in life, assisted by a certain amount of cunning. Pompidou had his fair share of the latter, but for Tricot, discretion, loyalty and clarity were the characteristics that he always brought to his duties as an adviser and as a collaborator.

He always saw his career as being that of an administrator. Born in Aurillac (Cantal), educated in Paris, where he studied law at the École de Droit and politics at the École Libre des Sciences Politiques, he quickly made his mark after the Liberation, becoming a member of the Conseil d'Etat and advising a number of ministers, including André Marie, who was prime minister for a short time in 1948.

But Tricot was preoccupied by the problem of France and its overseas possessions. With the coming to power of the socialist Pierre Mendès- France in 1954, he saw the opportunity of easing this problem, and was impressed by the new, energetic prime minister, who was ready to consider the problems of Tunisia and Morocco at the same time as he was making peace in Indo-China.

Tricot saw that France had to associate itself with the Tunisian nationalist party, to reassure the European population living in Tunisia and to prevent the French army from taking any independent action. He advised the minister responsible, and with Tunisian independence assured, he became director of the office of the French Resident in Tunis.

The disaster of the 1956 Suez campaign convinced him that neither France nor Britain should indulge in any further neo-colonial adventures; a point of view which affected his attitude towards the Algerian war that was growing in intensity.

Therefore when, in June 1958, the newly appointed secretary-general for Alger ian affairs, René Brouillet, invited him to be president of his private office, Tricot made his position clear. He put in writing his conviction that integration between Algeria and France was impossible, and that Algeria would become at least autonomous, and probably independent. This was a courageously honest attitude, de Gaulle having just made his triumphant "je vous ai compris" speech in Algiers and opinion being that the partisans of French Algeria had won a victory.

Tricot's position was tacitly accepted, but he was convinced that de Gaulle was still looking for an Algerian policy and had not yet made up his mind. The situation became clearer with what has been described as "the most memorable cabinet meeting" of August 26 1959. Tricot had written a report on the Algerian situation, which envisaged the establishment of peace to be followed by a referendum in which the Algerian population would decide on the country's future. The result was that several ministers, notably the prime minister, Michel Debré, who had earlier spoken of the necessity for the French to hold Algeria, changed their minds. The word "auto-determination" became the key word (although Tricot always denied that he had used it in his original report).

During the long months that followed until the final peace was signed at Evian in 1962, Tricot was the General's direct adviser on Algerian matters. While de Gaulle concealed his intentions and did not always inform his representatives of what he was doing, Tricot knew everything. The weakness of Tricot's position was that he hoped for a final solution in which Algeria would remain associated with France. He took part in secret negotiations with certain moderate nationalists and even, on June 10 1960, brought them to the Elysée Palace. But he had to accept full independence and, from March to July 1962, he was in Algiers attempting to maintain order in the sanguinary last days of France in Algeria.

In 1967, Tricot became the Secretary-General of the President of the Republic. This meant that he was closest to the General in the revolutionary days of 1968, and it was he who told the staff at the Elysée of de Gaulle's resignation in 1969.

After this he only appeared in public once. In 1985, after the sinking of the Greenpeace vessel Rainbow Warrior in Auckland harbour, President Mitterrand asked him to conduct an inquiry, to see if the French intelligence service had been involved. In fact they were deeply involved. But Tricot did not discover this. He did not think that responsible men would tell lies to him, as they did. He thought that everyone was as honourable as himself.

He is survived by his wife Gladys Mayer and two sons. A daughter predeceased him.

 Bernard Tricot, administrator and civil servant, born June 17 1920; died June 8 2000

fields.headline: Samuel Taylor
fields.trailText: There was a time, up to the late 1960s, when witty well-made drawing-room comedies about rich people were a staple of both Broadway and the West End. Playwright Samuel Taylor, who has died aged 87, was one of the last American playwrights in the tradition of Philip Barry and Kaufman and Hart.
fields.body:
There was a time, up to the late 1960s, when witty well-made drawing-room comedies about rich people were a staple of both Broadway and the West End. Playwright Samuel Taylor, who has died aged 87, was one of the last American playwrights in the tradition of Philip Barry and Kaufman and Hart. In fact, there are elements of Barry's Philadelphia Story and Holiday in two of Taylor's biggest hits, Sabrina Fair (1953) and The Pleasure of His Company (1958), both of which were turned into successful films.

Taylor, born in Chicago, attended the University of California, with interruptions as a merchant seaman. While working in New York as a play doctor and reader, he got the chance to rewrite a script, What A Life! It became a hit and was turned into the radio series The Aldrich Family, with the scripts written by Taylor.

He had been occupied for several years writing radio comedies before writing his first play, The Happy Time (1950), which ran for almost two years, after which it was made into a charming film starring Charles Boyer.

In 1951, Taylor adapted a French boulevard comedy by André Roussin for Gloria Swanson. The critics didn't like the show - Nina - or the star, and in New York it ran for only 45 performances.

However, Taylor's Sabrina Fair occupied the Broadway stage for 314 performances. The play, starring a miscast Margaret Sullivan opposite Joseph Cotton, told of a chauffeur's daughter who returns to Long Island as a sophisticated young woman after five years in Paris, and is courted by the two contrasting sons of her father's employer. It was less sparkling than the Billy Wilder movie, Sabrina (1954), in which Audrey Hepburn shone.

The opposite was true of The Pleasure of His Company, which Taylor co-wrote with its female lead Cornelia Otis Skinner. For the 1961 movie, Taylor wrote a straight adaptation of his play. Starring Fred Astaire in his second non-dancing role as a prodigal father, who, turning up for his daughter's wedding, turns everything upside down, it worked less well than on stage with Cyril Richard in New York and Nigel Patrick in London.

It was while he was working on The Pleasure of His Company, that Taylor was asked by Alfred Hitchcock to mend the script of Vertigo (1958), which had already gone through two writers. Taylor made substantial changes, adding characters, made more of the San Francisco background, and decided (controversially) to let the audience in on the film's secret before the hero (James Stewart) catches on.

Less to Taylor's credit was his screenplay for Goodbye Again (1961), which he adapted from Françoise Sagan's superficially sophisticated novel, Aimez-Vous Brahms? The film, starring Ingrid Bergman, Anthony Perkins and Yves Montand, was set in a chic Paris, as was No Strings (1962), for which Taylor wrote the book and which was the only Broadway musical for which Richard Rodgers wrote both the music and lyrics. It was a sophisticated romance between a European bum of a novelist (Richard Kiley) and a chic black fashion model (Diahann Carroll). It ran on Broadway for more than a year, but plans for a movie fell through because, owing to the inter-racial love story, the producers foresaw trouble from Southern distributors.

As the kind of theatre that Taylor represented started to fade, his last real stage success was Avanti! (1968) about a young American square businessman and a British "dolly bird" holed up together in a Rome hotel suite. The play, re-titled A Touch of Spring for its run in London starring Hayley Mills, was made into a far more entertaining and abrasive film by Billy Wilder, featuring Hayley's sister Juliet in 1972.

Among the several screenplays Taylor wrote were Rosie! (1967), with Rosalind Russell as a free-spirited grandmother, which was described by one critic as "a mawkish mixture of Auntie Mame and King Lear", and another Hitchcock picture, Topaz (1969), a cold-war thriller, one of the director's weakest.

Taylor is survived by his wife of 60 years, Suzanne Combes Taylor, and two sons.

 Samuel Taylor, playwright and screenwriter, born June 13 1912; died May 26 2000

As the kind of theatre that Taylor represented started to fade, his last real stage success was Avanti! (1968) about a young American square businessman and a British "dolly bird" holed up together in a Rome hotel suite. The play, re-titled A Touch of Spring for its run in London starring Hayley Mills, was made into a far more entertaining and abrasive film by Billy Wilder, featuring Hayley's sister Juliet in 1972. Among the several screenplays Taylor wrote were Rosie! (1967), with Rosalind Russell as a free-spirited grandmother, which was described by one critic as "a mawkish mixture of Auntie Mame and King Lear", and another Hitchcock picture, Topaz (1969), a cold-war thriller, one of the director's weakest. Taylor is survived by his wife of 60 years, Suzanne Combes Taylor, and two sons.  Samuel Taylor, playwright and screenwriter, born June 13 1912; died May 26 2000

fields.headline: Return of a craftier Croft
fields.standfirst: England recall a born-again Welsh spinner for the first test against West Indies tomorrow
fields.trailText: The lilt was decidedly Welsh and proud of it, the conversation flooded forth with fresh optimism and all the talk was of a strange phenomenon called "British cricket". It could mean only that Robert Croft, the Glamorgan off-spinner, was guaranteed a test comeback against West Indies tomorrow to revitalise an England career that had been assumed to be over.
fields.body:
The lilt was decidedly Welsh and proud of it, the conversation flooded forth with fresh optimism and all the talk was of a strange phenomenon called "British cricket". It could mean only that Robert Croft, the Glamorgan off-spinner, was guaranteed a test comeback against West Indies tomorrow to revitalise an England career that had been assumed to be over.

By his own admission Croft hit rock bottom last summer. He was disaffected with his own cricket and England (Britain even) were disaffected with him. His bowling was negative and predictable, scorned for lack of spin and variation. He saw himself plodding on for a couple more seasons before a disgruntled and premature retirement.

By the time he began late last summer to put things rightEngland were no longer interested. A series defeat against New Zealand had dropped them to the bottom of the test rankings and the frenzy was for a resort to youth: show me your birth certificate and I will show you the world.

Graeme Swann, Northamptonshire's upbeat all-rounder and nine years younger than Croft at 21, was one of the beneficiaries. But Swann's tour of South Africa was notable only for its inactivity. His form has declined markedly, to the point last week where he had a shocker in a side beaten by Oxford Universities, a fact which did not escape the selectors.

So it is back to Croft, the new-look Croft, his squat frame as stroppily combative as ever, but now complete with an idiosyncratic run-up, an unfettered imagination and, for good measure, a match analysis against the West Indians in Cardiff last week of eight for 70.

The Edgbaston pitch has been judged a good batting surface, making a spinner es sential, so Mark Ealham and Steve Harmison were sent back to their counties yesterday. The precocious leg-spin of Chris Schofield has suffered the same fate, in the belief that five left-handers in West Indies' top six make Croft's off-spin the natural option.

England, in a rare show of decisiveness, have already named a final XI, one in which Croft's return further underlines that the youth fixation has been quietly abandoned.

"I did wonder last summer whether I had a future," Croft says. "I had almost become bored with my own bowling. Practising for 20 minutes bowling at a single stump or a spot on the pitch had made me into a negative bowler.

"At test level you have to do something different to get batsmen out. I had stopped expressing myself in the way that I wanted to. I needed to impose myself and develop more variation in my game but I had become a flat, predictable, regulation bowler.

"I was told and I was told but you don't realise until you hit rock bottom. Then at the start of last season I played on a turning pitch or two with Glamorgan and didn't really feature. It was a low period. That's when it came home to me that I had to change."

Croft puts his reinvention back to the final six weeks of last season but it is in the past week that his change of approach has become widely noticed, first in troubling the West Indians, then in the Benson & Hedges Cup final against Gloucestershire at Lord's.

He now dances into the wicket, looking to get up on to his toes, as if someone has slipped an E into his drink. He yearns for the spin, flight and drift that had so pitilessly deserted him. Against the tourists last week he even delivered a ball or two from two yards behind the crease, an eye-catching statement of intent.

"It is now part of me," Croft insisted. But it cannot yet be so ingrained. The transition remains so unexplored, potentially so ephemeral, that Croft must fear regression, especially if he faces a concerted attempt by Brian Lara to hit him out of the attack.

Before the tour match Croft had taken only nine wickets in 178 overs for Glamorgan this season. It has taken a good deal of bloody-mindedness, and earnest net sessions, to return after a two-year absence for a 16th test cap.

"The only place to be is in the test team," he said. "I know there will be people snapping at my heels to get their job back."

Not everybody accepts that Swann and Schofield, persistently lauded in their progression through England age group sides, are snapping hard and often enough. Harmison will also be expected to prove at Durham that his involvement with the first three England squads of the summer has sharpened his desire.

Nick Knight is another who has learned over an uneven career to value the successful times and who has striven ceaselessly to relive them. Attitude was one reason he retained his place at No6 after Yorkshire's Michael Vaughan, the most diligent of the younger brigade, had emphasised a return to form and fitness against Durham last week.

"Realistically Vaughan was the original pick, but so be it," Knight said. "It's my third game in a row, I've been given an opportunity and it's up to me to take it."

England: Hussain (capt), Atherton, Ramprakash, Hick, Stewart, Knight, Flintoff, Croft, Caddick, Gough, Giddins.
