webTitle: Environment, transport and the regions of Nigeria

fields.headline: Environment, transport and the regions of Nigeria
fields.trailText: Environment questions, and there was no sign of the environment secretary and deputy prime minister. "Where is he?" grumbled the Tories, deprived of their monthly jeer and merry cries of "gin and tonic, please, steward!"
fields.body:
Environment questions, and there was no sign of the environment secretary and deputy prime minister. "Where is he?" grumbled the Tories, deprived of their monthly jeer and merry cries of "gin and tonic, please, steward!"

It turned out that John Prescott was in Nigeria, "at the personal request of the prime minister".

So it has come to this. "John, look, you've been doing a fantastic job. The way you handled prime minister's questions while I was looking after little Leo, ha ha! Look, crucial job in Nigeria, find what you can about how they run the railways there, cycle lanes in the jungle, really, you know, vital stuff for the next election, stay as long as you need - why not take the wife, the ballroom dancing in Kano is supposed to be really great, OK? John, OK?"

Instead we had Mr Prescott's team of understrappers, and what an earnest bunch they are. Michael Meacher was asked about GM foods and the way they might contaminate nearby fields. "We need to find the appro priate separation differentials and the matrix variable model," he said, and absolutely nobody registered the faintest surprise or bewilderment. It could be a breakfast cereal promotion: "Free matrix variable model in every box of GM Frostie Flakes. Kids, collect 'em all!"

After a while my eye fell upon Anne McIntosh, the Tory MP for Vale of York. It is she who has been in the habit of bombarding our office here with faxes describing every detail of her working day. "MP backs pork campaign", for example, and "MP welcomes Ainsty Farm Watch" are two recent arrivals.

For some reason she has stopped sending these, and I have an awful feeling it may be because I churlishly drew attention to her practice in this column. If so, I'm sorry. Anne, we love your press releases! We yearn for more "MP is 'top of the shops' in supermarket visit" and "MP inspects pylon". Please send more! "Just the fax, ma'am!" as they said on Dragnet.

Yesterday she looked quietly vulnerable, while smartly dressed in a trim primrose outfit. She had tabled question number 13, about traffic accidents in North Yorkshire, and as the moment drew near, she became more and more winsomely agitated.

She began to tap her order paper. Then she puffed her cheeks out. Next her eyes darted from side to side, and her fingers repeatedly tugged down her yellow skirt.

She chewed her lower lip, patted the bench, then dug the top of her pen into her finger. Most tellingly of all, she started laughing with John Bercow, the rottweiler who sits next to her. ("Seen sharing a nervous tic _ ")

Finally the moment came, and she asked her question in a strongish, firmish voice. According to the department's own figures, she said, North Yorkshire had the worst rate of traffic accidents in the country.

The correct answer, one might assume, is to ask why it is the government's fault that the people of North Yorkshire don't drive more carefully on their way to worm goats, or whatever it is people do up there.

But that would be unfair. It turns out to be people driving through the county on trunk roads who are having these crashes, and the local council which has to pick up the pieces, literally. ("MP visits new zebra crossing".)

Beverley Hughes, the minister, had very little to say. She did point out that, per mile of road, the county had a perfectly average safety record.

My guess is that the Prescott team is waiting for his return from Nigeria, and to study his analysis of traffic accident patterns in Sokoto province. And, who knows? He may even be allowed back before the next election.

webTitle: Windies the best bet to get us out of this fix

fields.headline: Windies the best bet to get us out of this fix
fields.trailText: Matthw Engel There is a theory, generally advanced by aunts of a certain age, that if you cannot think of anything nice to say you should say nothing at all. So that's cricket writing dead then.
fields.body:
There is a theory, generally advanced by aunts of a certain age, that if you cannot think of anything nice to say you should say nothing at all.

If adhered to rigorously, this would seriously limit the practice of journalism and would kill modern cricket writing stone dead. The stench of the international game gets fouler by the day. And we will, sure as anything, have to consider all that again before long.

It would be good to take refuge in the traditional summertime consolation of torpid afternoons on sunny, near-deserted cricket grounds around the shires. However, if there is anyone who understands when county matches take place these days, I have yet to meet them.

Cricket was not always like this. Three times since the second world war, the English game has been transformed by seasons of the utmost magnificence. Each time a new generation was enchanted and older cricket lovers were reinvigorated. It could happen again; but one would never bet on it, even after paying Hansie.

The first instance was 1947, when the war and ration-weary public were entranced by the sight of Denis Compton dominating a cricket season with effortless swagger. The most recent case was 1981, Botham's year, when a downbeat England - halfway towards losing the Ashes - suddenly became touched with stardust.

The other season has faded in memory a little more. As England prepare for a new West Indian summer, most nostalgia is centred on 1950 because of the golden jubilee and all that. That was the first series West Indies had won over here and it altered our perception of their cricket - but in a thoroughly misleading manner. The battle was determined by the spinners, and the English were able to react in a genially magnanimous and patronising way.

After that West Indian cricket went into eclipse: the 1950s were England's decade. Collie Smith was killed in a car crash when on the edge of batting greatness and Garry Sobers matured more slowly than had been hoped (this may or may not be any consolation to exasperated Flintoff-watchers but Sobers failed to score a century in his first 16 tests - then he made 365 not out).

By the time they came to England in 1963, however, West Indies had something close to the perfect team. Only England circa 1902, the Bradman Invincibles of 1948 and maybe the New Invincibles of Mark Taylor and Steve Waugh might stand comparison.

Balance was the key. That was pretty easy to achieve if you had Sobers on your side, since he was the world's best batsman and could also bowl fast, finger-spin, wrist-spin, whatever. So they effectively had 14 men on the field every time.

But being good was only part of it. They were thrilling. Even the anchormen - Conrad Hunte, Basil Butcher and Joe Solomon - were dashers in English terms. Rohan Kanhai was a sensation at No3, famous above all for his trademark falling-down shot when, in John Woodcock's words, "the ball went for six and Kanhai went for four".

Frank Worrell, nearing 40, batted down at No7, but Wisden called his 74 not out at Old Trafford "the most graceful exhibition of late-cutting seen in the last 50 years". He was, of course, an outstanding leader.

Wes Hall and Charlie Griffith (who chucked, said everyone) were fearsome spearheads, and Lance Gibbs was a great spinner. They were short only of a steady opening partner for Hunte.

Y et England were not wholly overmatched. They were six runs short of victory at Lord's when Colin Cowdrey came out with a broken arm. Fred Trueman bowled them to victory at Edgbaston. In the end class prevailed and West Indies took the series 3-1 but England had a chance of making it 2-2 until the final hours at the Oval.

And everywhere it was the same story: huge crowds. The season also saw the highly successful debut of one-day cricket: there were 25,000 at the first final of the Gillette Cup, coyly referred to by most of the media as "the Knock-Out Competition".

Three golden summers: 1947, 1963, 1981. The next one is thus overdue. There was another innovation in 1963: a single-wicket competition at Scarborough involving the leading all-rounders. It went well at first, then faded.

Imagine a single-wicket competition today. It would be fun; unfortunately it is the most fixable form of the game imaginable. Back to reality.

fields.headline: Umpire strikes back over claims
fields.trailText: The Pakistan umpire Javed Akhtar has vigorously rejected accusations that he accepted money to fix the 1998 Headingley test, claiming that any bad decisions he made were a result of human error.
fields.body:
The Pakistan umpire Javed Akhtar has vigorously rejected accusations that he accepted money to fix the 1998 Headingley test, claiming that any bad decisions he made were a result of human error.

Akhtar admitted yesterday that a couple of the nine lbw decisions he gave during the match, in which England beat South Africa by 23 runs, might have been poor but said they were innocent mistakes.

"I am only human, after all," he said. "But I have never been approached by a bookmaker. I am ready to swear any oath on that.

The 59-year-old retired umpire said the allegations by the South African cricket chief Ali Bacher were "a figment of his imagination". He said he would sue Bacher, accused him of being biased against Pakistan and challenged him to reveal the identity of Mr R, the Karachi bookmaker who allegedly bribed Akhtar. "The fact is South Africa were beaten by England and that's hard for them to swallow."

Indian officials, meanwhile, have described claims that Pakistan threw a World Cup game against them as "malicious fiction".

fields.headline: Police swoop on fixing suspects
fields.trailText: The unfolding drama of cricket's match-fixing crisis took yet another dramatic twist yesterday when police arrested three men in London in connection with alleged attempts to fix games.
fields.body:
The unfolding drama of cricket's match-fixing crisis took yet another dramatic twist yesterday when police arrested three men in London in connection with alleged attempts to fix games.

Two men, aged 35 and 44, were arrested at their north London homes shortly after 7am and a third man, aged 42, was arrested almost four hours later.

Their identity remains a mystery but it is believed that none is a player or official.

"The men arrested today have been taken to a west London police station for questioning and inquiries are continuing," a police spokesman said.

The men were seized by officers from the Organised Crime Group, which began investigations into corruption within cricket after allegations were made last year by the former England all-rounder Chris Lewis.

Hansie Cronje's day of reckoning at the King Commission, meanwhile, could come as soon as tomorrow.

The inquiry was adjourned at lunchtime yesterday after the commission advocate, Shamila Batohi, requested time to conduct "further investigations", and it is not certain whether the hearings will resume tomorrow or next week, with Friday being a bank holiday in South Africa.

For the moment Cronje remains tucked away at his brother Frans's home in Stellenbosch, 25 miles from Cape Town. The disgraced former captain's lawyers are eager for him to take the stand, and pressure is mounting for him to tell the world what he knows.

His role in England's victory over South Africa in last winter's Centurion Park test was thrust under the spotlight yesterday by Jacques Kallis. The South African batsman testified before Judge Edwin King about his displeasure at Cronje's controversial deal with Nasser Hussain, which left England needing 245 to win from 70 overs.

"We were quite shocked that he set them such an easy target," Kallis told the commission. "We were upset. Test matches are hard enough to win at the best of times so you don't want to give it away.

"I didn't think the target of 3.5 runs an over was enough. I thought four would be better. I told Hansie I wasn't happy with the declaration, but he was adamant he wanted to make a game of it. The last thing I wanted to do was give England confidence ahead of the one-day series."

Kallis's comments came only a day after another English victory, the 1998 Headingley test win over the same rivals, was tainted by claims of match-fixing. Kallis also corroborated Monday's evidence by Mark Boucher and Lance Klusener that Cronje had conveyed a bribe offer to them before the second test against India in Bangalore in March this year.

"He [Cronje] walked into the room in a joking manner and asked whether we were interested in setting up a game," Kallis said. "We told him to get lost."

The former wicketkeeper Dave Richardson shed further light on Pat Symcox's testimony last week that he had been offered a bribe by a current international player - known only as Mr X - in India in 1996.

Richardson said Symcox had revealed Mr X's identity to him. "He is a member of the Indian team, but when I hear about all these death threats I don't think I should name him."

Two men, aged 35 and 44, were arrested at their north London homes shortly after 7am and a third man, aged 42, was arrested almost four hours later. Their identity remains a mystery but it is believed that none is a player or official. "The men arrested today have been taken to a west London police station for questioning and inquiries are continuing," a police spokesman said. The men were seized by officers from the Organised Crime Group, which began investigations into corruption within cricket after allegations were made last year by the former England all-rounder Chris Lewis. Hansie Cronje's day of reckoning at the King Commission, meanwhile, could come as soon as tomorrow. The inquiry was adjourned at lunchtime yesterday after the commission advocate, Shamila Batohi, requested time to conduct "further investigations", and it is not certain whether the hearings will resume tomorrow or next week, with Friday being a bank holiday in South Africa. For the moment Cronje remains tucked away at his brother Frans's home in Stellenbosch, 25 miles from Cape Town. The disgraced former captain's lawyers are eager for him to take the stand, and pressure is mounting for him to tell the world what he knows. His role in England's victory over South Africa in last winter's Centurion Park test was thrust under the spotlight yesterday by Jacques Kallis. The South African batsman testified before Judge Edwin King about his displeasure at Cronje's controversial deal with Nasser Hussain, which left England needing 245 to win from 70 overs. "We were quite shocked that he set them such an easy target," Kallis told the commission. "We were upset. Test matches are hard enough to win at the best of times so you don't want to give it away. "I didn't think the target of 3.5 runs an over was enough. I thought four would be better. I told Hansie I wasn't happy with the declaration, but he was adamant he wanted to make a game of it. The last thing I wanted to do was give England confidence ahead of the one-day series." Kallis's comments came only a day after another English victory, the 1998 Headingley test win over the same rivals, was tainted by claims of match-fixing. Kallis also corroborated Monday's evidence by Mark Boucher and Lance Klusener that Cronje had conveyed a bribe offer to them before the second test against India in Bangalore in March this year. "He [Cronje] walked into the room in a joking manner and asked whether we were interested in setting up a game," Kallis said. "We told him to get lost." The former wicketkeeper Dave Richardson shed further light on Pat Symcox's testimony last week that he had been offered a bribe by a current international player - known only as Mr X - in India in 1996. Richardson said Symcox had revealed Mr X's identity to him. "He is a member of the Indian team, but when I hear about all these death threats I don't think I should name him."

webTitle: Elliott lights up the Cardiff gloom

fields.headline: Elliott lights up the Cardiff gloom
fields.standfirst: Glamorgan 220 v Essex
fields.trailText: Glamorgan 220 v Essex
fields.body:
Glamorgan emerged from the gloom of their Benson & Hedges Cup defeat at Lord's on Saturday back into the spotlight last night when they staged their first competitive floodlit match.

And they made a bright start to this National League Second Division game. Their captain Matthew Maynard had rallied his troops and after winning the toss they approached their innings with a steely resolve in an attempt to put the tame seven-wicket defeat by Gloucestershire behind them.

Matthew Elliott, largely out of form during the B&H Cup campaign, showed his intent with 94 from 115 balls, the backbone of Glamorgan's competitive 220 all out in 44.2 overs.

There has been controversy in the principality over Glamorgan's use of a pinch-hitter. Robert Croft has had little success in the role and with his selection for England the job fell to Keith Newell, underused in the one-day side so far, who obviously relished his promotion as he helped to give Glamorgan their best start in the competition.

Newell and Elliott's approach at the start was such that the DJ, who was playing CDs after every boundary, must have thought he was going to run out of tracks as the openers reached 50 in the 10th over.

The Essex opening bowlers struggled as Newell claimed seven fours in his 38 out of 59 before being caught at mid-wicket. And he proved only the hors d'oeuvre before the supper break as Elliott and Maynard tucked into the bowling.

On the back of his 104 at Lord's, for which he won the Gold Award, Maynard continued to display the sort of one-day form that may yet interest the England selectors. He was out just one delivery after scoring a controlled 52-ball half-century which put Glamorgan in a good position, especially considering Essex were without Stuart Law and Nasser Hussain.

Maynard holed out at long-on and Elliott, who had put on 98 with his captain in 18 overs, tried to see the innings through after also losing Adrian Dale and Steve James in fairly quick succession, but the Australian left-hander was out five overs from the end as Glamorgan's innings tailed off.
